<div class="titlepage">
<h1><span class="xlarge">RELIQUES OF</span><br>
ANCIENT ENGLISH<br>
POETRY<br>
<span class="medium">CONSISTING OF OLD HEROIC BALLADS, SONGS AND
OTHER PIECES OF OUR EARLIER POETS
TOGETHER WITH SOME FEW
OF LATER DATE</span></h1>
<p class="small">BY<br>
<span class="large">THOMAS PERCY, D.D.</span><br>
<span class="xsmall">BISHOP OF DROMORE</span></p>
<p class="small">EDITED, WITH A GENERAL INTRODUCTION, ADDITIONAL
PREFACES, NOTES, GLOSSARY, ETC.<br>
BY<br>
<span class="large">HENRY B. WHEATLEY, F.S.A.</span></p>
<p class="small">IN THREE VOLUMES<br>
<span class="medium">VOL. III</span></p>
<p><span class="large">LONDON: GEORGE ALLEN &amp; UNWIN LTD.</span><br>
<span class="stageleft">RUSKIN HOUSE</span> <span class="linenum">40 MUSEUM STREET, W.C.1<br></span>
</p><br></div>

<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_viii">[Pg viii]</a><br><a id="Page_1">[Pg 1]</a></span></p>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 600px;">
<img alt="" height="101" src="images/i001.png" width="600" id="img_images_i001.png">
</div>
<p class="ph1">RELIQUES OF ANCIENT POETRY, ETC.</p>
<p class="ph1">SERIES THE THIRD.</p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2> <a id="BOOK_I">BOOK I.</a></h2>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 100px;">
<img alt="" height="33" src="images/i001a.png" width="100" id="img_images_i001a.png">
</div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_2">[Pg 2]</a></span></p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"An ordinary song or ballad, that is the delight of
the common people, cannot fail to please all such
readers, as are not unqualified for the entertainment by
their affectation or their ignorance; and the reason is
plain, because the same paintings of nature which recommend
it to the most ordinary reader, will appear beautiful
to the most refined."—<span class="smcap">Addison</span>, in <i>Spectator</i>, No. 70.</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_3">[Pg 3]</a></span></p>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 600px;">
<img alt="" height="184" src="images/i003.png" width="600" id="img_images_i003.png">
</div>
<h3> <a id="POEMS_ON_KING_ARTHUR_etc"><span class="smcap">POEMS ON KING ARTHUR, etc.</span></a></h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i003t.png" id="img_images_i003t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> third volume being chiefly devoted to romantic
subjects, may not be improperly introduced with
a few slight strictures on the old metrical romances:
a subject the more worthy attention, as it seems
not to have been known to such as have written
on the nature and origin of books of chivalry,
that the first compositions of this kind were in
verse, and usually sung to the harp.<a id="FNanchor_1"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_1">[1]</a></p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_1"></a><a href="#FNanchor_1" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[1]</span></a> [See Appendix.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>I.<br>

THE BOY AND THE MANTLE</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i003i.png" id="img_images_i003i.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capi"><span class="smcap">Is</span> printed verbatim from the old MS. described in the
Preface.<a id="FNanchor_2"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_2">[2]</a> The Editor believes it more ancient than it
will appear to be at first sight; the transcriber of that
manuscript having reduced the orthography and style
in many instances to the standard of his own times.</p>
<p>The incidents of the <i>Mantle and the Knife</i> have not, that I can
recollect, been borrowed from any other writer. The former of
these evidently suggested to Spenser his conceit of <i>Florimel's</i>
<i>Girdle</i>, b. iv. c. 5, st. 3.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_4">[Pg 4]</a></span></p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"That girdle gave the virtue of chaste love<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wivehood true to all that did it beare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But whosoever contrarie doth prove,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Might not the same about her middle weare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But it would loose or else asunder teare."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>So it happened to the false Florimel, st. 16, when</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i6">"Being brought, about her middle small<br></span>
<span class="i2">They thought to gird, as best it her became,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But by no means they could it thereto frame,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For ever as they fastned it, it loos'd<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fell away, as feeling secret blame, &amp;c.<br></span>
<span class="i0">That all men wondred at the uncouth sight<br></span>
<span class="i2">And each one thought as to their fancies came.<br></span>
<span class="i2">But she herself did think it done for spight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And touched was with secret wrath and shame<br></span>
<span class="i2">Therewith, as thing deviz'd her to defame:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then many other ladies likewise tride<br></span>
<span class="i2">About their tender loynes to knit the same,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But it would not on none of them abide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But when they thought it fast, eftsoones it was untide.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thereat all knights gan laugh and ladies lowre,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Till that at last the gentle Amoret<br></span>
<span class="i2">Likewise assayed to prove that girdle's powre.<br></span>
<span class="i2">And having it about her middle set<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did find it fit withouten breach or let,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whereat the rest gan greatly to envie.<br></span>
<span class="i2">But Florimel exceedingly did fret<br></span>
<span class="i2">And snatching from her hand," &amp;c.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>As for the trial of the <i>Horne</i>, it is not peculiar to our poet: it
occurs in the old romance, intitled <i>Morte Arthur</i>, which was
translated out of French in the time of K. Edw. IV., and first
printed anno 1484. From that romance Ariosto is thought to
have borrowed his tale of the <i>Enchanted Cup</i>, c. 42, &amp;c. See Mr.
Warton's <i>Observations on the Faerie Queen</i>, &amp;c.</p>
<p>The story of the <i>Horn</i> in <i>Morte Arthur</i> varies a good deal from
this of our poet, as the reader will judge from the following
extract:—"By the way they met with a knight that was sent from
Morgan la Faye to king Arthur, and this knight had a fair horne
all garnished with gold, and the horne had such a virtue, that there
might no ladye or gentlewoman drinke of that horne, but if she
were true to her husband: and if shee were false she should spill
all the drinke, and if shee were true unto her lorde, shee might
drink peaceably: and because of queene Guenever and in despite
of Sir Launcelot du Lake, this horne was sent unto king Arthur."<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_5">[Pg 5]</a></span>
This horn is intercepted and brought unto another king named
Marke, who is not a whit more fortunate than the British hero, for
he makes "his qeene drinke thereof and an hundred ladies moe,
and there were but foure ladies of all those that drank cleane,"
of which number the said queen proves not to be one (book ii.
chap. 22, ed. 1632).</p>
<p>In other respects the two stories are so different, that we have
just reason to suppose this ballad was written before that romance
was translated into English.</p>
<p>As for queen Guenever, she is here represented no otherwise
than in the old histories and romances. Holinshed observes,
that "she was evil reported of, as noted of incontinence and
breach of faith to hir husband" (vol. i. p. 93).</p>
<p>Such readers, as have no relish for pure antiquity, will find
a more modern copy of this ballad at the end of the volume.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[For Percy's further notes on this ballad see the modernized
version (book iii. No. 18). Professor Child prints the ballad in
his <i>English and Scottish Ballads</i> (vol. i. p. 1) with a full notice of
the various forms of the story by way of introduction. He
writes:—"No incident is more common in romantic fiction than
the employment of some magical contrivance as a test of conjugal
fidelity, or of constancy in love. In some romances of the Round
Table, and tales founded upon them, this experiment is performed
by means either of an enchanted horn, of such properties that no
dishonoured husband or unfaithful wife can drink from it without
spilling, or of a mantle which will fit none but chaste women.
The earliest known instances of the use of these ordeals are
afforded by the <i>Lai du Corn</i>, by Robert Bikez, a French minstrel
of the twelfth or thirteenth century, and the <i>Fabliau du Mantel</i>
<i>Mautaillé</i>, which, in the opinion of a competent critic, dates from
the second half of the thirteenth century, and is only the older lay
worked up into a new shape (Wolf, <i>Ueber die Lais</i>, 327, sq., 342, sq.).
We are not to suppose, however, that either of these pieces presents
us with the primitive form of this humorous invention. Robert
Bikez tells us that he learned his story from an abbot, and that
'noble ecclesiast' stood but one further back in a line of tradition
which curiosity will never follow to its source."</p>
<p>Here follows a list of "the most remarkable cases of the use of
these and similar talismans in imaginative literature." To these
may be added the garland described in the curious old story of
the <i>Wright's Wife</i>, which has been printed since the publication of
Mr. Child's work.</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Haue here thys garlond of roses ryche,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In alle thys lond ys none yt lyche;<br></span>
<span class="i2">For ytt wylle euer be newe.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_6">[Pg 6]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Wete þou wele withowtyn fable,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alle the whyle thy wyfe ys stable<br></span>
<span class="i2">The chaplett wolle hold hewe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yf thy wyfe vse putry,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or tolle eny man to lye her by,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Than wolle yt change hewe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And by the garlond þou may see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fekylle or fals yf þat sche be,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or ellys yf sche be trewe."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p><i>The Wright's Chaste Wife</i> (E. E. Text Soc. 1865, 1. 55-66).]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i006.png" id="img_images_i006.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In the third day of may,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Carleile did come<br></span>
<span class="i0">A kind curteous child,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That cold<a id="FNanchor_3"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_3">[3]</a> much of wisdome.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A kirtle and a mantle                                                <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This child had uppon,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With 'brouches' and ringes<a id="FNanchor_4"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_4">[4]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Full richelye bedone.<a id="FNanchor_5"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_5">[5]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He had a sute of silke<br></span>
<span class="i0">About his middle drawne;                                            <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Without he cold of curtesye<br></span>
<span class="i0">He thought itt much shame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">God speed thee, king Arthur,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sitting at thy meate:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the goodly queene Guenéver,                                     <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I cannott her forgett.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I tell you, lords, in this hall;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I hett<a id="FNanchor_6"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_6">[6]</a> you all to 'heede';<a id="FNanchor_7"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_7">[7]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Except you be the more surer<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is you for to dread.                                                <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_7">[Pg 7]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He plucked out of his 'poterner,'<a id="FNanchor_8"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_8">[8]</a><a id="FNanchor_9"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_9">[9]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And longer wold not dwell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He pulled forth a pretty mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Betweene two nut-shells.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Have thou here, king Arthur;                                        <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Have thou heere of mee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Give itt to thy comely queene<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shapen as itt is alreadye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Itt shall never become that wiffe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That hath once done amisse.                                         <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then every knight in the kings court<br></span>
<span class="i0">Began to care for 'his.'<a id="FNanchor_10"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_10">[10]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Forth came dame Guénever;<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the mantle shee her 'hied';<a id="FNanchor_11"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_11">[11]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">The ladye shee was newfangle,                                       <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But yett shee was affrayd.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When shee had taken the mantle;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She stoode as shee had beene madd:<br></span>
<span class="i0">It was from the top to the toe<br></span>
<span class="i0">As sheeres had itt shread.                                          <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">One while was itt 'gule';<a id="FNanchor_12"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_12">[12]</a><a id="FNanchor_13"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_13">[13]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Another while was itt greene;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Another while was itt wadded:<a id="FNanchor_14"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_14">[14]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ill itt did her beseeme.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Another while was it blacke                                         <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And bore the worst hue:<br></span>
<span class="i0">By my troth, quoth king Arthur,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I thinke thou be not true.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_8">[Pg 8]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee threw downe the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That bright was of blee;<a id="FNanchor_15"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_15">[15]</a> <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Fast with a rudd<a id="FNanchor_16"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_16">[16]</a> redd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To her chamber can<a id="FNanchor_17"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_17">[17]</a> shee flee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She curst the weaver, and the walker,<a id="FNanchor_18"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_18">[18]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">That clothe that had wrought;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bade a vengeance on his crowne,                                 <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That hither hath itt brought.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I had rather be in a wood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Under a greene tree;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then in king Arthurs court<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shamed for to bee.                                                  <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Kay called forth his ladye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bade her come neere;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Saies, Madam, and thou be guiltye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I pray thee hold thee there.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Forth came his ladye                                                <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shortlye and anon;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Boldlye to the mantle<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then is shee gone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When she had tane the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And cast it her about;                                              <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then was shee bare<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Before all the rout.'<a id="FNanchor_19"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_19">[19]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then every knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That was in the kings court,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Talked, laughed, and showted<a id="FNanchor_20"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_20">[20]</a> <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Full oft att that sport.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_9">[Pg 9]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee threw downe the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That bright was of blee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fast, with a red rudd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To her chamber can[1] shee flee.                                    <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Forth came an old knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pattering ore a creede,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he proferred to this litle boy<br></span>
<span class="i0">Twenty markes to his meede;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And all the time of the Christmasse                                 <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Willinglye to ffeede;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For why this mantle might<br></span>
<span class="i0">Doe his wiffe some need.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When she had tane the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of cloth that was made,                                             <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shee had no more left on her,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But a tassell and a threed:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then every knight in the kings court<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bade evill might shee speed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee threw downe the mantle,                                        <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That bright was of blee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fast, with a redd rudd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To her chamber can<a id="FNanchor_21"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_21">[21]</a> shee flee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Craddocke called forth his ladye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bade her come in;                                              <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Saith, Winne this mantle, ladye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With a litle dinne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Winne this mantle, ladye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And it shal be thine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou never did amisse                                           <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since thou wast mine.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_10">[Pg 10]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Forth came Craddockes ladye<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shortlye and anon;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But boldlye to the mantle<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then is shee gone.                                                 <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When shee had tane the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And cast itt her about,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Upp att her great toe<br></span>
<span class="i0">It began to crinkle and crowt:<a id="FNanchor_22"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_22">[22]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shee said, bowe downe, mantle,                                     <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And shame me not for nought.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Once I did amisse,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I tell you certainlye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When I kist Craddockes mouth<br></span>
<span class="i0">Under a greene tree;                                               <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When I kist Craddockes mouth<br></span>
<span class="i0">Before he marryed mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When shee had her shreeven,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And her sines shee had tolde;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The mantle stoode about her                                        <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Right as shee wold:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Seemelye of coulour<br></span>
<span class="i0">Glittering like gold:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then every knight in Arthurs court<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did her behold.                                                    <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then spake dame Guénever<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Arthur our king;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She hath tane yonder mantle<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not with right, but with wronge.<a id="FNanchor_23"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_23">[23]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">See you not yonder woman,                                          <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That maketh her self soe 'cleane'?<a id="FNanchor_24"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_24">[24]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">I have seene tane out of her bedd<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of men fiveteene;<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_11">[Pg 11]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Priests, clarkes, and wedded men<br></span>
<span class="i0">From her bedeene:<a id="FNanchor_25"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_25">[25]</a><a id="FNanchor_26"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_26">[26]</a> <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yett shee taketh the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And maketh her self cleane.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then spake the litle boy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That kept the mantle in hold;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sayes, king, chasten thy wiffe,                                    <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of her words shee is to bold:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee is a bitch and a witch,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a whore bold:<br></span>
<span class="i0">King, in thine owne hall<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou art a cuckold.                                                <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The litle boy stoode<a id="FNanchor_27"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_27">[27]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Looking out a dore;<a id="FNanchor_28"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_28">[28]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">[And there as he was lookinge<br></span>
<span class="i0">He was ware of a wyld bore.]<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He was ware of a wyld bore,<a id="FNanchor_29"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_29">[29]</a> <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Wold have werryed a man:<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_29">[29]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">He pulld forth a wood kniffe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fast thither that he ran:<br></span>
<span class="i0">He brought in the bores head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And quitted him like a man.                                        <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He brought in the bores head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And was wonderous bold:<br></span>
<span class="i0">He said there was never a cuckolds kniffe<br></span>
<span class="i0">Carve itt that cold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Some rubbed their knives                                           <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Uppon a whetstone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Some threw them under the table,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And said they had none.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_12">[Pg 12]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">King Arthur, and the child<br></span>
<span class="i0">Stood looking upon them;<br></span>
<span class="i0">All their knives edges<br></span>
<span class="i0">Turned backe againe.<a id="FNanchor_30"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_30">[30]</a> <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Craddocke had a litle knive<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of iron and of steele;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He britled<a id="FNanchor_31"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_31">[31]</a> the bores head<a id="FNanchor_32"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_32">[32]</a> <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Wonderous weele;<br></span>
<span class="i0">That every knight in the kings court<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had a morssell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The litle boy had a horne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of red gold that ronge:                                            <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He said, there was noe cuckolde<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall drinke of my horne;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he shold it sheede<a id="FNanchor_33"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_33">[33]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Either behind or beforne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Some shedd on their shoulder,                                      <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And some on their knee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He that cold not hitt his mouthe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Put it in his eye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he that was a cuckold<br></span>
<span class="i0">Every man might him see.                                           <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Craddocke wan the horne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the bores head:<br></span>
<span class="i0">His ladie wan the mantle<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unto her meede.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Everye such a lovely ladye                                         <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">God send her well to speede.<br></span>
</div></div>

<hr class="chap">
<h3>II.<br>

THE MARRIAGE OF SIR GAWAINE</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i013.png" id="img_images_i013.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capi"><span class="smcap">Is</span> chiefly taken from the fragment of an old ballad in the
Editor's MS., which he has reason to believe more
ancient than the time of <i>Chaucer</i>, and what furnished
that bard with his <i>Wife of Bath's Tale</i>. The original
was so extremely mutilated, half of every leaf being torn away,
that without large supplements, &amp;c. it was deemed improper for
this collection: these it has therefore received, such as they are.
They are not here particularly pointed out, because the <i>Fragment</i>
itself will now be found printed at the end of this volume.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Sir Frederic Madden supposed this ballad to be founded upon
the <i>Weddynge of Syr Gawen and Dame Ragnell</i>, which he printed
from the Rawlinson MS. c. 86, fol. 128 b, in his <i>Syr Gawaine</i>.</p>
<p>Mr. Hales writes as follows respecting the various forms in which
the story appears in literature. "The wonderful 'metamorphosis'
on which this story turns is narrated in Gower's <i>Confessio Amantis</i>,
as the story of Florent and the King of Sicily's Daughter, taken by
him, as Tyrwhitt conjectures, from the <i>Gesta Romanorum</i>, or some
such collection. It appears again, as the reader will remember, in
Chaucer's <i>Wyf of Bathes Tale</i>. 'Worked over,' says Prof. Child,
'by some ballad-monger of the sixteenth century, and of course
reduced to ditch-water, this tale has found its way into the <i>Crown</i>
<i>Garland of Golden Roses</i>, part i. p. 68 (<i>Percy Society</i>, vol. vi.), 'Of
a Knight and a Faire Virgin.' On a similar transformation depends
the story of 'King Henrie' in Scott's <i>Minstrelsy</i>, edited from
Mrs. Brown's MS., with corrections from a recited fragment, and
modernized as 'Courteous King Jamie' in Lewis's <i>Tales of Wonder</i>.
'The prime original,' says Scott, 'is to be found in an Icelandic
Saga.'"<a id="FNanchor_34"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_34">[34]</a></p>
<p>Mr. Child prints (<i>English and Scottish Ballads</i>, vol. viii. p. 139)
two versions of a Scotch ballad entitled <i>Kempy Kaye</i>, which he
supposes to be an extravagant parody of <i>The Marriage of Sir</i>
<i>Gawaine</i>.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_14">[Pg 14]</a></span></p>
<h4><span class="smcap">Part the First.</span>
</h4>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i014.png" id="img_images_i014.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">King Arthur lives in merry Carleile,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And seemely is to see;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there with him queene Guenever,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That bride soe bright of blee.<a id="FNanchor_35"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_35">[35]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And there with him queene Guenever,                                  <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That bride so bright in bowre:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all his barons about him stoode,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That were both stiffe and stowre.<a id="FNanchor_36"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_36">[36]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The king a royale Christmasse kept,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With mirth and princelye cheare;                                  <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To him repaired many a knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That came both farre and neare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when they were to dinner sette,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And cups went freely round;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Before them came a faire damsèlle,                                  <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And knelt upon the ground.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A boone, a boone, O kinge Arthùre,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I beg a boone of thee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Avenge me of a carlish knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who hath shent<a id="FNanchor_37"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_37">[37]</a> my love and mee.                               <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At Tearne-Wadling<a id="FNanchor_38"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_38">[38]</a> his castle stands,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Near to that lake so fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And proudlye rise the battlements,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And streamers deck the air.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_15">[Pg 15]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Noe gentle knighte, nor ladye gay,                                  <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">May pass that castle-walle:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But from that foule discurteous knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Mishappe will them befalle.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hee's twyce the size of common men,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Wi' thewes, and sinewes stronge,                                  <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And on his backe he bears a clubbe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That is both thicke and longe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This grimme baròne 'twas our harde happe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But yester morne to see;<br></span>
<span class="i0">When to his bowre he bare my love,                                  <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And sore misused mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when I told him, king Arthùre<br></span>
<span class="i2">As lyttle shold him spare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Goe tell, sayd hee, that cuckold kinge,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To meete mee if he dare.                                          <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Upp then sterted king Arthùre,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And sware by hille and dale,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He ne'er wolde quitt that grimme baròne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Till he had made him quail.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Goe fetch my sword Excalibar:                                       <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Goe saddle mee my steede;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nowe, by my faye, that grimme baròne<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shall rue this ruthfulle deede.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he came to Tearne Wadlinge<br></span>
<span class="i2">Benethe the castle walle:                                         <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"Come forth; come forth; thou proude baròne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or yielde thyself my thralle."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">On magicke grounde that castle stoode,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fenc'd with many a spelle:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Noe valiant knighte could tread thereon,                            <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">But straite his courage felle.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_16">[Pg 16]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Forth then rush'd that carlish<a id="FNanchor_39"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_39">[39]</a> knight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">King Arthur felte the charme:<br></span>
<span class="i0">His sturdy sinewes lost their strengthe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Downe sunke his feeble arme.                                      <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nowe yield thee, yield thee, kinge Arthùre,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Now yield thee, unto mee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or fighte with mee, or lose thy lande,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Noe better termes maye bee,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Unlesse thou sweare upon the rood,                                  <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And promise on thy faye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here to returne to Tearne-Wadling,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Upon the new-yeare's daye;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And bringe me worde what thing it is<br></span>
<span class="i2">All women moste desyre;                                           <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This is thy ransome, Arthur, he sayes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He have noe other hyre.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">King Arthur then helde up his hande,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And sware upon his faye,<a id="FNanchor_40"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_40">[40]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then tooke his leave of the grimme barone                           <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And faste hee rode awaye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he rode east, and he rode west,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And did of all inquyre,<br></span>
<span class="i0">What thing it is all women crave,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And what they most desyre.                                        <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Some told him riches, pompe, or state;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Some rayment fine and brighte;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Some told him mirthe; some flatterye;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And some a jollye knighte.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_17">[Pg 17]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In letters all king Arthur wrote,                                   <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And seal'd them with his ringe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But still his minde was helde in doubte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Each tolde a different thinge.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As ruthfulle he rode over a more,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He saw a ladye sette                                              <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Betweene an oke, and a greene holléye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All clad in red<a id="FNanchor_41"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_41">[41]</a> scarlette.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her nose was crookt and turnd outwàrde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her chin stoode all awrye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And where as sholde have been her mouthe,                           <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Lo! there was set her eye:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her haires, like serpents, clung aboute<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her cheekes of deadlye hewe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A worse-form'd ladye than she was,<br></span>
<span class="i2">No man mote ever viewe.                                          <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To hail the king in seemelye sorte<br></span>
<span class="i2">This ladye was fulle faine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But king Arthùre all sore amaz'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">No aunswere made againe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What wight art thou, the ladye sayd,                               <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That wilt not speake to mee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir, I may chance to ease thy paine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Though I be foule to see.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If thou wilt ease my paine, he sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And helpe me in my neede;                                        <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ask what thou wilt, thou grimme ladyè,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And it shall bee thy meede.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_18">[Pg 18]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O sweare mee this upon the roode,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And promise on thy faye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here the secrette I will telle,                                <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That shall thy ransome paye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">King Arthur promis'd on his faye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And sware upon the roode;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The secrette then the ladye told,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As lightlye well shee cou'de.                                    <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now this shall be my paye, sir king,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And this my guerdon bee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That some yong fair and courtlye knight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou bringe to marrye mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Fast then pricked king Arthùre                                     <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Ore hille, and dale, and downe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And soone he founde the barone's bowre:<br></span>
<span class="i2">And soone the grimme baroùne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He bare his clubbe upon his backe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Hee stoode bothe stiffe and stronge;                             <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And, when he had the letters reade,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Awaye the lettres flunge.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nowe yielde thee, Arthur, and thy lands,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All forfeit unto mee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For this is not thy paye, sir king,                                <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor may thy ransome bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet hold thy hand, thou proud baròne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I praye thee hold thy hand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And give mee leave to speake once more<br></span>
<span class="i2">In reskewe of my land.                                           <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This morne, as I came over a more,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I saw a ladye sette<br></span>
<span class="i0">Betwene an oke, and a greene hollèye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All clad in red scarlètte.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_19">[Pg 19]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee sayes, all women will have their wille,                       <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">This is their chief desyre;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now yield, as thou art a barone true,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That I have payd mine hyre.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">An earlye vengeaunce light on her!<br></span>
<span class="i2">The carlish baron swore:                                         <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shee was my sister tolde thee this,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And shee's a mishapen whore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But here I will make mine avowe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To do her as ill a turne:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For an ever I may that foule theefe gette,                         <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In a fyre I will her burne.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="tb">
<h4> <span class="smcap">Part the Seconde.</span></h4>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i019.png" id="img_images_i019.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Homewarde pricked king Arthùre,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And a wearye man was hee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And soone he mette queene Guenever,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That bride so bright of blee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What newes! what newes! thou noble king,                             <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Howe, Arthur, hast thou sped?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where hast thou hung the carlish knighte?<br></span>
<span class="i2">And where bestow'd his head?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The carlish knight is safe for mee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And free fro mortal harme:                                        <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">On magicke grounde his castle stands,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fenc'd with many a charme.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To bowe to him I was fulle faine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And yielde mee to his hand:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And but for a lothly ladye, there                                   <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I sholde have lost my land.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_20">[Pg 20]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And nowe this fills my hearte with woe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And sorrowe of my life;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I swore a yonge and courtlye knight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sholde marry her to his wife.                                     <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then bespake him sir Gawàine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That was ever a gentle knighte:<br></span>
<span class="i0">That lothly ladye I will wed;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Therefore be merrye and lighte.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nowe naye, nowe naye, good sir Gawàine;                             <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My sister's sonne yee bee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">This lothlye ladye's all too grimme,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all too foule for yee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her nose is crookt and turn'd outwàrde;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her chin stands all awrye;                                        <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A worse form'd ladye than shee is<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was never seen with eye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What though her chin stand all awrye.<br></span>
<span class="i2">And shee be foule to see:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I'll marry her, unkle, for thy sake,                                <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And I'll thy ransome bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nowe thankes, nowe thankes, good sir Gawàine;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And a blessing thee betyde!<br></span>
<span class="i0">To-morrow wee'll have knights and squires,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And wee'll goe fetch thy bride.                                   <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And wee'll have hawkes and wee'll have houndes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To cover our intent;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wee'll away to the greene forèst,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As wee a hunting went.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Lancelot, sir Stephen<a id="FNanchor_42"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_42">[42]</a> bolde,                                <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">They rode with them that daye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And foremoste of the companye<br></span>
<span class="i2">There rode the stewarde Kaye:<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_21">[Pg 21]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Soe did sir Banier<a id="FNanchor_43"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_43">[43]</a> and sir Bore,<a id="FNanchor_44"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_44">[44]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And eke sir Garratte<a id="FNanchor_45"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_45">[45]</a> keene;                                   <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Tristram too, that gentle knight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To the forest freshe and greene.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when they came to the greene forrèst,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Beneathe a faire holley tree<br></span>
<span class="i0">There sate that ladye in red scarlètte                              <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That unseemelye was to see.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Kay beheld that lady's face,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And looked upon her sweere;<a id="FNanchor_46"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_46">[46]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whoever kisses that ladye, he sayes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of his kisse he stands in feare.                                  <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Kay beheld that ladye againe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And looked upon her snout;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whoever kisses that ladye, he sayes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of his kisse he stands in doubt.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Peace, brother Kay, sayde sir Gawàine,                              <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And amend thee of thy life:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For there is a knight amongst us all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Must marry her to his wife.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What marry this foule queane, quoth Kay,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I' the devil's name anone;                                        <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Gett mee a wife wherever I maye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In sooth shee shall be none.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then some tooke up their hawkes in haste,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And some took up their houndes;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sayd they wolde not marry her,                                  <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For cities, nor for townes.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_22">[Pg 22]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then bespake him king Arthùre,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And sware there by this daye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For a little foule sighte and mislikìnge,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yee shall not say her naye.                                       <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Peace, lordings, peace; sir Gawaine sayd;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor make debate and strife;<br></span>
<span class="i0">This lothlye ladye I will take,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And marry her to my wife.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nowe thankes, nowe thankes, good sir Gawaine,                       <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And a blessinge be thy meede!<br></span>
<span class="i0">For as I am thine owne ladyè,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou never shalt rue this deede.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then up they took that lothly dame,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And home anone they bringe:                                       <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And there sir Gawaine he her wed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And married her with a ringe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when they were in wed-bed laid,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all were done awaye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">"Come turne to mee, mine owne wed-lord                              <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Come turne to mee I praye."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Gawaine scant could lift his head,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For sorrowe and for care;<br></span>
<span class="i0">When, lo! instead of that lothelye dame,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Hee sawe a young ladye faire.                                    <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sweet blushes stayn'd her rud-red cheeke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her eyen were blacke as sloe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The ripening cherrye swellde her lippe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all her necke was snowe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Gawaine kiss'd that lady faire,                                <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Lying upon the sheete:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And swore, as he was a true knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The spice was never soe sweete.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_23">[Pg 23]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Gawaine kiss'd that lady brighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Lying there by his side:                                         <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"The fairest flower is not soe faire:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou never can'st bee my bride."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I am thy bride, mine owne deare lorde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The same whiche thou didst knowe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That was soe lothlye, and was wont                                 <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Upon the wild more to goe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nowe, gentle Gawaine, chuse, quoth shee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And make thy choice with care;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whether by night, or else by daye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shall I be foule or faire?                                       <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"To have thee foule still in the night,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When I with thee should playe!<br></span>
<span class="i0">I had rather farre, my lady deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To have thee foule by daye."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What when gaye ladyes goe with their lordes                        <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To drinke the ale and wine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alas! then I must hide myself,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I must not goe with mine?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"My faire ladyè, sir Gawaine sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I yield me to thy skille;                                        <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Because thou art mine owne ladyè<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou shalt have all thy wille."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nowe blessed be thou, sweete Gawàine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And the daye that I thee see;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For as thou seest mee at this time,                                <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Soe shall I ever bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My father was an aged knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And yet it chanced soe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He tooke to wife a false ladyè,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whiche broughte me to this woe.                                  <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_24">[Pg 24]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee witch'd mee, being a faire yonge maide,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In the greene forèst to dwelle;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there to abide in lothlye shape,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Most like a fiend of helle.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Midst mores and mosses; woods, and wilds;                          <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To lead a lonesome life:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till some yong faire and courtlye knighte<br></span>
<span class="i2">Wolde marrye me to his wife:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nor fully to gaine mine owne trewe shape,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Such was her devilish skille;                                    <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Until he wolde yielde to be rul'd by mee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And let mee have all my wille.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She witchd my brother to a carlish boore,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And made him stiffe and stronge;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And built him a bowre on magicke grounde,                          <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To live by rapine and wronge.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But now the spelle is broken throughe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And wronge is turnde to righte;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Henceforth I shall bee a faire ladyè,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And hee be a gentle knighte.                                     <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">⁂</p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_34"></a><a href="#FNanchor_34" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[34]</span></a> [Percy folio MS. ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. i. p. 104.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_35"></a><a href="#FNanchor_35" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[35]</span></a> [complexion.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_36"></a><a href="#FNanchor_36" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[36]</span></a> [strong.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_37"></a><a href="#FNanchor_37" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[37]</span></a> [abused.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_38"></a><a href="#FNanchor_38" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[38]</span></a> <i>Tearne-Wadling</i> is the name of a small lake [in Inglewood
Forest] near Hesketh in Cumberland, on the road from Penrith to
Carlisle. There is a tradition, that an old castle once stood near
the lake, the remains of which were not long since visible. <i>Tarn</i>,
in the dialect of that country, signifies a small lake, and is still in
use. ["Tarn-Wadling ... has been for the last ten years a wide
meadow grazed by hundreds of sheep."—<span class="smcap">J. S. Glennie</span>, in <i>Macmillan's</i>
<i>Mag.</i> Dec. 1867, p. 167, col. 2.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_39"></a><a href="#FNanchor_39" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[39]</span></a> churlish.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_40"></a><a href="#FNanchor_40" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[40]</span></a> faith.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_41"></a><a href="#FNanchor_41" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[41]</span></a> This was a common phrase in our old writers; so Chaucer, in
his prologue to the <i>Cant. Tales</i>, says of the wife of Bath:—
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Her hosen were of fyne scarlet red."<br></span>
</div></div>
</div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_42"></a><a href="#FNanchor_42" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[42]</span></a> Sir F. Madden remarks that Sir Stephen does not appear in
the Round Table Romances.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_43"></a><a href="#FNanchor_43" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[43]</span></a> [Perhaps intended for Bedver, the King's Constable, Tennyson's
Bedivere, but more probably Ban of Benoyk, the brother of Bors.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_44"></a><a href="#FNanchor_44" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[44]</span></a> [Bors de Gauves, or Gaunes.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_45"></a><a href="#FNanchor_45" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[45]</span></a> [Gareth, or Gaheret, Sir Gawain's younger brother.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_46"></a><a href="#FNanchor_46" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[46]</span></a> [neck.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>III.<br>

KING RYENCE'S CHALLENGE.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i024.png" id="img_images_i024.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> song is more modern than many of those which
follow it, but is placed here for the sake of the subject.
It was sung before queene Elizabeth at the grand entertainment
at Kenelworth-castle in 1575, and was probably
composed for that occasion. In a letter describing those
festivities, it is thus mentioned: "A Minstral came forth with a
sollem song, warranted for story out of K. Arthur's acts, whereof
I gat a copy, and is this:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"So it fell out on a Pentecost, &amp;c."<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_25">[Pg 25]</a></span></p>
<p>After the song the narrative proceeds: "At this the Minstrell
made a pause and a curtezy for Primus Passus. More of the song
is thear, but I gatt it not."</p>
<p>The story in Morte Arthur, whence it is taken, runs as follows:
"Came a messenger hastely from king Ryence of North-Wales,—saying,
that king Ryence had discomfited and overcomen eleaven
kings, and everiche of them did him homage, and that was this:
they gave him their beards cleane flayne off.—wherefore the messenger
came for king Arthur's beard, for king Ryence had purfeled
a mantell with kings beards, and there lacked for one a place of
the mantell, wherefore he sent for his beard, or else he would enter
into his lands, and brenn and slay, and never leave till he have
thy head and thy beard. Well, said king Arthur, thou hast said
thy message, which is the most villainous and lewdest message that
ever man heard sent to a king. Also thou mayest see my beard is
full young yet for to make a purfell of, but tell thou the king that—or
it be long he shall do to me homage on both his knees, or
else he shall leese his head." [B. i. c. 24. See also the same
Romance, b. i. c. 92.]</p>
<p>The thought seems to be originally taken from Jeff. Monmouth's
<i>Hist.</i> b. x. c. 3. which is alluded to by Drayton in his <i>Poly-Olb.</i>
<i>Song.</i> 4 and by Spenser in <i>Faer. Qu.</i> 6. 1. 13. 15. See the Observations
on Spenser, vol. ii. p. 223.</p>
<p>The following text is composed of the best readings selected
from three different copies. The first in Enderbie's <i>Cambria</i>
<i>Triumphans</i>, p. 197. The second in the Letter abovementioned.
And the third inserted in MS. in a copy of <i>Morte Arthur</i>, 1632, in
the Bodleian Library.</p>
<p>Stow tells us, that king Arthur kept his round table at "diverse
places, but especially at Carlion, Winchester, and Camalet in
Somersetshire." This <i>Camalet</i>, sometimes a famous towne or
castle, is situate on a very high tor or hill, &amp;c. (See an exact
description in Stowe's <i>Annals</i>, ed. 1631, p. 55.)</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i025.png" id="img_images_i025.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">As it fell out on a Pentecost day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">King Arthur at Camelot kept his court royall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his faire queene dame Guenever the gay;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And many bold barons sitting in hall;<br></span>
<span class="i2">With ladies attired in purple and pall;                            <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_26">[Pg 26]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And heraults in hewkes,<a id="FNanchor_47"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_47">[47]</a> hooting on high,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Cryed, <i>Largesse, Largesse, Chevaliers tres-hardie</i>.<a id="FNanchor_48"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_48">[48]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A doughty dwarfe to the uppermost deas<a id="FNanchor_49"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_49">[49]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Right pertlye gan pricke, kneeling on knee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With steven<a id="FNanchor_50"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_50">[50]</a> fulle stoute amids all the preas,<a id="FNanchor_51"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_51">[51]</a> <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Sayd, Nowe sir king Arthur, God save thee, and see!<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sir Ryence of North-gales<a id="FNanchor_52"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_52">[52]</a> greeteth well thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bids thee thy beard anon to him send,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or else from thy jaws he will it off rend.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For his robe of state is a rich scarlet mantle,                     <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With eleven kings beards bordered<a id="FNanchor_53"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_53">[53]</a> about,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there is room lefte yet in a kantle,<a id="FNanchor_54"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_54">[54]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">For thine to stande, to make the twelfth out:<br></span>
<span class="i2">This must be done, be thou never so stout;<br></span>
<span class="i0">This must be done, I tell thee no fable,                            <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Maugre<a id="FNanchor_55"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_55">[55]</a> the teethe of all thy round table.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When this mortal message from his mouthe past,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Great was the noyse bothe in hall and in bower:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The king fum'd; the queene screecht; ladies were aghast;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Princes puffd; barons blustred; lords began lower;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Knights stormed; squires startled, like steeds in a stower;       <span class="linenum">26</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Pages and yeomen yell'd out in the hall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then in came sir Kay, the 'king's' seneschal.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_27">[Pg 27]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Silence, my soveraignes, quoth this courteous knight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And in that stound the stowre<a id="FNanchor_56"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_56">[56]</a> began still:                    <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">'Then' the dwarfe's dinner full deerely was dight;<a id="FNanchor_57"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_57">[57]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of wine and wassel he had his wille:<br></span>
<span class="i2">And, when he had eaten and drunken his fill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An hundred pieces of fine coyned gold<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were given this dwarf for his message bold.                         <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But say to sir Ryence, thou dwarf, quoth the king,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That for his bold message I do him defye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And shortlye with basins and pans will him ring<br></span>
<span class="i2">Out of North-gales; where he and I<br></span>
<span class="i2">With swords, and not razors, quickly shall trye,                  <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whether he, or king Arthur will prove the best barbor:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And therewith he shook his good sword Excalàbor.<br></span>
<span class="i0">       *       *       *       *       *<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>†‡† Strada, in his <i>Prolusions</i>, has ridiculed the story of the
Giant's Mantle, made of the Beards of Kings.</p></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_47"></a><a href="#FNanchor_47" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[47]</span></a> [party-coloured coats.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_48"></a><a href="#FNanchor_48" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[48]</span></a> <i>Largesse, Largesse.</i> The heralds resounded these words as oft
as they received of the bounty of the knights. See <i>Memoires de la</i>
<i>Chevalerie</i>, tom. i. p. 99.—The expression is still used in the form
of installing knights of the garter.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_49"></a><a href="#FNanchor_49" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[49]</span></a> [dais or upper table.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_50"></a><a href="#FNanchor_50" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[50]</span></a> [voice.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_51"></a><a href="#FNanchor_51" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[51]</span></a> [press.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_52"></a><a href="#FNanchor_52" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[52]</span></a> [North Wales.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_53"></a><a href="#FNanchor_53" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[53]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> set round the border, as furs are now round the gowns of
Magistrates.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_54"></a><a href="#FNanchor_54" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[54]</span></a> [corner.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_55"></a><a href="#FNanchor_55" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[55]</span></a> [in spite of.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_56"></a><a href="#FNanchor_56" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[56]</span></a> [that moment the tumult.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_57"></a><a href="#FNanchor_57" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[57]</span></a> [decked.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>IV.<br>

KING ARTHUR'S DEATH.</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">A Fragment.</span>
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i027.png" id="img_images_i027.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> subject of this ballad is evidently taken from the old
romance <i>Morte Arthur</i>, but with some variations, especially
in the concluding stanzas; in which the author
seems rather to follow the traditions of the old Welsh
Bards, who believed that King Arthur was not dead, "but conveied
awaie by the Fairies into some pleasant place, where he should
remaine for a time, and then returne againe and reign in as great
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_28">[Pg 28]</a></span>authority as ever." Holinshed, b. 5, c. 14, or as it is expressed in
an old Chronicle printed at Antwerp 1493, by Ger. de Leew,
"The Bretons supposen, that he [K. Arthur]—shall come yet and
conquere all Bretaigne, for certes this is the prophicye of Merlyn:
He sayd, that his deth shall be doubteous; and sayd soth, for men
thereof yet have doubte, and shullen for ever more,—for men wyt
not whether that he lyveth or is dede." See more ancient testimonies
in Selden's <i>Notes on Polyolbion, Song III.</i></p>
<p>This fragment being very incorrect and imperfect in the original
MS. hath received some conjectural emendations, and even a supplement
of three or four stanzas composed from the romance of
<i>Morte Arthur</i>.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The two ballads here entitled <i>King Arthur's Death</i> and <i>The</i>
<i>Legend of King Arthur</i> are united in the Folio MS. (ed. Hales and
Furnivall, vol. i. p. 497), but they are evidently two distinct songs.
The first ballad forms part ii. of the MS. copy, which has fourteen
verses at the end not printed here. The last four verses are
printed at the end of the next ballad. Percy has taken great
liberties with his original, and has not left a single line unaltered,
as will be seen by comparing it with the original printed at the
end. Additional lines are also interpolated which are now enclosed
within brackets, and it will be seen that these unnecessary
amplifications do not improve the effect of the poem. It will also
be seen that in vv. 41-44 the father and son of the original are
changed into uncle and nephew.</p>
<p>This last scene in the life of King Arthur is the most beautiful
and touching portion of his history, and the romancers and minstrels
were never tired of telling it in every form.</p>
<p>According to one tradition Arthur still sleeps under St. Michael's
Mount ("the guarded Mount" of Milton's <i>Lycidas</i>), and according
to another beneath Richmond Castle, Yorkshire.</p>
<p>Mr. Willmott, in his edition of the <i>Reliques</i>, writes, "according
to popular superstition in Sicily, Arthur is preserved alive by his
sister la Fata Morgana, whose fairy palace is occasionally seen
from Reggio in the opposite sea of Messina."]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i028.png" id="img_images_i028.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">       *       *       *       *       *<br></span>
<span class="i0">On Trinitye Mondaye in the morne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">This sore battayle was doom'd to bee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where manye a knighte cry'd, Well-awaye!<br></span>
<span class="i2">Alacke, it was the more pittìe.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_29">[Pg 29]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ere the first crowinge of the cocke,                                 <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">When as the kinge in his bed laye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He thoughte sir Gawaine to him came,<a id="FNanchor_58"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_58">[58]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And there to him these wordes did saye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nowe, as you are mine unkle deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And as you prize your life, this daye                             <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O meet not with your foe in fighte;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Putt off the battayle, if yee maye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For sir Launcelot is now in Fraunce,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And with him many an hardye knighte:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who will within this moneth be backe,                               <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And will assiste yee in the fighte.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The kinge then call'd his nobles all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Before the breakinge of the daye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tolde them howe sir Gawaine came,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And there to him these wordes did saye.                           <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">His nobles all this counsayle gave,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That earlye in the morning, hee<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shold send awaye an herauld at armes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To aske a parley faire and free.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then twelve good knightes king Arthure chose,                       <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The best of all that with him were:<br></span>
<span class="i0">To parley with the foe in field,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And make with him agreement faire.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The king he charged all his hoste,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In readinesse there for to bee:                                   <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But noe man sholde noe weapon sturre,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unlesse a sword drawne they shold see<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_30">[Pg 30]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And Mordred on the other parte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Twelve of his knights did likewise bringe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The beste of all his companye,                                      <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To hold the parley with the kinge.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Mordred alsoe charged his hoste,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In readinesse there for to bee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But noe man sholde noe weapon sturre,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But if a sworde drawne they shold see.                            <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For he durste not his unkle truste,<a id="FNanchor_59"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_59">[59]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor he his nephewe, sothe to tell:<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_59">[59]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Alacke! it was a woefulle case,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As ere in Christentye befelle.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But when they were together mette,                                  <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And both to faire accordance broughte;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a month's league betweene them sette,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Before the battayle sholde be foughte;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">An addere crept forth of a bushe,<br></span>
