<span class="i2">Stunge one o' th' king's knightes on the knee:                    <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Alacke! it was a woefulle chance,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As ever was in Christentìe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When the knighte found him wounded sore,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And sawe the wild-worme<a id="FNanchor_60"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_60">[60]</a> hanginge there;<br></span>
<span class="i0">His sworde he from his scabberde drewe;                             <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">A piteous case as ye shall heare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For when the two hostes sawe the sworde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They joyned battayle instantlye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till of soe manye noble knightes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">On one side there were left but three.                            <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_31">[Pg 31]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For all were slain that durst abide,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And but some fewe that fled awaye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ay mee! it was a bloodye fielde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As ere was foughte on summer's daye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Upon king Arthur's own partyè,                                      <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Onlye himselfe escaped there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Lukyn duke of Gloster free,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And the king's butler Bedevere.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when the king beheld his knightes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All dead and scattered on the molde;                              <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">[The teares fast trickled downe his face;<br></span>
<span class="i2">That manlye face in fight so bolde.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nowe reste yee all, brave knights, he said,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Soe true and faithful to your trust:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And must yee then, ye valiant hearts,                               <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Be lefte to moulder into dust!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Most loyal have yee been to mee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Most true and faithful unto deathe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, oh! to rayse yee up againe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">How freelye could I yield my breathe!]                            <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But see the traitor's yet alive,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Lo where hee stalkes among the deade!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nowe bitterlye he shall abye:<a id="FNanchor_61"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_61">[61]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And vengeance fall upon his head.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O staye, my liege, then sayd the duke;                              <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">O staye for love and charitìe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">[Remember what the vision spake,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor meete your foe, if it may bee.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_32">[Pg 32]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O, staye mee not, thou worthye wight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">This debt my loyal knights I owe:                                 <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Betide me life, betide me death,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I will avenge them of their foe.]<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then straite he grasp'd his trustye speare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And on his horse then mounted hee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">As his butler holpe him to his horse,                               <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His bowels gushed to his knee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Alas! then sayd the noble king,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That I should live this sight to see!<br></span>
<span class="i0">To see this good knight here be slaine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All for his love in helping mee!                                 <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He put his speare into his reste,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And to sir Mordred loud gan crye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">[Nowe sette thyself upon thy guarde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For, traitor, nowe thy death is nye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Mordred lifted up his sworde,                                  <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And fierce to meet the king ran hee:]<br></span>
<span class="i0">The king his speare he through him thrust;<br></span>
<span class="i2">A fathom thorow his bodìe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When Mordered felt the stroke of death,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And found that he was wounded soe;                               <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He thruste himselfe upon the speare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And strucke the king a deadlye blowe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then grimmlye dyed sir Mordered,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Presentlye upon that tree:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bloody streames ranne from the kinge                           <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Ere to the duke returned hee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Lukyn then he thus bespake,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sir knighte, thou hast beene faithfulle tryde,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nowe take my sword Excalibar,<a id="FNanchor_62"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_62">[62]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That hangs so freelye by my syde:                                <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_33">[Pg 33]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O take my sword Excalibar,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And there into the river throwe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For here, henceforth, benethe this tree,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All use of weapons I foregoe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[And fare thee well, thou trustye sword,                           <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">A better neer had valiant knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With thee full ofte, and manye a daye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Have I withstood my foe in fighte.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With this good fauchion in my hande,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Oft have I reapd the bloody feelde:                              <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But nowe the fatalle houre is come,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That never more I may thee weelde.]<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The duke to the river side he went,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And there his owne sword in threwe he:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he kept back Excalibar,                                        <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He kept it back in privitie.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[For all of coleyne<a id="FNanchor_63"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_63">[63]</a> was the blade;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all the hilte of precious stone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ever alacke! then sayd the knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Must such a sword awaye be throwne?]                             <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then backe he came unto the kinge,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who sayd, Sir Lukyn, what did yee see?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nothing, my liege, save that the winde<br></span>
<span class="i2">Blewe oer the waters faire and free.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O goe againe, then said the kinge,                                 <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">O good sir Lukyn, goe againe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Into the rivere throwe my sword,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor keepe me lingering here in paine.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_34">[Pg 34]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The duke then to the river went,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And the kings scabberd in threwe hee;                            <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But hee kept backe Excalibar,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And hid it undernethe a tree.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then backe he came to tell the kinge,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who sayde, Sir Lukyn sawe ye oughte?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nothinge, my liege, save that the winde                            <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Nowe with the angrye waters fought.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O Lukyn, Lukyn, said the kinge,<br></span>
<span class="i2">[Twice haste thou dealt deceytfullye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alacke, whom may wee ever truste,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When suche a knighte soe false can bee?                          <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Saye, wouldst thou have thy master dead;<br></span>
<span class="i2">All for a sword, that wins thine eye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nowe goe againe, and throwe it in,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or here the one of us shall dye.]<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The duke, all shent with this rebuke,                              <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">No aunswere made unto the kinge:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But to the rivere tooke the sworde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And threwe it far as he coulde flinge.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A hande and an arme did meete the sworde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And flourishd three times in the air;                            <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">[Then sunke benethe the renninge streme,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And of the duke was seene noe mair.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All sore astonied stood the duke;<br></span>
<span class="i2">He stood as still, as still mote bee:]<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then hastend backe to telle the kinge;                             <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">But he was gone from under the tree.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But to what place he cold not tell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For never after hee did him spye:<a id="FNanchor_64"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_64">[64]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">But hee sawe a barge goe from the land,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_35">[Pg 35]</a></span>
<span class="i2">And hee heard ladyes howle and crye<a id="FNanchor_65"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_65">[65]</a>.                         <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And whether the kinge were there, or not,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Hee never knewe, nor ever colde:<br></span>
<span class="i0">[For from that sad and direfulle daye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Hee never more was scene on molde.]<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">⁂</p>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 100px;">
<img alt="" height="37" src="images/i035.png" width="100" id="img_images_i035.png">
</div>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i035t.png" id="img_images_i035t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capm"><span class="smcap">[The</span> following forms Part II. of a ballad entitled <i>King</i>
<i>Arthur's Death</i>, in the folio MS. ed. Hales and Furnivall,
vol. i. p. 501.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">but vpon a Monday after Trinity Sonday<br></span>
<span class="i0">this battaile foughten cold bee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">where many a Knight cryed well-away!<br></span>
<span class="i0">alacke, the more pittye!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">but vpon Sunday in the euening then,                                 <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">when the King in his bedd did Lye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">he thought Sir Gawaine to him came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; thus to him did say:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Now as you are my vnckle deere,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I pray you be ruled by mee,                                         <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">doe not fight as to-morrow day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">but put the battelle of if you may;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"for Sir Lancelott is now in france,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; many Knights with him full hardye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; with-in this Month here hee wilbe,                                <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">great aide wilbe to thee."<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_36">[Pg 36]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">hee wakened forth of his dreames;<br></span>
<span class="i0">to his Nobles that told hee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">how he thought Sir Gawaine to him came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; these words sayd Certainly.                                       <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; then thé gaue the King councell all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">vpon Munday Earlye<br></span>
<span class="i0">that hee shold send one of his heralds of armes<br></span>
<span class="i0">to parle with his sonne, if itt might bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; 12 knights King Arthur chose,                                     <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">the best in his companye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">that they shold goe to meete his sonne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">to agree if itt cold bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; the King charged all his host<br></span>
<span class="i0">in readynesse for to bee,                                           <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">that Noe man shold noe weapons stur<br></span>
<span class="i0">with-out a sword drawne amongst his Knights thé see.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; Mordred vpon the other part,<br></span>
<span class="i0">12 of his Knights chose hee<br></span>
<span class="i0">that they shold goe to meete his father                             <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">betweene those 2 hosts fayre &amp; free.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; Mordred charged his ost<br></span>
<span class="i0">in like mannor most certaínely,<br></span>
<span class="i0">that noe man shold noe weapons sturr<br></span>
<span class="i0">with-out a sword drawne amongst them thé see;                       <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">for he durst not his father trust,<br></span>
<span class="i0">nor the father the sonne certainley.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alacke! this was a woefull case<br></span>
<span class="i0">as euer was in christentye!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">but when they were mett together there,                             <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; agreed of all things as itt shold bee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; a monthes League then there was<br></span>
<span class="i0">before the battele foughten shold bee,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">an Adder came forth of Bush,<br></span>
<span class="i0">stunge one of king Arthirs Knights below his knee;                  <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">alacke! this was a woefull chance<br></span>
<span class="i0">as euer was in christentye!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">the Knight he found him wounded there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; see the wild worme there to bee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">his sword out of his scabberd he drew;                              <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">alas! itt was the more pittye!<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_37">[Pg 37]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; when these 2 osts saw they sword drawen,<br></span>
<span class="i0">thé Ioyned battell certainlye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till of a 100: 1000: men<br></span>
<span class="i0">of one side was left but 3.                                         <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">but all were slaine that durst abyde,<br></span>
<span class="i0">but some awaye that did flee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">King Arthur upon his owne partye<br></span>
<span class="i0">himselfe aliue cold be,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; Lukin the Duke of Gloster,                                        <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; Bedever his Butler certainlye<br></span>
<span class="i0">the King looked about him there<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; saw his Knights all slaine to bee;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Alas!" then sayd noble King Arthur<br></span>
<span class="i0">"that ever this sight I see!                                        <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">to see all my good Knights lye slaine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; the traitor yett aliue to bee!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">loe where he leanes vpon his sword hillts<br></span>
<span class="i0">amongst his dead men certainlye!<br></span>
<span class="i0">I will goe slay him att this time;                                  <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">neuer att better advantage I shall him see."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Nay! stay here, my Leege!" then said the Duke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">"for loue and charitye!<br></span>
<span class="i0">for wee haue the battell woone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">for yett aliue we are but 3:"                                       <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">the king wold not be perswaded then,<br></span>
<span class="i0">but his horsse then mounted hee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">his Butler [that] helped him to horsse,<br></span>
<span class="i0">his bowells gushed to his knee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Alas!" then said noble king Arthur,                                <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"that this sight I euer see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">to see this good knight for to be slaine<br></span>
<span class="i0">for loue for to helpe mee!"<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">he put his speare into his rest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; att his sonne he ryd feirclye,                                    <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; through him there his speare he thrust<br></span>
<span class="i0">a fatham thorrow his body.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">the sonne he felld him wounded there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; knew his death then to bee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">he thrust himselfe vpon his speare,                                 <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; gaue his father a wound certainlye.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_38">[Pg 38]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">but there dyed Sir Mordred<br></span>
<span class="i0">presently vpon that tree.<br></span>
<span class="i0">but or ere the King returned againe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">his butler was dead certainlye.                                    <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">then bespake him Noble King Arthur,<br></span>
<span class="i0">these were the words sayd hee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">sayes "take my sword Escalberd<br></span>
<span class="i0">from my side fayre &amp; free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; throw itt into this riuer heere;                                 <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">for all the vse of weapons Ile deliuer vppe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">heere vnderneath this tree."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">the Duke to the riuer side he went,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; his sword in threw hee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; then he kept Escalberd,                                          <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I tell you certainlye;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; then he came to tell the King,<br></span>
<span class="i0">the king said, "Lukin what did thou see?"<br></span>
<span class="i0">noe thing, my leege," the[n] sayd the duke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">"I tell you certainlye."                                           <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"O goe againe," said the king<br></span>
<span class="i0">"for loue &amp; charitye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; throw my sword into that riuer,<br></span>
<span class="i0">that neuer I doe itt see."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">the Duke to the riuer side he went,                                <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; the kings scaberd in threw hee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; still he kept Escalberd<br></span>
<span class="i0">for vertue sake faire &amp; free.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">he came againe to tell the King;<br></span>
<span class="i0">the King sayd, "Lukin what did thou see?"                          <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"nothing my leege," then sayd the Duke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">"I tell you certainlye."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"O goe againe Lukin," said the King,<br></span>
<span class="i0">"or the one of vs shall dye."<br></span>
<span class="i0">then the Duke to the riuer sid went,                               <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; then Kings sword then threw hee:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A hand &amp; an arme did meete that sword,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; flourished 3 times certainlye<br></span>
<span class="i0">he came againe to tell the King,<br></span>
<span class="i0">but the king was gone from vnder the tree                          <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_39">[Pg 39]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">but to what place, he cold not tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">for neuer after hee did him see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">but he see a barge from the land goe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; hearde Ladyes houle &amp; cry certainlye;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">but whether the king was there or noe                              <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">he knew not certainlye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">the Duke walked by that Riuers side<br></span>
<span class="i0">till a chappell there found hee,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; a preist by the aulter side there stood.<br></span>
<span class="i0">the Duke kneeled downe there on his knee                           <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; prayed the preists, "for Christs sake<br></span>
<span class="i0">the rights of the church bestow on mee!"<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">for many dangerous wounds he had vpon him<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; liklye he was to dye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; there the Duke liued in prayer                                   <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">till the time that hee did dye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">King Arthur liued King 22 yeere<br></span>
<span class="i0">in honor and great fame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; thus by death suddenlye<br></span>
<span class="i0">was depriued from the same.                                        <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">ffins.]</p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_58"></a><a href="#FNanchor_58" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[58]</span></a> Sir Gawaine had been killed at Arthur's landing on his return
from abroad. See the next ballad, ver. 73.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_59"></a><a href="#FNanchor_59" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[59]</span></a> [Ver. 41, 42, the folio MS. reads father ... sonne.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_60"></a><a href="#FNanchor_60" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[60]</span></a> [serpent.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_61"></a><a href="#FNanchor_61" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[61]</span></a> [pay for or expiate.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_62"></a><a href="#FNanchor_62" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[62]</span></a> More commonly called, <i>Caliburn</i>. In the folio MS. <i>Escallberd</i>.
[Percy notes in the MS. that "Caliburn was presented <span class="smcap">A.D.</span>
1191 to Tancred, King of Sicily, by our King Richard I. See
Rapin, vol. i."]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_63"></a><a href="#FNanchor_63" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[63]</span></a> [Cologne steel.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_64"></a><a href="#FNanchor_64" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[64]</span></a> Ver. 178, see MS.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_65"></a><a href="#FNanchor_65" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[65]</span></a> Not unlike that passage in Virgil.
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Summoque ulularunt vertice nymphæ."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>
<i>Ladies</i> was the word our old English writers used for <i>Nymphs</i>:
As in the following lines of an old song in the Editor's folio MS.
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"When scorching Phœbus he did mount,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Lady Venus went to hunt;<br></span>
<span class="i2">To whom Diana did resort,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With all the Ladyes of hills, and valleys<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of springs, and floodes, &amp;c."<br></span>
</div></div>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>V.<br>

THE LEGEND OF KING ARTHUR.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i039.png" id="img_images_i039.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capm"><span class="smcap">We</span> have here a short summary of K. Arthur's History
as given by Jeff. of Monmouth and the old chronicles,
with the addition of a few circumstances from the romance
Morte Arthur.—The ancient chronicle of Ger.
de Leew (quoted above in p. <a href="#Page_28" class="pginternal">28</a>), seems to have been chiefly
followed: upon the authority of which we have restored some of
the names which were corrupted in the MS. and have transposed
one stanza, which appeared to be misplaced, (<i>viz.</i> that beginning
at ver. 49, which in the MS. followed ver. 36.)</p>
<p>Printed from the Editor's ancient folio Manuscript.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This ballad as previously stated is the first part of the poem in
the MS. and precedes the one here printed before it. Percy made
comparatively few alterations in this part and all of them are now
noted at the foot of the page.]</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_40">[Pg 40]</a></span></p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i040.png" id="img_images_i040.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Of Brutus' blood, in Brittaine borne,<a id="FNanchor_66"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_66">[66]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">King Arthur I am to name;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Through Christendome, and Heathynesse,<a id="FNanchor_67"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_67">[67]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Well knowne is my worthy fame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In Jesus Christ I doe beleeve;                                       <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I am a christyan bore:<a id="FNanchor_68"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_68">[68]</a><a id="FNanchor_69"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_69">[69]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">The Father, Sone, and Holy Gost<br></span>
<span class="i2">One God, I doe adore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In the four hundred ninetieth yeere,<a id="FNanchor_70"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_70">[70]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Over Brittaine I did rayne,                                       <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">After my savior Christ his byrth:<br></span>
<span class="i2">What time I did maintaine<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The fellowshipp of the table round,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Soe famous in those dayes;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whereatt a hundred noble knights,                                   <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And thirty sat alwayes:<a id="FNanchor_71"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_71">[71]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Who for their deeds and martiall feates,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As bookes done yett record,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Amongst all other nations<a id="FNanchor_72"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_72">[72]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Wer feared throwgh the world.                                     <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And in the castle off Tyntagill<a id="FNanchor_73"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_73">[73]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">King Uther mee begate<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Agyana a bewtyous ladye,<a id="FNanchor_74"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_74">[74]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And come of "hie" estate.<a id="FNanchor_75"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_75">[75]</a><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_41">[Pg 41]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when I was fifteen yeere old,                                   <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Then was I crowned kinge:<br></span>
<span class="i0">All Brittaine that was att an upròre,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I did to quiett bringe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And drove the Saxons from the realme,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who had opprest this land;                                        <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">All Scotland then throughe manly feats<a id="FNanchor_76"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_76">[76]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">I conquered with my hand.<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_76">[76]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ireland, Denmarke, Norway,<br></span>
<span class="i2">These countryes wan I all;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Iseland, Gotheland, and Swethland;                                  <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And made their kings my thrall.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I conquered all Gallya,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That now is called France;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And slew the hardye Froll in feild<a id="FNanchor_77"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_77">[77]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">My honor to advance.                                              <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And the ugly gyant Dynabus<a id="FNanchor_78"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_78">[78]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Soe terrible to vewe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That in Saint Barnards mount did lye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">By force of armes I slew:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And Lucyus the emperour of Rome                                     <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I brought to deadly wracke;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a thousand more of noble knightes<br></span>
<span class="i2">For feare did turne their backe:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Five kinges of "paynims"<a id="FNanchor_79"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_79">[79]</a> I did kill<a id="FNanchor_80"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_80">[80]</a><a id="FNanchor_81"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_81">[81]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Amidst that bloody strife;<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_81">[81]</a> <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Besides the Grecian emperour<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_81">[81]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who alsoe lost his liffe.<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_81">[81]</a><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_42">[Pg 42]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Whose carcasse I did send to Rome<br></span>
<span class="i2">Cladd poorlye on a beere;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And afterward I past Mount-Joye                                     <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The next approaching yeere.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then I came to Rome, where I was mett<br></span>
<span class="i2">Right as a conquerour,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And by all the cardinalls solempnelye<br></span>
<span class="i2">I was crowned an emperour.                                        <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">One winter there I made abode:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then word to mee was brought<br></span>
<span class="i0">How Mordred had oppressd the crowne:<br></span>
<span class="i2">What treason he had wrought<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Att home in Brittaine with my queene;                               <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Therfore I came with speede<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Brittaine backe, with all my power,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To quitt that traiterous deede:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And soone at Sandwiche I arrivde,<a id="FNanchor_82"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_82">[82]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Where Mordred me withstoode:                                      <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But yett at last I landed there,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With effusion of much blood.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For there my nephew sir Gawaine dyed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Being wounded in that sore,<a id="FNanchor_83"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_83">[83]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">The whiche sir Lancelot in fight<a id="FNanchor_84"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_84">[84]</a> <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Had given him before.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thence chased I Mordered away,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who fledd to London right,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From London to Winchester, and<br></span>
<span class="i2">To Cornewalle tooke his flyght.<a id="FNanchor_85"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_85">[85]</a> <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_43">[Pg 43]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And still I him pursued with speed<br></span>
<span class="i2">Till at the last we mett:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whereby an appointed day of fight<a id="FNanchor_86"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_86">[86]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Was there agreed and sett.<a id="FNanchor_87"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_87">[87]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Where we did fight, of mortal life<a id="FNanchor_88"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_88">[88]</a> <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Eche other to deprive,<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_88">[88]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Till of a hundred thousand men<br></span>
<span class="i2">Scarce one was left a live.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There all the noble chivalrye<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of Brittaine tooke their end.                                     <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O see how fickle is their state<br></span>
<span class="i2">That doe on feates depend!<a id="FNanchor_89"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_89">[89]</a><a id="FNanchor_90"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_90">[90]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There all the traiterous men were slaine<br></span>
<span class="i2">Not one escapte away;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there dyed all my vallyant knightes.                            <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Alas! that woefull day!<a id="FNanchor_91"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_91">[91]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Two and twenty yeere I ware the crowne<br></span>
<span class="i2">In honor and great fame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus by death was suddenlye<br></span>
<span class="i2">Deprived of the same.                                            <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_44">[Pg 44]</a></span></p><div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_67"></a><a href="#FNanchor_67" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[67]</span></a> [heathendom.]</p></div>

<div class="footnote">

his reign <span class="smcap">A.D.</span> 515, according to the Chronicles.</p></div>

<span class="i0">And then I conquered througe manly feats,<br></span>
<span class="i0">All Scottlande with my hands, MS.]<br></span>
</div></div>
</div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_77"></a><a href="#FNanchor_77" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[77]</span></a> V. 39. Froland feild, MS. Froll, according to the Chronicles, was

of Pavye, MS.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_81"></a><a href="#FNanchor_81" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[81]</span></a> [V. 49-52. this stanza occurs after v. 36 in the MS.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_82"></a><a href="#FNanchor_82" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[82]</span></a> [Ver. 69. and when at Sandwich I did land.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_83"></a><a href="#FNanchor_83" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[83]</span></a> [V. 74. on that.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_85"></a><a href="#FNanchor_85" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[85]</span></a> [V. 80. he tooke. MS.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">

</p>

<span class="i0">Where wee did fight soe mortallye<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of live eche other to deprive.]<br></span>
</div></div>
</div>
<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_91"></a><a href="#FNanchor_91" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[91]</span></a> [V. 96 is the end of the first
part in the MS., the stanza
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">King Arthur lived King 22 yeere<br></span>
<span class="i2">in honor and great fame<br></span>
<span class="i0">and thus by death suddenlye<br></span>
<span class="i2">was deprived from the same<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>
ends the second part, which is printed by Percy as <i>King Arthur's</i>
<i>death</i>, see previous ballad.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>VI.<br>

A DYTTIE TO HEY DOWNE.</h3>
<p>Copied from an old MS. in the Cotton Library [British Museum]
(Vesp. A. xxv. fol. 170), intitled, "Divers things of Hen. viij's
time."</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i044.png" id="img_images_i044.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Who sekes to tame the blustering winde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or causse the floods bend to his wyll,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or els against dame nature's kinde<br></span>
<span class="i2">To "change" things frame by cunning skyll:<a id="FNanchor_92"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_92">[92]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">That man I thinke bestoweth paine,                                   <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thoughe that his laboure be in vaine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Who strives to breake the sturdye steele,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or goeth about to staye the sunne;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who thinks to causse an oke to reele,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which never can by force be done:                                 <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That man likewise bestoweth paine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thoughe that his laboure be in vaine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Who thinks to stryve against the streame,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And for to sayle without a maste;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unlesse he thinks perhapps to faine,                                <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His travell ys forelorne and waste;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so in cure of all his paine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His travell ys his cheffest gaine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So he lykewise, that goes about<br></span>
<span class="i2">To please eche eye and every eare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had nede to have withouten doubt<br></span>
<span class="i2">A golden gyft with hym to beare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For evyll report shall be his gaine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Though he bestowe both toyle and paine.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_45">[Pg 45]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">God grant eche man one to amend;                                    <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">God send us all a happy place;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And let us pray unto the end,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That we may have our princes grace:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Amen, Amen! so shall we gaine<br></span>
<span class="i0">A dewe reward for all our paine.                                    <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_92"></a><a href="#FNanchor_92" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[92]</span></a> Ver. 4. causse, MS.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>VII.<br>

GLASGERION.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i045.png" id="img_images_i045.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">An</span> ingenious Friend thinks that the following old Ditty
(which is printed from the Editor's folio MS.) may
possibly have given birth to the Tragedy of the <i>Orphan</i>,
in which Polidore intercepts Monimia's intended favours
to Castalio.</p>
<p>See what is said concerning the hero of this song, (who is celebrated
by <i>Chaucer</i> under the name of <i>Glaskyrion</i>) in the Essay
affixed to vol. i. note H. pt. iv. (2).</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The hero of this ballad is the same as "gret Glascurion," placed
by Chaucer in the <i>House of Fame</i> by the side of Orpheus, and also
associated with Orpheus by Gawain Douglas in the <i>Palice of Honour</i>.
Percy's note in the Folio MS. is "It was not necessary to correct
this much for the press;" (ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. i. p. 246).
It will be seen, however, by the collations at the foot of the page
that several corrections were made, not always for the better. Thus
ver. 96, "who did his ladye grieve," is certainly weaker than the
original,—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"And asked noe man noe leave."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>Jamieson (<i>Popular Ballads</i>, 1806, vol. i. p. 91) prints an inferior
version under the name of <i>Glenkindie</i>. Mr. Hale points out, however,
that "the Scotch version is more perfect in one point—in the
test question put to the page before the assignation is disclosed to
him:—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'O mith I tell you, Gib my man,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gin I a man had slain?'<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>Some such question perhaps would give more force to vv. 85-88 of
our version." He also very justly observes, "perhaps there is no
ballad that represents more keenly the great gulf fixed between
churl and noble—a profounder horror at the crossing over it."]</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_46">[Pg 46]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i046.png" id="img_images_i046.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Glasgerion was a kings owne sonne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And a harper he was goode:<br></span>
<span class="i0">He harped in the kinges chambere,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where cuppe and candle stoode.<a id="FNanchor_93"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_93">[93]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And soe did hee in the queens chamber,                               <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Till ladies waxed "glad."<a id="FNanchor_94"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_94">[94]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And then bespake the kinges daughter;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And these wordes thus shee sayd.<a id="FNanchor_95"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_95">[95]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Strike on, strike on, Glasgèrion,<a id="FNanchor_96"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_96">[96]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of thy striking doe not blinne:<a id="FNanchor_97"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_97">[97]</a> <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Theres never a stroke comes oer thy harpe,<a id="FNanchor_98"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_98">[98]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">But it glads my hart withinne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Faire might he fall,<a id="FNanchor_99"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_99">[99]</a> ladye, quoth hee,<a id="FNanchor_100"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_100">[100]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who taught you nowe to speake!<br></span>
<span class="i0">I have loved you, ladye, seven longe yeere<a id="FNanchor_101"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_101">[101]</a> <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My minde I neere durst breake.<a id="FNanchor_102"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_102">[102]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But come to my bower, my Glasgèrion,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When all men are att rest:<br></span>
<span class="i0">As I am a ladie true of my promise,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou shalt bee a welcome guest.                                   <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Home then came Glasgèrion,<a id="FNanchor_103"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_103">[103]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">A glad man, lord! was hee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, come thou hither, Jacke my boy;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Come hither unto mee.<a id="FNanchor_104"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_104">[104]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For the kinges daughter of Normandye                                <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Hath granted mee my boone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And att her chambere must I bee<br></span>
<span class="i2">Beffore the cocke have crowen.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_47">[Pg 47]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O master, master, then quoth hee,<a id="FNanchor_105"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_105">[105]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Lay your head downe on this stone:                                <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For I will waken you, master deere,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Afore it be time to gone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But up then rose that lither<a id="FNanchor_106"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_106">[106]</a> ladd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And hose and shoone did on:<a id="FNanchor_107"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_107">[107]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">A coller he cast upon his necke,                                    <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Hee seemed a gentleman.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he came to the ladies chamber,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He thrild upon a pinn.<a id="FNanchor_108"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_108">[108]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">The lady was true of her promise,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Rose up and lett him in.                                          <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He did not take the lady gaye<br></span>
<span class="i2">To boulster nor to bed:<a id="FNanchor_109"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_109">[109]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">"Nor thoughe hee had his wicked wille,<a id="FNanchor_110"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_110">[110]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">"A single word he sed."<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_110">[110]</a><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_48">[Pg 48]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He did not kisse that ladyes mouthe,<a id="FNanchor_111"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_111">[111]</a> <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor when he came, nor youd:<a id="FNanchor_112"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_112">[112]</a><a id="FNanchor_113"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_113">[113]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And sore mistrusted that ladye gay,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He was of some churls bloud.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But home then came that lither ladd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And did off his hose and shoone;                                  <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And cast the coller from off his necke:<a id="FNanchor_114"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_114">[114]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">He was but a churlès sonne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Awake, awake, my deere master,<a id="FNanchor_115"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_115">[115]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">[The cock hath well-nigh crowen.<a id="FNanchor_116"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_116">[116]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Awake, awake, my master deere,]<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_116">[116]</a> <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I hold it time to be gone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For I have saddled your horsse, mastèr,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Well bridled I have your steede:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I have served you a good breakfast:<a id="FNanchor_117"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_117">[117]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">For thereof ye have need.<a id="FNanchor_118"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_118">[118]</a> <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Up then rose, good Glasgeriòn,<a id="FNanchor_119"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_119">[119]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And did on hose and shoone;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And cast a coller about his necke:<br></span>
<span class="i2">For he was a kinge his sonne.<a id="FNanchor_120"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_120">[120]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he came to the ladyes chamber,<a id="FNanchor_121"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_121">[121]</a> <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He thrild upon the pinne:<a id="FNanchor_122"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_122">[122]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">The ladye was more than true of promise,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And rose and let him in.<a id="FNanchor_123"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_123">[123]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Saies, whether have you left with me<br></span>
<span class="i2">Your bracelett or your glove?                                     <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or are you returned backe againe<a id="FNanchor_124"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_124">[124]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">To know more of my love?<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_49">[Pg 49]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Glasgèrion swore a full great othe<br></span>
<span class="i2">By oake, and ashe, and thorne;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lady, I was never in your chambèr.                                  <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Sith the time that I was borne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O then it was your lither foot-page,<a id="FNanchor_125"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_125">[125]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">He hath beguiled mee.<a id="FNanchor_126"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_126">[126]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then shee pulled forth a little pen-kniffe,<a id="FNanchor_127"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_127">[127]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That hanged by her knee:                                          <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sayes, there shall never noe churlès blood<br></span>
<span class="i2">Within my bodye spring:<a id="FNanchor_128"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_128">[128]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">[No churlès blood shall ever defile<a id="FNanchor_129"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_129">[129]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">The daughter of a kinge.]<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_129">[129]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Home then went Glasgèrion,<a id="FNanchor_130"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_130">[130]</a> <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And woe, good lord, was hee.<a id="FNanchor_131"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_131">[131]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sayes, come thou hither, Jacke my boy,<a id="FNanchor_132"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_132">[132]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Come hither unto mee.<a id="FNanchor_133"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_133">[133]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If I had killed a man to night,<a id="FNanchor_134"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_134">[134]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Jacke, I would tell it thee:                                      <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But if I have not killed a man to night<br></span>
<span class="i2">Jacke, thou hast killed three.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he puld out his bright browne sword,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And dryed it on his sleeve,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he smote off that lither ladds head,                            <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who did his ladye grieve.<a id="FNanchor_135"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_135">[135]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He sett the swords poynt till his brest,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The pummil untill a stone:<a id="FNanchor_136"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_136">[136]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Throw the falsenesse of that lither ladd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">These three lives werne all gone.                                <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_50">[Pg 50]</a></span></p><div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>

<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">
