<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_102"></a><a href="#FNanchor_102" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[102]</span></a> [V. 16. my hart I durst neere breake.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_103"></a><a href="#FNanchor_103" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[103]</span></a> [V. 21. but whom then.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_104"></a><a href="#FNanchor_104" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[104]</span></a> [V. 24. her love is granted mee.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_105"></a><a href="#FNanchor_105" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[105]</span></a> [Ver. 29. but come you hither Master, quoth he.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_106"></a><a href="#FNanchor_106" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[106]</span></a> [wicked.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_107"></a><a href="#FNanchor_107" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[107]</span></a> [V. 34. and did on hose and shoone.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_108"></a><a href="#FNanchor_108" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[108]</span></a> This is elsewhere expressed "<i>twirled the pin</i>," or "<i>tirled at</i>
<i>the pin</i>" (see b. ii. s. vi. v. 3.) and seems to refer to the turning
round the button on the outside of a door, by which the latch
rises, still used in cottages.
</p>
<p>
[The explanation given by Percy in this note is an unfounded
guess. The Risp or tirling pin was very generally used in the
north to do the duty afterwards performed by the knocker. There
are several of these curious contrivances in the Antiquarian
Museum at Edinburgh, and they are described by D. Wilson in
his <i>Memorials of Edinburgh in the Olden Time</i>, as follows,—"These
antique precursors of the knocker and bell are still frequently
to be met with in the steep turnpikes of the Old Town,
notwithstanding the cupidity of the Antiquarian collectors. The
ring is drawn up and down the notched iron rod and makes a very
audible noise within." (1848, vol. i. p. 97).]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_109"></a><a href="#FNanchor_109" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[109]</span></a> [V. 42. nor noe bed.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_110"></a><a href="#FNanchor_110" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[110]</span></a> [V. 43-4.
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">but downe upon her chamber flore<br></span>
<span class="i0">full soone he hath her layd.]<br></span>
</div></div>
</div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_111"></a><a href="#FNanchor_111" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[111]</span></a> [Ver. 45. that lady gay.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_112"></a><a href="#FNanchor_112" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[112]</span></a> [went.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_113"></a><a href="#FNanchor_113" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[113]</span></a> [Ver. 46. when he came nor when he youd.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_114"></a><a href="#FNanchor_114" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[114]</span></a> [V. 51. that coller from about.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_115"></a><a href="#FNanchor_115" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[115]</span></a> [V. 53. awaken quoth hee my master deere.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_116"></a><a href="#FNanchor_116" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[116]</span></a> [V. 54-5. not in MS.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_117"></a><a href="#FNanchor_117" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[117]</span></a> [V. 59. have not I served a.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_118"></a><a href="#FNanchor_118" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[118]</span></a> [V. 60. when times comes I have need.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_119"></a><a href="#FNanchor_119" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[119]</span></a> [V. 61. but up.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_120"></a><a href="#FNanchor_120" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[120]</span></a> [V. 64. he was a kinges sonne.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_121"></a><a href="#FNanchor_121" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[121]</span></a> [V. 65. that ladies.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_122"></a><a href="#FNanchor_122" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[122]</span></a> [V. 66. upon a.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_123"></a><a href="#FNanchor_123" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[123]</span></a> [V. 68. rose up and.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_124"></a><a href="#FNanchor_124" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[124]</span></a> [V. 71. you are. MS]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_125"></a><a href="#FNanchor_125" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[125]</span></a> Ver. 77. litle, MS.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_126"></a><a href="#FNanchor_126" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[126]</span></a> [V. 78. falsly hath.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_127"></a><a href="#FNanchor_127" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[127]</span></a> [V. 79. and then.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_128"></a><a href="#FNanchor_128" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[128]</span></a> [V. 82. spring within my body.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_129"></a><a href="#FNanchor_129" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[129]</span></a> [V. 83-4. not in MS.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_130"></a><a href="#FNanchor_130" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[130]</span></a> [V. 85. but home then.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_131"></a><a href="#FNanchor_131" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[131]</span></a> [V. 86. a woe man good was hee.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_132"></a><a href="#FNanchor_132" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[132]</span></a> [V. 87. come hither thou.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_133"></a><a href="#FNanchor_133" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[133]</span></a> [V. 88. come thou.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_134"></a><a href="#FNanchor_134" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[134]</span></a> [V. 89. ffor if.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_135"></a><a href="#FNanchor_135" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[135]</span></a> [V. 96. and asked noe man noe leave.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_136"></a><a href="#FNanchor_136" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[136]</span></a> [V. 98. till a. MS.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>VIII.<br>

OLD ROBIN OF PORTINGALE.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i050f.png" id="img_images_i050f.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">From</span> an ancient copy in the Editor's folio MS. which
was judged to require considerable corrections.</p>
<p>In the former edition the hero of this piece had been
called Sir Robin, but that title not being in the MS. is
now omitted.</p>
<p><i>Giles</i>, steward to a rich old merchant trading to <i>Portugal</i>, is
qualified with the title of <i>Sir</i>, not as being a knight, but rather,
I conceive, as having received an inferior order of priesthood.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Percy's note in the MS. is as follows, "When I first set to
examine this I had not yet learnt to hold this old MS. in much
regard." Every line is altered, so that it has been necessary to add
a copy of the original, although the interest of the ballad itself is
not very great. Percy's most notable correction is the introduction
of 20 good knights to help Robin against his wife's twenty-four
traitors.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i050l.png" id="img_images_i050l.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Let never again soe old a man<br></span>
<span class="i2">Marrye soe yonge a wife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As did old Robin of Portingale;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who may rue all the dayes of his life.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For the mayors daughter of Lin, god wott,                            <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He chose her to his wife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thought with her to have lived in love,<br></span>
<span class="i2">By they fell to hate and strife.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">They scarce were in their wed-bed laid,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And scarce was hee asleepe,                                       <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But upp shee rose, and forth shee goes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To the steward, and gan to weepe.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_51">[Pg 51]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sleepe you, wake you, faire sir Gyles?<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or be you not within?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sleepe you, wake you, faire sir Gyles,                              <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Arise and let me inn.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O, I am waking, sweete, he said,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sweete ladye, what is your will?<br></span>
<span class="i0">I have unbethought me of a wile<a id="FNanchor_137"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_137">[137]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">How my wed-lord weell spill.<a id="FNanchor_138"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_138">[138]</a> <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Twenty-four good knights, shee sayes.<br></span>
<span class="i2">That dwell about this towne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Even twenty-four of my next cozèns,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Will helpe to dinge<a id="FNanchor_139"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_139">[139]</a> him downe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All that beheard his litle footepage,                               <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">As he watered his masters steed;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for his masters sad perille<br></span>
<span class="i2">His verry heart did bleed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He mourned still, and wept full sore;<br></span>
<span class="i2">I sweare by the holy roode                                        <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The teares he for his master wept<br></span>
<span class="i2">Were blent water and bloude.<a id="FNanchor_140"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_140">[140]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And that beheard his deare mastèr<br></span>
<span class="i2">As he stood at his garden pale:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sayes, Ever alacke, my litle foot-page,                             <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">What causes thee to wail?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hath any one done to thee wronge<br></span>
<span class="i2">Any of thy fellowes here?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or is any of thy good friends dead,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That thou shedst manye a teare?                                   <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_52">[Pg 52]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Or, if it be my head bookes-man,<a id="FNanchor_141"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_141">[141]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Aggrieved he shal bee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For no man here within my howse,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shall doe wrong unto thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O, it is not your head bookes-man,                                  <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor none of his degree:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But, on to-morrow ere it be noone<a id="FNanchor_142"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_142">[142]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">All deemed<a id="FNanchor_143"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_143">[143]</a> to die are yee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And of that bethank your head stewàrd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And thank your gay ladie.                                         <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If this be true, my litle foot-page,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The heyre of my land thoust bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If it be not true, my dear mastèr,<br></span>
<span class="i2">No good death let me die.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If it be not true, thou litle foot-page,                            <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">A dead corse shalt thou lie.<a id="FNanchor_144"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_144">[144]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O call now downe my faire ladye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">O call her downe to mee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tell my ladye gay how sicke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And like to die I bee.                                            <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Downe then came his ladye faire,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All clad in purple and pall:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The rings that were on her fingèrs,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Cast light thorrow the hall.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What is your will, my owne wed-lord?                                <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">What is your will with mee?<br></span>
<span class="i0">O see, my ladye deere, how sicke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And like to die I bee.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_53">[Pg 53]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And thou be sicke, my own wed-lord,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Soe sore it grieveth me:                                          <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But my five maydens and myselfe<br></span>
<span class="i2">Will "watch thy" bedde for thee:<a id="FNanchor_145"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_145">[145]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And at the waking of your first sleepe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">We will a hott drinke make:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And at the waking of your "next" sleepe,<a id="FNanchor_146"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_146">[146]</a> <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Your sorrowes we will slake.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He put a silk cote on his backe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And mail of manye a fold:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hee putt a steele cap on his head,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was gilt with good red gold.                                      <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He layd a bright browne sword by his side,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And another att his feete:<br></span>
<span class="i0">"And twentye good knights he placed at hand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To watch him in his sleepe."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And about the middle time of the night,                             <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Came twentye-four traitours inn:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Giles he was the foremost man,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The leader of that ginn.<a id="FNanchor_147"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_147">[147]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Old Robin with his bright browne sword,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sir Gyles head soon did winn:                                     <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And scant of all those twenty-four,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Went out one quick<a id="FNanchor_148"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_148">[148]</a> agenn.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">None save only a litle foot page,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Crept forth at a window of stone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he had two armes when he came in,                               <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And he went back with one.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_54">[Pg 54]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Upp then came that ladie gaye<br></span>
<span class="i2">With torches burning bright:<br></span>
<span class="i0">She thought to have brought sir Gyles a drinke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Butt she found her owne wedd knight.                             <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The first thinge that she stumbled on<br></span>
<span class="i2">It was sir Gyles his foote:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sayes, Ever alacke, and woe is mee!<br></span>
<span class="i2">Here lyes my sweete hart-roote.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The next thinge that she stumbled on                               <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">It was sir Gyles his heade;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sayes, Ever, alacke, and woe is me!<br></span>
<span class="i2">Heere lyes my true love deade.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hee cutt the pappes beside her brest,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And did her body spille;<a id="FNanchor_149"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_149">[149]</a> <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He cutt the eares beside her heade,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And bade her love her fille.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He called then up his litle foot-page,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And made him there his heyre;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sayd henceforth my worldlye goodes                             <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And countrye I forsweare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He shope<a id="FNanchor_150"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_150">[150]</a> the crosse on his right shouldèr,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of the white "clothe" and the redde,<a id="FNanchor_151"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_151">[151]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And went him into the holy land,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Wheras Christ was quicke and dead.                               <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_55">[Pg 55]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i055.png" id="img_images_i055.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capm"><span class="smcap">[The</span> following is the original ballad from the Folio MS.
ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. i. p. 235.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">God! let neuer soe old a man<br></span>
<span class="i0">marry so yonge a wiffe<br></span>
<span class="i0">as did old Robin of portingale!<br></span>
<span class="i0">he may rue all the dayes of his liffe.                               <span class="linenum">4</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">ffor the Maiors daughter of Lin, god wott,<br></span>
<span class="i0">he chose her to his wife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; thought to haue liued in quiettnesse<br></span>
<span class="i0">with her all the dayes of his liffe.                                 <span class="linenum">8</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">they had not in their wed bed laid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">scarcly were both on sleepe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">but vpp shee rose, &amp; forth shee goes<br></span>
<span class="i0">to Sir Gyles, &amp; fast can weepe,                                     <span class="linenum">12</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Saies, "sleepe you, wake you, faire Sir Gyles,<br></span>
<span class="i0">or be not you within?"<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"but I am waking, sweete," he said,<br></span>
<span class="i0">"Lady, what is your will?"                                          <span class="linenum">16</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"I haue vnbethought me of a will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">how my wed Lord we shall spill.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"24 knights, she sayes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">that dwells about this towne,                                       <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">eene 24 of my Next Cozens,<br></span>
<span class="i0">will helpe to dinge him downe."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">with that beheard his litle foote page<br></span>
<span class="i0">as he was watering his Masters steed,                               <span class="linenum">24</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Soe s * * * *<br></span>
<span class="i0">his verry heart did bleed;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">he mourned, sist, and wept full sore;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I sweare by the holy roode,                                         <span class="linenum">28</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">the teares he for his Master wept<br></span>
<span class="i0">were blend water &amp; bloude.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">with that beheard his deare Master<br></span>
<span class="i0">as in his garden sate,                                              <span class="linenum">32</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">says, "euer alacke my litle page!<br></span>
<span class="i0">what causes thee to weepe?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"hath any one done to thee wronge,<br></span>
<span class="i0">any of thy fellowes here,                                           <span class="linenum">36</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">or is any of thy good friends dead<br></span>
<span class="i0">which makes thee shed such teares?<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_56">[Pg 56]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"or if it be my head bookes man,<br></span>
<span class="i0">grieued againe he shalbe,                                           <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">nor noe man within my howse<br></span>
<span class="i0">shall doe wrong vnto thee."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"but it is not your head bookes man,<br></span>
<span class="i0">nor none of his degree,                                             <span class="linenum">44</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">but or to morrow, ere it be Noone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">you are deemed to die;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; of that thanke your head Steward,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; after your gay Ladie."                                            <span class="linenum">48</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"If it be true, my little foote page,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ile make thee heyre of all my land."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"if it be not true, my deare Master,<br></span>
<span class="i0">god let me neuer dye."                                              <span class="linenum">52</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"if it be not true, thou little foot page,<br></span>
<span class="i0">a dead corse shalt thou be."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">he called downe his head kookes man,<br></span>
<span class="i0">cooke in kitchen super to dresse:                                   <span class="linenum">56</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"all &amp; anon, my deare Master,<br></span>
<span class="i0">anon at your request."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; call you downe my faire Lady,<br></span>
<span class="i0">this night to supp with mee."                                       <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; downe then came that fayre Lady,<br></span>
<span class="i0">was cladd all in purple &amp; palle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">the rings that were vpon her fingers<br></span>
<span class="i0">cast light thorrow the hall.                                        <span class="linenum">64</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"What is your will, my owne wed Lord,<br></span>
<span class="i0">what is your will with mee?"<br></span>
<span class="i0">"I am sicke, fayre Lady,<br></span>
<span class="i0">sore sicke, &amp; like to dye."                                         <span class="linenum">68</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"but &amp; you be sicke, my owne wed Lord,<br></span>
<span class="i0">soe sore it greiueth mee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">but my 5 maydens &amp; my selfe<br></span>
<span class="i0">will goe &amp; make your bedd,                                          <span class="linenum">72</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; at the wakening of your first sleepe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">you shall haue a hott drinke Made,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; at the wakening of your first sleepe<br></span>
<span class="i0">your sorrowes will haue a slake."                                   <span class="linenum">76</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_57">[Pg 57]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">he put a silke cote on his backe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">was 13 inches folde,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; put a steele cap vpon his head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">was gilded with good red gold;                                      <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; he layd a bright browne sword by his side,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; another att his ffeete,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; full well knew old Robin then<br></span>
<span class="i0">whether he shold wake or sleepe.                                    <span class="linenum">84</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; about the Middle time of the Night<br></span>
<span class="i0">came 24 good knights in,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Syr Gyles he was the formost man,<br></span>
<span class="i0">soe well he knew that ginne.                                        <span class="linenum">88</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Old Robin with a bright browne sword<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Gyles head he did winne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">soe did he all those 24,<br></span>
<span class="i0">neuer a one went quicke out [agen;]                                 <span class="linenum">92</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">none but one litle foot page<br></span>
<span class="i0">crept forth at a window of stone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; he had 2 armes when he came in<br></span>
<span class="i0">And [when he went out he had none].                                 <span class="linenum">96</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Vpp then came that Ladie bright<br></span>
<span class="i0">with torches burning light;<br></span>
<span class="i0">shee thought to haue brought Sir Gyles a drinke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">but shee found her owne wedd Knight,                               <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; the first thinge that this Ladye stumbled vpon,<br></span>
<span class="i0">was of Sir Gyles his ffoote,<br></span>
<span class="i0">sayes, "euer alacke, and woe is me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">heere lyes my sweete hart roote!"                                  <span class="linenum">104</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; the 2<sup>d</sup> thing that this Ladie stumbled on,<br></span>
<span class="i0">was of Sir Gyles his head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">sayes, "euer alacke, and woe is me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">heere lyes my true loue deade!"                                    <span class="linenum">108</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">hee cutt the papps beside he[r] brest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; bad her wish her will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; he cutt the eares beside her heade,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; bade her wish on still.                                          <span class="linenum">112</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Mickle is the mans blood I haue spent<br></span>
<span class="i0">to doe thee &amp; me some good,"<br></span>
<span class="i0">sayes, "euer alacke, my fayre Lady,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I thinke that I was woode?"                                        <span class="linenum">116</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_58">[Pg 58]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">he calld then vp his litle foote page,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; made him heyre of all his land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; he shope the crosse in his right sholder<br></span>
<span class="i0">of the white flesh &amp; the redd.                                     <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; he sent him into the holy land<br></span>
<span class="i0">wheras Christ was quicke &amp; dead.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">ffins.]</p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_137"></a><a href="#FNanchor_137" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[137]</span></a> Ver. 19. <i>unbethought</i>, (properly <i>onbethought</i>) this word is still
used in the Midland counties in the same sense as <i>bethought</i>.</p></div>

<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_150"></a><a href="#FNanchor_150" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[150]</span></a> [shaped.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_151"></a><a href="#FNanchor_151" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[151]</span></a> Every person who went on a <i>Croisade</i> to the Holy Land,
usually wore a cross on his upper garment, on the right shoulder,
as a badge of his profession. Different nations were distinguished
by crosses of different colours: The English wore white; the
French red; &amp;c. This circumstance seems to be confounded in
the ballad. (V. Spelman, <i>Gloss</i>.)</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>IX.<br>

CHILD WATERS.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i058.png" id="img_images_i058.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap"><i>Child</i></span> is frequently used by our old writers, as a Title.
It is repeatedly given to Prince Arthur in the Fairie
Queen: and the son of a king is in the same poem
called "Child Tristram." (B. 5. c. 11. st. 8. 13.—B. 6.
c. 2. st. 36.—<i>Ibid.</i> c. 8. st. 15.) In an old ballad quoted in
Shakespeare's <i>K. Lear</i>, the hero of Ariosto is called <i>Child Roland</i>.
Mr. Theobald supposes this use of the word was received along
with their romances from the Spaniards, with whom <i>Infante</i> signifies
a "Prince." A more eminent critic tells us, that "in the old
times of chivalry, the noble youth, who were candidates for knighthood,
during the time of their probation were called <i>Infans</i>, <i>Varlets</i>,
<i>Damoysels</i>, <i>Bacheliers</i>. The most noble of the youth were
particularly called <i>Infans</i>." (Vid. Warb. Shakesp.) A late commentator
on Spenser observes, that the Saxon word cniht, knight,
signifies also a "child." (See Upton's gloss to the F. Q.)</p>
<p>The Editor's folio MS. whence the following piece is taken (with
some corrections), affords several other ballads, wherein the word
<i>Child</i> occurs as a title: but in none of these it signifies "Prince."
See the song intitled <i>Gil Morrice</i>, in this volume.</p>
<p>It ought to be observed, that the Word <i>Child</i> or <i>Chield</i> is still
used in North Britain to denominate a Man, commonly with some
contemptuous character affixed to him, but sometimes to denote
Man in general.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This ballad gives us a curious insight into ancient manners,
and shows what were our forefathers' notions of the perfection of
female character. They would have agreed with the propounder
of the question—What is woman's mission? answer, sub-mission.
Like patient Grissel, Ellen bears worse sufferings than the Nut-Brown
Maid has to hear of, and in spite of the worst usage she<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_59">[Pg 59]</a></span>
never swerves from her devotion. This English version was the
first published, but the story is the same as <i>Lai le Frêne</i>, preserved
in English in the Auchinleck MS. and in Norman in the <i>Lais</i> of
Marie, which were written about the year 1250.</p>
<p>Jamieson (<i>Popular Ballads and Songs</i>, 1806, vol. i. p. 113) published
his Scottish version under the more appropriate name of
<i>Burd Ellen</i>, who is the real heroine rather than the ruffian Waters
is the hero. Adopting the idea of Mrs. Hampden Pye, who wrote
a ballad on the same subject, he changes the character of the
catastrophe by adding three concluding stanzas to wind up the
story in an unhappy manner. Another version of the ballad, which
ends happily, is given in Kinloch's <i>Ancient Scottish Ballads</i> under
the title of Lady Margaret. A German version of this ballad was
made by the poet Bürger.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i059.png" id="img_images_i059.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Childe Waters in his stable stoode<br></span>
<span class="i2">And stroakt his milke white steede<br></span>
<span class="i0">To him a fayre yonge ladye came<a id="FNanchor_152"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_152">[152]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">As ever ware womans weede.<a id="FNanchor_153"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_153">[153]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sayes, Christ you save, good Childe Waters;                          <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Sayes, Christ you save, and see:<br></span>
<span class="i0">My girdle of gold that was too longe,<a id="FNanchor_154"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_154">[154]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Is now too short for mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And all is with one chyld of yours,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I feele sturre att my side;                                       <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">My gowne of greene it is too straighte;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Before, it was too wide.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If the child be mine, faire Ellen, he sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be mine as you tell mee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then take you Cheshire and Lancashire both,<a id="FNanchor_155"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_155">[155]</a> <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Take them your owne to bee.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_60">[Pg 60]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If the childe be mine, faire Ellen, he sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Be mine, as you doe sweare:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then take you Cheshire and Lancashire both,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And make that child your heyre.                                   <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee saies, I had rather have one kisse,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Child Waters, of thy mouth;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than I wolde have Cheshire and Lancashire both,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That lye by north and south.<a id="FNanchor_156"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_156">[156]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And I had rather have one twinkling,<a id="FNanchor_157"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_157">[157]</a> <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Childe Waters, of thine ee:<a id="FNanchor_158"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_158">[158]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then I wolde have Cheshire and Lancashire both<br></span>
<span class="i2">To take them mine owne to bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To morrow, Ellen, I must forth ryde<br></span>
<span class="i2">Farr into the north countrie;<a id="FNanchor_159"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_159">[159]</a> <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The fairest lady that I can find,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ellen, must goe with mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[Thoughe I am not that lady fayre,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet let me go with thee.]<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ever I pray you, Child Watèrs,                                  <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Your foot-page let me bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If you will my foot-page be, Ellèn,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As you doe tell to mee;<a id="FNanchor_160"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_160">[160]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then you must cut your gowne of greene,<br></span>
<span class="i2">An inch above your knee:                                          <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Soe must you doe your yellowe lockes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">An inch above your ee:<a id="FNanchor_161"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_161">[161]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">You must tell no man what is my name;<br></span>
<span class="i2">My foot-page then you shall bee.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_61">[Pg 61]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee, all the long day Child Waters rode,<a id="FNanchor_162"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_162">[162]</a> <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Ran barefoote by his side;<a id="FNanchor_163"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_163">[163]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yett was he never so courteous a knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To say, Ellen, will you ryde?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee, all the long day Child Waters rode,<a id="FNanchor_164"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_164">[164]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Ran barefoote thorow the broome;<a id="FNanchor_165"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_165">[165]</a> <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yett hee was never soe curteous a knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To say, put on your shoone.<a id="FNanchor_166"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_166">[166]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ride softlye, shee sayd, O Childe Waters,<a id="FNanchor_167"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_167">[167]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Why doe you ryde soe fast?<br></span>
<span class="i0">The childe, which is no mans but thine,<a id="FNanchor_168"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_168">[168]</a> <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My bodye itt will brast.<a id="FNanchor_169"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_169">[169]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hee sayth, seest thou yonder water, Ellen,<a id="FNanchor_170"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_170">[170]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That flows from banke to brimme.—<br></span>
<span class="i0">I trust to God, O Child Waters,<a id="FNanchor_171"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_171">[171]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">You never will see<a id="FNanchor_172"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_172">[172]</a> mee swimme.                               <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But when shee came to the waters side,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shee sayled to the chinne:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Except the Lord of heaven be my speed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Now must I learne to swimme.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The salt waters bare up her clothes;<a id="FNanchor_173"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_173">[173]</a> <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Our Ladye bare upp her chinne:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Childe Waters was a woe man, good Lord,<a id="FNanchor_174"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_174">[174]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">To see faire Ellen swimme.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when shee over the water was,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shee then came to his knee:                                       <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He said, Come hither, thou faire Ellèn,<a id="FNanchor_175"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_175">[175]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Loe yonder what I see.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_62">[Pg 62]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Seest thou not yonder hall, Ellèn?<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of redd gold shines the yate:<a id="FNanchor_176"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_176">[176]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of twenty foure faire ladyes there,<a id="FNanchor_177"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_177">[177]</a> <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The fairest is my mate.<a id="FNanchor_178"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_178">[178]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Seest thou not yonder hall, Ellèn?<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of redd gold shines the towre:<a id="FNanchor_179"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_179">[179]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">There are twenty four faire ladyes there,<a id="FNanchor_180"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_180">[180]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">The fairest is my paramoure.                                      <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I see the hall now, Child Waters,<a id="FNanchor_181"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_181">[181]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of redd gold shines the yate:<a id="FNanchor_182"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_182">[182]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">God give you good now of yourselfe,<a id="FNanchor_183"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_183">[183]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And of your worthye mate.<a id="FNanchor_184"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_184">[184]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I see the hall now, Child Waters,<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_181">[181]</a> <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of redd golde shines the towre:<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_182">[182]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">God give you good now of yourselfe,<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_183">[183]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And of your paramoure.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There twenty four fayre ladyes were<a id="FNanchor_185"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_185">[185]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">A playing att the ball:<a id="FNanchor_186"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_186">[186]</a> <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Ellen the fairest ladye there,<a id="FNanchor_187"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_187">[187]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Must bring his steed to the stall.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There twenty four fayre ladyes were<a id="FNanchor_188"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_188">[188]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">A playinge at the chesse;<a id="FNanchor_189"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_189">[189]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And Ellen the fayrest ladye there,<a id="FNanchor_190"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_190">[190]</a> <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Must bring his horse to gresse.<a id="FNanchor_191"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_191">[191]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And then bespake Childe Waters sister,<br></span>
<span class="i2">These were the wordes said shee:<a id="FNanchor_192"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_192">[192]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">You have the prettyest foot-page, brother,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That ever I saw with mine ee.<a id="FNanchor_193"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_193">[193]</a> <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_63">[Pg 63]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But that his bellye it is soe bigg,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His girdle goes wonderous hie:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And let him, I pray you, Childe Watèrs,<a id="FNanchor_194"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_194">[194]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Goe into the chamber with mee.<a id="FNanchor_195"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_195">[195]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[It is not fit for a little foot-page,                             <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That has run throughe mosse and myre,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To go into the chamber with any ladye.<br></span>
<span class="i2">That weares soe riche attyre.]<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It is more meete for a litle foot-page,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That has run throughe mosse and myre.                            <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To take his supper upon his knee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And sitt downe by the kitchen fyer.<a id="FNanchor_196"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_196">[196]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But when they had supped every one,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To bedd they tooke theyr waye:<a id="FNanchor_197"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_197">[197]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">He sayd, come hither, my little foot-page,                         <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And hearken what I saye.<a id="FNanchor_198"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_198">[198]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Goe thee downe into yonder towne,<a id="FNanchor_199"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_199">[199]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And low into the street;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fayrest ladye that thou can finde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Hyer her in mine armes to sleepe,                                <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And take her up in thine armes twaine,<a id="FNanchor_200"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_200">[200]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">For filinge<a id="FNanchor_201"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_201">[201]</a> of her feete.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ellen is gone into the towne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And low into the streete:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fairest ladye that shee cold find,                             <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Shee hyred in his armes to sleepe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tooke her up in her armes twayne,<a id="FNanchor_202"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_202">[202]</a><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_64">[Pg 64]</a></span>
<span class="i2">For filing of her feete.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I praye you nowe, good Childe Watèrs,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Let mee lye at your bedds feete:<a id="FNanchor_203"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_203">[203]</a> <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For there is noe place about this house,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where I may 'saye a slepe<a id="FNanchor_204"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_204">[204]</a>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[He gave her leave, and faire Ellèn<br></span>
<span class="i2">Down at his beds feet laye:]<br></span>
<span class="i0">This done the nighte drove on apace,<a id="FNanchor_205"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_205">[205]</a> <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And when it was neare the daye,<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_205">[205]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hee sayd, Rise up, my litle foot-page,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Give my steede corne and haye;<a id="FNanchor_206"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_206">[206]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And soe doe thou the good black oats,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To carry mee better awaye.<a id="FNanchor_207"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_207">[207]</a> <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Up then rose the faire Ellèn<a id="FNanchor_208"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_208">[208]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And gave his steede corne and hay:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And soe shee did the good blacke oates,<a id="FNanchor_209"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_209">[209]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">To carry him the better away.<a id="FNanchor_210"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_210">[210]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee leaned her backe to the manger side,<a id="FNanchor_211"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_211">[211]</a> <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And grievouslye did groane:<br></span>
<span class="i0">[Shee leaned her back to the manger side,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And there shee made her moane.]<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And that beheard his mother deere,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shee heard her there monand.<a id="FNanchor_212"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_212">[212]</a> <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shee sayd, Rise up, thou Child Watèrs,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I think thee a cursed man.<a id="FNanchor_213"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_213">[213]</a><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_65">[Pg 65]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For in thy stable is a ghost,<a id="FNanchor_214"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_214">[214]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That grievouslye doth grone.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or else some woman laboures of childe,                             <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">She is soe woe-begone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Up then rose Childe Waters soon,<a id="FNanchor_215"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_215">[215]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And did on his shirte of silke;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And then he put on his other clothes,<a id="FNanchor_216"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_216">[216]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">On his body as white as milke.                                   <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he came to the stable dore,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Full still there hee did stand,<a id="FNanchor_217"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_217">[217]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">That hee mighte heare his fayre Ellèn,<a id="FNanchor_218"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_218">[218]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Howe shee made her monànd<a id="FNanchor_219"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_219">[219]</a>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She sayd, Lullabye, mine owne deere child,<a id="FNanchor_220"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_220">[220]</a> <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Lullabye, dere child, dere:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I wold thy father were a king,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy mother layd on a biere.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Peace now, hee said, good faire Ellèn.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Be of good cheere, I praye;<a id="FNanchor_221"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_221">[221]</a> <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the bridal and the churching both<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shall bee upon one day.<a id="FNanchor_222"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_222">[222]</a><br></span>
</div></div>

<p><a id="Footnote_221"></a><a href="#FNanchor_221" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[221]</span></a> [V. 170. and be of good cheere I thee pray.]</p></div>

<p><a id="Footnote_222"></a><a href="#FNanchor_222" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[222]</span></a> [V. 172. they shall, MS.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>X.<br>

PHILLIDA AND CORYDON.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i066.png" id="img_images_i066.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> Sonnet is given from a small quarto MS. in the
Editor's possession, written in the time of Q. Elizabeth.
Another Copy of it containing some variations, is reprinted
in the <i>Muses' Library</i>, p. 295, from an ancient
miscellany, intitled <i>England's Helicon</i>, 1600, 4to. The author was
<i>Nicholas Breton</i>, a writer of some fame in the reign of Elizabeth;
who also published an interlude intitled <i>An old man's lesson and</i>
<i>a young man's love</i>, 4to., and many other little pieces in prose and
verse, the titles of which may be seen in Winstanley, Ames' <i>Typog.</i>
and Osborne's <i>Harl. Catalog.</i> &amp;c.—He is mentioned with great
respect by <i>Meres</i>, in his 2d pt. of <i>Wit's Common-wealth</i>, 1598,
f. 283, and is alluded to in Beaumont and Fletcher's <i>Scornful Lady</i>,
act ii., and again in <i>Wit without Money</i>, act iii.—See Whalley's
<i>Ben Jonson</i>, vol. iii. p. 103.</p>
<p>The present Edition is improved by a copy in <i>England's Helicon</i>,
edit. 1614, 8vo.</p>
<p>This little Pastoral is one of the Songs in "The Honourable
Entertainment gieven to the Queenes Majestie in Progresse at
Elvetham in Hampshire, by the R. H. the Earle of Hertford,
1591, 4to." (Printed by Wolfe. No name of author.) See in
that pamphlet,</p>
<p class="center">"The thirde daies Entertainment.
</p>
<p>"On Wednesday morning about 9 o'clock, as her Majestie
opened a casement of her gallerie window, ther were 3 excellent
musitians, who being disguised in auncient country attire, did
greet her with a pleasant song of <i>Corydon and Phillida</i>, made in
3 parts of purpose. The song, as well for the worth of the dittie
as the aptnesse of the note thereto applied, it pleased her Highnesse
after it had been once sung to command it againe, and
highly to grace it with her cheerefull acceptance and commendation.</p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">The Plowman's Song.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0"><i>In the merrie month of May, &amp;c."</i><br></span>
</div></div>
<p>The splendour and magnificence of Elizabeth's reign is nowhere
more strongly painted than in these little diaries of some of her
summer excursions to the houses of her nobility; nor could a<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_67">[Pg 67]</a></span>
more acceptable present be given to the world, than a republication
of a select number of such details as this of the entertainment at
<i>Elvetham</i>, that at <i>Killingworth</i>, &amp;c., &amp;c., which so strongly mark
the spirit of the times, and present us with scenes so very remote
from modern manners.</p>
<p>Since the above was written, the public hath been gratified with
a most compleat work on the foregoing subject, intitled, <i>The Progresses</i>
<i>and Public Processions of Queen Elizabeth, &amp;c. By John</i>
<i>Nichols, F.A.S., Edinb. and Perth</i>, 1788, 2 vols. 4to.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The author of this elegant little poem was a most voluminous
author, and "is supposed to be the same Capt. Nicholas Breton,
who was of Norton in Northamptonshire, and dying there June 22,
1624, has a monument in that church."<a id="FNanchor_223"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_223">[223]</a> Dr. Rimbault (<i>Musical</i>
<i>Illustrations of Percy's Reliques</i>) writes as follows of the music:—"We
have here two settings of this beautiful pastoral, the first as it
was sung by the 'three excellent musitians' before Queen Elizabeth
in 1591; the second as it was reset in the following century. The
first is extracted from <i>Madrigals to 3, 4, and 5 parts, apt for viols</i>
<i>and voices</i>, newly composed by Michael Este, 1604; the second
from <i>Cheerfull Ayres or Ballads, set for three voyces</i>, by Dr. John
Wilson, Oxford, 1660. The latter became extremely popular, and
is included in D'Urfey's <i>Pills to Purge Melancholy</i>, 1719, and
several other musical miscellanies of subsequent date."]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i067.png" id="img_images_i067.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In the merrie moneth of Maye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In a morne by break of daye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With a troope of damselles playing<br></span>
<span class="i0">Forthe "I yode" forsooth a maying:<a id="FNanchor_224"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_224">[224]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When anon by a wood side,                                            <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where as Maye was in his pride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I espied all alone<br></span>
<span class="i0">Phillida and Corydon.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Much adoe there was, god wot;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He wold love, and she wold not.                                     <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She sayde, never man was trewe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He sayes, none was false to you.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_68">[Pg 68]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He sayde, hee had lovde her longe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">She sayes, love should have no wronge.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Corydon wold kisse her then:                                        <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She sayes, maydes must kisse no men,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Tyll they doe for good and all.<br></span>
<span class="i0">When she made the shepperde call<br></span>
<span class="i0">All the heavens to wytnes truthe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Never loved a truer youthe.                                         <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then with manie a prettie othe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea and nay, and, faith and trothe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Suche as seelie shepperdes use<br></span>
<span class="i0">When they will not love abuse;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Love, that had bene long deluded,                                   <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Was with kisses sweete concluded;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Phillida with garlands gaye<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was made the lady of the Maye.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_223"></a><a href="#FNanchor_223" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[223]</span></a> [England's <i>Helicon</i> (Brydges' <i>British Bibliographer</i>, vol. iii.)]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_224"></a><a href="#FNanchor_224" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[224]</span></a> Ver. 4. the wode, MS.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XI.<br>

LITTLE MUSGRAVE AND LADY BARNARD.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i068.png" id="img_images_i068.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> ballad is ancient, and has been popular; we find it
quoted in many old plays. See Beaum. and Fletcher's
<i>Knight of the Burning Pestle</i>, 4to. 1613, act v. sc. iii.
<i>The Varietie, a comedy</i>, 12mo. 1649, act iv. &amp;c. In Sir
William Davenant's play, <i>The Witts</i>, a. iii. a gallant thus boasts of
himself:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Limber and sound! besides I sing Musgrave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for Chevy-chace no lark comes near me."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>In the Pepys <i>Collection</i>, vol. iii. p. 314, is an imitation of this
old song, in 33 stanzas, by a more modern pen, with many alterations,
but evidently for the worse.</p>
<p>This is given from an old printed copy in the British Museum,<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_69">[Pg 69]</a></span>
with corrections; some of which are from a fragment in the Editor's
folio MS. It is also printed in Dryden's <i>Collection of Miscellaneous</i>
<i>Poems</i>.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The copy of this ballad in the Folio MS. (ed. Hales and Furnivall,
vol. i. p. 119) is a mutilated fragment consisting of only ten complete
stanzas and three half ones. The oldest entire copy is to be found
in <i>Wit Restor'd</i>, 1658, where it is called <i>the</i> old <i>ballad of little</i>
<i>Musgrave</i>, which is given by Professor Child (<i>English and Scottish</i>
<i>Ballads</i>, vol. ii. p. 15) in preference to Percy's. This version, not
very exactly transcribed, is printed in Dryden's <i>Miscellany Poems</i>
(1716, vol. iii. 312), and Ritson (<i>Ancient Songs and Ballads</i>, vol. ii.
p. 116) copied it from thence. Ritson writes of one of Percy's
statements above: "Dr. Percy indeed, by some mistake, gives it
as from an old printed copy in the British Museum; observing
that 'In the Pepys collection is an imitation of this old song in
a different measure, by a more modern pen, with many alterations,
but evidently for the worse.' It is very true, and not less so that
the only copies in the museum (for there are two) are more recent
impressions of this identical <i>imitation</i>."</p>
<p>It is the 14th stanza slightly altered which is quoted in the
<i>Knight of the Burning Pestle</i>.</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"And some they whistled, and some they sung,<br></span>
<span class="i18">Hey down down!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And some did loudly say<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ever as Lord Barnet's horn blew,<br></span>
<span class="i18">Away Musgrave, away."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>There are several Scottish versions, in which the reciters have
altered the locality. Jamieson has printed one which he calls
<i>Lord Barnaby</i> (<i>Popular Ballads and Songs</i>, i. 170). He states
that he had heard it repeated both in Morayshire and in the
southern counties.</p>
<p>Motherwell gives the air in his <i>Minstrelsy</i> which he noted down
from oral communication, and this verse—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"It fell upon a Martinmas time<br></span>
<span class="i2">When the nobles were a drinking wine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That little Mushiegrove to the kirk he did go<br></span>
<span class="i2">For to see the ladies come in."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>Mr. J. H. Dixon includes a version entitled <i>Lord Burnett and</i>
<i>Little Munsgrove</i> in his Scottish Traditional Versions of Ancient
Ballads (Percy Society, vol. xvii.)</p>
<p>Home adopted the name of Lady Barnard in his <i>Douglas</i> before
he took that of Lady Randolph, see No. 18, Gil Morrice.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_70">[Pg 70]</a></span></p>
<p>There is another ballad called <i>The Bonny Birdy</i>, with a similar
story. Jamieson (i. 162) prints it and alters the title to <i>Lord</i>
<i>Randal</i>.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i070.png" id="img_images_i070.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As it fell out on a highe holye daye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As many bee in the yeare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When yong men and maides together do goe<br></span>
<span class="i2">Their masses and mattins to heare,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Little Musgràve came to the church door,                             <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The priest was at the mass;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he had more mind of the fine womèn,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then he had of our Ladyes grace.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And some of them were clad in greene,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And others were clad in pall;                                     <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And then came in my lord Barnardes wife,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The fairest among them all.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee cast an eye on little Musgràve<br></span>
<span class="i2">As bright as the summer sunne:<br></span>
<span class="i0">O then bethought him little Musgràve,                               <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">This ladyes heart I have wonne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth she, I have loved thee, little Musgràve,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Fulle long and manye a daye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">So have I loved you, ladye faire,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet word I never durst saye.                                      <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I have a bower at Bucklesford-Bury,<a id="FNanchor_225"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_225">[225]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Full daintilye bedight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thoult wend thither, my little Musgràve,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thoust lig in mine armes all night.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_71">[Pg 71]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth hee, I thanke yee, ladye faire,                               <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">This kindness yee shew to mee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And whether it be to my weale or woe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">This night will I lig with thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All this beheard a litle foot-page,<br></span>
<span class="i2">By his ladyes coach as he ranne:                                  <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth he, thoughe I am my ladyes page,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet Ime my lord Barnardes manne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My lord Barnàrd shall knowe of this,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Although I lose a limbe.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ever whereas the bridges were broke,                            <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He layd him downe to swimme.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Asleep or awake, thou lord Barnàrd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As thou art a man of life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lo! this same night at Bucklesford-Bury<br></span>
<span class="i2">Litle Musgrave's in bed with thy wife.                            <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If it be trew, thou litle foote-page,<br></span>
<span class="i2">This tale thou hast told to mee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then all my lands in Bucklesford-Bury<br></span>
<span class="i2">I freelye will give to thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But and it be a lye, thou litle foot-page,                          <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">This tale thou hast told to mee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the highest tree in Bucklesford-Bury<br></span>
<span class="i2">All hanged shalt thou bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Rise up, rise up, my merry men all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And saddle me my good steede;                                     <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">This night must I to Bucklesford-bury;<br></span>
<span class="i2">God wott, I had never more neede.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then some they whistled, and some they sang,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And some did loudlye saye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whenever lord Barnardes horne it blewe,                             <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Awaye, Musgràve, away.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_72">[Pg 72]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Methinkes I heare the throstle cocke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Methinkes I heare the jay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinkes I heare lord Barnards home;<br></span>
<span class="i2">I would I were awaye.                                             <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Lye still, lye still, thou little Musgràve,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And huggle me from the cold;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For it is but some shephardes boye<br></span>
<span class="i2">A whistling his sheepe to the fold.<a id="FNanchor_226"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_226">[226]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Is not thy hawke upon the pearche,                                  <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy horse eating corne and haye?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thou a gay lady within thine armes:<br></span>
<span class="i2">And wouldst thou be awaye?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">By this lord Barnard was come to the dore,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And lighted upon a stone:                                         <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he pulled out three silver keyes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And opened the dores eche one.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He lifted up the coverlett,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He lifted up the sheete;<br></span>
<span class="i0">How now, how now, thou little Musgràve,                             <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Dost find my gaye ladye sweete?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I find her sweete, quoth little Musgràve,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The more is my griefe and paine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ide gladlye give three hundred poundes<br></span>
<span class="i2">That I were on yonder plaine.                                     <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Arise, arise, thou little Musgràve,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And put thy cloathes nowe on,<br></span>
<span class="i0">It shall never be said in my countree,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That I killed a naked man.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_73">[Pg 73]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I have two swordes in one scabbàrde,                                <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Full deare they cost my purse;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thou shalt have the best of them,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And I will have the worse.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The first stroke that little Musgrave strucke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He hurt lord Barnard sore;                                        <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The next stroke that lord Barnard strucke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Little Musgrave never strucke more.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With that bespake the ladye faire,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In bed whereas she laye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Althoughe thou art dead, my little Musgràve,                        <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet for thee I will praye:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And wishe well to thy soule will I,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So long as I have life;<br></span>
<span class="i0">So will I not do for thee, Barnàrd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thoughe I am thy wedded wife.                                    <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He cut her pappes from off her brest;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Great pitye it was to see<br></span>
<span class="i0">The drops of this fair ladyes bloode<br></span>
<span class="i2">Run trickling downe her knee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Wo worth, wo worth ye, my merrye men all,                          <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">You never were borne for my goode:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Why did you not offer to stay my hande,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When you sawe me wax so woode?<a id="FNanchor_227"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_227">[227]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For I have slaine the fairest sir knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That ever rode on a steede;                                      <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So have I done the fairest lady,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That ever ware womans weede.<a id="FNanchor_228"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_228">[228]</a><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_74">[Pg 74]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A grave, a grave, Lord Barnard cryde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To putt these lovers in;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But lay my ladye o' the upper hande,                               <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For she comes o' the better kin.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>†‡† That the more modern copy is to be dated about the middle
of the last century, will be readily conceived from the tenor of the
concluding stanza, viz.</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"This sad Mischief by Lust was wrought;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then let us call for Grace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That we may shun the wicked vice,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fly from Sin a-pace."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_225"></a><a href="#FNanchor_225" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[225]</span></a> Bucklefield-berry, fol. MS.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_226"></a><a href="#FNanchor_226" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[226]</span></a> Ver. 64. Is whistling sheepe ore the mold, fol. MS.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_227"></a><a href="#FNanchor_227" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[227]</span></a> [wildly angry.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_228"></a><a href="#FNanchor_228" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[228]</span></a> [See the last stanza of <i>Childe Maurice</i> from Folio MS., book i.
No. 18, which is almost identical with this.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XII.<br>

THE EW-BUGHTS, MARION.</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">A Scottish Song.</span>
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i074t.png" id="img_images_i074t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> sonnet appears to be ancient: that and its simplicity
of sentiment have recommended it to a place
here.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This is marked in Ramsay's <i>Tea Table Miscellany</i> as
an old song with additions. It is not known who wrote the song
or who composed the air belonging to it. They are both old.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i074w.png" id="img_images_i074w.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Will ye gae to the ew-bughts,<a id="FNanchor_229"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_229">[229]</a> Marion,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And wear in<a id="FNanchor_230"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_230">[230]</a> the sheip wi' mee?<br></span>
<span class="i0">The sun shines sweit, my Marion,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But nae half sae sweit as thee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">O Marion's a bonnie lass;                                            <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
