<span class="i2">And the blyth blinks<a id="FNanchor_231"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_231">[231]</a> in her ee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And fain wad I marrie Marion,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Gin Marion wad marrie mee.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_75">[Pg 75]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Theire's gowd in your garters, Marion;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And siller on your white hauss-bane<a id="FNanchor_232"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_232">[232]</a>:                         <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Fou faine wad I kisse my Marion<br></span>
<span class="i2">At eene quhan I cum hame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Theire's braw lads in Earnslaw, Marion,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Quha gape and glowr wi' their ee<br></span>
<span class="i0">At kirk, quhan they see my Marion;                                  <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Bot nane of them lues<a id="FNanchor_233"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_233">[233]</a> like mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ive nine milk-ews, my Marion,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A cow and a brawney quay;<a id="FNanchor_234"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_234">[234]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ise gie tham au to my Marion,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Just on her bridal day.                                           <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And yees get a grein sey<a id="FNanchor_235"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_235">[235]</a> apron,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And waistcote o' London broun;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wow bot ye will be vaporing<br></span>
<span class="i2">Quhaneir ye gang to the toun.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ime yong and stout, my Marion,                                      <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">None dance lik mee on the greine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gin ye forsak me, Marion,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ise een gae draw up wi' Jeane.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sae put on your pearlins,<a id="FNanchor_236"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_236">[236]</a> Marion,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And kirtle oth' cramasie;<a id="FNanchor_237"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_237">[237]</a> <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And sune as my chin has nae haire on,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I sall cum west, and see yee.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_76">[Pg 76]</a></span></p><div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_229"></a><a href="#FNanchor_229" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[229]</span></a> [the pens in which the ewes are milked.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_230"></a><a href="#FNanchor_230" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[230]</span></a> [gather in.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_231"></a><a href="#FNanchor_231" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[231]</span></a> [joy sparkles.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_232"></a><a href="#FNanchor_232" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[232]</span></a> <i>Hauss bane, i.e.</i> The neck-bone. Marion had probably a
silver locket on, tied close to her neck with a ribband, an usual
ornament in Scotland; where a sore throat is called "<i>a sair hause</i>,"
properly <i>halse</i>.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_233"></a><a href="#FNanchor_233" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[233]</span></a> [loves.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_234"></a><a href="#FNanchor_234" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[234]</span></a> [young heifer.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_235"></a><a href="#FNanchor_235" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[235]</span></a> [woollen cloth.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_236"></a><a href="#FNanchor_236" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[236]</span></a> [a kind of lace made of thread or silk.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_237"></a><a href="#FNanchor_237" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[237]</span></a> [crimson.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XIII.<br>

THE KNIGHT, AND SHEPHERD'S
DAUGHTER.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i076.png" id="img_images_i076.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> ballad (given from an old black-letter copy, with
some corrections) was popular in the time of Q. Elizabeth,
being usually printed with her picture before it, as
Hearne informs us in his preface to <i>Gul. Neubrig. Hist.</i>
<i>Oxon.</i> 1719, 8vo. vol. i. p. lxx. It is quoted in Fletcher's comedy
of the <i>Pilgrim</i>, act iv. sc. 2.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[It is also quoted in <i>The Knight of the Burning Pestle</i>:</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"He set her on a milk white steed." (l. 85.)<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>There are several Scottish versions given by Buchan, Kinloch, and
Motherwell. The latter claims greater antiquity for his over Percy's.
It appears, however, to be a southern ballad adapted by the Scotch
and improved in its humour. The heroine practices various artifices
to maintain the character of a "beggar's brat" when riding
back with <i>Earl Richard</i>.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i076t.png" id="img_images_i076t.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There was a shepherd's daughter<br></span>
<span class="i2">Came tripping on the waye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there by chance a knighte shee mett,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which caused her to staye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Good morrowe to you, beauteous maide,                                <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">These words pronounced hee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">O I shall dye this daye, he sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">If Ive not my wille of thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The Lord forbid, the maide replyde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That you shold waxe so wode!                                      <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"But for all that shee could do or saye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He wold not be withstood."<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_77">[Pg 77]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sith you have had your wille of mee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And put me to open shame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, if you are a courteous knighte,                                <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Tell me what is your name?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Some do call mee Jacke, sweet heart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And some do call mee Jille;<a id="FNanchor_238"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_238">[238]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">But when I come to the kings faire courte<br></span>
<span class="i2">They call me Wilfulle Wille.                                      <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He sett his foot into the stirrup,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And awaye then he did ride;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She tuckt her girdle about her middle,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And ranne close by his side.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But when she came to the brode watèr,                               <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">She sett her brest and swamme;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And when she was got out againe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She tooke to her heels and ranne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He never was the courteous knighte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To saye, faire maide, will ye ride?                               <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"And she was ever too loving a maide"<br></span>
<span class="i2">To saye, sir knighte abide.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When she came to the kings faire courte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She knocked at the ring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">So readye was the king himself                                      <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To let this faire maide in.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now Christ you save, my gracious liege,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Now Christ you save and see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">You have a knighte within your courte<br></span>
<span class="i2">This daye hath robbed mee.                                        <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_78">[Pg 78]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What hath he robbed thee of, sweet heart?<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of purple or of pall?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or hath he took thy gaye gold ring<br></span>
<span class="i2">From off thy finger small?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He hath not robbed mee, my leige,                                   <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of purple nor of pall:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he hath gotten my maiden head,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which grieves mee worst of all.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now if he be a batchelor,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His bodye Ile give to thee;<a id="FNanchor_239"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_239">[239]</a> <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But if he be a married man,<br></span>
<span class="i2">High hanged he shall bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He called downe his merrye men all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">By one, by two, by three;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir William used to bee the first,                                  <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">But nowe the last came hee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He brought her downe full fortye pounde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Tyed up withinne a glove:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Faire maid, Ile give the same to thee;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Go, seeke thee another love.                                      <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O Ile have none of your gold, she sayde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor Ile have none of your fee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But your faire bodye I must have,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The king hath granted mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir William ranne and fetchd her then                               <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Five hundred pound in golde,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Saying, faire maide, take this to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy fault will never be tolde.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_79">[Pg 79]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Tis not the gold that shall mee tempt,<br></span>
<span class="i2">These words then answered shee,                                   <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But your own bodye I must have,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The king hath granted mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Would I had dranke the water cleare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When I did drinke the wine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rather than any shepherds brat                                      <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Shold bee a ladye of mine!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Would I had drank the puddle foule,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When I did drink the ale,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rather than ever a shepherds brat<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shold tell me such a tale!                                        <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A shepherds brat even as I was,<br></span>
<span class="i2">You mote have let me bee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I never had come othe kings faire courte,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To crave any love of thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He sett her on a milk-white steede,                                 <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And himself upon a graye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He hung a bugle about his necke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And soe they rode awaye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But when they came unto the place,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where marriage-rites were done,                                   <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She proved herself a dukes daughtèr,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And he but a squires sonne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now marrye me, or not, sir knight.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Your pleasure shall be free:<br></span>
<span class="i0">If you make me ladye of one good towne,                             <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Ile make you lord of three.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ah! cursed bee the gold, he sayd.<br></span>
<span class="i2">If thou hadst not been trewe.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I shold have forsaken my sweet love,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And have changed her for a newe.                                 <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_80">[Pg 80]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And now their hearts being linked fast,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They joyned hand in hande:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus he had both purse, and person too,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all at his commande.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">*</p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_238"></a><a href="#FNanchor_238" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[238]</span></a> [Jill is sometimes used as a woman's name and at other times
as a man's.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_239"></a><a href="#FNanchor_239" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[239]</span></a> [Ver. 50. <i>His bodye Ile give to thee.</i>] This was agreeable to the
feudal customs: The Lord had a right to give a wife to his vassals.
See Shakespeare's <i>All's well that ends well</i>.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XIV.<br>

THE SHEPHERD'S ADDRESS TO HIS
MUSE.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i080t.png" id="img_images_i080t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> poem, originally printed from the small MS. volume,
mentioned above in No. X., has been improved by a
more perfect copy in <i>England's Helicon</i>, where the
author is discovered to be <i>N. Breton</i>.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i080g.png" id="img_images_i080g.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Good Muse, rocke me aslepe<br></span>
<span class="i2">With some sweete harmony:<br></span>
<span class="i0">This wearie eyes is not to kepe<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy wary company.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sweete Love, begon a while,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou seest my heavines:                                            <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Beautie is borne but to beguyle<br></span>
<span class="i2">My harte of happines.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">See howe my little flocke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That lovde to feede on highe,                                     <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Doe headlonge tumble downe the rocke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And in the valley dye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The bushes and the trees,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That were so freshe and greene,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Doe all their deintie colors leese,                                 <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And not a leafe is seene.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_81">[Pg 81]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The blacke birde and the thrushe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That made the woodes to ringe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With all the rest, are now at hushe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And not a note they singe.                                        <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Swete Philomele, the birde<br></span>
<span class="i2">That hath the heavenly throte,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Doth nowe, alas! not once afforde<br></span>
<span class="i2">Recordinge of a note.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The flowers have had a frost,                                       <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The herbs have loste their savoure;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Phillida the faire hath lost<br></span>
<span class="i2">"For me her wonted" favour.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus all these careful sights,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So kill me in conceit;                                            <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That now to hope upon delights,<br></span>
<span class="i2">It is but meere deceite.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And therefore, my sweete Muse,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That knowest what helpe is best,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Doe nowe thy heavenlie conninge use                                 <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To sett my harte at rest:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And in a dreame bewraie<br></span>
<span class="i2">What fate shal be my frende;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whether my life shall still decaye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or when my sorrowes ende.                                         <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 100px;">
<img alt="" height="35" src="images/i081.png" width="100" id="img_images_i081.png">
</div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_82">[Pg 82]</a></span></p>
<h3>XV.<br>

LORD THOMAS AND FAIR ELLINOR</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i082i.png" id="img_images_i082i.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capi"><span class="smcap">Is</span> given (with corrections) from an ancient copy in black
letter, in the Pepys collection, intitled, <i>A tragical ballad</i>
<i>on the unfortunate love of lord Thomas and fair Ellinor,</i>
<i>together with the downfall of the browne girl</i>.—In the
same collection may be seen an attempt to modernize this old
song, and reduce it to a different measure: A proof of its popularity.</p>
<p>The reader will find a Scottish song on a similar subject to
this, towards the end of this volume, intitled, <i>Lord Thomas and</i>
<i>Lady Annet</i>.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This is one of the ballads still kept in print in Seven Dials, and
Ritson describes it as having "every appearance of being originally
a minstrel song."</p>
<p>There is a series of ballads on the same subject—</p>
<p>1. <i>Lord Thomas and Fair Annet</i>, (see book iii. No. 4.)</p>
<p>2. <i>Fair Margaret and Sweet William</i>, (see book ii. No. 4.)</p>
<p>3. <i>Sweet Willie and Fair Annie</i>, (Jamieson's <i>Popular Ballads</i>,
l. 22.)</p>
<p>The last named ballad is a combination of the first two, the first
part being similar to <i>Lord Thomas</i>, and the second part to <i>Fair</i>
<i>Margaret</i>.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i082l.png" id="img_images_i082l.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Lord Thomas he was a bold forrestèr,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And a chaser of the kings deere;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Faire Ellinor was a fine womàn,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And lord Thomas he loved her deare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Come riddle my riddle, dear mother, he sayd,                         <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And riddle us both as one;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whether I shall marrye with faire Ellinòr,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And let the browne girl alone?<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_83">[Pg 83]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The browne girl she has got houses and lands,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Faire Ellinor she has got none,                                   <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And therefore I charge thee on my blessìng,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To bring me the browne girl home.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And as it befelle on a high holidaye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As many there are beside,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lord Thomas he went to faire Ellinòr,                               <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That should have been his bride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he came to faire Ellinors bower,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He knocked there at the ring,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And who was so readye as faire Ellinòr,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To lett lord Thomas withinn.                                      <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What newes, what newes, lord Thomas, she sayd?<br></span>
<span class="i2">What newes dost thou bring to mee?<br></span>
<span class="i0">I am come to bid thee to my weddìng,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And that is bad newes for thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O God forbid, lord Thomas, she sayd,                                <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That such a thing should be done;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I thought to have been the bride my selfe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And thou to have been the bridegrome.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Come riddle my riddle, dear mother, she sayd,<a id="FNanchor_240"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_240">[240]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And riddle it all in one;                                         <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whether I shall goe to lord Thomas his wedding,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or whether shall tarry at home?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There are manye that are your friendes, daughtèr,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And manye a one your foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Therefore I charge you on my blessing,                              <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To lord Thomas his wedding don't goe.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_84">[Pg 84]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There are manye that are my friendes, mothèr;<br></span>
<span class="i2">But were every one my foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Betide me life, betide me death,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To lord Thomas his wedding I'ld goe.                              <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She cloathed herself in gallant attire,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And her merrye men all in greene;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as they rid through every towne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They took her to be some queene.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But when she came to lord Thomas his gate,                          <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">She knocked there at the ring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And who was so readye as lord Thomàs,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To lett faire Ellinor in.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Is this your bride, fair Ellinor sayd?<br></span>
<span class="i2">Methinks she looks wonderous browne;                              <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou mightest have had as faire a womàn,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As ever trod on the grounde.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Despise her not, fair Ellin, he sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Despise her not unto mee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For better I love thy little fingèr,                                <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Than all her whole bodèe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This browne bride had a little penknife,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That was both long and sharpe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And betwixt the short ribs and the long,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She prickd faire Ellinor's harte.                                 <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O Christ thee save, lord Thomas, hee sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Methinks thou lookst wonderous wan;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou usedst to look with as fresh a colòur,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As ever the sun shone on.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Oh, art thou blind, lord Thomas? she sayd,                          <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Or canst thou not very well see?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Oh! dost thou not see my owne hearts bloode<br></span>
<span class="i2">Run trickling down my knee.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_85">[Pg 85]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Lord Thomas he had a sword by his side;<br></span>
<span class="i2">As he walked about the halle,                                     <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He cut off his brides head from her shouldèrs,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And threw it against the walle.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He set the hilte against the grounde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And the point against his harte.<br></span>
<span class="i0">There never three lovers together did meete,                        <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That sooner againe did parte.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_240"></a><a href="#FNanchor_240" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[240]</span></a> Ver. 29. It should probably be, <i>Read me, read, &amp;c., i.e.</i> Advise
me, advise.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XVI.<br>

CUPID AND CAMPASPE.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i085t.png" id="img_images_i085t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> elegant little sonnet is found in the third act of an
old play intitled <i>Alexander and Campaspe</i>, written by
John Lilye, a celebrated writer in the time of queen
Elizabeth. That play was first printed in 1591; but
this copy is given from a later edition.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[These pretty epigrammatic verses occur in act iii. sc. 5. of Lilly's
play as a song by Apelles. The first edition of <i>Campaspe</i> was
printed in 1584, and that of 1591, mentioned above, is the second
edition. This song, however, was omitted in all the editions printed
before that of E. Blount (<i>Six Court Comedies, 1632.</i>)]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i085c.png" id="img_images_i085c.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Cupid and my Campaspe playd<br></span>
<span class="i0">At cardes for kisses; Cupid payd:<br></span>
<span class="i0">He stakes his quiver, bow and arrows,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His mothers doves, and teame of sparrows;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Loses them too; then down he throws                                  <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The coral of his lippe, the rose<br></span>
<span class="i0">Growing on's cheek (but none knows how)<br></span>
<span class="i0">With these, the crystal of his browe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And then the dimple of his chinne;<br></span>
<span class="i0">All these did my Campaspe winne.                                    <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_86">[Pg 86]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At last he set her both his eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She won, and Cupid blind did rise.<br></span>
<span class="i2">O Love! has she done this to thee?<br></span>
<span class="i2">What shall, alas! become of mee?<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XVII.<br>

THE LADY TURNED SERVING-MAN</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i086i.png" id="img_images_i086i.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capi"><span class="smcap">Is</span> given from a written copy, containing some improvements
(perhaps modern ones), upon the popular ballad,
intitled, <i>The famous flower of Serving-men</i>: or the <i>Lady</i>
<i>turned Serving-man</i>.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[It is printed in the <i>Collection of Old Ballads</i> (i. 216) without
the <i>improvements</i>. After verse 56 the first person is changed to
the third in the original, but Percy altered this and made the first
person run on throughout. Kinloch (<i>Ancient Scottish Ballads</i>,
p. 95) gives a very mutilated and varied version of this ballad in
the Scottish dress under the title of <i>Sweet Willie</i>, which was taken
down from the recitation of an old woman in Lanark. There is a
similar story in Swedish and Danish.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i086y.png" id="img_images_i086y.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">You beauteous ladyes, great and small,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I write unto you one and all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whereby that you may understand<br></span>
<span class="i0">What I have suffered in the land.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I was by birth a lady faire,                                         <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An ancient barons only heire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And when my good old father dyed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then I became a young knightes bride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And there my love built me a bower,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bedeck'd with many a fragrant flower;                               <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A braver bower you ne'er did see<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then my true-love did build for mee.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_87">[Pg 87]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And there I livde a ladye gay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till fortune wrought our loves decay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For there came foes so fierce a band,                               <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That soon they over-run the land.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">They came upon us in the night,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And brent my bower, and slew my knight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And trembling hid in mans array,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I scant with life escap'd away.                                     <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In the midst of this extremitìe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My servants all did from me flee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus was I left myself alone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With heart more cold than any stone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet though my heart was full of care,                               <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Heaven would not suffer me to dispaire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wherefore in haste I chang'd my name<br></span>
<span class="i0">From faire Elise, to sweet Williame:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And therewithall I cut my haire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Resolv'd my man's attire to weare;                                  <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And in my beaver, hose and band,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I travell'd far through many a land.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At length all wearied with my toil,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I sate me downe to rest awhile;<br></span>
<span class="i0">My heart it was so fill'd with woe,                                 <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That downe my cheeke the teares did flow.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It chanc'd the king of that same place<br></span>
<span class="i0">With all his lords a hunting was,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And seeing me weepe, upon the same<br></span>
<span class="i0">Askt who I was, and whence I came.                                  <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then to his grace I did replye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I am a poore and friendlesse boye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Though nobly borne, nowe forc'd to bee<br></span>
<span class="i0">A serving-man of lowe degree.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_88">[Pg 88]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Stand up, faire youth, the king reply'd,                            <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For thee a service I'll provyde:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But tell me first what thou canst do;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt be fitted thereunto.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Wilt thou be usher of my hall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To wait upon my nobles all?                                         <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or wilt be taster of my wine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To 'tend on me when I shall dine?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Or wilt thou be my chamberlaine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">About my person to remaine?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or wilt thou be one of my guard,                                    <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I will give thee great reward?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Chuse, gentle youth, said he, thy place.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then I reply'd, If it please your grace<br></span>
<span class="i0">To shew such favour unto mee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Your chamberlaine I faine would bee.                                <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The king then smiling gave consent,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And straitwaye to his court I went;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where I behavde so faithfullìe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That hee great favour showd to mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now marke what fortune did provide;                                 <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The king he would a hunting ride<br></span>
<span class="i0">With all his lords and noble traine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sweet William must at home remaine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus being left alone behind,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My former state came in my mind:                                    <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I wept to see my mans array;<br></span>
<span class="i0">No longer now a ladye gay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And meeting with a ladyes vest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Within the same myself I drest;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With silken robes, and jewels rare,                                 <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I deckt me, as a ladye faire:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_89">[Pg 89]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And taking up a lute straitwaye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Upon the same I strove to play;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sweetly to the same did sing,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As made both hall and chamber ring.                                 <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"My father was as brave a lord,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As ever Europe might afford;<br></span>
<span class="i0">My mother was a lady bright;<br></span>
<span class="i0">My husband was a valiant knight:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"And I myself a ladye gay,                                          <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Bedeckt with gorgeous rich array;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The happiest lady in the land,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had not more pleasure at command.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"I had my musicke every day<br></span>
<span class="i0">Harmonious lessons for to play;                                     <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I had my virgins fair and free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Continually to wait on mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But now, alas! my husband's dead,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all my friends are from me fled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My former days are past and gone,                                   <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I am now a serving-man."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And fetching many a tender sigh,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As thinking no one then was nigh,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In pensive mood I laid me lowe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My heart was full, the tears did flowe.                            <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The king, who had a huntinge gone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Grewe weary of his sport anone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And leaving all his gallant traine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Turn'd on the sudden home againe:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he reach'd his statelye tower,                            <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Hearing one sing within his bower,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He stopt to listen, and to see<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who sung there so melodiouslìe.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_90">[Pg 90]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus heard he everye word I sed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And saw the pearlye teares I shed,                                 <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And found to his amazement there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sweete William was a ladye faire.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then stepping in, Faire ladye, rise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dry, said he, those lovelye eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I have heard thy mournful tale,                                <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The which shall turne to thy availe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A crimson dye my face orespred,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I blusht for shame, and hung my head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To find my sex and story knowne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When as I thought I was alone.                                     <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But to be briefe, his royall grace<br></span>
<span class="i0">Grewe so enamour'd of my face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The richest gifts he proffered mee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His mistress if that I would bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ah! no, my liege, I firmlye sayd,                                  <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I'll rather in my grave be layd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And though your grace hath won my heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I ne'er will act soe base a part.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Faire ladye, pardon me, sayd hee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy virtue shall rewarded bee,                                     <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And since it is soe fairly tryde<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt become my royal bride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then strait to end his amorous strife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He tooke sweet William to his wife.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The like before was never seene,                                   <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A serving-man became a queene.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_91">[Pg 91]</a></span><span class="stageright">⁂</span><br>
</p>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XVIII.<br>

GIL MORRICE.</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">A Scottish Ballad.</span>
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i091.png" id="img_images_i091.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> following piece hath run thro' two editions in Scotland:
the second was printed at Glasgow in 1755, 8vo.
Prefixed to them both is an advertisement, setting forth
that the preservation of this poem was owing "to a
lady, who favoured the printers with a copy, as it was carefully
collected from the mouths of old women and nurses;" and "any
reader that can render it more correct or complete," is desired to
oblige the public with such improvements. In consequence of
this advertisement sixteen additional verses have been produced
and handed about in manuscript, which are here inserted in their
proper places: (these are from ver. 109, to ver. 121, and from ver.
124, to ver. 129, but are perhaps, after all, only an ingenious interpolation.)</p>
<p>As this poem lays claim to a pretty high antiquity, we have
assigned it a place among our early pieces: though, after all, there
is reason to believe it has received very considerable modern improvements:
for in the Editor's ancient MS. collection is a very
old imperfect copy of the same ballad: wherein though the leading
features of the story are the same, yet the colouring here is so much
improved and heightened, and so many additional strokes are
thrown in, that it is evident the whole has undergone a revisal.</p>
<p>This little pathetic tale suggested the plot of the tragedy of
<i>Douglas</i>.</p>
<p>Since it was first printed, the Editor has been assured that the
foregoing ballad is still current in many parts of Scotland, where
the hero is universally known by the name of <i>Child Maurice</i>, pronounced
by the common people <i>Cheild</i> or <i>Cheeld</i>; which occasioned
the mistake.</p>
<p>It may be proper to mention that other copies read ver. 110,
thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Shot frae the golden sun"<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>And ver. 116, as follows:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"His een like azure sheene."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>N.B. The Editor's MS. instead of "lord Barnard," has "John
Stewart;" and instead of "Gil Morrice," <i>Child Maurice</i>, which last
is probably the original title. See above, p. <a href="#Page_58" class="pginternal">58</a>.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_92">[Pg 92]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[<i>Gil Maurice</i> is one of the most popular of the old ballads and it
is also one of the most corrupt. The present copy is so tinkered
that it is not surprising Burns regarded the ballad as a modern composition
and classed it with <i>Hardyknute</i>, a position afterwards taken
up by Robert Chambers in his pamphlet <i>The Romantic Scottish Ballads,</i>
<i>their epoch and authorship</i>. The fact however that the story
is preserved in the Folio MS. and also in several other forms obtained
from tradition prove it to be an authentic ballad. Jamieson
thinks it has all the appearance of being a true narrative of some
incident that had really taken place. Motherwell devotes several
pages of his <i>Minstrelsy</i> (pp. 257-286) to an account of the various
versions. He says that tradition points out the "green wood" of
the ballad in the ancient forest of Dundaff in Stirlingshire.</p>
<p>The request for additions mentioned above by Percy was a
tempting bait eagerly caught at, and the edition of 1755 was a
made up text with additional verses. Besides vv. 109-120, 125-128,
which are known to be interpolations, Professor Child (<i>English</i>
<i>and Scottish Ballads</i>, vol. ii. p. 38) also degrades to the foot of
the page the verses from 177 to the end, on the authority of Jamieson,
who says, that "having been attentive to all the proceedings
in most of the trials at the bar of ballad criticism I may venture
to hazard an opinion that the genuine text ends with 'ver. 176.'"
Ritson and Motherwell are of the same opinion. Sir Walter Scott
notes on the interpolated verses, "In the beautiful and simple
ballad of <i>Gil Morris</i> some affected person has stuck in one or
two factitious verses which, like vulgar persons in a drawing room,
betray themselves by their over-finery."</p>
<p>The fine copy in the Folio MS. (ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. ii.
p. 500), which Jamieson thought debased and totally unworthy of
the subject, which Chambers calls "a poor, bald imperfect composition,"
and Mr. Hales more accurately designates as "a noble
specimen of our ballad poetry in all its strength," was first printed
by Jamieson (<i>Popular Ballads and Songs</i>, 1806, vol. i. p. 8), and
is now added to the present version. The last stanza of the Folio
MS. copy is identical with the last stanza but one of <i>Little Musgrave</i>
<i>and Lady Barnard</i>, with which it seems to have some
connection both in subject and name.</p>
<p>Prof. Aytoun points out that vv. 51-58 of Percy's copy, which
are now placed within brackets, are taken from <i>Lady Maisry</i>, a
ballad obtained from recitation and printed by Jamieson (vol. i.
p. 73).</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"O whan he came to broken briggs<br></span>
<span class="i2">He bent his bow and swam,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And whan he came to the green grass growin'<br></span>
<span class="i2">He slack'd his shoon and ran.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_93">[Pg 93]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And whan he came to Lord William's yeats<br></span>
<span class="i2">He badena to chap or ca',<br></span>
<span class="i0">But set his bent bow to his breast<br></span>
<span class="i2">And lightly lap the wa'."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>It is however only fair to Percy to say that he printed <i>Gil Morice</i>
before <i>Lady Maisry</i> was published.</p>
<p>Gray wrote to a friend, "I have got the old Scotch ballad on
which <i>Douglas</i> was founded; it is divine, and as long as from
hence [Cambridge] to Aston."</p>
<p>Jamieson says, on the authority of Sir Walter Scott, that after
the appearance of Home's <i>Douglas</i> six additional stanzas, beginning—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"She heard him speak, but fell despair<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sat rooted in her heart<br></span>
<span class="i0">She heard him, and she heard nae mair<br></span>
<span class="i2">Though sair she rued the smart,"<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>were written to complete the ballad, and in accordance with the
final catastrophe of the tragedy Lord Barnard rushes into the
thickest of the fight—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"and meets the death he sought."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>When the play was produced in Edinburgh in 1756 the heroine
was named Lady Barnard, and the alteration to Lady Randolph
was made on its appearance in England in the following year.</p>
<p>Jamieson gives three stanzas of a traditional version of the
ballad, the whole of which neither he nor Motherwell could
recover, although Mr. Sharpe told the latter that they were incorporated
in an Annandale version which contained a novel feature
in the story.</p>
<p>Motherwell prints a version called <i>Chield Morice</i>, which he took
down from the recitation of an old woman of 70 in 1827, and
which she had learned in infancy from her grandmother. She told
Motherwell "that at a later period of her life she also committed
to memory <i>Gill Morice</i>, which began with young lasses like her
to be a greater favourite, and more fashionable than the set which
her grandmother and other old folks used to sing under the title
of <i>Chield Morice</i>." He also prints <i>Child Moryce</i>, taken down
from the singing of widow M'Cormick of Paisley in 1825, and
adds his opinion that Morice and Maurice are evident corruptions
of Norice—a foster child. The story of Langhorne's <i>Owen of</i>
<i>Carron</i> is also taken from this ballad.]</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_94">[Pg 94]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i094.png" id="img_images_i094.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Gil Morrice was an erlès son,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His name it waxed wide;<br></span>
<span class="i0">It was nae for his great richès,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor yet his mickle pride;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bot it was for a lady gay,                                           <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That livd on Carron side.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quhair sall I get a bonny boy,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That will win hose and shoen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">That will gae to lord Barnards ha',<br></span>
<span class="i2">And bid his lady cum?                                             <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And ye maun rin my errand, Willie;<a id="FNanchor_241"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_241">[241]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And ye may rin wi' pride;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quhen other boys gae on their foot,<br></span>
<span class="i2">On horse-back ye sall ride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O no! Oh no! my master dear!                                        <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I dare nae for my life;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I'll no gae to the bauld baròns,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For to triest furth his wife.<br></span>
<span class="i0">My bird Willie, my boy Willie;<br></span>
<span class="i2">My dear Willie, he sayd:                                          <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">How can ye strive against the stream?<br></span>
<span class="i2">For I sall be obeyd.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Bot, O my master dear! he cryd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In grene wod ye're your lain;<a id="FNanchor_242"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_242">[242]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Gi owre sic thochts, I walde ye rede,<a id="FNanchor_243"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_243">[243]</a> <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For fear ye should be tain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Haste, haste, I say, gae to the ha',<br></span>
<span class="i2">Bid hir cum here wi speid:<br></span>
<span class="i0">If ye refuse my heigh command,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ill gar your body bleid.                                          <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_95">[Pg 95]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Gae bid hir take this gay mantèl,<br></span>
<span class="i2">'Tis a' gowd bot the hem;<a id="FNanchor_244"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_244">[244]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Bid hir cum to the gude grene wode,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And bring nane bot hir lain:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there it is, a silken sarke,                                    <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her ain hand sewd the sleive;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bid hir cum to Gill Morice,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Speir nae bauld barons leave.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yes, I will gae your black errand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Though it be to your cost;                                        <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sen ye by me will nae be warn'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In it ye sall find frost.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The baron he is a man of might,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He neir could bide to taunt,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As ye will see before its nicht,                                    <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">How sma' ye hae to vaunt.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And sen I maun your errand rin<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sae sair against my will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I'se mak a vow and keip it trow,<br></span>
<span class="i2">It sall be done for ill.                                          <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">[And quhen he came to broken brigue,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He bent his bow and swam;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And quhen he came to grass growing,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Set down his feet and ran.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And quhen he came to Barnards ha',                                  <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Would neither chap<a id="FNanchor_245"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_245">[245]</a> nor ca':<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bot set his bent bow to his breist,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And lichtly lap the wa'.]<a id="FNanchor_246"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_246">[246]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">He wauld nae tell the man his errand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Though he stude at the gait;                                      <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Bot straiht into the ha' he cam,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Quhair they were set at meit.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_96">[Pg 96]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hail! hail! my gentle sire and dame!<br></span>
<span class="i2">My message winna waite;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dame, ye maun to the gude grene wod                                 <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Before that it be late.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ye're bidden tak this gay mantèl,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Tis a' gowd bot the hem:<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_244">[244]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">You maun gae to the gude grene wode,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ev'n by your sel alane.                                           <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And there it is, a silken sarke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Your ain hand sewd the sleive;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ye maun gae speik to Gill Morìce;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Speir nae bauld barons leave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lady stamped wi' hir foot,                                      <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And winked wi' hir ee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bot a' that she coud say or do,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Forbidden he wad nae bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Its surely to my bow'r-womàn;<br></span>
<span class="i2">It neir could be to me.                                           <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I brocht it to lord Barnards lady;<br></span>
<span class="i2">I trow that ye be she.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then up and spack the wylie nurse,<br></span>
<span class="i2">(The bairn upon hir knee)<br></span>
<span class="i0">If it be cum frae Gill Morice,                                      <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">It's deir welcum to mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ye leid, ye leid, ye filthy nurse,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sae loud I heird ye lee;<a id="FNanchor_247"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_247">[247]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">I brocht it to lord Barnards lady;<br></span>
<span class="i2">I trow ye be nae shee.                                            <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then up and spack the bauld baròn,<br></span>
<span class="i2">An angry man was hee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He's tain the table wi' his foot,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_97">[Pg 97]</a></span>
<span class="i2">Sae has he wi' his knee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till siller cup and 'mazer'<a id="FNanchor_248"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_248">[248]</a> dish                               <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In flinders he gard flee.<a id="FNanchor_249"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_249">[249]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Gae bring a robe of your clidìng,<a id="FNanchor_250"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_250">[250]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That hings upon the pin;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I'll gae to the gude grene wode,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And speik wi' your lemmàn.                                       <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O bide at hame, now lord Barnàrd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I warde ye bide at hame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Neir wyte<a id="FNanchor_251"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_251">[251]</a> a man for violence,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That neir wate<a id="FNanchor_252"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_252">[252]</a> ye wi' nane.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Gil Morice sate in gude grene wode,                                <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He whistled and he sang':<br></span>
<span class="i0">O what mean a' the folk comìng,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My mother tarries lang.<br></span>
<span class="i0">[His hair was like the threeds of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Drawne frae Minervas loome:                                      <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His lipps like roses drapping dew,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His breath was a' perfume.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">His brow was like the mountain snae<br></span>
<span class="i2">Gilt by the morning beam:<br></span>
<span class="i0">His cheeks like living roses glow:                                 <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His een like azure stream.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The boy was clad in robes of grene,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sweete as the infant spring:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And like the mavis on the bush,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He gart the vallies ring.]                                       <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The baron came to the grene wode,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Wi' mickle dule and care,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there he first spied Gill Morìce<br></span>
<span class="i2">Kameing his yellow hair:<br></span>
<span class="i0">[That sweetly wavd around his face,                                <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_98">[Pg 98]</a></span>
<span class="i2">That face beyond compare:<br></span>
<span class="i0">He sang sae sweet it might dispel,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A' rage but fell despair.]<a id="FNanchor_253"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_253">[253]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nae wonder, nae wonder, Gill Morìce,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My lady loed thee weel,                                          <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The fairest part of my bodie<br></span>
<span class="i2">Is blacker than thy heel.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet neir the less now, Gill Morìce,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For a' thy great beautiè,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ye's rew the day ye eir was born;                                  <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That head sall gae wi' me.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now he has drawn his trusty brand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And slaited on the strae;<a id="FNanchor_254"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_254">[254]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And thro' Gill Morice' fair body<br></span>
<span class="i2">He's gar cauld iron gae.                                         <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he has tain Gill Morice' head<br></span>
<span class="i2">And set it on a speir;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The meanest man in a' his train<br></span>
<span class="i2">Has gotten that head to bear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he has tain Gill Morice up,                                    <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Laid him across his steid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And brocht him to his painted bowr<br></span>
<span class="i2">And laid him on a bed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lady sat on castil wa',<br></span>
<span class="i2">Beheld baith dale and doun;                                      <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And there she saw Gill Morice' head<br></span>
<span class="i2">Cum trailing to the toun.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_99">[Pg 99]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Far better I loe that bluidy head,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Both and that yellow hair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than lord Barnard, and a' his lands,                               <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">As they lig here and thair.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And she has tain her Gill Morice,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And kissd baith mouth and chin:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I was once as fow of Gill Morice,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As the hip is o' the stean.<a id="FNanchor_255"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_255">[255]</a> <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I got ye in my father's house,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Wi' mickle sin and shame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I brocht thee up in gude grene wode,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Under the heavy rain.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Oft have I by thy cradle sitten,                                   <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And fondly seen thee sleip;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now I gae about thy grave,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The saut tears for to weip.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And syne she kissd his bluidy cheik,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And syne his bluidy chin:                                        <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O better I loe my Gill Morice<br></span>
<span class="i2">Than a' my kith and kin!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Away, away, ye ill womàn,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And an il deith mait ye dee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gin I had kend he'd bin your son,                                  <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He'd neir bin slain for mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[Obraid me not, my lord Barnard!<br></span>
<span class="i2">Obraid me not for shame!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wi' that saim speir O pierce my heart!<br></span>
<span class="i2">And put me out o' pain.                                          <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Since nothing bot Gill Morice head<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy jelous rage could quell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let that saim hand now tak hir life,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That neir to thee did ill.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_100">[Pg 100]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To me nae after days nor nichts                                    <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Will eir be saft or kind;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I'll fill the air with heavy sighs,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And greet till I am blind.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Enouch of blood by me's bin spilt,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Seek not your death frae mee;                                    <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I rather lourd it had been my sel<br></span>
<span class="i2">Than eather him or thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With waefo wae I hear your plaint;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sair, sair I rew the deid,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That eir this cursed hand of mine                                  <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Had gard his body bleid.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dry up your tears, my winsome dame,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ye neir can heal the wound;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ye see his head upon the speir,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His heart's blude on the ground.                                 <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I curse the hand that did the deid,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The heart that thocht the ill;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The feet that bore me wi' silk speid,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The comely youth to kill.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I'll ay lament for Gill Morice,                                    <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">As gin he were mine ain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I'll neir forget the dreiry day<br></span>
<span class="i2">On which the youth was slain.]<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 100px;">
<img alt="" height="28" src="images/i100.png" width="100" id="img_images_i100.png">
</div>
<div class="blockquot">
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i100t.png" id="img_images_i100t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capm"><span class="smcap">[The</span> following is copied from the Folio MS. (ed. H. &amp; F.
vol. 2. pp. 502-506.)</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Childe Maurice hunted ithe siluen wood,<br></span>
<span class="i2">he hunted itt round about,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; noebodye that he ffound therin,<br></span>
<span class="i2">nor none there was with-out.                                       <span class="linenum">4</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; he tooke his siluer combe in his hand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">to kembe his yellow lockes;<br></span>
<span class="i0">he sayes, "come hither, thou litle ffoot page,<br></span>
<span class="i2">that runneth lowlye by my knee;                                    <span class="linenum">8</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">ffor thou shalt goe to Iohn stewards wiffe<br></span>
<span class="i2">&amp; pray her speake with mee.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_101">[Pg 101]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; as itt ffalls out many times,<br></span>
<span class="i2">as knotts beene knitt on a kell,                                  <span class="linenum">12</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">or Marchant men gone to Leeue London<br></span>
<span class="i2">either to buy ware or sell,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"I, and greete thou doe that Ladye well,<br></span>
<span class="i2">euer soe well ffroe mee,—                                        <span class="linenum">16</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And as itt ffalles out many times<br></span>
<span class="i2">as any hart can thinke,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"as schoole masters are in any schoole house<br></span>
<span class="i2">writting with pen and Iinke,—                                    <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">ffor if I might, as well as shee may,<br></span>
<span class="i2">this night I wold with her speake.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; heere I send her a mantle of greene,<br></span>
<span class="i2">as greene as any grasse,                                          <span class="linenum">24</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; bidd her come to the siluer wood<br></span>
<span class="i2">to hunt with Child Maurice;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; there I send her a ring of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i2">a ring of precyous stone,                                         <span class="linenum">28</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; bidd her come to the siluer wood;<br></span>
<span class="i2">let ffor no kind of man."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">one while this litle boy he yode,<br></span>
<span class="i2">another while he ran;                                             <span class="linenum">32</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">vntill he came to Iohn Stewards hall,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I-wis he neuer blan.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; of nurture the child had good;<br></span>
<span class="i2">hee ran vp hall &amp; bower ffree,                                    <span class="linenum">36</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; when he came to this Lady ffaire,<br></span>
<span class="i2">sayes, "god you saue and see!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"I am come ffrom Chιld Maurice,<br></span>
<span class="i2">a message vnto thee;                                              <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; Child Maurice, he greetes you well,<br></span>
<span class="i2">&amp; euer soe well ffrom mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; as itt ffalls out oftentimes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">as knotts beene knitt on a kell,                                  <span class="linenum">44</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">or Marchant men gone to leeue London,<br></span>
<span class="i2">either ffor to buy ware or sell,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; as oftentimes he greetes you well<br></span>
<span class="i2">as any hart can thinke,                                           <span class="linenum">48</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">or schoole masters in any schoole<br></span>
<span class="i2">wryting with pen and inke;<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_102">[Pg 102]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; heere he sends a Mantle of greene,<br></span>
<span class="i2">as greene as any grasse,                                          <span class="linenum">52</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; he bidds you come to the siluer wood,<br></span>
<span class="i2">to hunt with Child Maurice.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; heere he sends you a ring of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i2">a ring of the precyous stone,                                     <span class="linenum">56</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">he prayes you to come to the siluer wood,<br></span>
<span class="i2">let ffor no kind of man."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"now peace, now peace, thou litle ffootpage,<br></span>
<span class="i2">ffor Christes sake, I pray thee!                                  <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">ffor if my lord heare one of these words,<br></span>
<span class="i2">thou must be hanged hye!"<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Iohn steward stood vnder the Castle wall,<br></span>
<span class="i2">&amp; he wrote the words euerye one,                                  <span class="linenum">64</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; he called vnto his horskeeper,<br></span>
<span class="i2">"make readye you my steede!"<br></span>
<span class="i0">I, and soe hee did to his Chamberlaine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">"make readye then my weede!"                                      <span class="linenum">68</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; he cast a lease<a id="FNanchor_256"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_256">[256]</a> vpon his backe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">&amp; he rode to the siluer wood;<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; there he sought all about,<br></span>
<span class="i2">about the siluer wood,                                            <span class="linenum">72</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; there he ffound him Child Maurice<br></span>
<span class="i2">sitting vpon a blocke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">with a siluer combe in his hand<br></span>
<span class="i2">kembing his yellow locke.                                         <span class="linenum">76</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">he sayes, "how now, how now, Child Maurice?<br></span>
<span class="i2">alacke! how may this bee?"<br></span>
<span class="i0">but then stood vp him Child Maurice,<br></span>
<span class="i2">&amp; sayd these words trulye:                                        <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"I doe not know your Ladye," he said,<br></span>
<span class="i2">"if that I doe her see."<br></span>
<span class="i0">"ffor thou hast sent her loue tokens,<br></span>
<span class="i2">more now then 2 or 3;                                             <span class="linenum">84</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"ffor thou hast sent her a mantle of greene,<br></span>
<span class="i2">as greene as any grasse,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; bade her come to the siluer woode<br></span>
<span class="i2">to hunt with Child Maurice;                                       <span class="linenum">88</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_103">[Pg 103]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"&amp; thou [hast] sent her a ring of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i2">a ring of precyous stone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; bade her come to the siluer wood,<br></span>
<span class="i2">let ffor noe kind of man.                                         <span class="linenum">92</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"and by my ffaith, now, Child Maurice,<br></span>
<span class="i2">the tone of vs shall dye!"<br></span>
<span class="i0">"Now be my troth," sayd Child Maurice,<br></span>
<span class="i2">"&amp; that shall not be I."                                          <span class="linenum">96</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">but hee pulled forth a bright browne sword<br></span>
<span class="i2">&amp; dryed itt on the grasse,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; soe ffast he smote att Iohn Steward,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I-wisse he neuer rest.                                           <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">then hee pulled fforth his bright browne sword,<br></span>
<span class="i2">&amp; dryed itt on his sleeue;<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; the ffirst good stroke Iohn Stewart stroke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Child Maurice head he did cleeue;                                <span class="linenum">104</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">&amp; he pricked itt on his swords poynt,<br></span>
<span class="i2">went singing there beside,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; he rode till he came to that Ladye ffaire<br></span>
<span class="i2">wheras this ladye Lyed;                                          <span class="linenum">108</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">and sayes "dost thou know Child Maurice head<br></span>
<span class="i2">if that thou dost itt see?<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; lapp itt soft, &amp; kisse itt offt,<br></span>
<span class="i2">ffor thou louedst him better then mee."                          <span class="linenum">112</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">but when shee looked on Child Maurice head<br></span>
<span class="i2">shee neuer spake words but 3,<br></span>
<span class="i0">"I neuer beare no Child but one,<br></span>
<span class="i2">&amp; you haue slaine him trulye."                                   <span class="linenum">116</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">sayes, "wicked by my merry men all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I gaue Meate, drinke, &amp; Clothe!<br></span>
<span class="i0">but cold they not haue holden me<br></span>
