<span class="i2">when I was in all that wrath?                                    <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"ffor I haue slaine one of the curteouse[s]t Knights<br></span>
<span class="i2">that euer bestrode a steed!<br></span>
<span class="i0">soe haue I done one [of] the fairest Ladyes<br></span>
<span class="i2">that euer ware womans weede!"                                    <span class="linenum">124</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">ffins]</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_104">[Pg 104]</a><br><a id="Page_105">[Pg 105]</a></span></p><div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>

<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_249"></a><a href="#FNanchor_249" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[249]</span></a> [in splinters he made fly.]</p></div>

<p><a id="Footnote_252"></a><a href="#FNanchor_252" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[252]</span></a> [blamed.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_253"></a><a href="#FNanchor_253" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[253]</span></a> Ver. 128. So Milton,—
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Vernal delight and joy: able to drive<br></span>
<span class="i0">All sadness but despair."—<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">B. iv. v. 155.</p>
</div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_254"></a><a href="#FNanchor_254" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[254]</span></a> [and wiped it on the grass.]</p></div>

<p class="center">THE END OF THE FIRST BOOK.
</p>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 600px;">
<img alt="" height="95" src="images/i105.png" width="600" id="img_images_i105.png">
</div>
<p class="ph1">RELIQUES OF ANCIENT POETRY, ETC.</p>
<p class="ph1">SERIES THE THIRD.</p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2> <a id="BOOK_II">BOOK II.</a></h2>
<div class="figcenter" style="height: 100px;">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i105a.png" id="img_images_i105a.png">
</div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_106">[Pg 106]</a><br><a id="Page_107">[Pg 107]</a></span></p>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 600px;">
<img alt="" height="103" src="images/i107.png" width="600" id="img_images_i107.png">
</div>
<h3>I.<br>

THE LEGEND OF SIR GUY</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i107c.png" id="img_images_i107c.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">Contains</span> a short summary of the exploits of this
famous champion, as recorded in the old story books;
and is commonly intitled, "A pleasant song of the
valiant deeds of chivalry atchieved by that noble knight
sir Guy of Warwick, who, for the love of fair Phelis, became a
hermit, and dyed in a cave of craggy rocke, a mile distant from
Warwick."</p>
<p>The history of Sir Guy, tho' now very properly resigned to
children, was once admired by all readers of wit and taste: for
taste and wit had once their childhood. Although of English
growth, it was early a favourite with other nations: it appeared in
French in 1525; and is alluded to in the old Spanish romance
<i>Tirante el Blanco</i>, which, it is believed, was written not long after
the year 1430. See advertisement to the French translation, 2
vols. 12mo.</p>
<p>The original whence all these stories are extracted is a very
ancient romance in old English verse, which is quoted by Chaucer
as a celebrated piece even in his time (viz.:—</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">"Men speken of romances of price,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Horne childe and Ippotis,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of Bevis, and sir Guy," &amp;c.—<i>R. of Thop.</i>)<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>and was usually sung to the harp at Christmas dinners and
brideales, as we learn from Puttenham's <i>Art of Poetry</i>, 4to. 1589.</p>
<p>This ancient romance is not wholly lost. An imperfect copy in
black letter, "Imprynted at London——for Wylliam Copland,"
in 34 sheets 4to. without date, is still preserved among Mr. Garrick's
collection of old plays. As a specimen of the poetry of
this antique rhymer, take his description of the dragon mentioned
in v. 105 of the following ballad:—</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_108">[Pg 108]</a></span></p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">"——A messenger came to the king.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Syr king, he sayd, lysten me now,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For bad tydinges I bring you,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In Northumberlande there is no man,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But that they be slayne everychone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For there dare no man route,<br></span>
<span class="i0">By twenty myle rounde aboute,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For doubt of a fowle dragon,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That sleath men and beastes downe.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He is blacke as any cole,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rugged as a rough fole;<br></span>
<span class="i0">His bodye from the navill upwarde<br></span>
<span class="i0">No man may it pierce it is so harde;<br></span>
<span class="i0">His neck is great as any summere;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He renneth as swifte as any distrere;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pawes he hath as a lyon:<br></span>
<span class="i0">All that he toucheth he sleath dead downe.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Great winges he hath to flight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That is no man that bare him might.<br></span>
<span class="i0">There may no man fight him agayne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But that he sleath him certayne:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For a fowler beast then is he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ywis of none never heard ye."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>Sir William Dugdale is of opinion that the story of Guy is
not wholly apocryphal, tho' he acknowledges the monks have
sounded out his praises too hyperbolically. In particular, he
gives the duel fought with the Danish champion as a real historical
truth, and fixes the date of it in the year 926, Ætat. Guy, 67. See
his <i>Warwickshire</i>.</p>
<p>The following is written upon the same plan as ballad v. book
i., but which is the original and which the copy cannot be decided.
This song is ancient, as may be inferred from the idiom preserved
in the margin, v. 94, 102: and was once popular, as appears
from Fletcher's <i>Knight of the Burning Pestle</i>, act 2, sc. ult.</p>
<p>It is here published from an ancient MS. copy in the editor's old
folio volume, collated with two printed ones, one of which is in
black letter in the Pepys collection.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Guy was one of the most popular of the heroes of romance, and
the Folio MS. contains three pieces upon his history, viz., the two
printed here and <i>Guy and Colbrand</i>.</p>
<p>The original of the present ballad in the Folio MS., entitled
<i>Guy and Phillis</i> (ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. ii. p. 201), is a
mere fragment beginning with verse 89. Percy tore out certain
leaves to send to the printer, and in consequence the whole of<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_109">[Pg 109]</a></span>
<i>King Estmere</i> and the beginning of this ballad are lost. Alterations
have been made in nearly every verse by the help of the printed
copies. <i>Guy and Phillis</i> was entered on the Stationers' books, 5th
January, 1591-2.</p>
<p>We are told by Dugdale that an English traveller, about the
year 1410, was hospitably received at Jerusalem by the Soldan's
lieutenant, who, hearing that Lord Beauchamp "was descended
from the famous Guy of Warwick, whose story they had in books
of their own language, invited him to his palace; and royally
feasting him, presented him with three precious stones of great
value, besides divers cloaths of silk and gold given to his servants."
Dugdale's authority for this story was John Rous, a priest of the
chapel at Guy's Cliff, near Warwick, who compiled a biography
of the hero, in which all the incidents of the romance are narrated
as sober fact. The constant praises of the hero bored some people,
and Corbet, in his <i>Iter Boreale</i>, expressed the hope that he should
hear no more of him—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"May all the ballads be call'd in and dye<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which sing the warrs of Colebrand and Sir Guy."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>Much valuable information on this subject will be found in Mr.
Hale's interesting introduction to the Guy poems in the Folio MS.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i109.png" id="img_images_i109.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Was ever knight for ladyes sake<br></span>
<span class="i2">Soe tost in love, as I sir Guy<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Phelis fayre, that lady bright<br></span>
<span class="i2">As ever man beheld with eye?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She gave me leave myself to try,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The valiant knight with sheeld and speare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere that her love shee wold grant me;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which made mee venture far and neare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then proved I a baron bold,<a id="FNanchor_257"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_257">[257]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">In deeds of armes the doughtyest knight<br></span>
<span class="i0">That in those dayes in England was,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With sworde and speare in feild to fight.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_110">[Pg 110]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">An English man I was by birthe:<br></span>
<span class="i2">In faith of Christ a christyan true:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The wicked lawes of infidells                                       <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I sought by prowesse to subdue.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Nine' hundred twenty yeere and odde<a id="FNanchor_258"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_258">[258]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">After our Saviour Christ his birth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When king Athèlstone wore the crowne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I lived heere upon the earth.                                     <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sometime I was of Warwicke erle,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And, as I sayd, of very truth<br></span>
<span class="i0">A ladyes love did me constraine<br></span>
<span class="i2">To seeke strange ventures in my youth.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To win me fame by feates of armes                                   <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In strange and sundry heathen lands;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where I atchieved for her sake<br></span>
<span class="i2">Right dangerous conquests with my hands.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For first I sayled to Normandye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And there I stoutlye wan in fight                                 <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The emperours daughter of Almaine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">From manye a vallyant worthye knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then passed I the seas to Greece<br></span>
<span class="i2">To helpe the emperour in his right;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Against the mightye souldans hoaste                                 <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of puissant Persians for to fight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Where I did slay of Sarazens,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And heathen pagans, manye a man;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And slew the souldans cozen deere,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who had to name doughtye Coldràn.                                 <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Eskeldered a famous knight<br></span>
<span class="i2">To death likewise I did pursue:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Elmayne king of Tyre alsoe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Most terrible in fight to viewe.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_111">[Pg 111]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I went into the souldans hoast,                                     <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Being thither on embassage sent,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And brought his head awaye with mee;<br></span>
<span class="i2">I having slaine him in his tent.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There was a dragon in that land<br></span>
<span class="i2">Most fiercelye mett me by the waye                                <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As hee a lyon did pursue,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which I myself did alsoe slay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then soon I past the seas from Greece,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And came to Pavye land aright:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where I the duke of Pavye killed,                                   <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His hainous treason to requite.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To England then I came with speede,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To wedd faire Phelis lady bright:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For love of whome I travelled farr<br></span>
<span class="i2">To try my manhood and my might.                                   <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But when I had espoused her,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I stayd with her but fortye dayes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere that I left this ladye faire,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And went from her beyond the seas.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All cladd in gray, in pilgrim sort,                                 <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My voyage from her I did take<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unto the blessed Holy-land,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For Jesus Christ my Saviours sake.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Where I erle Jonas did redeeme,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all his sonnes which were fifteene,                           <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who with the cruell Sarazens<br></span>
<span class="i2">In prison for long time had beene.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I slew the gyant Amarant<br></span>
<span class="i2">In battel fiercelye hand to hand:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And doughty Barknard killed I,                                      <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">A treacherous knight of Pavye land.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_112">[Pg 112]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then I to England came againe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And here with Colbronde fell I fought:<br></span>
<span class="i0">An ugly gyant, which the Danes<br></span>
<span class="i2">Had for their champion hither brought.                            <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I overcame him in the feild,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And slewe him soone right valliantlye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wherebye this land I did redeeme<br></span>
<span class="i2">From Danish tribute utterlye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And afterwards I offered upp                                        <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The use of weapons solemnlye<br></span>
<span class="i0">At Winchester, whereas I fought,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In sight of manye farr and nye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'But first,' neare Winsor, I did slaye<br></span>
<span class="i2">A bore of passing might and strength;                             <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose like in England never was<br></span>
<span class="i2">For hugenesse both in bredth, and length.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Some of his bones in Warwicke yett,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Within the castle there doe lye:<a id="FNanchor_259"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_259">[259]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">One of his sheeld-bones to this day                                 <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Hangs in the citye of Coventrye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">On Dunsmore heath I alsoe slewe<br></span>
<span class="i2">A monstrous wyld and cruell beast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Calld the Dun-cow of Dunsmore heath;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which manye people had opprest.                                  <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Some of her bones in Warwicke yett<br></span>
<span class="i2">Still for a monument doe lye;<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_259">[259]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And there exposed to lookers viewe<br></span>
<span class="i2">As wonderous strange, they may espye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A dragon in Northumberland,                                        <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I alsoe did in fight destroye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which did bothe man and beast oppresse,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all the countrye sore annoye.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_113">[Pg 113]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At length to Warwicke I did come,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Like pilgrim poore and was not knowne;                           <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And there I lived a hermitts life<br></span>
<span class="i2">A mile and more out of the towne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Where with my hands I hewed a house<br></span>
<span class="i2">Out of a craggy rocke of stone;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And lived like a palmer poore                                      <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Within that cave myself alone:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And daylye came to begg my bread<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of Phelis att my castle gate;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not knowne unto my loved wiffe<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who dailye mourned for her mate.                                 <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Till att the last I fell sore sicke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yea sicke soe sore that I must dye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I sent to her a ring of golde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">By which shee knew me presentlye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then shee repairing to the cave                                    <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Before that I gave up the ghost;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Herself closd up my dying eyes:<br></span>
<span class="i2">My Phelis faire, whom I lovd most.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus dreadful death did me arrest,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To bring my corpes unto the grave;                               <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And like a palmer dyed I,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Wherby I sought my soule to save.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My body that endured this toyle,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Though now it be consumed to mold;<br></span>
<span class="i0">My statue faire engraven in stone,                                 <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In Warwicke still you may behold.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_114">[Pg 114]</a></span></p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_257"></a><a href="#FNanchor_257" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[257]</span></a> Ver. 9. The proud Sir Guy, <i>PC.</i></p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_258"></a><a href="#FNanchor_258" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[258]</span></a> Ver. 17. Two hundred, MS. and P.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_259"></a><a href="#FNanchor_259" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[259]</span></a> Ver. 94, 102, doth lye, MS.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>II.<br>

GUY AND AMARANT.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i114.png" id="img_images_i114.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> Editor found this Poem in his ancient folio manuscript
among the old ballads; he was desirous therefore
that it should still accompany them; and as it is not
altogether devoid of merit, its insertion here will be
pardoned.</p>
<p>Although this piece seems not imperfect, there is reason to
believe that it is only part of a much larger poem, which contained
the whole history of sir Guy: for upon comparing it with the common
story book 12mo. we find the latter to be nothing more than
this poem reduced to prose: which is only effected by now and
then altering the rhyme, and throwing out some few of the poetical
ornaments. The disguise is so slight, that it is an easy matter to
pick complete stanzas in any page of that book.</p>
<p>The author of this poem has shown some invention. Though
he took the subject from the old romance quoted before, he has
adorned it afresh, and made the story intirely his own.</p>
<p>This poem has been discovered to be a fragment of, "The
famous historie of Guy earl of Warwicke, by <i>Samuel Rowlands</i>,
London, printed by J. Bell, 1649, 4to." in xii cantos, beginning
thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"When dreadful Mars in armour every day."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>Whether the edition in 1649, was the first, is not known, but the
author <i>Sam. Rowlands</i> was one of the minor poets who lived in
the reigns of Q. Elizabeth and James I. and perhaps later. His
other poems are chiefly of the religious kind, which makes it probable
that the hist. of Guy was one of his earliest performances.—There
are extant of his (1.) "<i>The betraying of Christ, Judas in</i>
<i>dispaire, the seven words of our Saviour on the crosse, with other</i>
<i>poems on the passion, &amp;c.</i> 1598, 4to. (Ames Typ. p. 428.)—(2.) <i>A</i>
<i>Theatre of delightful Recreation.</i> Lond. printed for A. Johnson,
1605," 4to. (Penes editor.) This is a book of poems on subjects
chiefly taken from the old Testament. (3.) "<i>Memory of Christ's</i>
<i>miracles, in verse.</i> Lond. 1618, 4to." (4.) "<i>Heaven's glory, earth's</i>
<i>vanity, and hell's horror.</i> Lond. 1638, 8vo." (These two in Bod.
Cat.)</p>
<p>In the present edition the following poem has been much
improved from the printed copy.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_115">[Pg 115]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This poem is a very poor thing and looks very like a joke in
some parts. In the Folio MS. Percy has written "By the elegance
of language and easy flow of the versification this poem should be
more modern than the rest."</p>
<p>Mr. Furnivall adds to this expression of opinion the following
note, "the first bombastic rhodomontade affair in the book. Certainly
modern and certainly bad" (Folio MS. ed. Hales and Furnivall,
vol. ii. p. 136.) Collations from the MS. are added at the
foot of the page.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i115.png" id="img_images_i115.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Guy journeyes towards that sanctifyed ground,<a id="FNanchor_260"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_260">[260]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Whereas the Jewes fayre citye sometime stood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wherin our Saviour's sacred head was crowned,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And where for sinfull man he shed his blood:<br></span>
<span class="i0">To see the sepulcher was his intent,                                 <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The tombe that Joseph unto Jesus lent.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With tedious miles he tyred his wearye feet,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And passed desart places full of danger,<br></span>
<span class="i0">At last with a most woefull wight<a id="FNanchor_261"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_261">[261]</a> did meet,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A man that unto sorrow was noe stranger:                          <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For he had fifteen sonnes, made captives all<br></span>
<span class="i0">To slavish bondage, in extremest thrall.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A gyant called Amarant detaind them,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whom noe man durst encounter for his strength:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who in a castle, which he held, had chaind them:                    <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Guy questions, where? and understands at length<br></span>
<span class="i0">The place not farr.—Lend me thy sword, quoth hee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ile lend my manhood all thy sonnes to free.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With that he goes, and lays upon the dore,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Like one that sayes, I must, and will come in:<a id="FNanchor_262"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_262">[262]</a> <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The gyant never was soe rowz'd before;<a id="FNanchor_263"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_263">[263]</a><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_116">[Pg 116]</a></span>
<span class="i2">For noe such knocking at his gate had bin:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Soe takes his keyes, and clubb, and cometh out<br></span>
<span class="i0">Staring with ireful countenance about.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sirra, quoth hee, what busines hast thou heere?<a id="FNanchor_264"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_264">[264]</a> <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Art come to feast the crowes about my walls?<a id="FNanchor_265"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_265">[265]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Didst never heare, noe ransome can him cleere,<a id="FNanchor_266"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_266">[266]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That in the compasse of my furye falls:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For making me to take a porters paines,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With this same clubb I will dash out thy braines.                   <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Gyant, quoth Guy, y'are quarrelsome I see,<a id="FNanchor_267"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_267">[267]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Choller and you seem very neere of kin:<a id="FNanchor_268"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_268">[268]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Most dangerous at the clubb belike you bee;<a id="FNanchor_269"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_269">[269]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">I have bin better armed, though nowe goe thin;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But shew thy utmost hate, enlarge thy spight,                       <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Keene is my weapon, and shall doe me right.<a id="FNanchor_270"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_270">[270]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Soe draws his sword, salutes him with the same<a id="FNanchor_271"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_271">[271]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">About the head, the shoulders, and the side:<a id="FNanchor_272"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_272">[272]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whilst his erected clubb doth death proclaime,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Standinge with huge Colossus' spacious stride,                    <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Putting such vigour to his knotty beame,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That like a furnace he did smoke extreame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But on the ground he spent his strokes in vaine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For Guy was nimble to avoyde them still,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ever ere he heav'd his clubb againe,<a id="FNanchor_273"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_273">[273]</a> <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Did brush his plated coat against his will:<a id="FNanchor_274"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_274">[274]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Att such advantage Guy wold never fayle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To bang him soundlye in his coate of mayle.<a id="FNanchor_275"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_275">[275]</a><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_117">[Pg 117]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Att last through thirst the gyant feeble grewe,<a id="FNanchor_276"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_276">[276]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And sayd to Guy, As thou'rt of humane race,                       <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shew itt in this, give natures wants their dewe,<a id="FNanchor_277"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_277">[277]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Let me but goe, and drinke in yonder place:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou canst not yeeld to "me" a smaller thing,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than to graunt life, thats given by the spring.<a id="FNanchor_278"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_278">[278]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I graunt thee leave, quoth Guye, goe drink thy last,<a id="FNanchor_279"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_279">[279]</a> <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Go pledge the dragon, and the salvage bore<a id="FNanchor_280"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_280">[280]</a>:<a id="FNanchor_281"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_281">[281]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Succeed the tragedyes that they have past,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But never thinke to taste cold water more:<a id="FNanchor_282"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_282">[282]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Drinke deepe to Death and unto him carouse:<a id="FNanchor_283"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_283">[283]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Bid him receive thee in his earthen house.                          <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Soe to the spring he goes, and slakes his thirst;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Takeing the water in extremely like<br></span>
<span class="i0">Some wracked shipp that on a rocke is burst,<a id="FNanchor_284"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_284">[284]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Whose forced hulke against the stones does stryke;<a id="FNanchor_285"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_285">[285]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Scooping it in soe fast with both his hands,                        <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That Guy admiring to behold it stands.<a id="FNanchor_286"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_286">[286]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Come on, quoth Guy, let us to worke againe,<a id="FNanchor_287"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_287">[287]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou stayest about thy liquor overlong;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fish, which in the river doe remaine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Will want thereby; thy drinking doth them wrong:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But I will see their satisfaction made,                             <span class="linenum">71</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With gyants blood they must, and shall be payd.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Villaine, quoth Amarant, Ile crush thee streight;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy life shall pay thy daring toungs offence:<br></span>
<span class="i0">This clubb, which is about some hundred weight,                     <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Is deathes commission to dispatch thee hence:<a id="FNanchor_288"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_288">[288]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Dresse thee for ravens dyett I must needes;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_118">[Pg 118]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And breake thy bones, as they were made of reedes.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Incensed much by these bold pagan bostes,<a id="FNanchor_289"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_289">[289]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Which worthye Guy cold ill endure to heare,                       <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He hewes upon those bigg supporting postes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which like two pillars did his body beare:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Amarant for those wounds in choller growes<br></span>
<span class="i0">And desperatelye att Guy his clubb he throwes:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Which did directly on his body light,                               <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Soe violent, and weighty there-withall,<a id="FNanchor_290"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_290">[290]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">That downe to ground on sudden came the knight;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And, ere he cold recover from the fall,<a id="FNanchor_291"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_291">[291]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">The gyant gott his clubb againe in fist,<a id="FNanchor_292"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_292">[292]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And aimd a stroke that wonderfullye mist.<a id="FNanchor_293"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_293">[293]</a> <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Traytor, quoth Guy, thy falshood Ile repay,<br></span>
<span class="i2">This coward act to intercept my bloode.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sayes Amarant, Ile murther any way,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With enemyes all vantages are good:<br></span>
<span class="i0">O could I poyson in thy nostrills blowe,                            <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Besure of it I wold dispatch thee soe.<a id="FNanchor_294"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_294">[294]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Its well, said Guy, thy honest thoughts appeare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Within that beastlye bulke where devills dwell;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which are thy tenants while thou livest heare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But will be landlords when thou comest in hell:                  <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Vile miscreant, prepare thee for their den,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Inhumane monster, hatefull unto men.<a id="FNanchor_295"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_295">[295]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But breathe thy selfe a time, while I goe drinke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For flameing Phœbus with his fyerye eye<br></span>
<span class="i0">Torments me soe with burning heat, I thinke                        <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My thirst wold serve to drinke an ocean drye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Forbear a litle, as I delt with thee.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_119">[Pg 119]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Amarant, 'Thou hast noe foole of mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Noe, sillye wretch, my father taught more witt,<br></span>
<span class="i2">How I shold use such enemyes as thou;                            <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By all my gods I doe rejoice at itt,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To understand that thirst constraines thee now;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For all the treasure, that the world containes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">One drop of water shall not coole thy vaines.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Releeve my foe! why, 'twere a madmans part:                        <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Refresh an adversarye to my wrong!<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou imagine this, a child thou art:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Noe, fellow, I have known the world too long<br></span>
<span class="i0">To be soe simple: now I know thy want,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A minutes space of breathing I'll not grant.<a id="FNanchor_296"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_296">[296]</a> <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And with these words heaving aloft his clubb<br></span>
<span class="i2">Into the ayre, he swings the same about:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then shakes his lockes, and doth his temples rubb,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And, like the Cyclops, in his pride doth strout:<a id="FNanchor_297"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_297">[297]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sirra, sayes hee, I have you at a lift,                            <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now you are come unto your latest shift.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Perish forever: with this stroke I send thee<br></span>
<span class="i2">A medicine, that will doe thy thirst much good;<a id="FNanchor_298"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_298">[298]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Take noe more care for drinke before I end thee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And then wee'll have carouses of thy blood:                      <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Here's at thee with a butchers downright blow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To please my furye with thine overthrow.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Infernall, false, obdurate feend, said Guy,<a id="FNanchor_299"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_299">[299]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That seemst a lumpe of crueltye from hell;<a id="FNanchor_300"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_300">[300]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Ungratefull monster, since thou dost deny<a id="FNanchor_301"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_301">[301]</a> <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The thing to mee wherin I used thee well:<br></span>
<span class="i0">With more revenge, than ere my sword did make,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_120">[Pg 120]</a></span>
<span class="i0">On thy accursed head revenge Ile take.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thy gyants longitude shall shorter shrinke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Except thy sun-scorcht skin be weapon proof:<a id="FNanchor_302"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_302">[302]</a> <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Farewell my thirst; I doe disdaine to drinke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Streames keepe your waters to your owne behoof;<a id="FNanchor_303"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_303">[303]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or let wild beasts be welcome thereunto;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With those pearle drops I will not have to do.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Here, tyrant, take a taste of my good-will,<a id="FNanchor_304"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_304">[304]</a> <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For thus I doe begin my bloodye bout:<br></span>
<span class="i0">You cannot chuse but like the greeting ill;<br></span>
<span class="i2">It is not that same clubb will beare you out;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And take this payment on thy shaggye crowne.—<br></span>
<span class="i0">A blowe that brought him with a vengeance downe.                   <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Guy sett foot upon the monsters brest,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And from his shoulders did his head divide;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which with a yawninge mouth did gape, unblest;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Noe dragons jawes were ever scene soe wide<br></span>
<span class="i0">To open and to shut, till life was spent.                          <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then Guy tooke keyes and to the castle went.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Where manye woefull captives he did find,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which had beene tyred with extremityes;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whom he in freindly manner did unbind,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And reasoned with them of their miseryes:<a id="FNanchor_305"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_305">[305]</a> <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Eche told a tale with teares, and sighes, and cryes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">All weeping to him with complaining eyes.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There tender ladyes in darke dungeons lay,<a id="FNanchor_306"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_306">[306]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That were surprised in the desart wood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And had noe other dyett everye day,                                <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">But flesh of humane creatures for their food:<a id="FNanchor_307"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_307">[307]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Some with their lovers bodyes had beene fed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in their wombes their husbands buryed.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_121">[Pg 121]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now he bethinkes him of his being there,                           <span class="linenum">169</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To enlarge the wronged brethren from their woes;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, as he searcheth, doth great clamours heare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">By which sad sound's direction on he goes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Untill he findes a darksome obscure gate,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Arm'd strongly ouer all with iron plate.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">That he unlockes, and enters, where appeares,                      <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The strangest object that he ever saw;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Men that with famishment of many yeares,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Were like deathes picture, which the painters draw;<a id="FNanchor_308"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_308">[308]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Divers of them were hanged by eche thombe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Others head-downward: by the middle some.                          <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With diligence he takes them from the walle,<a id="FNanchor_309"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_309">[309]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">With lybertye their thraldome to acquaint:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the perplexed knight their father calls,<a id="FNanchor_310"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_310">[310]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And sayes, Receive thy sonnes though poore and faint:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I promisd you their lives, accept of that;                         <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But did not warrant you they shold be fat.<a id="FNanchor_311"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_311">[311]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The castle I doe give thee, heere's the keyes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where tyranye for many yeeres did dwell:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Procure the gentle tender ladyes ease,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For pittyes sake, use wronged women well:<a id="FNanchor_312"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_312">[312]</a> <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Men easilye revenge the wrongs men do:<a id="FNanchor_313"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_313">[313]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">But poore weake women have not strength thereto.<a id="FNanchor_314"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_314">[314]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The good old man, even overjoyed with this,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Fell on the ground, and wold have kist Guys feete:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Father, quoth he, refraine soe base a kiss,                        <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For age to honor youth I hold unmeete:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ambitious pryde hath hurt mee all it can,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I goe to mortifie a sinfull man.<br></span>
</div></div>

<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_309"></a><a href="#FNanchor_309" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[309]</span></a> [V. 181. walls.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_310"></a><a href="#FNanchor_310" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[310]</span></a> [V. 183. the father.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">
