<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_313"></a><a href="#FNanchor_313" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[313]</span></a> [V. 191. men may easilye revenge the deeds men doe.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_314"></a><a href="#FNanchor_314" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[314]</span></a> [V. 192. no strength. MS.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>III.<br>

THE AULD GOOD-MAN.</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">A Scottish Song.</span>
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i122i.png" id="img_images_i122i.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capi"><span class="smcap">I </span>have not been able to meet with a more ancient
copy of this humourous old song, than that printed in
the <i>Tea-Table miscellany, &amp;c.</i> which seems to have
admitted some corruptions.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This song is printed in Ramsay's <i>Tea-Table Miscellany</i> as old,
and it is also given in the <i>Orpheus Caledonius</i>, 1725. "Auld goodman"
means a first husband.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i122l.png" id="img_images_i122l.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Late in an evening forth I went<br></span>
<span class="i2">A little before the sun gade down,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there I chanc't, by accident,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To light on a battle new begun:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A man and his wife wer fawn<a id="FNanchor_315"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_315">[315]</a> in a strife,                        <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I canna weel tell ye how it began;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But aye she wail'd her wretched life,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Cryeng, Evir alake, mine auld goodman!<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">He.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thy auld goodman, that thou tells of,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The country kens where he was born,                               <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Was but a silly poor vagabond,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And ilka ane leugh him to scorn:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For he did spend and make an end<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of gear 'his fathers nevir' wan;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He gart the poor stand frae the door;                               <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Sae tell nae mair of thy auld goodman.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_123">[Pg 123]</a></span></p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">She.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My heart, alake! is liken to break,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whan I think on my winsome John,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His blinkan ee, and gait sae free,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was naithing like thee, thou dosend<a id="FNanchor_316"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_316">[316]</a> drone;                   <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Wi' his rosie face, and flaxen hair,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And skin as white as ony swan,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He was large and tall, and comely withall;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou'lt nevir be like mine auld goodman.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">He.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Why dost thou plein?<a id="FNanchor_317"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_317">[317]</a> I thee maintein;                          <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For meal and mawt thou disna want:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But thy wild bees I canna please,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Now whan our gear gins to grow scant:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of houshold stuff thou hast enough;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou wants for neither pot nor pan;                               <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Of sicklike ware he left thee bare;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sae tell nae mair of thy auld goodman.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">She.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yes I may tell, and fret my sell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To think on those blyth days I had,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whan I and he, together ley                                         <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In armes into a well-made bed:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now I sigh and may be sad,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy courage is cauld, thy colour wan,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou falds thy feet and fa's asleep;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou'lt nevir be like mine auld goodman.                          <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then coming was the night sae dark,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And gane was a' the light of day?<br></span>
<span class="i0">The carle was fear'd to miss his mark,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And therefore wad nae longer stay:<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_124">[Pg 124]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Then up he gat, and ran his way,                                    <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I trowe, the wife the day she wan;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And aye the owreword<a id="FNanchor_318"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_318">[318]</a> of the fray<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was, Evir alake! mine auld goodman.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_315"></a><a href="#FNanchor_315" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[315]</span></a> [fallen.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_316"></a><a href="#FNanchor_316" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[316]</span></a> [dozing or stupid.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_317"></a><a href="#FNanchor_317" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[317]</span></a> [complain.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_318"></a><a href="#FNanchor_318" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[318]</span></a> [last word or burden.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>IV.<br>

FAIR MARGARET AND SWEET WILLIAM.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i124.png" id="img_images_i124.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> seems to be the old song quoted in Fletcher's
<i>Knight of the burning pestle</i>, acts 2d and 3d; altho' the
six lines there preserved are somewhat different from
those in the ballad, as it stands at present. The reader
will not wonder at this, when he is informed that this is only given
from a modern printed copy picked up on a stall. It's full title is
<i>Fair Margaret's Misfortunes; or Sweet William's frightful dreams</i>
<i>on his wedding night, with the sudden death and burial of those noble</i>
<i>lovers</i>.—</p>
<p>The lines preserved in the play are this distich,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"You are no love for me, Margaret,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I am no love for you."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>And the following stanza,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"When it was grown to dark midnight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all were fast asleep,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In came Margarets grimly ghost<br></span>
<span class="i2">And stood at Williams feet."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>These lines have acquired an importance by giving birth to one
of the most beautiful ballads in our own or any language. See
the song intitled <i>Margaret's Ghost</i>, at the end of this volume.</p>
<p>Since the first edition some improvements have been inserted,
which were communicated by a lady of the first distinction, as she
had heard this song repeated in her infancy.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The ballads on the two lovers Margaret and William are
numerous, culminating as they do in Mallet's <i>William and Mar<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_125">[Pg 125]</a></span>garet</i>.
See <i>Sweet William's Ghost</i> (No. 6 in this book) and
Mallet's ballad (No. 16 of book iii). The present ballad is also
in the Douce Collection and in that of the late Mr. George Daniel.
Jamieson prints (<i>Popular Ballads and Songs</i>, 1806, vol. i. p. 22)
a ballad entitled <i>Sweet Willie and Fair Annie</i>, which may be
divided into two parts, the first resembling <i>Lord Thomas and Fair</i>
<i>Elinor</i>, and the second, <i>Fair Annie's Ghost</i>, is still more like the
following ballad.</p>
<p>Mr. Chappell remarks, "Another point deserving notice in the
old ballad is that one part of it has furnished the principal subject
of the modern burlesque ballad <i>Lord Lovel</i>, and another that of
T. Hood's song, <i>Mary's Ghost</i>."]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i125.png" id="img_images_i125.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As it fell out on a long summer's day<br></span>
<span class="i2">Two lovers they sat on a hill;<br></span>
<span class="i0">They sat together that long summer's day,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And could not talk their fill.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I see no harm by you, Margarèt,                                      <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And you see none by mee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Before to-morrow at eight o' the clock<br></span>
<span class="i2">A rich wedding you shall see.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Fair Margaret sat in her bower-windòw,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Combing her yellow hair;                                          <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">There she spyed sweet William and his bride,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As they were a riding near.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then down she layd her ivory combe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And braided her hair in twain:<br></span>
<span class="i0">She went alive out of her bower,                                    <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">But ne'er came alive in't again.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When day was gone, and night was come,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all men fast asleep,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then came the spirit of fair Marg'ret,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And stood at Williams feet.                                       <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_126">[Pg 126]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Are you awake, sweet William? shee said;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or, sweet William, are you asleep?<br></span>
<span class="i0">God give you joy of your gay bride-bed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And me of my winding-sheet.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When day was come, and night was gone,                              <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And all men wak'd from sleep,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sweet William to his lady sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My dear, I have cause to weep.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I dreamt a dream, my dear ladyè,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Such dreames are never good:                                      <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I dreamt my bower was full of red 'wine,'<a id="FNanchor_319"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_319">[319]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And my bride-bed full of blood.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Such dreams, such dreams, my honoured Sir,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They never do prove good;<br></span>
<span class="i0">To dream thy bower was full of red 'wine,'<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_319">[319]</a> <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And thy bride-bed full of blood.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He called up his merry men all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">By one, by two, and by three;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Saying, I'll away to fair Marg'ret's bower,<br></span>
<span class="i2">By the leave of my ladiè.                                         <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he came to fair Marg'ret's bower,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He knocked at the ring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And who so ready as her seven brethrèn<br></span>
<span class="i2">To let sweet William in.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then he turned up the covering-sheet,                               <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Pray let me see the dead;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Methinks she looks all pale and wan,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She hath lost her cherry red.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I'll do more for thee, Margarèt,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Than any of thy kin;                                              <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For I will kiss thy pale wan lips,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Though a smile I cannot win.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_127">[Pg 127]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With that bespake the seven brethrèn,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Making most piteous mone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">You may go kiss your jolly brown bride,                             <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And let our sister alone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If I do kiss my jolly brown bride,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I do but what is right;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I neer made a vow to yonder poor corpse<br></span>
<span class="i2">By day, nor yet by night.                                         <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Deal on, deal on, my merry men all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Deal on your cake and your wine<a id="FNanchor_320"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_320">[320]</a>:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For whatever is dealt at her funeral to-day,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shall be dealt to-morrow at mine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Fair Margaret dyed to-day, to-day,                                  <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Sweet William dyed the morrow:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fair Margaret dyed for pure true love,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sweet William dyed for sorrow.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Margaret was buryed in the lower chancèl,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And William in the higher:                                        <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Out of her brest there sprang a rose,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And out of his a briar.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">They grew till they grew unto the church-top,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And then they could grow no higher;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there they tyed in a true lovers knot,                          <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Which made all the people admire.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then came the clerk of the parìsh,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As you the truth shall hear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And by misfortune cut them down,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or they had now been there.                                       <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_128">[Pg 128]</a></span></p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_319"></a><a href="#FNanchor_319" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[319]</span></a> Ver. 31, 35. Swine, <i>PCC.</i></p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_320"></a><a href="#FNanchor_320" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[320]</span></a> Alluding to the dole anciently given at funerals.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>V.<br>

BARBARA ALLEN'S CRUELTY.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i128g.png" id="img_images_i128g.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">Given</span>, with some corrections, from an old black letter
copy, intitled, <i>Barbara Allen's cruelty, or the young man's</i>
<i>tragedy</i>.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[It is not clear why Percy separated this English version of
<i>Barbara Allen</i> from the Scottish version entitled <i>Sir John Grehme</i>
<i>and Barbara Allan</i> (No. 7).</p>
<p>Goldsmith in his third Essay says, "the music of the finest
singer is dissonance to what I felt when our dairy maid sung me
into tears with <i>Johnny Armstrong's Last Good Night</i>, or the
<i>Cruelty of Barbara Allen</i>."</p>
<p>It has been suggested that for "Scarlet towne" in the first verse
should be read Carlisle town, but as some printed copies have
Reading town we may suppose that a pun is intended.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i128i.png" id="img_images_i128i.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In Scarlet towne, where I was borne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">There was a faire maid dwellin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Made every youth crye, Wel-awaye!<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her name was Barbara Allen.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All in the merrye month of may,                                      <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">When greene buds they were swellin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yong Jemmye Grove on his death-bed lay,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For love of Barbara Allen.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He sent his man unto her then,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To the town, where shee was dwellin;                              <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">You must come to my master deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Giff your name be Barbara Allen.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For death is printed on his face,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And ore his hart is stealin:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then haste away to comfort him,                                     <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">O lovelye Barbara Allen.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_129">[Pg 129]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Though death be printed on his face,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And ore his harte is stealin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet little better shall he bee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For bonny Barbara Allen.                                          <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So slowly, slowly, she came up,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And slowly she came nye him;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all she sayd, when there she came,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Young man, I think y'are dying.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He turnd his face unto her strait,                                  <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With deadlye sorrow sighing;<br></span>
<span class="i0">O lovely maid, come pity mee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ime on my deth-bed lying.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If on your death-bed you doe lye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">What needs the tale you are tellin:                               <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I cannot keep you from your death;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Farewell, sayd Barbara Allen.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He turnd his face unto the wall,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As deadlye pangs he fell in:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Adieu! adieu! adieu to you all,                                     <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Adieu to Barbara Allen.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As she was walking ore the fields,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She heard the bell a knellin;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And every stroke did seem to saye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unworthy Barbara Allen.                                           <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She turnd her bodye round about,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And spied the corps a coming:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Laye down, laye down the corps, she sayd<br></span>
<span class="i2">That I may look upon him.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With scornful eye she looked downe,                                 <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her cheeke with laughter swellin;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whilst all her friends cryd out amaine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unworthye Barbara Allen.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_130">[Pg 130]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When he was dead, and laid in grave,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her harte was struck with sorrowe,                                <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O mother, mother, make my bed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For I shall dye to-morrowe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hard harted creature him to slight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who loved me so dearlye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">O that I had beene more kind to him,                                <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">When he was alive and neare me!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She, on her death-bed as she laye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Beg'd to be buried by him;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sore repented of the daye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That she did ere denye him.                                       <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Farewell, she sayd, ye virgins all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And shun the fault I fell in:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Henceforth take warning by the fall<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of cruel Barbara Allen.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>VI.<br>

SWEET WILLIAM'S GHOST.</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">A SCOTTISH BALLAD.</span>
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i130.png" id="img_images_i130.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">From</span> Allan Ramsay's <i>Tea-Table Miscellany</i>. The concluding
stanza of this piece seems modern.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[In the previous ballad (No. 4) and in Mallet's <i>William</i>
<i>and Margaret</i> it is Margaret who appears to William, but
in the present one and in some other versions William is made
to die first. In <i>Clerk Saunders</i> (<i>Minstrelsy of the Scottish Border</i>)
Scott has joined two distinct stories, and the second part, in
which the spirit of Clerk Saunders appears to May Margaret,
closely resembles the present ballad. Besides these there are
two other versions. Kinloch's, entitled <span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_131">[Pg 131]</a></span><i>Sweet William and May</i>
<i>Margaret</i>, and Motherwell's <i>William and Marjorie</i>. Dr. Rimbault
points out that the chief incidents in Bürger's <i>Leonora</i> resemble
those in this ballad.</p>
<p>The last two stanzas are probably Ramsay's own.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i131.png" id="img_images_i131.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There came a ghost to Margaret's door,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With many a grievous grone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ay he tirled at the pin;<a id="FNanchor_321"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_321">[321]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">But answer made she none.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Is this my father Philip?                                            <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Or is't my brother John?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or is't my true love Willie,<br></span>
<span class="i2">From Scotland new come home?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Tis not thy father Philip;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor yet thy brother John:                                         <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But tis thy true love Willie<br></span>
<span class="i2">From Scotland new come home,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O sweet Margret! O dear Margret!<br></span>
<span class="i2">I pray thee speak to mee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Give me my faith and troth, Margret,                                <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">As I gave it to thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thy faith and troth thou'se nevir get,<br></span>
<span class="i2">'Of me shalt nevir win,'<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till that thou come within my bower,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And kiss my cheek and chin.                                       <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If I should come within thy bower,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I am no earthly man:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And should I kiss thy rosy lipp,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy days will not be lang.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_132">[Pg 132]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O sweet Margret, O dear Margret,                                    <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I pray thee speak to mee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Give me my faith and troth, Margret,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As I gave it to thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thy faith and troth thou'se nevir get,<br></span>
<span class="i2">'Of me shalt nevir win,'                                          <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Till thou take me to yon kirk yard,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And wed me with a ring.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My bones are buried in a kirk yard<br></span>
<span class="i2">Afar beyond the sea,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And it is but my sprite, Margret,                                   <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That's speaking now to thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She stretched out her lilly-white hand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As for to do her best:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hae there your faith and troth, Willie,<br></span>
<span class="i2">God send your soul good rest.                                     <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now she has kilted her robes of green,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A piece below her knee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And a' the live-lang winter night<br></span>
<span class="i2">The dead corps followed shee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Is there any room at your head, Willie?                             <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Or any room at your feet?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or any room at your side, Willie,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Wherein that I may creep?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There's nae room at my head, Margret,<br></span>
<span class="i2">There's nae room at my feet,                                      <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">There's no room at my side, Margret,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My coffin is made so meet.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then up and crew the red red cock,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And up then crew the gray:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tis time, tis time, my dear Margret,                                <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That 'I' were gane away.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_133">[Pg 133]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[No more the ghost to Margret said,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But, with a grievous grone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Evanish'd in a cloud of mist,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And left her all alone.                                           <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O stay, my only true love, stay,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The constant Margret cried:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wan grew her cheeks, she clos'd her een,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Stretch'd her saft limbs, and died.]<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_321"></a><a href="#FNanchor_321" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[321]</span></a> [See note, <i>ante</i>, p. <a href="#Page_47" class="pginternal">47</a>.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>VII.<br>

SIR JOHN GREHME AND BARBARA ALLAN.</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">A SCOTTISH BALLAD.</span>
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i133p.png" id="img_images_i133p.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">Printed</span>, with a few conjectural emendations, from a
written copy.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Pepys, in Jan. 1665-1666, heard Mrs. Knipp, the
actress, sing "her little Scotch song of <i>Barbery Allen</i>" at Lord
Brouncker's, and he was "in perfect pleasure to hear her sing"
it. It was first printed in Ramsay's <i>Tea-Table Miscellany</i> (ii.
171).</p>
<p>"I remember," says Mr. C. Kirkpatrick Sharpe, "that the
peasantry of Annandale sang many more verses of this ballad
than have appeared in print, but they were of no merit, containing
numerous magnificent offers from the lover to his mistress, and
amongst others some ships in sight, which may strengthen the
belief that this song was composed near the shores of the Solway."—<i>Addit.</i>
<i>Illustrations to Stenhouse.</i>]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i133i.png" id="img_images_i133i.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It was in and about the Martinmas time,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When the greene leaves wer a fallan;<br></span>
<span class="i0">That Sir John Grehme o' the west countrye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Fell in luve wi' Barbara Allan.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_134">[Pg 134]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He sent his man down throw the towne,                                <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To the plaice wher she was dwellan:<br></span>
<span class="i0">O haste and cum to my maister deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Gin ye bin Barbara Allan.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O hooly, hooly raise she up,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To the plaice wher he was lyan;                                   <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And whan she drew the curtain by,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Young man, I think ye're dyan.<a id="FNanchor_322"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_322">[322]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O its I'm sick, and very very sick,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And its a' for Barbara Allan.<br></span>
<span class="i0">O the better for me ye'se never be,                                 <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Though your harts blude wer spillan.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Remember ye nat in the tavern, sir,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whan ye the cups wer fillan;<br></span>
<span class="i0">How ye made the healths gae round and round,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And slighted Barbara Allan?                                       <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He turn'd his face unto the wa'<br></span>
<span class="i2">And death was with him dealan;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Adiew! adiew! my dear friends a',<br></span>
<span class="i2">Be kind to Barbara Allan.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then hooly, hooly raise she up,                                     <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And hooly, hooly left him;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sighan said, she could not stay,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Since death of life had reft him.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She had not gane a mile but twa,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whan she heard the deid-bell knellan;                             <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And everye jow the deid-bell geid,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Cried, Wae to Barbara Allan!<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_135">[Pg 135]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O mither, mither, mak my bed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">O make it saft and narrow:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since my love died for me to-day,                                   <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Ise die for him to morrowe.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">⁂</p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_322"></a><a href="#FNanchor_322" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[322]</span></a> An ingenious friend thinks the rhymes <i>Dyand</i> and <i>Lyand</i>
ought to be transposed; as the taunt <i>Young man, I think ye're</i>
<i>yand</i>, would be very characteristical.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>VIII.<br>

THE BAILIFF'S DAUGHTER OF ISLINGTON.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i135f.png" id="img_images_i135f.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">From</span> an ancient black-letter copy in the Pepys <i>Collection</i>,
with some improvements communicated by a lady as
she had heard the same recited in her youth. The full
title is, <i>True love requited: Or, the Bailiff's daughter of</i>
<i>Islington</i>.</p>
<p><i>Islington</i> in Norfolk is probably the place here meant.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Copies of this charming old ballad are found in all the large
collections, and two tunes are associated with it.</p>
<p>Percy's suggestion that Islington in Norfolk is referred to is not
a probable one, and there seems to be no reason for depriving the
better known Islington of the south of the honour of having given
birth to the bailiff's daughter. Islington at the time when this
ballad was written was a country village quite unconnected with
London, and a person who represented "a squier minstrel of
Middlesex" made a speech before Queen Elizabeth at Kenilworth
in 1575, in which he declared "how the worshipful village of Islington
[was] well knooen too bee one of the most auncient and best
tounz in England, next to London."]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i135t.png" id="img_images_i135t.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There was a youthe, and a well-beloved youthe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And he was a squires son;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He loved the bayliffes daughter deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That lived in Islington.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_136">[Pg 136]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet she was coye and would not believe                               <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That he did love her soe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Noe nor at any time would she<br></span>
<span class="i2">Any countenance to him showe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But when his friendes did understand<br></span>
<span class="i2">His fond and foolish minde,                                       <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They sent him up to faire London<br></span>
<span class="i2">An apprentice for to binde.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he had been seven long yeares,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And never his love could see:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many a teare have I shed for her sake,                              <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">When she little thought of mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then all the maids of Islington<br></span>
<span class="i2">Went forth to sport and playe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">All but the bayliffes daughter deare;<br></span>
<span class="i2">She secretly stole awaye.                                         <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She pulled off her gowne of greene,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And put on ragged attire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to faire London she would go<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her true love to enquire.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And as she went along the high road,                                <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The weather being hot and drye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She sat her downe upon a green bank,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And her true love came riding bye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She started up, with a colour soe redd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Catching hold of his bridle-reine;                                <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">One penny, one penny, kind sir, she sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Will ease me of much paine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Before I give you one penny, sweet-heart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Praye tell me where you were borne.<br></span>
<span class="i0">At Islington, kind sir, sayd shee,                                  <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Where I have had many a scorne.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_137">[Pg 137]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I prythee, sweet-heart, then tell to mee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">O tell me, whether you knowe<br></span>
<span class="i0">The bayliffes daughter of Islington,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She is dead, sir, long agoe.                                      <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If she be dead, then take my horse,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My saddle and bridle also;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I will into some farr countrye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where noe man shall me knowe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O staye, O staye, thou goodlye youthe,                              <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">She standeth by thy side;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She is here alive, she is not dead,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And readye to be thy bride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O farewell griefe, and welcome joye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ten thousand times therefore;                                     <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For nowe I have founde mine owne true love,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whom I thought I should never see more.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>IX.<br>

THE WILLOW TREE.</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">A Pastoral Dialogue.</span>
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i137.png" id="img_images_i137.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">From</span> the small black-letter collection, intitled, <i>The</i>
<i>Golden Garland of princely delights</i>; collated with
two other copies, and corrected by conjecture.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Dr. Rimbault gives the melody of this pretty little pastoral
on the favourite subject of wearing the willow from a MS. dated
1639 in the Advocate's Library, Edinburgh. It is also to be
found in the celebrated Skene MS. in the same library, and again
in all the editions of Forbes's <i>Cantus</i>.]</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_138">[Pg 138]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Willy.</span>
</p>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i138.png" id="img_images_i138.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">How now, shepherde, what meanes that?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Why that willowe in thy hat?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Why thy scarffes of red and yellowe<br></span>
<span class="i0">Turn'd to branches of greene willowe?<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Cuddy.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">They are chang'd, and so am I;                                       <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sorrowes live, but pleasures die:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Phillis hath forsaken mee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which makes me weare the willowe-tree.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Willy.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Phillis! shee that lov'd thee long?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is shee the lass hath done thee wrong?                              <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shee that lov'd thee long and best,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is her love turn'd to a jest?<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Cuddy.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee that long true love profest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She hath robb'd my heart of rest:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For she a new love loves, not mee;                                  <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Which makes me wear the willowe-tree.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Willy.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Come then, shepherde, let us joine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since thy happ is like to mine:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For the maid I thought most true,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Mee hath also bid adieu.                                            <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Cuddy.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thy hard happ doth mine appease,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Companye doth sorrowe ease:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet, Phillis, still I pine for thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And still must weare the willowe-tree.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_139">[Pg 139]</a></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Willy.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shepherde, be advis'd by mee,                                       <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Cast off grief and willowe-tree:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thy grief brings her content,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She is pleas'd if thou lament.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Cuddy.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Herdsman, I'll be rul'd by thee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">There lyes grief and willowe-tree:                                  <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Henceforth I will do as they,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And love a new love every day.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>X.<br>

THE LADY'S FALL</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i139.png" id="img_images_i139.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capi"><span class="smcap">Is</span> given (with corrections) from the Editor's ancient folio
MS.<a id="FNanchor_323"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_323">[323]</a> collated with two printed copies in black-letter;
one in the British Museum, the other in the Pepys
Collection. Its old title is, <i>A lamentable ballad of the</i>
<i>Lady's fall</i>. To the tune of, <i>In Pescod time, &amp;c.</i>—The ballad
here referred to is preserved in the <i>Muses Library</i>, 8vo. p. 281.
It is an allegory or vision, intitled, <i>The Shepherd's Slumber</i>, and
opens with some pretty rural images, viz.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"In pescod time when hound to horn<br></span>
<span class="i2">Gives eare till buck be kil'd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And little lads with pipes of corne<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sate keeping beasts a-field."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"I went to gather strawberries<br></span>
<span class="i0">By woods and groves full fair, &amp;c."<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Mr. Hales thinks it possible that this ballad was written by the
same author as <i>The Children in the Wood</i>—"the same facility of
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_140">[Pg 140]</a></span>language and of rhyme, the same power of pathos, the same
extreme simplicity characterise both ballads."</p>
<p>Mr. Chappell says that <i>Chevy Chace</i> was sometimes sung to the
tune of <i>In Pescod time</i>, as were the <i>Bride's burial</i> (No. 12), and
<i>Lady Isabella's Tragedy</i> (No. 14). The various readings from the
original MS. are noted at the foot of the page.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i140.png" id="img_images_i140.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Marke well my heavy dolefull tale,<br></span>
<span class="i2">You loyall lovers all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And heedfully beare in your brest,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A gallant ladyes fall.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Long was she wooed, ere shee was wonne,                              <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To lead a wedded life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But folly wrought her overthrowe<br></span>
<span class="i2">Before she was a wife.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Too soone, alas! shee gave consent<br></span>
<span class="i2">And yeelded to his will,                                          <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Though he protested to be true,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And faithfull to her still.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shee felt her body altered quite,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her bright hue waxed pale,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her lovelye cheeks chang'd color white,<a id="FNanchor_324"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_324">[324]</a> <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her strength began to fayle.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Soe that with many a sorrowful sigh,<a id="FNanchor_325"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_325">[325]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">This beauteous ladye milde,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With greeved hart, perceived herselfe<br></span>
<span class="i2">To have conceived with childe.<a id="FNanchor_326"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_326">[326]</a> <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shee kept it from her parents sight<br></span>
<span class="i2">As close as close might bee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And soe put on her silken gowne<br></span>
<span class="i2">None might her swelling see.<a id="FNanchor_327"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_327">[327]</a><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_141">[Pg 141]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Unto her lover secretly                                             <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her greefe shee did bewray,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And walking with him hand in hand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">These words to him did say;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Behold, quoth shee, a maids distresse<a id="FNanchor_328"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_328">[328]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">By love brought to thy bowe;<a id="FNanchor_329"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_329">[329]</a> <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Behold I goe with childe by thee,<a id="FNanchor_330"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_330">[330]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Tho none thereof doth knowe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The litle babe springs in my wombe<a id="FNanchor_331"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_331">[331]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">To heare its fathers voyce,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lett it not be a bastard called,<a id="FNanchor_332"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_332">[332]</a> <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Sith I made thee my choyce:<br></span>
<span class="i0">[Come, come, my love, perform thy vowe<a id="FNanchor_333"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_333">[333]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And wed me out of hand;<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_333">[333]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">O leave me not in this extreme<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_333">[333]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of griefe, alas! to stand.]<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_333">[333]</a> <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Think on thy former promises,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy oathes and vowes eche one;<a id="FNanchor_334"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_334">[334]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Remember with what bitter teares<br></span>
<span class="i2">To mee thou madest thy moane.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Convay me to some secrett place,                                    <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And marry me with speede;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or with thy rapyer end my life,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ere further shame proceede.<a id="FNanchor_335"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_335">[335]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Alacke! my beauteous love, quoth hee,<a id="FNanchor_336"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_336">[336]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">My joye, and only dear;<a id="FNanchor_337"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_337">[337]</a> <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Which way can I convay thee hence,<a id="FNanchor_338"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_338">[338]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">When dangers are so near?<a id="FNanchor_339"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_339">[339]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy friends are all of hye degree,<a id="FNanchor_340"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_340">[340]</a><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_142">[Pg 142]</a></span>
<span class="i2">And I of meane estate;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full hard it is to gett thee forthe<a id="FNanchor_341"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_341">[341]</a> <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Out of thy fathers gate.<a id="FNanchor_342"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_342">[342]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Dread not thy life to save my fame,<a id="FNanchor_343"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_343">[343]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">For if thou taken bee,<a id="FNanchor_344"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_344">[344]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">My selfe will step betweene the swords,<a id="FNanchor_345"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_345">[345]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And take the harme on mee:<a id="FNanchor_346"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_346">[346]</a> <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Soe shall I scape dishonor quite;<a id="FNanchor_347"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_347">[347]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And if I should be slaine<a id="FNanchor_348"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_348">[348]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">What could they say, but that true love<br></span>
<span class="i2">Had wrought a ladyes bane.<a id="FNanchor_349"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_349">[349]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But feare not any further harme;                                    <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My selfe will soe devise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That I will ryde away with thee<a id="FNanchor_350"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_350">[350]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Unknowen of mortall eyes:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Disguised like some pretty page<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ile meete thee in the darke,                                      <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And all alone Ile come to thee<br></span>
<span class="i2">Hard by my fathers parke.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And there, quoth hee, Ile meete my deare<br></span>
<span class="i2">If God soe lend me life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On this day month without all fayle                                 <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I will make thee my wife.<a id="FNanchor_351"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_351">[351]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then with a sweet and loving kisse,<a id="FNanchor_352"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_352">[352]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">They parted presentlye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And att their partinge brinish teares<br></span>
<span class="i2">Stoode in eche others eye,                                        <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_143">[Pg 143]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Att length the wished day was come,<a id="FNanchor_353"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_353">[353]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">On which this beauteous mayd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With longing eyes, and strange attire,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For her true lover stayd.<br></span>
<span class="i0">When any person shee espyed<a id="FNanchor_354"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_354">[354]</a> <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Come ryding ore the plaine,<a id="FNanchor_355"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_355">[355]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">She hop'd it was her owne true love:<a id="FNanchor_356"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_356">[356]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">But all her hopes were vaine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then did shee weepe and sore bewayle<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her most unhappy fate;                                            <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then did shee speake these woefull words,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As succourless she sate;<a id="FNanchor_357"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_357">[357]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">O false, forsworne, and faithlesse man,<a id="FNanchor_358"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_358">[358]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Disloyall in thy love,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hast thou forgott thy promise past,                                 <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And wilt thou perjured prove?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And hast thou now forsaken mee<br></span>
<span class="i2">In this my great distresse,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To end my dayes in open shame,<a id="FNanchor_359"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_359">[359]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Which thou mightst well redresse?<a id="FNanchor_360"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_360">[360]</a> <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Woe worth the time I eer believ'd<a id="FNanchor_361"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_361">[361]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That flattering tongue of thine:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wold God that I had never seene<br></span>
<span class="i2">The teares of thy false eyne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And thus with many a sorrowful sigh,<a id="FNanchor_362"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_362">[362]</a> <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Homewards shee went againe;<a id="FNanchor_363"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_363">[363]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Noe rest came in her waterye eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shee felt such privye paine.<a id="FNanchor_364"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_364">[364]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">In travail strong shee fell that night,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_144">[Pg 144]</a></span>
<span class="i2">With many a bitter throwe;<a id="FNanchor_365"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_365">[365]</a> <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">What woefull paines shee then did feel,<a id="FNanchor_366"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_366">[366]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Doth eche good woman knowe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee called up her waiting mayd,<a id="FNanchor_367"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_367">[367]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That lay at her bedds feete,<a id="FNanchor_368"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_368">[368]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who musing at her mistress woe,<a id="FNanchor_369"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_369">[369]</a> <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Began full fast to weepe.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Weepe not, said shee, but shutt the dores,<a id="FNanchor_370"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_370">[370]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And windowes round about,<a id="FNanchor_371"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_371">[371]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Let none bewray my wretched state,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But keepe all persons out.                                       <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O mistress, call your mother deare;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of women you have neede,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And of some skilfull midwifes helpe,<a id="FNanchor_372"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_372">[372]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">That better may you speed.<a id="FNanchor_373"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_373">[373]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Call not my mother for thy life,                                   <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor fetch no woman here;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The midwives helpe comes all too late,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My death I doe not feare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With that the babe sprang from her wombe<br></span>
<span class="i2">No creature being nye,<a id="FNanchor_374"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_374">[374]</a> <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And with one sighe, which brake her hart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">This gentle dame did dye.<a id="FNanchor_375"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_375">[375]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">The lovely litle infant younge,<a id="FNanchor_376"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_376">[376]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">[The mother being dead,]<a id="FNanchor_377"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_377">[377]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Resigned its new received breath,                                  <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To him that had it made.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_145">[Pg 145]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Next morning came her own true love,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Affrighted at the newes,<a id="FNanchor_378"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_378">[378]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he for sorrow slew himselfe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whom eche one did accuse.                                        <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The mother with her new borne babe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Were laide both in one grave:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their parents overworne with woe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">No joy thenceforth cold have.<a id="FNanchor_379"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_379">[379]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Take heed, you dayntye damsells all,                               <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of flattering words beware,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to the honour of your name<br></span>
<span class="i2">Have an especial care.<a id="FNanchor_380"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_380">[380]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">[Too true, alas! this story is,<a id="FNanchor_381"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_381">[381]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">As many one can tell:<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_381">[381]</a> <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">By others harmes learne to be wise,<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_381">[381]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And you shall do full well.]<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_381">[381]</a><br></span>
</div></div>

<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_360"></a><a href="#FNanchor_360" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[360]</span></a> [V. 100. which well thou might.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_361"></a><a href="#FNanchor_361" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[361]</span></a> [V. 101. I did beleeve.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_362"></a><a href="#FNanchor_362" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[362]</span></a> [V. 105. soe that with many a grievous groane.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_363"></a><a href="#FNanchor_363" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[363]</span></a> [V. 106. amaine.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_364"></a><a href="#FNanchor_364" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[364]</span></a> [V. 108. shee found.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_365"></a><a href="#FNanchor_365" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[365]</span></a> [Ver. 110. thraw.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_366"></a><a href="#FNanchor_366" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[366]</span></a> [V. 111. shee felt that night.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_367"></a><a href="#FNanchor_367" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[367]</span></a> [V. 113. mayd.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_368"></a><a href="#FNanchor_368" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[368]</span></a> [V. 114. who lay.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_369"></a><a href="#FNanchor_369" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[369]</span></a> [V. 115. and musing at her great woe.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_370"></a><a href="#FNanchor_370" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[370]</span></a> [V. 117. shee sayth.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_371"></a><a href="#FNanchor_371" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[371]</span></a> [V. 118. all about.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_372"></a><a href="#FNanchor_372" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[372]</span></a> [V. 123. and to some.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_373"></a><a href="#FNanchor_373" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[373]</span></a> [V. 124. the better.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_374"></a><a href="#FNanchor_374" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[374]</span></a> [V. 130. being by.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_375"></a><a href="#FNanchor_375" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[375]</span></a> [V. 132. gallant dame.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_376"></a><a href="#FNanchor_376" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[376]</span></a> [V. 133. litle lovely.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_377"></a><a href="#FNanchor_377" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[377]</span></a> [V. 134. the pretty smiling babe.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_378"></a><a href="#FNanchor_378" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[378]</span></a> [Ver. 138. with this newes.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_379"></a><a href="#FNanchor_379" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[379]</span></a> [V. 144. no joy that they.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_380"></a><a href="#FNanchor_380" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[380]</span></a> [V. 148. have you a specyall care.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_381"></a><a href="#FNanchor_381" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[381]</span></a> [V. 149-152. not in MS.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XI.<br>

WALY WALY, LOVE BE BONNY.</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">A Scottish Song.</span>
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i145.png" id="img_images_i145.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> is a very ancient song, but we could only give it
from a modern copy. Some editions instead of the
four last lines in the second stanza have these, which
have too much merit to be wholly suppressed:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Whan cockle shells turn siller bells,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And muscles grow on every tree,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When frost and snaw sall warm us aw',<br></span>
<span class="i2">Than sall my love prove true to me."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>
<span class="stageright">See the <i>Orpheus Caledonius, &amp;c.</i></span><br>
</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_146">[Pg 146]</a></span></p>
<p>Arthur's-seat mentioned in ver. 17, is a hill near Edinborough;
near the bottom of which is St. Anthony's well.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[There has been considerable difference of opinion among ballad
collectors relative to this beautiful song. Some suppose it to be
a portion of the ballad entitled <i>Lord Jamie Douglas</i>, which relates
to James Douglas, second Marquis of Douglas, who married Lady
Barbara Erskine, eldest daughter of John, ninth Earl of Mar, on
the seventh of September, 1670, and afterwards repudiated her
on account of a false accusation of adultery made against her by
Lowrie, laird of Blackwood. Prof. Aytoun, however, believes that
certain verses of <i>Waly Waly</i> have wrongly been mixed up with
<i>Lord Jamie Douglas</i>. There is very little doubt that the song was
in existence long before 1670, and it also appears to be the
lamentation of a forsaken girl rather than of a wife. Mr. Stenhouse
and others considered it to belong to the age of Queen
Mary and to refer to some affair at Court. Aytoun writes, "there is
also evidence that it was composed before 1566, for there is extant
a MS. of that year in which some of the lines are transcribed," but
Mr. Maidment gives the following opinion—"that the ballad is
of ancient date is undoubted, but we are not quite prepared to
admit that it goes back as far as 1566, the date of the manuscript
transcribed by Thomas Wode from an ancient church music book
compiled by Dean John Angus, Andrew Blackhall, and others, in
which it said the first [second] stanza is thus parodied:—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hey trollie lollie, love is jollie,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A quhile, quhil itt is new<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quhen it is old, it grows full cold,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Wae worth the love untrue.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>Never having had access to the MS., we may be permitted to
remark that the phraseology of the burlesque is not exactly that
of the reign of Queen Mary" (<i>Scottish Ballads and Songs</i>, 1868,
vol. ii. p. 49.)</p>
<p>Allan Ramsay was the first to publish the song, and he marked
it as ancient.</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"When cockle shells turn silver bells,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When wine drieps red frae ilka tree,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When frost and snaw will warm us a'<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then I'll cum down and dine wi' thee,"<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>is the fourth stanza of <i>Jamie Douglas</i>, printed by John Finlay, in
his <i>Scottish Historical and Romantic Ballads</i> (vol. ii.)]</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_147">[Pg 147]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i147.png" id="img_images_i147.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O waly<a id="FNanchor_382"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_382">[382]</a> waly up the bank,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And waly waly down the brae,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And waly waly yon burn side,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where I and my love wer wont to gae.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I leant my back unto an aik,                                         <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I thought it was a trusty tree;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But first it bow'd, and syne it brak,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sae my true love did lichtly me.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O waly, waly, gin love be bonny,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A little time while it is new;                                    <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But when its auld, it waxeth cauld,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fades awa' like morning dew.<br></span>
<span class="i0">O wherfore shuld I busk my head?<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or wherfore shuld I kame my hair?<br></span>
<span class="i0">For my true love has me forsook,                                    <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And says he'll never loe me mair.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now Arthur-seat sall be my bed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The sheets shall neir be fyl'd<a id="FNanchor_383"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_383">[383]</a> by me:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Saint Anton's well sall be my drink,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Since my true love has forsaken me.                               <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Marti'mas wind, when wilt thou blaw,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And shake the green leaves aff the tree?<br></span>
<span class="i0">O gentle death, whan wilt thou cum?<br></span>
<span class="i2">For of my life I am wearìe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Tis not the frost, that freezes fell,                               <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor blawing snaws inclemencìe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis not sic cauld, that makes me cry,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But my loves heart grown cauld to me.<br></span>
<span class="i0">When we came in by Glasgowe town,<br></span>
<span class="i2">We were a comely sight to see,                                    <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">My love was cled in black velvet,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And I my-sell in cramasie.<a id="FNanchor_384"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_384">[384]</a><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_148">[Pg 148]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But had I wist, before I kisst,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That love had been sae ill to win;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I had lockt my heart in a case of gowd,                             <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And pinnd it with a siller pin.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, oh! if my young babe were born,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And set upon the nurses knee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I my sell were dead and gane!<br></span>
<span class="i2">For a maid again Ise never be.                                    <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_382"></a><a href="#FNanchor_382" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[382]</span></a> [interjection of lamentation.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_383"></a><a href="#FNanchor_383" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[383]</span></a> [defiled.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_384"></a><a href="#FNanchor_384" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[384]</span></a> [crimson.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XII.<br>

THE BRIDE'S BURIAL.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i148f.png" id="img_images_i148f.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">From</span> two ancient copies in black-letter: one in the
Pepys Collection; the other in the British Museum.</p>
<p class="center">To the tune of <i>The Lady's Fall</i>.
</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i148c.png" id="img_images_i148c.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Come mourne, come mourne with mee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">You loyall lovers all;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lament my loss in weeds of woe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whom griping grief doth thrall.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Like to the drooping vine,                                           <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Cut by the gardener's knife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Even so my heart, with sorrow slaine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Doth bleed for my sweet wife.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">By death, that grislye ghost,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My turtle dove is slaine,                                         <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I am left, unhappy man,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To spend my dayes in paine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her beauty late so bright,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Like roses in their prime,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is wasted like the mountain snowe,                                  <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Before warme Phebus' shine.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_149">[Pg 149]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her faire red colour'd cheeks<br></span>
<span class="i2">Now pale and wan; her eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That late did shine like crystal stars;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Alas, their light it dies:                                        <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her prettye lilly hands,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With fingers long and small,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In colour like the earthly claye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yea, cold and stiff withall.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When as the morning star                                            <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her golden gates had spred,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that the glittering sun arose<br></span>
<span class="i2">Forth from fair Thetis' bed;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then did my love awake,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Most like a lilly-flower,                                         <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And as the lovely queene of heaven,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So shone shee in her bower.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Attired was shee then,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Like Flora in her pride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Like one of bright Diana's nymphs,                                  <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">So look'd my loving bride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And as fair Helen's face,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did Grecian dames besmirche,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So did my dear exceed in sight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All virgins in the church.                                        <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When we had knitt the knott<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of holy wedlock-band,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Like alabaster joyn'd to jett,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So stood we hand in hand;<br></span>
