</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then lo! a chilling cold                                            <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Strucke every vital part,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And griping grief, like pangs of death,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Seiz'd on my true love's heart.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_150">[Pg 150]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Down in a swoon she fell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As cold as any stone;                                             <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Like Venus picture lacking life,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So was my love brought home.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At length her rosye red,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Throughout her comely face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As Phœbus beames with watry cloudes                              <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Was cover'd for a space.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When with a grievous groane,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And voice both hoarse and drye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Farewell, quoth she, my loving friend,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For I this daye must dye;                                         <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The messenger of God,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With golden trumpe I see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With manye other angels more,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which sound and call for mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Instead of musicke sweet,                                           <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Go toll my passing-bell;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with sweet flowers strow my grave,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That in my chamber smell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Strip off my bride's arraye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My cork shoes from my feet;                                       <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And, gentle mother, be not coye<br></span>
<span class="i2">To bring my winding-sheet.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My wedding dinner drest,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Bestowe upon the poor,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And on the hungry, needy, maimde,                                   <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Now craving at the door.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Instead of virgins yong,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My bride-bed for to see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Go cause some cunning carpenter,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To make a chest for mee.                                          <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_151">[Pg 151]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My bride laces of silk<br></span>
<span class="i2">Bestowd, for maidens meet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">May fitly serve, when I am dead,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To tye my hands and feet.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And thou, my lover true,                                            <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My husband and my friend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let me intreat thee here to staye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Until my life doth end.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now leave to talk of love,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And humblye on your knee,                                         <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Direct your prayers unto God:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But mourn no more for mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In love as we have livde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In love let us depart;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I, in token of my love,                                         <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Do kiss thee with my heart.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O staunch those bootless teares,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy weeping tis in vaine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I am not lost, for wee in heaven<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shall one daye meet againe.                                      <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With that shee turn'd aside,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As one dispos'd to sleep,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And like a lamb departed life;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whose friends did sorely weep.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her true love seeing this,                                         <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Did fetch a grievous groane,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As tho' his heart would burst in twaine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And thus he made his moane.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O darke and dismal daye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A daye of grief and care,                                        <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That hath bereft the sun so bright,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whose beams refresht the air.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_152">[Pg 152]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now woe unto the world,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all that therein dwell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">O that I were with thee in heaven,                                 <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For here I live in hell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And now this lover lives<br></span>
<span class="i2">A discontented life,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose bride was brought unto the grave<br></span>
<span class="i2">A maiden and a wife.                                             <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A garland fresh and faire<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of lillies there was made,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In sign of her virginitye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And on her coffin laid.<a id="FNanchor_385"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_385">[385]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Six maidens, all in white,                                         <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Did beare her to the ground:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The bells did ring in solemn sort,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And made a dolefull sound.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In earth they laid her then,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For hungry wormes a preye;                                       <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So shall the fairest face alive<br></span>
<span class="i2">At length be brought to claye.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_153">[Pg 153]</a></span></p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_385"></a><a href="#FNanchor_385" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[385]</span></a> ["It was an ancient and pleasing custom to place a garland
made of white flowers and white riband upon the coffin of a
maiden; it was afterwards hung up over her customary seat in
church. Sometimes a pair of white gloves, or paper cut to the
shape of gloves, was hung beneath the garland. Chaplets of the
kind still hang in some of the Derbyshire churches, and at Hathersage
in that county the custom is still retained."—(<i>Transactions of</i>
<i>the Essex Archælogical Society</i>, vol. i. 1858, p. 118.) See <i>Corydon's</i>
<i>Doleful Knell</i>, vol. ii. book ii. No. 27, p. 275. Ophelia is "allowed
her virgin crants" (or garland)—<i>Hamlet</i>, act v. sc. 1. See also an
interesting article on <i>Funeral Garlands</i> by Llewellyn Jewitt in the
<i>Reliquary</i>, vol. i. (1860), p. 5.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XIII.<br>

DULCINA.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i153g.png" id="img_images_i153g.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">Given</span> from two ancient copies, one in black-print, in
the Pepys Collection: the other in the Editor's folio
MS. Each of these contained a stanza not found in
the other. What seemed the best readings were
selected from both.</p>
<p>This song is quoted as very popular in Walton's <i>Compleat Angler</i>,
chap. ii. It is more ancient than the ballad of <i>Robin Good-Fellow</i>
printed below, which yet is supposed to have been written by Ben.
Jonson.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The Milk-woman in Walton's <i>Angler</i> says, "What song was it,
I pray you? Was it <i>Come shepherds deck your heads</i>, or <i>As at</i>
<i>noon Dulcina rested</i>?"</p>
<p>In the Registers of the Stationers' Company, under date of
May 22, 1615, there is an entry transferring the right of publication
from one printer to another of <i>A Ballett of Dulcina to the tune of</i>
<i>Forgoe me nowe, come to me sone</i>. Mr. Chappell also tells us that
<i>Dulcina</i> was one of the tunes to the "Psalms and Songs of Sion,
turned into the language and set to the tunes of a strange land,"
1642.</p>
<p>The editors of the Folio MS., more scrupulous than the bishop,
have not printed this song in its proper place, but have turned it
into the Supplement of <i>Loose and Humourous Songs</i> (p. <a href="#Page_32" class="pginternal">32</a>). The
third stanza of the MS. beginning</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Words whose hopes might have enjoyned"<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>is not printed in the present copy. The third stanza here is the
fourth of the MS., and the fourth stanza is not in the MS. at all.</p>
<p>Cayley and Ellis attribute this song to Raleigh, but without
sufficient authority.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i153a.png" id="img_images_i153a.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As at noone Dulcina rested<br></span>
<span class="i2">In her sweete and shady bower;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Came a shepherd, and requested<br></span>
<span class="i2">In her lapp to sleepe an hour.<br></span>
<span class="i6">But from her looke                                             <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">A wounde he tooke<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_154">[Pg 154]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Soe deepe, that for a further boone<br></span>
<span class="i4">The nymph he prayes.<br></span>
<span class="i4">Wherto shee sayes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Forgoe me now, come to me soone.                                    <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But in vayne shee did conjure him<br></span>
<span class="i2">To depart her presence soe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Having a thousand tongues to allure him,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And but one to bid him goe:<br></span>
<span class="i6">Where lipps invite,                                           <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">And eyes delight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And cheekes, as fresh as rose in june,<br></span>
<span class="i6">Persuade delay;<br></span>
<span class="i6">What boots, she say,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Forgoe me now, come to me soone?                                  <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He demands what time for pleasure<br></span>
<span class="i2">Can there be more fit than now:<br></span>
<span class="i0">She sayes, night gives love that leysure,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which the day can not allow.<br></span>
<span class="i6">He sayes, the sight                                           <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">'Improves delight.<br></span>
<span class="i2">'Which she denies: Nights mirkie noone<br></span>
<span class="i6">In Venus' playes<br></span>
<span class="i6">Makes bold, shee sayes;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Forgoe me now, come to mee soone.                                 <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But what promise or profession<br></span>
<span class="i2">From his hands could purchase scope?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who would sell the sweet possession<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of suche beautye for a hope?<br></span>
<span class="i6">Or for the sight                                              <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">Of lingering night<br></span>
<span class="i2">Foregoe the present joyes of noone?<br></span>
<span class="i6">Though ne'er soe faire<br></span>
<span class="i6">Her speeches were,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Forgoe me now, come to me soone.                                    <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_155">[Pg 155]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">How, at last, agreed these lovers?<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shee was fayre, and he was young:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The tongue may tell what th'eye discovers;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Joyes unseene are never sung.<br></span>
<span class="i6">Did shee consent,                                             <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">Or he relent;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Accepts he night, or grants shee noone;<br></span>
<span class="i6">Left he her a mayd,<br></span>
<span class="i6">Or not; she sayd<br></span>
<span class="i2">Forgoe me now, come to me soone.                                  <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XIV.<br>

THE LADY ISABELLA'S TRAGEDY.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i155.png" id="img_images_i155.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> ballad is given from an old black-letter copy in the
Pepys Collection, collated with another in the British
Museum, H. 263, folio. It is there intitled, "<i>The Lady</i>
<i>Isabella's Tragedy, or the Step-Mother's Cruelty</i>: being
a relation of a lamentable and cruel murther, committed on the
body of the lady Isabella, the only daughter of a noble duke, &amp;c.
To the tune of, <i>The Lady's Fall</i>." To some copies are annexed
eight more modern stanzas, intitled, <i>The Dutchess's and Cook's</i>
<i>Lamentation</i>.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i155t.png" id="img_images_i155t.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There was a lord of worthy fame,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And a hunting he would ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Attended by a noble traine<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of gentrye by his side.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And while he did in chase remaine,                                   <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To see both sport and playe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">His ladye went, as she did feigne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unto the church to praye.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_156">[Pg 156]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This lord he had a daughter deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whose beauty shone so bright,                                     <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She was belov'd, both far and neare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of many a lord and knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Fair Isabella was she call'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A creature faire was shee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She was her father's only joye;                                     <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">As you shall after see.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Therefore her cruel step-mothèr<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did envye her so much;<br></span>
<span class="i0">That daye by daye she sought her life,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her malice it was such.                                           <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She bargain'd with the master-cook,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To take her life awaye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And taking of her daughters book,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She thus to her did saye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Go home, sweet daughter, I thee praye,                              <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Go hasten presentlie;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tell unto the master-cook<br></span>
<span class="i2">These wordes that I tell thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And bid him dresse to dinner streight<br></span>
<span class="i2">That faire and milk-white doe,                                    <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That in the parke doth shine so bright,<br></span>
<span class="i2">There's none so faire to showe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This ladye fearing of no harme,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Obey'd her mothers will;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And presentlye she hasted home,                                     <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her pleasure to fulfill.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She streight into the kitchen went,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her message for to tell;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there she spied the master-cook,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who did with malice swell.                                        <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_157">[Pg 157]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nowe, master-cook, it must be soe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Do that which I thee tell:<br></span>
<span class="i0">You needes must dresse the milk-white doe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which you do knowe full well.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then streight his cruell bloodye hands,                             <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He on the ladye layd;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who quivering and shaking stands,<br></span>
<span class="i2">While thus to her he sayd:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thou art the doe, that I must dresse;<br></span>
<span class="i2">See here, behold my knife;                                        <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For it is pointed presently<br></span>
<span class="i2">To rid thee of thy life.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O then, cried out the scullion-boye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As loud as loud might bee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">O save her life, good master-cook,                                  <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And make your pyes of mee!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For pityes sake do not destroye<br></span>
<span class="i2">My ladye with your knife;<br></span>
<span class="i0">You know shee is her father's joye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For Christes sake save her life.                                  <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I will not save her life, he sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor make my pyes of thee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet if thou dost this deed bewraye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy butcher I will bee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now when this lord he did come home                                 <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For to sit downe and eat;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He called for his daughter deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To come and carve his meat.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now sit you downe, his ladye sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">O sit you downe to meat:                                          <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Into some nunnery she is gone;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Your daughter deare forget.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_158">[Pg 158]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then solemnlye he made a vowe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Before the companìe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">That he would neither eat nor drinke,                               <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Until he did her see.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O then bespake the scullion-boye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With a loud voice so hye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">If now you will your daughter see,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My lord, cut up that pye:                                         <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Wherein her fleshe is minced small,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And parched with the fire:<br></span>
<span class="i0">All caused by her step-mothèr,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who did her death desire.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And cursed bee the master-cook,                                     <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">O cursed may he bee!<br></span>
<span class="i0">I proffered him my own hearts blood,<br></span>
<span class="i2">From death to set her free.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then all in blacke this lord did mourne;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And for his daughters sake,                                       <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He judged her cruell step-mothèr<br></span>
<span class="i2">To be burnt at a stake.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Likewise he judg'd the master-cook<br></span>
<span class="i2">In boiling lead to stand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And made the simple scullion-boye                                   <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The heire of all his land.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_159">[Pg 159]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XV.<br>

A HUE AND CRY AFTER CUPID.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i159t.png" id="img_images_i159t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> song is a kind of translation of a pretty poem of
Tasso's, called <i>Amore fuggitivo</i>, generally printed with
his <i>Aminta</i>, and originally imitated from the first Idyllium
of Moschus.</p>
<p>It is extracted from Ben Jonson's Masque at the marriage of
lord viscount Hadington, on Shrove-Tuesday, 1608. One stanza
full of dry mythology is here omitted, as it had been dropped in
a copy of this song printed in a small volume called <i>Le Prince</i>
<i>d'Amour</i>. Lond. 1660, 8vo.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The stanza of the first Grace which Percy left out is as follows:—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"At his sight the sun hath turn'd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Neptune in the waters burn'd;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hell hath felt a greater heat;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Jove himself forsook his seat:<br></span>
<span class="i0">From the centre to the sky<br></span>
<span class="i0">Are his trophies reared high."]<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i159b.png" id="img_images_i159b.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[<i>1 Grace.</i>] Beauties have yee seen a toy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Called Love, a little boy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Almost naked, wanton, blinde;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Cruel now; and then as kinde?<br></span>
<span class="i0">If he be amongst yee, say;                                           <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He is Venus' run away.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[<i>2 Grace.</i>] Shee, that will but now discover<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where the winged wag doth hover,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall to-night receive a kisse,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How and where herselfe would wish:                                  <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But who brings him to his mother<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall have that kisse, and another.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_160">[Pg 160]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[<i>3 Grace.</i>] Markes he hath about him plentie;<br></span>
<span class="i0">You may know him among twentie:<br></span>
<span class="i0">All his body is a fire,                                             <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And his breath a flame entire:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which, being shot, like lightning, in,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wounds the heart, but not the skin.<br></span>
<span class="i0">       *       *       *       *       *<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[<i>2 Grace.</i>] Wings he hath, which though yee clip,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He will leape from lip to lip,                                      <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Over liver, lights, and heart;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet not stay in any part.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, if chance his arrow misses,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He will shoot himselfe in kisses.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[<i>3 Grace.</i>] He doth beare a golden bow,                       <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And a quiver hanging low,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Full of arrowes, which outbrave<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dian's shafts; where, if he have<br></span>
<span class="i0">Any head more sharpe than other,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With that first he strikes his mother.                              <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[<i>1 Grace.</i>] Still the fairest are his fuell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When his daies are to be cruell;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lovers hearts are all his food,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his baths their warmest bloud:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nought but wounds his hand doth season,                             <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And he hates none like to Reason.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[<i>2 Grace.</i>] Trust him not: his words, though sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Seldome with his heart doe meet:<br></span>
<span class="i0">All his practice is deceit;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Everie gift is but a bait;                                          <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Not a kisse but poyson beares;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And most treason's in his teares.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[<i>3 Grace.</i>] Idle minutes are his raigne;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then the straggler makes his gaine,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_161">[Pg 161]</a></span>
<span class="i0">By presenting maids with toyes                                      <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And would have yee thinke hem joyes;<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis the ambition of the elfe<br></span>
<span class="i0">To have all childish as himselfe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">[<i>1 Grace.</i>] If by these yee please to know him,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Beauties, be not nice, but show him.                                <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">[<i>2 Grace.</i>] Though ye had a will to hide him,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, we hope, yee'le not abide him.<br></span>
<span class="i0">[<i>3 Grace.</i>] Since yee heare this falser's play,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that he is Venus' run-away.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XVI.<br>

THE KING OF FRANCE'S DAUGHTER.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i161.png" id="img_images_i161.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> story of this ballad seems to be taken from an incident
in the domestic history of Charles the Bald, king
of France. His daughter Judith was betrothed to
Ethelwulph king of England: but before the marriage
was consummated, Ethelwulph died, and she returned to France:
whence she was carried off by Baldwyn, Forester of Flanders;
who, after many crosses and difficulties, at length obtained the
king's consent to their marriage, and was made Earl of Flanders.
This happened about <span class="smcap">A.D.</span> 863.—See Rapin, Henault, and the
French historians.</p>
<p>The following copy is given from the Editor's ancient folio MS.
collated with another in black-letter in the Pepys Collection, intitled,
<i>An excellent Ballad of a prince of England's courtship to the</i>
<i>king of France's daughter, &amp;c.</i> To the tune of <i>Crimson Velvet</i>.</p>
<p>Many breaches having been made in this old song by the hand
of time, principally (as might be expected) in the quick returns
of the rhime; an attempt is here made to repair them.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This ballad was written by Thomas Deloney, who included it
in his <i>Garland of Goodwill</i> (Percy Society, vol. xxx. p. 52). It is,
as Percy points out, founded on history, but Deloney paid little
attention to facts. All the first part of the poem, which tells of the
miserable end of the English prince of suitable age to the young<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_162">[Pg 162]</a></span>
French princess, is fiction. Judith was Ethelwulf's wife for about
two years, and on the death of her husband she married his son
Ethelbert. The only historical fact that is followed in the ballad
is the marriage of Judith with Baldwin, Great Forester of France,
from which union descended Matilda, the wife of William the Conqueror.</p>
<p>The copy in the Folio MS. (ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. iii.
p. 441) is entitled "In the Dayes of Olde." Percy altered it considerably,
sometimes following the printed copy and sometimes the
MS.</p>
<p>Mr. Hales suggests that the name of the tune is derived from
the dress of the princess, described in vv. 185-6,—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Their mothers riche array<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was of crimson velvet,"<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>and Mr. Chappell agrees with him.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i162.png" id="img_images_i162.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In the dayes of old,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When faire France did flourish,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Storyes plaine have told,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Lovers felt annoye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The queene a daughter bare,                                          <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Whom beautye's queene did nourish:<br></span>
<span class="i0">She was lovelye faire<br></span>
<span class="i2">She was her father's joye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A prince of England came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose deeds did merit fame,                                         <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">But he was exil'd, and outcast:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Love his soul did fire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shee granted his desire,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Their hearts in one were linked fast.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which when her father proved,                                       <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sorelye he was moved,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And tormented in his minde.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He sought for to prevent them;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, to discontent them,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Fortune cross'd these lovers kinde.                               <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_163">[Pg 163]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When these princes twaine<br></span>
<span class="i2">Were thus barr'd of pleasure,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Through the kinges disdaine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which their joyes withstoode:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lady soone prepar'd                                             <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her jewells and her treasure;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Having no regard<br></span>
<span class="i2">For state and royall bloode;<br></span>
<span class="i0">In homelye poore array<br></span>
<span class="i0">She went from court away,                                           <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To meet her joye and hearts delight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who in a forest great<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had taken up his seat,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To wayt her coming in the night.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But, lo! what sudden danger                                         <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To this princely stranger<br></span>
<span class="i2">Chanced, as he sate alone!<br></span>
<span class="i0">By outlawes he was robbed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with ponyards stabbed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Uttering many a dying grone.                                      <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The princesse, arm'd by love,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And by chaste desire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">All the night did rove<br></span>
<span class="i2">Without dread at all:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Still unknowne she past                                             <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In her strange attire;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Coming at the last<br></span>
<span class="i2">Within echoes call,—<br></span>
<span class="i0">You faire woods, quoth shee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Honoured may you bee,                                               <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Harbouring my heart's delight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which encompass here<br></span>
<span class="i0">My joye and only deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My trustye friend, and comelye knight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sweete, I come unto thee,                                           <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sweete, I come to woo thee;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_164">[Pg 164]</a></span>
<span class="i2">That thou mayst not angry bee<br></span>
<span class="i0">For my long delaying;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thy curteous staying<br></span>
<span class="i2">Soone amendes Ile make to thee.                                   <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Passing thus alone<br></span>
<span class="i2">Through the silent forest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Many a grievous grone<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sounded in her eares:<br></span>
<span class="i0">She heard one complayne                                             <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And lament the sorest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Seeming all in payne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shedding deadly teares.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Farewell, my deare, quoth hee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whom I must never see;                                              <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For why my life is att an end,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Through villaines crueltye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thy sweet sake I dye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To show I am a faithfull friend.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here I lye a bleeding,                                              <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">While my thoughts are feeding<br></span>
<span class="i2">On the rarest beautye found.<br></span>
<span class="i0">O hard happ, that may be!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Little knows my ladye<br></span>
<span class="i2">My heartes blood lyes on the ground.                              <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With that a grone he sends<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which did burst in sunder<br></span>
<span class="i0">All the tender bands<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of his gentle heart.<br></span>
<span class="i0">She, who knewe his voice,                                           <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">At his wordes did wonder;<br></span>
<span class="i0">All her former joyes<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did to griefe convert.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Strait she ran to see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who this man shold bee,                                             <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That soe like her love did seeme:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_165">[Pg 165]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her lovely lord she found<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lye slaine upon the ground,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Smear'd with gore a ghastlye streame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which his lady spying,                                              <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shrieking, fainting, crying,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her sorrows could not uttered bee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fate, she cryed, too cruell:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For thee—my dearest jewell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Would God! that I had dyed for thee.                             <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">His pale lippes, alas!<br></span>
<span class="i2">Twentye times she kissed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his face did wash<br></span>
<span class="i2">With her trickling teares:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Every gaping wound                                                 <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Tenderlye she pressed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And did wipe it round<br></span>
<span class="i2">With her golden haires.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Speake, faire love, quoth shee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Speake, fair prince, to mee,                                       <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">One sweete word of comfort give:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lift up thy deare eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Listen to my cryes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thinke in what sad griefe I live.<br></span>
<span class="i0">All in vain she sued,                                              <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">All in vain she wooed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The prince's life was fled and gone.<br></span>
<span class="i0">There stood she still mourning,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till the suns retourning,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And bright day was coming on.                                    <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In this great distresse<br></span>
<span class="i2">Weeping, wayling ever,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Oft shee cryed, alas!<br></span>
<span class="i2">What will become of mee?<br></span>
<span class="i0">To my fathers court                                                <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I returne will never:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_166">[Pg 166]</a></span>
<span class="i0">But in lowlye sort<br></span>
<span class="i2">I will a servant bee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">While thus she made her mone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Weeping all alone,                                                 <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In this deepe and deadlye feare:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A for'ster all in greene,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Most comelye to be seene,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ranging the woods did find her there.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Moved with her sorrowe,                                            <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Maid, quoth hee, good morrowe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">What hard happ has brought thee here?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Harder happ did never<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two kinde hearts dissever:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Here lyes slaine my brother deare.                               <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Where may I remaine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Gentle for'ster, shew me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Till I can obtaine<br></span>
<span class="i2">A service in my neede?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Paines I will not spare:                                           <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">This kinde favour doe me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">It will ease my care;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Heaven shall be thy meede.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The for'ster all amazed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">On her beautye gazed,                                              <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Till his heart was set on fire.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If, faire maid, quoth hee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">You will goe with mee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">You shall have your hearts desire.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He brought her to his mother,                                      <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And above all other<br></span>
<span class="i2">He sett forth this maidens praise.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Long was his heart inflamed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">At length her love he gained,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fortune crown'd his future dayes.                            <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus unknowne he wedde<br></span>
<span class="i2">With a kings faire daughter;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_167">[Pg 167]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Children seven they had,<br></span>
<span class="i2">'Ere she told her birth.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which when once he knew,                                           <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Humblye he besought her,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He to the world might shew<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her rank and princelye worth.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He cloath'd his children then,<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Not like other men)                                               <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In partye-colours strange to see;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The right side cloth of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The left side to behold,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of woollen cloth still framed hee<a id="FNanchor_386"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_386">[386]</a>.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Men thereat did wonder;                                            <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Golden fame did thunder<br></span>
<span class="i2">This strange deede in every place:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The king of France came thither,<br></span>
<span class="i0">It being pleasant weather,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In those woods the hart to chase.                                <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The children then they bring,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So their mother will'd it,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where the royall king<br></span>
<span class="i2">Must of force come bye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their mothers riche array,                                         <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i1">Was of crimson velvet:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their fathers all of gray,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Seemelye to the eye.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_168">[Pg 168]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Then this famous king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Noting every thing,                                                <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Askt how he durst be so bold<br></span>
<span class="i0">To let his wife soe weare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And decke his children there<br></span>
<span class="i2">In costly robes of pearl and gold.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The forrester replying,                                            <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And the cause descrying<a id="FNanchor_387"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_387">[387]</a>,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To the king these words did say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Well may they, by their mother,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Weare rich clothes with other,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Being by birth a princesse gay.                                  <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The king aroused thus,<br></span>
<span class="i2">More heedfullye beheld them,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till a crimson blush<br></span>
<span class="i2">His remembrance crost.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The more I fix my mind                                             <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">On thy wife and children,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The more methinks I find<br></span>
<span class="i2">The daughter which I lost.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Falling on her knee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I am that child, quoth shee;                                       <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Pardon mee, my soveraine liege.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The king perceiving this,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His daughter deare did kiss,<br></span>
<span class="i2">While joyfull teares did stopp his speeche.<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his traine he tourned,                                        <span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And with them sojourned.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Strait he dubb'd her husband knight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then made him erle of Flanders,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And chiefe of his commanders:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thus were their sorrowes put to flight.                          <span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">⁂</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_169">[Pg 169]</a></span></p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_386"></a><a href="#FNanchor_386" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[386]</span></a> This will remind the reader of the livery and device of Charles
Brandon, a private gentleman, who married the Queen Dowager
of France, sister of Henry VIII. At a tournament which he held
at his wedding, the trappings of his horse were half Cloth of gold,
and half Frieze, with the following Motto:—
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Cloth of Gold, do not despise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' thou art matcht with Cloth of Frize,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Cloth of Frize, be not too bold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' thou art matcht with Cloth of Gold."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>
See Sir W. Temple's <i>Misc.</i> vol. iii. p. 356.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_387"></a><a href="#FNanchor_387" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[387]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> describing.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XVII.<br>

THE SWEET NEGLECT.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i169.png" id="img_images_i169.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> little madrigal (extracted from Ben. Jonson's <i>Silent</i>
<i>Woman</i>, act i. sc. 1, first acted in 1609) is in imitation
of a Latin Poem printed at the end of the Variorum
Edit. of Petronius, beginning, <i>Semper munditias, semper</i>
<i>Basilissa, decoras</i>, &amp;c. See Whalley's <i>Ben Jonson</i>, vol. ii. p. 420.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i169s.png" id="img_images_i169s.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Still to be neat, still to be drest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As you were going to a feast:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Still to be pou'dred, still perfum'd:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lady, it is to be presum'd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Though art's hid causes are not found,                               <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">All is not sweet, all is not sound.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Give me a looke, give me a face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That makes simplicitie a grace;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Robes loosely flowing, haire as free:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Such sweet neglect more taketh me,                                  <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Than all th' adulteries of art,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That strike mine eyes, but not my heart.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XVIII.<br>

THE CHILDREN IN THE WOOD.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i169t.png" id="img_images_i169t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> subject of this very popular ballad (which has
been set in so favourable a light by the <i>Spectator</i>, No.
85.) seems to be taken from an old play, intitled,
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_170">[Pg 170]</a></span><i>Two lamentable Tragedies; The one of the murder</i>
<i>of Maister Beech, a chandler in Thames streete, &amp;c. The other</i>
<i>of a young child murthered in a wood by two ruffins, with the</i>
<i>consent of his unkle.</i> By Rob. Yarrington, 1601, 4to. Our ballad-maker
has strictly followed the play in the description of the
father and mother's dying charge: in the uncle's promise to take
care of their issue: his hiring two ruffians to destroy his ward,
under pretence of sending him to school: their chusing a wood
to perpetrate the murder in: one of the ruffians relenting, and
a battle ensuing, &amp;c. In other respects he has departed from the
play. In the latter the scene is laid in Padua: there is but one
child: which is murdered by a sudden stab of the unrelenting
ruffian: he is slain himself by his less bloody companion; but ere
he dies gives the other a mortal wound: the latter living just long
enough to impeach the uncle; who, in consequence of this impeachment,
is arraigned and executed by the hand of justice, &amp;c.
Whoever compares the play with the ballad, will have no doubt
but the former is the original: the language is far more obsolete,
and such a vein of simplicity runs through the whole performance,
that, had the ballad been written first, there is no doubt but every
circumstance of it would have been received into the drama:
whereas this was probably built on some Italian novel.</p>
<p>Printed from two ancient copies, one of them in black-letter in
the Pepys Collection. Its title at large is, <i>The Children in the</i>
<i>Wood; or, The Norfolk Gentleman's Last Will and Testament: To</i>
<i>the tune of Rogero, &amp;c.</i></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Ritson thought he had refuted Percy's statement that the play
was older than the ballad by pointing out that the latter was
entered in the Stationers' books in 1595, but I find in Baker's
<i>Biographia Dramatica</i> an assertion that Yarrington's play was not
printed "till many years after it was written." The following is
the form of the entry at Stationers' Hall, "15 Oct. 1595. Thomas
Millington entred for his copie under th[e h]andes of bothe the
Wardens a ballad intituled <i>The Norfolk Gent, his Will and Testament</i>
<i>and howe he commytted the keepinge of his children to his owne</i>
<i>brother whoe delte most wickedly with them and howe God plagued</i>
<i>him for it.</i>" Sharon Turner and Miss Halsted favoured the rather
untenable opinion that the wicked uncle was intended to represent
Richard III., and therefore that the date of the ballad was much
earlier than that usually claimed for it. Turner writes in his <i>History</i>
<i>of England</i>, "I have sometimes fancied that the popular
ballad may have been written at this time on Richard and his
nephews before it was quite safe to stigmatize him more openly."</p>
<p>Wailing, or Wayland Wood, a large cover near Walton in Norfolk
is the place which tradition assigns to the tragedy, but the
people of Wood Dalling also claim the honour for their village.</p>
<p>Addison speaks of the ballad as "one of the darling songs of
the common people, [which] has been the delight of most English<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_171">[Pg 171]</a></span>men
in some part of their age," and points out that the circumstance</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">... robin-red-breast piously<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did cover them with leaves,<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>has a parallel in Horace, who tells us that when he was a child,
fallen asleep in a desert wood, the turtle doves took pity on him
and covered him with leaves.</p>
<p>The popular belief that the robin covers dead bodies with leaves
(probably founded on the habits of the bird) is of considerable
antiquity. The passage in Cymbeline (act iv. sc. 2) naturally
occurs as the chief illustration:—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">... "the ruddock would,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With charitable bill....<br></span>
<span class="i0">... bring thee all this,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea and furr'd moss besides, when flowers are none,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To winter-ground thy corse."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>In Webster's <i>White Devil</i>, act v., we read:—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Call for the robin red breast and the wren<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since o'er shady groves they hover<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with leaves and flowers do cover<br></span>
<span class="i0">The friendless bodies of unburied men."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>The critics suppose Webster to have imitated Shakespere here,
but there is no ground for any such supposition. The industry of
Reed, Steevens, and Douce has supplied us with several passages
from old literature in which this characteristic of the robin is referred
to.</p>
<p>In "<i>Cornucopiæ, or, divers Secrets</i>; wherein is contained the rare
secrets of man, beasts, fowles, fishes, trees, plants, stones, and
such like, most pleasant and profitable, and not before committed
to bee printed in English. Newlie drawen out of divers Latine
Authors into English by Thomas Johnson," 4to. London, 1596,
occurs the following passage:—"The robin red-breast if he find a
man or woman dead will cover all his face with mosse, and some
thinke that if the body should remaine unburied that hee woulde
cover the whole body also."</p>
<p>This little secret of Johnson is copied by Thomas Lupton into
his <i>A Thousand Notable Things of sundrie sorts newly corrected</i>,
1601, where it appears as No. 37 of book i.</p>
<p>Michael Drayton has the following lines in his poem, <i>The Owl</i>:</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Cov'ring with moss the dead's unclosed eye<br></span>
<span class="i0">The little red-breast teacheth charitie."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_172">[Pg 172]</a></span></p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>In Dekker's <i>Villanies discovered by lanthorn and candlelight</i>, 1616,
we read, "They that cheere up a prisoner but with their sight are
Robin red-breasts, that bring strawes in their bils to cover a dead
man in extremitìe." This is sufficient evidence that the belief was
wide-spread.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i172.png" id="img_images_i172.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now ponder well, you parents deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">These wordes, which I shall write;<br></span>
<span class="i0">A doleful story you shall heare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In time brought forth to light.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A gentleman of good account                                          <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In Norfolke dwelt of late,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who did in honour far surmount<br></span>
<span class="i2">Most men of his estate.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sore sicke he was, and like to dye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">No helpe his life could save;                                     <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His wife by him as sicke did lye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And both possest one grave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">No love between these two was lost,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Each was to other kinde,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In love they liv'd, in love they dyed,                              <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And left two babes behinde:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The one a fine and pretty boy,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Not passing three yeares olde;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The other a girl more young than he,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fram'd in beautyes molde.                                     <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The father left his little son,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As plainlye doth appeare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When he to perfect age should come,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Three hundred poundes a yeare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And to his little daughter Jane                                     <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Five hundred poundes in gold,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To be paid down on marriage-day,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which might not be controll'd:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_173">[Pg 173]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But if the children chance to dye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ere they to age should come,                                      <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Their uncle should possesse their wealth;<br></span>
<span class="i2">For so the wille did run.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now, brother, said the dying man,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Look to my children deare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be good unto my boy and girl,                                       <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">No friendes else have they here:<br></span>
<span class="i0">To God and you I recommend<br></span>
<span class="i2">My children deare this daye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But little while be sure we have<br></span>
<span class="i2">Within this world to staye.                                       <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">You must be father and mother both,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And uncle all in one;<br></span>
<span class="i0">God knowes what will become of them,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When I am dead and gone.<br></span>
<span class="i0">With that bespake their mother deare,                               <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">O brother kinde, quoth shee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">You are the man must bring our babes<br></span>
<span class="i2">To wealth or miserie:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And if you keep them carefully,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then God will you reward;                                         <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But if you otherwise should deal,<br></span>
<span class="i2">God will your deedes regard.<br></span>
<span class="i0">With lippes as cold as any stone,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They kist their children small:<br></span>
<span class="i0">God bless you both, my children deare;                              <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With that the teares did fall.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">These speeches then their brother spake<br></span>
<span class="i2">To this sicke couple there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The keeping of your little ones<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sweet sister, do not feare;                                       <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">God never prosper me nor mine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor aught else that I have,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If I do wrong your children deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When you are layd in grave.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_174">[Pg 174]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The parents being dead and gone,                                    <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The children home he takes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bringes them straite unto his house,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where much of them he makes.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He had not kept these pretty babes<br></span>
<span class="i2">A twelvemonth and a daye,                                         <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But, for their wealth, he did devise<br></span>
<span class="i2">To make them both awaye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He bargain'd with two ruffians strong,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which were of furious mood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That they should take these children young,                         <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And slaye them in a wood.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He told his wife an artful tale,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He would the children send<br></span>
<span class="i0">To be brought up in faire Londòn,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With one that was his friend.                                     <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Away then went those pretty babes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Rejoycing at that tide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rejoycing with a merry minde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They should on cock-horse ride.<br></span>
<span class="i0">They prate and prattle pleasantly,                                  <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">As they rode on the waye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To those that should their butchers be,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And work their lives decaye:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So that the pretty speeche they had,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Made Murder's heart relent;                                       <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And they that undertooke the deed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Full sore did now repent.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet one of them more hard of heart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did vowe to do his charge,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Because the wretch, that hired him,                                 <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Had paid him very large.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The other won't agree thereto,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So here they fall to strife;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With one another they did fight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">About the childrens life:                                        <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_175">[Pg 175]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he that was of mildest mood,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did slaye the other there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Within an unfrequented wood;<br></span>
<span class="i2">The babes did quake for feare!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He took the children by the hand,                                  <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Teares standing in their eye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bad them straitwaye follow him,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And look they did not crye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And two long miles he ledd them on,<br></span>
<span class="i2">While they for food complaine:                                   <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Staye here, quoth he, I'll bring you bread,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When I come back againe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">These pretty babes, with hand in hand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Went wandering up and downe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But never more could see the man                                   <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Approaching from the town:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their prettye lippes with black-berries,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Were all besmear'd and dyed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And when they sawe the darksome night,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They sat them downe and cryed.                                   <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus wandered these poor innocents,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Till deathe did end their grief,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In one anothers armes they dyed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As wanting due relief:<br></span>
<span class="i0">No burial 'this' pretty 'pair'<a id="FNanchor_388"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_388">[388]</a> <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of any man receives,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till Robin-red-breast piously<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did cover them with leaves.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And now the heavy wrathe of God<br></span>
<span class="i2">Upon their uncle fell;                                           <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, fearfull fiends did haunt his house,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His conscience felt an hell:<br></span>
<span class="i0">His barnes were fir'd, his goodes consum'd,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_176">[Pg 176]</a></span>
<span class="i2">His landes were barren made,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His cattle dyed within the field,                                  <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And nothing with him stayd.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And in a voyage to Portugal<a id="FNanchor_389"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_389">[389]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Two of his sonnes did dye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to conclude, himselfe was brought<br></span>
<span class="i2">To want and miserye:                                             <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He pawn'd and mortgaged all his land<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ere seven yeares came about.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And now at length this wicked act<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did by this meanes come out:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The fellowe, that did take in hand                                 <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">These children for to kill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was for a robbery judg'd to dye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Such was God's blessed will:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who did confess the very truth,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As here hath been display'd:                                     <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Their uncle having dyed in gaol,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where he for debt was layd.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">You that executors be made,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And overseers eke<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of children that be fatherless,                                    <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And infants mild and meek;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Take you example by this thing,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And yield to each his right,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lest God with such like miserye<br></span>
<span class="i2">Your wicked minds requite.                                       <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_177">[Pg 177]</a></span></p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_388"></a><a href="#FNanchor_388" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[388]</span></a> Ver. 125. these ... babes. <i>P.P.</i></p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_389"></a><a href="#FNanchor_389" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[389]</span></a> [Ritson has the following note (<i>Ancient Songs</i>, 1829, vol. ii.
P. 155): "<i>the</i> voyage, <span class="smcap">A.D.</span> 1588. See the Catalogue of the Harl.
MSS. No. 167 (15). Dr. Percy, not knowing that the text alludes
to a particular event, has altered it to <i>a</i> voyage."]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XIX.<br>

A LOVER OF LATE.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i177p.png" id="img_images_i177p.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">Printed</span>, with a few slight corrections, from the Editor's
folio MS.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This song is printed, Hales and Furnivall's edition
of the MS. vol. iii. p. 389.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i177a.png" id="img_images_i177a.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i4">A lover of late was I,<br></span>
<span class="i6">For Cupid would have it soe,<br></span>
<span class="i4">The boy that hath never an eye,<br></span>
<span class="i6">As every man doth know:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I sighed and sobbed, and cryed, alas!                                <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For her that laught, and called me ass.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i4">Then knew not I what to doe,<br></span>
<span class="i6">When I saw itt was in vaine<a id="FNanchor_390"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_390">[390]</a><br></span>
<span class="i4">A lady soe coy to wooe,<br></span>
<span class="i6">Who gave me the asse soe plaine:<a id="FNanchor_391"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_391">[391]</a> <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet would I her asse freelye bee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Soe shee would helpe, and beare with mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i4">An' I were as faire as shee,<a id="FNanchor_392"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_392">[392]</a><br></span>
<span class="i6">Or shee were as kind as I,<a id="FNanchor_393"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_393">[393]</a><br></span>
<span class="i4">What payre cold have made, as wee,                              <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">Soe prettye a sympathye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I was as kind as she was faire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But for all this wee cold not paire.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_178">[Pg 178]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Paire with her that will for mee,<br></span>
<span class="i4">With her I will never paire;                                    <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That cunningly can be coy,<br></span>
<span class="i4">For being a little faire.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The asse Ile leave to her disdaine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And now I am myselfe againe.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_390"></a><a href="#FNanchor_390" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[390]</span></a> [Ver. 8. when I see itt was vaine.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_391"></a><a href="#FNanchor_391" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[391]</span></a> [V. 10. and gave.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_392"></a><a href="#FNanchor_392" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[392]</span></a> [V. 13. faine, MS.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_393"></a><a href="#FNanchor_393" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[393]</span></a> [V. 14. and shee, MS.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XX.<br>

THE KING AND MILLER OF MANSFIELD.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i178.png" id="img_images_i178.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capi"><span class="smcap">It</span> has been a favourite subject with our English ballad-makers
to represent our kings conversing, either by
accident or design, with the meanest of their subjects.
Of the former kind, besides this song of the King and
the Miller; we have K. Henry and the Soldier; K. James I. and
the Tinker; K. William III. and the Forrester &amp;c. Of the latter
sort, are K. Alfred and the Shepherd; K. Edward IV. and the
Tanner;<a id="FNanchor_394"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_394">[394]</a> K. Henry VIII. and the Cobler, &amp;c.—A few of the
best of these are admitted into this collection. Both the author
of the following ballad, and others who have written on the same
plan, seem to have copied a very ancient poem, intitled <i>John</i>
<i>the Reeve</i>, which is built on an adventure of the same kind, that
happened between K. Edward Longshanks, and one of his Reeves
or Bailiffs. This is a piece of great antiquity, being written before
the time of Edward IV. and for its genuine humour, diverting incidents,
and faithful picture of rustic manners, is infinitely superior
to all that have been since written in imitation of it. The Editor
has a copy in his ancient folio MS. but its length rendered it improper
for this volume, it consisting of more than 900 lines. It
contains also some corruptions, and the Editor chuses to defer its
publication in hopes that some time or other he shall be able to
remove them.</p>
<p>The following is printed, with corrections, from the editor's
folio MS. collated with an old black-letter copy in the Pepys
Col<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_179">[Pg 179]</a></span>lection, intitled <i>A pleasant ballad of K. Henry II. and the Miller</i>
<i>of Mansfield, &amp;c.</i></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This ballad of <i>Henry II. and the Miller of Mansfield</i> cannot be
traced farther back than the end of Elizabeth's reign or the beginning
of James's. One of the three copies in the Roxburghe
Collection is dated by Mr. Chappell between 1621 and 1655, and
the copy in the Folio MS. (ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. ii. p. 147)
was written about the same period. (See Roxburghe <i>Ballads</i>, ed.
Chappell, vol. i. p. 538.)</p>
<p>As there are earlier copies than the one in the Folio MS. it has
not been thought necessary to add Collations.</p>
<p><i>John the Reeve</i>, referred to above, is one of the earliest and most
interesting of this large class of tales. It was printed for the first
time in Hales and Furnivall's edition of the MS. (vol. ii. p. 550)
with a valuable introduction.</p>
<p>This spirited poem was probably written originally in the middle
of the fifteenth century. "It professes to describe an incident
that took place in the days of King Edward. It adds:</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Of that name were Kings <i>three</i><br></span>
<span class="i0">But Edward with the long shanks was he,<br></span>
<span class="i6">A lord of great renown.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>The poem then was written after the death of Edward III.; that is,
after 1377, and before the accession of Edward IV., that is before
1461."]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<h4><span class="smcap">Part the First.</span>
</h4>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i179.png" id="img_images_i179.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Henry, our royall king, would ride a hunting<br></span>
<span class="i2">To the greene forest so pleasant and faire;<br></span>
<span class="i0">To see the harts skipping, and dainty does tripping:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unto merry Sherwood his nobles repaire:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hawke and hound were unbound, all things prepar'd                    <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For the game, in the same, with good regard.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All a long summers day rode the king pleasantlye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With all his princes and nobles eche one;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_180">[Pg 180]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Chasing the hart and hind, and the bucke gallantlye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Till the dark evening forc'd all to turne home.                   <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then at last, riding fast, he had lost quite<br></span>
