<span class="i0">All his lords in the wood, late in the night.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Wandering thus wearilye, all alone, up and downe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With a rude miller he mett at the last:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Asking the ready way unto faire Nottingham;                         <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Sir, quoth the miller, I meane not to jest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet I thinke, what I thinke, sooth for to say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">You doe not lightlye ride out of your way.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Why, what dost thou think of me, quoth our king merrily,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Passing thy judgment upon me so briefe?                           <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Good faith, sayd the miller, I meane not to flatter thee;<br></span>
<span class="i2">I guess thee to be but some gentleman thiefe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Stand thee backe, in the darke; light not adowne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lest that I presentlye cracke thy knaves crowne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thou dost abuse me much, quoth the king, saying thus;               <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I am a gentleman; lodging I lacke.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou hast not, quoth th' miller, one groat in thy purse;<br></span>
<span class="i2">All thy inheritance hanges on thy backe.<a id="FNanchor_395"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_395">[395]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">I have gold to discharge all that I call;<br></span>
<span class="i0">If it be forty pence, I will pay all.                               <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If thou beest a true man, then quoth the miller,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I sweare by my toll-dish, I'll lodge thee all night.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here's my hand, quoth the king, that was I ever.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nay, soft, quoth the miller, thou may'st be a sprite.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Better I'll know thee, ere hands we will shake;                     <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With none but honest men hands will I take.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_181">[Pg 181]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus they went all along unto the miller's house;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where they were seething of puddings and souse:<a id="FNanchor_396"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_396">[396]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">The miller first enter'd in, after him went the king;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Never came hee in soe smoakye a house.                            <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now, quoth hee, let me see here what you are.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth our king, looke your fill, and doe not spare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I like well thy countenance, thou hast an honest face<br></span>
<span class="i2">With my son Richard this night thou shalt lye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth his wife, by my troth, it is a handsome youth,                <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet it's best, husband, to deal warilye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Art thou no run away, prythee, youth, tell?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shew me thy passport, and all shal be well.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then our king presentlye, making lowe courtesye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With his hatt in his hand, thus he did say;                       <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I have no passport, nor never was servitor,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But a poor courtyer, rode out of my way:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for your kindness here offered to mee,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I will requite you in everye degree.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then to the miller his wife whisper'd secretlye,                    <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Saying, It seemeth, this youth's of good kin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Both by his apparel, and eke by his manners;<br></span>
<span class="i2">To turne him out, certainlye, were a great sin.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, quoth hee, you may see, he hath some grace<br></span>
<span class="i0">When he doth speake to his betters in place.                        <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Well, quo' the millers wife, young man, ye're welcome here;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And, though I say it, well lodged shall be:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fresh straw will I have, laid on thy bed so brave,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And good brown hempen sheets likewise, quoth shee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Aye, quoth the good man; and when that is done,                     <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou shalt lye with no worse, than our own sonne.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_182">[Pg 182]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nay, first, quoth Richard, good-fellowe, tell me true,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Host thou noe creepers within thy gay hose?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or art thou not troubled with the scabbado?<br></span>
<span class="i2">I pray, quoth the king, what creatures are those?                 <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Art thou not lowsy, nor scabby? quoth he:<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou beest, surely thou lyest not with mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This caus'd the king, suddenlye, to laugh most heartilye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Till the teares trickled fast downe from his eyes.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then to their supper were they set orderlye,                        <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With hot bag-puddings, and good apple-pyes;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nappy ale, good and stale, in a browne bowle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which did about the board merrilye trowle.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Here, quoth the miller, good fellowe, I drinke to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And to all 'cuckholds, wherever they bee.'<a id="FNanchor_397"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_397">[397]</a> <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I pledge thee, quotth our king, and thanke thee heartilye<br></span>
<span class="i2">For my good welcome in everye degree:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And here, in like manner, I drinke to thy sonne.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Do then, quoth Richard, and quicke let it come.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Wife, quoth the miller, fetch me forth lightfoote,                  <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And of his sweetnesse a little we'll taste.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A fair ven'son pastye brought she out presentlye.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Eate, quoth the miller, but, sir, make no waste.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here's dainty lightfoote! In faith, sayd the king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I never before eat so daintye a thing.                              <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I wis, quoth Richard, no daintye at all it is,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For we doe eate of it everye day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">In what place, sayd our king, may be bought like to this?<br></span>
<span class="i2">We never pay pennye for itt, by my fay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">From merry Sherwood we fetch it home here;                          <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now and then we make bold with our kings deer.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_183">[Pg 183]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then I thinke, sayd our king, that it is venison.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Eche foole, quoth Richard, full well may know that:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Never are wee without two or three in the roof,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Very well fleshed, and excellent fat:                            <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But, prythee, say nothing wherever thou goe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">We would not, for two pence, the king should it knowe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Doubt not, then sayd the king, my promist secresye;<br></span>
<span class="i2">The king shall never know more on't for mee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A cupp of lambs-wool<a id="FNanchor_398"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_398">[398]</a> they dranke unto him then,               <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And to their bedds they past presentlie.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The nobles, next morning, went all up and down,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For to seeke out the king in everye towne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At last, at the miller's 'cott,' soone they espy'd him out,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As he was mounting upon his faire steede;                        <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To whom they came presently, falling down on their knee;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which made the millers heart wofully bleede;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shaking and quaking, before him he stood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thinking he should have been hang'd, by the rood.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The king perceiving him fearfully trembling,                       <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Drew forth his sword, but nothing he sed:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The miller downe did fall, crying before them all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Doubting the king would have cut off his head.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he his kind courtesye for to requite,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gave him great living, and dubb'd him a knight.                    <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_184">[Pg 184]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<h4><span class="smcap">Part the Seconde.</span>
</h4>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i184.png" id="img_images_i184.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When as our royall king came home from Nottingham,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And with his nobles at Westminster lay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Recounting the sports and pastimes they had taken,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In this late progress along on the way;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of them all, great and small, he did protest,                        <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The miller of Mansfield's sport liked him best.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And now, my lords, quoth the king, I am determined<br></span>
<span class="i2">Against St. Georges next sumptuous feast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That this old miller, our new confirm'd knight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With his son Richard, shall here be my guest:                     <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For, in this merryment, 'tis my desire<br></span>
<span class="i0">To talke with the jolly knight, and the young squire.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When as the noble lords saw the kinges pleasantness,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They were right joyfull and glad in their hearts:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A pursuivant there was sent straighte on the business,              <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The which had often-times been in those parts.<br></span>
<span class="i0">When he came to the place, where they did dwell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His message orderlye then 'gan he tell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">God save your worshippe, then said the messenger,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And grant your ladye her own hearts desire;                       <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And to your sonne Richard good fortune and happiness;<br></span>
<span class="i2">That sweet, gentle, and gallant young squire.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Our king greets you well, and thus he doth say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">You must come to the court on St. George's day;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Therfore, in any case, faile not to be in place.                    <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I wis, quoth the miller, this is an odd jest:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_185">[Pg 185]</a></span>
<span class="i0">What should we doe there? faith, I am halfe afraid.<br></span>
<span class="i2">I doubt, quoth Richard, to be hang'd at the least.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, quoth the messenger, you doe mistake;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Our king he provides a great feast for your sake.                   <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then sayd the miller, By my troth, messenger,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou hast contented my worshippe full well.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hold here are three farthings, to quite thy gentleness,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For these happy tydings, which thou dost tell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let me see, hear thou mee; tell to our king,                        <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">We'll wayt on his mastershipp in everye thing.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The pursuivant smiled at their simplicitye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And, making many leggs, tooke their reward;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his leave taking with great humilitye<br></span>
<span class="i2">To the kings court againe he repair'd;                            <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shewing unto his grace, merry and free,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The knightes most liberall gift and bountie.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When he was gone away, thus gan the miller say,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Here come expences and charges indeed;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now must we needs be brave, tho' we spend all we have;              <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i3">For of new garments we have great need:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of horses and serving-men we must have store,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With bridles and saddles, and twentye things more.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Tushe, sir John, quoth his wife, why should you frett, or frowne?<br></span>
<span class="i2">You shall ne'er be att no charges for mee;                        <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For I will turne and trim up my old russet gowne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With everye thing else as fine as may bee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And on our mill-horses swift we will ride,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With pillowes and pannells, as we shall provide.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In this most statelye sort, rode they unto the court,               <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Their jolly sonne Richard rode foremost of all;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_186">[Pg 186]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Who set up, for good hap, a cocks feather in his cap,<a id="FNanchor_399"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_399">[399]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">And so they jetted<a id="FNanchor_400"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_400">[400]</a> downe to the kings hall;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The merry old miller with hands on his side;<br></span>
<span class="i0">His wife, like maid Marian, did mince at that tide.<a id="FNanchor_401"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_401">[401]</a> <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The king and his nobles that heard of their coming,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Meeting this gallant knight with his brave traine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Welcome, sir knight, quoth he, with your gay lady:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Good sir John Cockle, once welcome againe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And soe is the squire of courage soe free.                          <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth Dicke, A bots on you! do you know mee?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth our king gentlye, how should I forget thee?<br></span>
<span class="i2">That wast my owne bed-fellowe, well it I wot.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, sir, quoth Richard, and by the same token,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou with thy farting didst make the bed hot.                     <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou whore-son unhappy knave, then quoth the knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Speake cleanly to our king, or else go sh***.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The king and his courtiers laugh at this heartily,<br></span>
<span class="i2">While the king taketh them both by the hand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the court-dames, and maids, like to the queen of spades        <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The millers wife did soe orderlye stand.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A milk-maids courtesye at every word;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And downe all the folkes were set to the board.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There the king royally, in princelye majestye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sate at his dinner with joy and delight;                          <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When they had eaten well, then he to jesting fell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And in a bowle of wine dranke to the knight:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here's to you both, in wine, ale and beer;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_187">[Pg 187]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Thanking you heartilye for my good cheer.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth sir John Cockle, I'll pledge you a pottle,                    <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Were it the best ale in Nottinghamshire:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But then said our king, now I think of a thing;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Some of your lightfoote I would we had here.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ho! ho! quoth Richard, full well I may say it,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis knavery to eate it, and then to betray it.                     <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Why art thou angry? quoth our king merrilye;<br></span>
<span class="i2">In faith, I take it now very unkind:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I thought thou wouldst pledge me in ale and wine heartily.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Quoth Dicke, You are like to stay till I have din'd:<br></span>
<span class="i0">You feed us with twatling dishes soe small;                         <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Zounds, a blacke-pudding is better than all.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Aye, marry, quoth our king, that were a daintye thing,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Could a man get but one here for to eate.<br></span>
<span class="i0">With that Dicke straite arose, and pluckt one from his hose,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which with heat of his breech gan to sweate.                     <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The king made a proffer to snatch it away:—<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Tis meat for your master: good sir, you must stay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus in great merriment was the time wholly spent;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And then the ladyes prepared to dance.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Old Sir John Cockle, and Richard, incontinent<a id="FNanchor_402"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_402">[402]</a> <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Unto their places the king did advance.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here with the ladyes such sport they did make,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The nobles with laughing did make their sides ake.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Many thankes for their paines did the king give them,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Asking young Richard then, if he would wed;                      <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Among these ladyes free, tell me which liketh thee?<br></span>
<span class="i2">Quoth he, Jugg Grumball, Sir, with the red head:<br></span>
<span class="i0">She's my love, she's my life, her will I wed;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_188">[Pg 188]</a></span>
<span class="i0">She hath sworn I shall have her maidenhead.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then sir John Cockle the king called unto him,                     <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And of merry Sherwood made him o'er seer;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gave him out of hand three hundred pound yearlye:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Take heed now you steale no more of my deer:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And once a quarter let's here have your view;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And now, sir John Cockle, I bid you adieu.                         <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_394"></a><a href="#FNanchor_394" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[394]</span></a> [See vol. ii. book i. No. 15.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_395"></a><a href="#FNanchor_395" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[395]</span></a> The king says this.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_396"></a><a href="#FNanchor_396" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[396]</span></a> [The head, feet, and ears of swine boiled and pickled for
eating.—<i>Halliwell's Dictionary.</i>]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_397"></a><a href="#FNanchor_397" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[397]</span></a> [Ver. 80. courtnalls, that courteous be. <i>MS. and P.</i>]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_398"></a><a href="#FNanchor_398" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[398]</span></a> [A favourite liquor among the common people, composed of
ale and roasted apples, the pulp of the apple worked up with the
ale till the mixture formed a smooth beverage. <i>Nares' Glossary.</i>]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_399"></a><a href="#FNanchor_399" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[399]</span></a> [Ver. 57. <i>for good hap</i>: <i>i.e.</i> for good luck; they were going on
an hazardous expedition.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_400"></a><a href="#FNanchor_400" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[400]</span></a> [strutted.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_401"></a><a href="#FNanchor_401" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[401]</span></a> [Ver. 60. Maid Marian in the Morris dance, was represented by
a man in woman's cloaths, who was to take short steps in order to
sustain the female character.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_402"></a><a href="#FNanchor_402" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[402]</span></a> [forthwith.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XXI.<br>

THE SHEPHERD'S RESOLUTION.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i188.png" id="img_images_i188.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> beautiful old song was written by a poet, whose
name would have been utterly forgotten, if it had not
been preserved by <i>Swift</i>, as a term of contempt.
<i>Dryden</i> and <i>Wither</i> are coupled by him like the
<i>Bavius</i> and <i>Mævius</i> of Virgil. <i>Dryden</i>, however, has had justice
done him by posterity: and as for <i>Wither</i>, though of subordinate
merit, that he was not altogether devoid of genius, will be
judged from the following stanzas. The truth is, <i>Wither</i> was a
very voluminous party-writer: and as his political and satyrical
strokes rendered him extremely popular in his life-time; so afterwards,
when these were no longer relished, they totally consigned
his writings to oblivion.</p>
<p><i>George Wither</i> was born June 11, 1588, and in his younger
years distinguished himself by some pastoral pieces, that were not
inelegant; but growing afterwards involved in the political and
religious disputes in the times of James I. and Charles I. he
employed his poetical vein in severe pasquils on the court and
clergy, and was occasionally a sufferer for the freedom of his pen.
In the civil war that ensued, he exerted himself in the service of
the Parliament, and became a considerable sharer in the spoils.
He was even one of those provincial tyrants, whom Oliver distributed
over the kingdom, under the name of Major Generals;
and had the fleecing of the county of Surrey: but surviving the
Restoration, he outlived both his power and his affluence; and<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_189">[Pg 189]</a></span>
giving vent to his chagrin in libels on the court, was long a
prisoner in Newgate and the Tower. He died at length on the
2d of May, 1667.</p>
<p>During the whole course of his life, <i>Wither</i> was a continual
publisher; having generally for opponent, <i>Taylor</i> the Water-poet.
The long list of his productions may be seen in Wood's <i>Athenæ.</i>
<i>Oxon.</i> vol. ii. His most popular satire is intitled, <i>Abuses whipt</i>
<i>and stript</i>, 1613. His most poetical pieces were eclogues, intitled,
<i>The Shepherd's Hunting</i>, 1615, 8vo. and others printed at the end
of Browne's <i>Shepherd's Pipe</i>, 1614, 8vo. The following sonnet is
extracted from a long pastoral piece of his, intitled, <i>The Mistresse</i>
<i>of Philarete</i>, 1622, 8vo. which is said in the preface to be one of
the Author's first poems; and may therefore be dated as early as
any of the foregoing.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This favourite song appeared in 1619, appended to Wither's
<i>Fidelia</i>, and again in his <i>Juvenilia</i> in 1633 in <i>Fair Virtue the</i>
<i>mistress of Philarete</i>. It was reprinted again and again, and
occurs in the Folio MS. (ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. ii. p. 50).</p>
<p>Mr. Chappell refers to a copy in the Pepys Collection entitled,
<i>A New Song of a young man's opinion of the difference between good</i>
<i>and bad women</i>, the first line of which is, "Shall I <i>wrestling</i> in
despaire?" This reading seems to have been pretty popular, as
Mr. Chappell gives two instances of the tune being called "<i>Shall</i>
<i>I wrastle in despair?</i>" Mr. Chappell prints a song in the same
metre and with a similar burden, which has been attributed on
insufficient evidence to Sir Walter Raleigh. The first stanza is as
follows:—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Shall I like a hermit dwell<br></span>
<span class="i0">On a rock or in a cell?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Calling home the smallest part<br></span>
<span class="i0">That is missing of my heart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To bestow it where I may<br></span>
<span class="i0">Meet a rival every day?<br></span>
<span class="i0">If she undervalues me<br></span>
<span class="i0">What care I how fair she be."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p><i>Popular Music of the Olden Time</i>, vol. i. p. 315.]</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_190">[Pg 190]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i190.png" id="img_images_i190.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shall I, wasting in dispaire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dye because a woman's faire?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or make pale my cheeks with care,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Cause another's rosie are?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be shee fairer then the day,                                         <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or the flowery meads in may;<br></span>
<span class="i2">If she be not so to me,<a id="FNanchor_403"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_403">[403]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">What care I how faire shee be?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shall my foolish heart be pin'd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Cause I see a woman kind?                                          <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Or a well-disposed nature<br></span>
<span class="i0">Joyned with a lovely feature?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Be she meeker, kinder, than<br></span>
<span class="i0">The turtle-dove or pelican:<br></span>
<span class="i2">If shee be not so to me,                                          <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">What care I how kind shee be?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shall a woman's virtues move<br></span>
<span class="i0">Me to perish for her love?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or, her well-deservings knowne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Make me quite forget mine owne?                                     <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Be shee with that goodnesse blest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which may merit name of Best;<br></span>
<span class="i2">If she be not such to me,<a id="FNanchor_404"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_404">[404]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">What care I how good she be?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Cause her fortune seems too high,<a id="FNanchor_405"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_405">[405]</a> <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall I play the foole and dye?<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_405">[405]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Those that beare a noble minde,<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_405">[405]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where they want of riches find,<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_405">[405]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Think what with them they would doe,<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_405">[405]</a><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_191">[Pg 191]</a></span>
<span class="i0">That without them dare to woe;<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_405">[405]</a> <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And, unlesse that minde I see,<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_405">[405]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">What care I how great she be?<a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_405">[405]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Great or good, or kind or faire,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I will ne'er the more dispaire:<br></span>
<span class="i0">If she love me, this beleeve;                                       <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I will die ere she shall grieve.<br></span>
<span class="i0">If she slight me when I wooe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I can scorn and let her goe:<br></span>
<span class="i2">If shee be not fit for me,<br></span>
<span class="i2">What care I for whom she be?                                      <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_403"></a><a href="#FNanchor_403" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[403]</span></a> [Ver. 7. if shee thinke not well of mee, MS.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_404"></a><a href="#FNanchor_404" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[404]</span></a> [V. 23. soe to me, MS.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_405"></a><a href="#FNanchor_405" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[405]</span></a> [V. 25-32. this stanza is not in the MS.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XXII.<br>

QUEEN DIDO.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i191.png" id="img_images_i191.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">Such</span> is the title given in the editor's folio MS.<a id="FNanchor_406"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_406">[406]</a> to this
excellent old ballad, which, in the common printed
copies, is inscribed, <i>Eneas, wandering Prince of Troy</i>.
It is here given from that MS. collated with two different
printed copies, both in black-letter, in the Pepys Collection.</p>
<p>The reader will smile to observe with what natural and affecting
simplicity, our ancient ballad-maker has engrafted a Gothic conclusion
on the classic story of Virgil, from whom, however, it is
probable he had it not. Nor can it be denied, but he has dealt
out his poetical justice with a more impartial hand, than that
celebrated poet.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This once popular ballad was entered on the Registers of the
Stationers Company in 1564-5 as "a ballett intituled <i>The Wanderynge</i>
<i>Prince</i>." Its great popularity is evidenced by the frequent references
in literature and the large number of ballads sung to the
tune of <i>Queen Dido</i> or <i>Troy towne</i>. In <i>The Penniless Parliament of</i>
<i>Threadbare Poets</i>, 1608, ale-knights are said to "sing <i>Queen Dido</i>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_192">[Pg 192]</a></span>over a cup and tell strange news over an ale-pot," and the same
song is referred to in Fletcher's <i>Captain</i> (act iii. sc. 3) and his
<i>Bonduca</i>, act i. sc. 2.</p>
<p>The only tune that Mr. Chappell could find for the ballad was
one by Dr. John Wilson (the Jack Wilson of Shakspere's stage
according to Dr. Rimbault), which is printed in his <i>Cheerful Ayres</i>
<i>or Ballads</i>, Oxford, 1660.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i192.png" id="img_images_i192.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">When Troy towne had, for ten yeeres "past,"<a id="FNanchor_407"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_407">[407]</a><br></span>
<span class="i4">Withstood the Greekes in manfull wise,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then did their foes encrease soe fast,<br></span>
<span class="i4">That to resist none could suffice:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wast lye those walls, that were soe good,                            <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And corne now growes where Troy towne stoode.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Æneas, wandering prince of Troy,<br></span>
<span class="i4">When he for land long time had sought,<br></span>
<span class="i2">At length arriving with great joy,<br></span>
<span class="i4">To mighty Carthage walls was brought;                           <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where Dido queene, with sumptuous feast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did entertaine that wandering guest.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">And, as in hall at meate, they sate,<br></span>
<span class="i4">The queene, desirous newes to heare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">"Says, of thy Troys unhappy fate"                                 <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Declare to me thou Trojan deare:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The heavy hap and chance soe bad,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That thou, poore wandering prince, hast had,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">And then anon this comelye knight,<br></span>
<span class="i4">With words demure, as he cold well,                             <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of his unhappy ten yeares "fight,"<br></span>
<span class="i4">Soe true a tale began to tell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With words soe sweete, and sighes so deepe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That oft he made them all to weepe.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_193">[Pg 193]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">And then a thousand sighes he fet,<a id="FNanchor_408"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_408">[408]</a> <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And every sigh brought teares amaine;<br></span>
<span class="i2">That where he sate the place was wett,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As though he had seene those warrs againe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Soe that the queene, with ruth therfore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Said, worthy prince, enough, no more.                               <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">And then the darksome night drew on,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And twinkling starres the skye bespred;<br></span>
<span class="i2">When he his dolefull tale had done,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And every one was layd in bedd:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where they full sweetly tooke their rest,                           <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Save only Dido's boyling brest.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">This silly woman never slept,<br></span>
<span class="i4">But in her chamber, all alone,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As one unhappye, alwayes wept,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And to the walls shee made her mone;                            <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That she shold still desire in vaine<br></span>
<span class="i0">The thing, she never must obtaine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">And thus in grieffe she spent the night,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Till twinkling starres the skye were fled,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And Phœbus, with his glistering light,                         <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Through misty cloudes appeared red;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then tidings came to her anon,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That all the Trojan shipps were gone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">And then the queene with bloody knife<br></span>
<span class="i4">Did arme her hart as hard as stone,                             <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet, something loth to loose her life,<br></span>
<span class="i4">In woefull wise she made her mone;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, rowling on her carefull bed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With sighes and sobbs, these words shee sayd:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">O wretched Dido queene! quoth shee,                               <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">I see thy end approacheth neare;<br></span>
<span class="i2">For hee is fled away from thee,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_194">[Pg 194]</a></span>
<span class="i4">Whom thou didst love and hold so deare:<br></span>
<span class="i0">What is he gone, and passed by?<br></span>
<span class="i0">O hart, prepare thyselfe to dye.                                    <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Though reason says, thou shouldst forbeare,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And stay thy hand from bloudy stroke;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet fancy bids thee not to fear,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Which fetter'd thee in Cupids yoke.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Come death, quoth shee, resolve my smart!—                         <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And with those words shee peerced her hart.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">When death had pierced the tender hart<br></span>
<span class="i4">Of Dido, Carthaginian queene;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whose bloudy knife did end the smart,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Which shee sustain'd in mournfull teene<a id="FNanchor_409"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_409">[409]</a>;                   <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Æneas being shipt and gone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose flattery caused all her mone;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Her funerall most costly made,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And all things finisht mournfullye;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her body fine in mold was laid,                                   <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Where itt consumed speedilye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her sisters teares her tombe bestrewde;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her subjects griefe their kindnesse shewed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Then was Æneas in an ile<br></span>
<span class="i4">In Grecya, where he stayd long space,                           <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Wheras her sister in short while<br></span>
<span class="i4">Writt to him to his vile disgrace;<br></span>
<span class="i0">In speeches bitter to his mind<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shee told him plaine he was unkind.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">False-harted wretch, quoth shee, thou art;                        <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And traiterouslye thou hast betraid<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unto thy lure a gentle hart,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Which unto thee much welcome made;<br></span>
<span class="i0">My sister deare, and Carthage' joy,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_195">[Pg 195]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Whose folly bred her deere annoy.                                   <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Yett on her death-bed when shee lay,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Shee prayd for thy prosperitye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Beseeching god, that every day<br></span>
<span class="i4">Might breed thy great felicitye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus by thy meanes I lost a friend;                                 <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Heavens send thee such untimely end.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">When he these lines, full fraught with gall,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Perused had, and wayed them right,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His lofty courage then did fall;<br></span>
<span class="i4">And straight appeared in his sight                             <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Queene Dido's ghost, both grim and pale;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which made this valliant souldier quaile.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Æneas, quoth this ghastly ghost,<br></span>
<span class="i4">My whole delight when I did live,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thee of all men I loved most;                                    <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">My fancy and my will did give;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For entertainment I thee gave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unthankefully thou didst me grave.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Therfore prepare thy flitting soule<br></span>
<span class="i4">To wander with me in the aire;                                 <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Where deadlye griefe shall make it howle,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Because of me thou tookst no care:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Delay not time, thy glasse is run,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy date is past, thy life is done.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">O stay a while, thou lovely sprite,                              <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Be not soe hasty to convay<br></span>
<span class="i2">My soule into eternall night,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Where itt shall ne're behold bright day.<br></span>
<span class="i0">O doe not frowne; thy angry looke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hath "all my soule with horror shooke."<a id="FNanchor_410"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_410">[410]</a> <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_196">[Pg 196]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">But, woe is me! all is in vaine,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And bootless is my dismall crye;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Time will not be recalled againe,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Nor thou surcease before I dye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">O lett me live, and make amends                                    <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To some of thy most deerest friends.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">But seeing thou obdurate art,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And wilt no pittye on me show,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Because from thee I did depart,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And left unpaid what I did owe:                                <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I must content myselfe to take<br></span>
<span class="i0">What lott to me thou wilt partake.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">And thus, as one being in a trance,<br></span>
<span class="i4">A multitude of uglye feinds<br></span>
<span class="i2">About this woffull prince did dance;                             <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">He had no helpe of any friends:<br></span>
<span class="i0">His body then they tooke away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And no man knew his dying day.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_406"></a><a href="#FNanchor_406" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[406]</span></a> [Ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. iii. p. 502.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_407"></a><a href="#FNanchor_407" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[407]</span></a> [Ver. 1. 21. war. MS. and PP.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_408"></a><a href="#FNanchor_408" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[408]</span></a> fetched.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_409"></a><a href="#FNanchor_409" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[409]</span></a> [trouble.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_410"></a><a href="#FNanchor_410" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[410]</span></a> Ver. 120. MS. <i>Hath</i> made my breath my life forsooke.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XXIII.<br>

THE WITCHES' SONG</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i196.png" id="img_images_i196.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">From</span> Ben Jonson's <i>Masque of Queens</i> presented at
Whitehall, Feb. 2, 1609.</p>
<p>The editor thought it incumbent on him to insert
some old pieces on the popular superstition concerning
witches, hobgoblins, fairies, and ghosts. The last of these make
their appearance in most of the tragical ballads; and in the following
songs will be found some description of the former.</p>
<p>It is true, this song of the Witches, falling from the learned pen
of Ben Jonson, is rather an extract from the various incantations
of classical antiquity, than a display of the opinions of our own
vulgar. But let it be observed, that a parcel of learned wiseacres
had just before busied themselves on this subject, in compliment<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_197">[Pg 197]</a></span>
to K. James I. whose weakness on this head is well known: and
these had so ransacked all writers, ancient and modern, and so
blended and kneaded together the several superstitions of different
times and nations, that those of genuine English growth could no
longer be traced out and distinguished.</p>
<p>By good luck the whimsical belief of fairies and goblins could
furnish no pretences for torturing our fellow-creatures, and therefore
we have this handed down to us pure and unsophisticated.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">1 Witch.</span><a id="FNanchor_411"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_411">[411]</a>
</p>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i197.png" id="img_images_i197.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I have been all day looking after<br></span>
<span class="i0">A raven feeding upon a quarter;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, soone as she turn'd her beak to the south,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I snatch'd this morsell out of her mouth.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">2 Witch.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I have beene gathering wolves haires,                                <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The madd dogges foames, and adders eares;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The spurging of a deadmans eyes:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all since the evening starre did rise.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">3 Witch.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I last night lay all alone<br></span>
<span class="i0">O' the ground, to heare the mandrake grone;                         <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And pluckt him up, though he grew full low:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, as I had done, the cocke did crow.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">4 Witch.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And I ha' beene chusing out this scull<br></span>
<span class="i0">From charnell houses that were full;<br></span>
<span class="i0">From private grots, and publike pits;                               <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_198">[Pg 198]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And frighted a sexton out of his wits.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">5 Witch.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Under a cradle I did crepe<br></span>
<span class="i0">By day; and, when the childe was a-sleepe<br></span>
<span class="i0">At night, I suck'd the breath; and rose,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And pluck'd the nodding nurse by the nose.                          <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">6 Witch.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I had a dagger: what did I with that?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Killed an infant to have his fat.<br></span>
<span class="i0">A piper it got at a church-ale,<a id="FNanchor_412"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_412">[412]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">I bade him again blow wind i' the taile.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">7 Witch.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A murderer, yonder, was hung in chaines;                            <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The sunne and the wind had shrunke his veines:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I bit off a sinew; I clipp'd his haire;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I brought off his ragges, that danc'd i' the ayre.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">8 Witch.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The scrich-owles egges and the feathers blacke,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The bloud of the frogge, and the bone in his backe                  <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I have been getting; and made of his skin<br></span>
<span class="i0">A purset, to keep sir Cranion<a id="FNanchor_413"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_413">[413]</a> in.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">9 Witch.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And I ha' beene plucking (plants among)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hemlock, henbane, adders-tongue,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Night-shade, moone-wort, libbards-bane<a id="FNanchor_414"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_414">[414]</a>;                        <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And twise by the dogges was like to be tane.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_199">[Pg 199]</a></span></p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">10 Witch.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I from the jawes of a gardiner's bitch<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did snatch these bones, and then leap'd the ditch:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet went I back to the house againe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kill'd the blacke cat, and here is the braine.                      <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">11 Witch.</span>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I went to the toad, breedes under the wall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I charmed him out, and he came at my call;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I scratch'd out the eyes of the owle before;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I tore the batts wing: what would you have more?<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Dame.</span><a id="FNanchor_415"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_415">[415]</a>
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yes: I have brought, to helpe your vows,                            <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Horned poppie, cypresse boughes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fig-tree wild, that growes on tombes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And juice, that from the larch-tree comes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The basiliskes bloud, and the viper's skin:<br></span>
<span class="i2">And now our orgies let's begin.                                   <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_411"></a><a href="#FNanchor_411" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[411]</span></a> [These witches are called Hags by Jonson.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_412"></a><a href="#FNanchor_412" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[412]</span></a> [a wake or feast in commemoration of the dedication of a
church.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_413"></a><a href="#FNanchor_413" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[413]</span></a> [skull.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_414"></a><a href="#FNanchor_414" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[414]</span></a> [the herb wolfbane.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_415"></a><a href="#FNanchor_415" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[415]</span></a> [Jonson meant the Dame to represent Ate or the goddess of
Mischief.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XXIV.<br>

ROBIN GOOD-FELLOW,</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i199.png" id="img_images_i199.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">Alias</span> <i>Pucke</i>, alias <i>Hobgoblin</i>, in the creed of ancient
superstition, was a kind of merry sprite, whose character
and atchievements are recorded in this ballad, and in
those well-known lines of Milton's <i>L'Allegro</i>, which the
antiquarian Peck supposes to be owing to it:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Tells how the drudging <i>Goblin</i> swet<br></span>
<span class="i0">To earn his creame-bowle duly set;<br></span>
<span class="i0">When in one night ere glimpse of morne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His shadowy flail hath thresh'd the corn<br></span>
<span class="i0">That ten day-labourers could not end;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_200">[Pg 200]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Then lies him down the lubber fiend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And stretch'd out all the chimneys length,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Basks at the fire his hairy strength,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And crop-full out of doors he flings,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere the first cock his matins rings."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>The reader will observe that our simple ancestors had reduced
all these whimsies to a kind of system, as regular, and perhaps
more consistent, than many parts of classic mythology: a proof of
the extensive influence and vast antiquity of these superstitions.
Mankind, and especially the common people, could not every
where have been so unanimously agreed concerning these arbitrary
notions, if they had not prevailed among them for many
ages. Indeed, a learned friend in Wales assures the Editor, that
the existence of Fairies and Goblins is alluded to by the most
ancient British Bards, who mention them under various names,
one of the most common of which signifies, <i>The spirits of the</i>
<i>mountains</i>. See also Preface to Song XXV.</p>
<p>This song, which Peck attributes to Ben Jonson, (tho' it is not
found among his works) is chiefly printed from an ancient black-letter
copy in the British Museum. It seems to have been originally
intended for some Masque.</p>
<p>It is intitled, in the old black-letter copies, <i>The mad merry</i>
<i>Prankes of Robin Goodfellow</i>. To the tune of <i>Dulcina</i>, &amp;c. (See
No. XIII. above.)</p>
<p>To one, if not more of the old copies, are prefixed two wooden
cuts, said to be taken from Bulwer's <i>Artificial Changeling, &amp;c.</i>,
which, as they seem to correspond with the notions then entertained
of the whimsical appearances of this fantastic spirit, and
perhaps were copied in the dresses in which he was formerly exhibited
on the stage, are, to gratify the curious, engraven below.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The copy in the Roxburghe <i>Collection</i> (ed. Chappell, vol. ii.
pl. i. p. 80) is printed by H[enry] G[osson], who was a contemporary
of Ben Jonson. Some little books in prose on <i>Robin Goodfellow</i>,
written in the seventeenth century, were printed for the
Percy Society by Mr. J. P. Collier.]</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_201">[Pg 201]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i201.png" id="img_images_i201.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">From Oberon, in fairye land,<br></span>
<span class="i4">The king of ghosts and shadowes there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Mad Robin I, at his command,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Am sent to viewe the night-sports here.<br></span>
<span class="i8">What revell rout                                             <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">Is kept about,<br></span>
<span class="i4">In every corner where I go,<br></span>
<span class="i8">I will o'ersee,<br></span>
<span class="i8">And merry bee,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And make good sport, with ho, ho, ho!                           <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">More swift than lightening can I flye<br></span>
<span class="i4">About this aery welkin soone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, in a minutes space, descrye<br></span>
<span class="i4">Each thing that's done belowe the moone,<br></span>
<span class="i8">There's not a hag                                           <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">Or ghost shall wag,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Or cry, ware Goblins! where I go;<br></span>
<span class="i8">But Robin I<br></span>
<span class="i8">Their feates will spy,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And send them home, with ho, ho, ho!                            <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Whene'er such wanderers I meete,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As from their night-sports they trudge home;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With counterfeiting voice I greete<br></span>
<span class="i4">And call them on, with me to roame<br></span>
<span class="i8">Thro' woods, thro' lakes,                                   <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">Thro' bogs, thro' brakes;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Or else, unseene, with them I go,<br></span>
<span class="i8">All in the nicke<br></span>
<span class="i8">To play some tricke<br></span>
<span class="i4">And frolicke it, with ho, ho, ho!                               <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sometimes I meete them like a man;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sometimes, an ox, sometimes, a hound;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to a horse I turn me can;<br></span>
<span class="i4">To trip and trot about them round.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_202">[Pg 202]</a></span>
<span class="i8">But if, to ride,                                            <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">My backe they stride,<br></span>
<span class="i4">More swift than wind away I go,<br></span>
<span class="i8">Ore hedge and lands,<br></span>
<span class="i8">Thro' pools and ponds<br></span>
<span class="i4">I whirry, laughing, ho, ho, ho!                                 <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When lads and lasses merry be,<br></span>
<span class="i4">With possets and with juncates fine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unseene of all the company,<br></span>
<span class="i4">I eat their cakes and sip their wine;<br></span>
<span class="i8">And, to make sport,                                         <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">I fart and snort;<br></span>
<span class="i4">And out the candles I do blow:<br></span>
<span class="i8">The maids I kiss;<br></span>
<span class="i8">They shrieke—Who's this?<br></span>
<span class="i4">I answer nought, but ho, ho, ho!                                <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet now and then, the maids to please,<br></span>
<span class="i4">At midnight I card up their wooll;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And while they sleepe, and take their ease,<br></span>
<span class="i4">With wheel to threads their flax I pull.<br></span>
<span class="i8">I grind at mill                                             <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">Their malt up still;<br></span>
<span class="i4">I dress their hemp, I spin their tow.<br></span>
<span class="i8">If any 'wake,<br></span>
<span class="i8">And would me take,<br></span>
<span class="i4">I wend me, laughing, ho, ho, ho!                                <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When house or harth doth sluttish lye,<a id="FNanchor_416"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_416">[416]</a><br></span>
<span class="i4">I pinch the maidens blacke and blue;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The bed-clothes from the bedd pull I,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And lay them naked all to view.<br></span>
<span class="i8">'Twixt sleepe and wake,                                     <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">I do them take,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And on the key-cold floor them throw.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_203">[Pg 203]</a></span>
<span class="i8">If out they cry,<br></span>
<span class="i8">Then forth I fly,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And loudly laugh out, ho, ho, ho!                               <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When any need to borrowe ought,<br></span>
<span class="i4">We lend them what they do require;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for the use demand we nought;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Our owne is all we do desire.<br></span>
<span class="i8">If to repay,                                                <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">They do delay,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Abroad amongst them then I go,<br></span>
<span class="i8">And night by night,<br></span>
<span class="i8">I them affright<br></span>
<span class="i4">With pinchings, dreames, and ho, ho, ho!                        <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When lazie queans have nought to do,<br></span>
<span class="i4">But study how to cog and lye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">To make debate and mischief too,<br></span>
<span class="i4">'Twixt one another secretlye:<br></span>
<span class="i8">I marke their gloze,                                        <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">And it disclose,<br></span>
<span class="i4">To them whom they have wronged so;<br></span>
<span class="i8">When I have done,<br></span>
<span class="i8">I get me gone,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And leave them scolding, ho, ho, ho!                            <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When men do traps and engins set<br></span>
<span class="i4">In loop-holes, where the vermine creepe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who from their foldes and houses, get<br></span>
<span class="i4">Their duckes and geese, and lambes and sheepe:<br></span>
<span class="i8">I spy the gin,                                              <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">And enter in,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And seeme a vermine taken so;<br></span>
<span class="i8">But when they there<br></span>
<span class="i8">Approach me neare,<br></span>
<span class="i4">I leap out laughing, ho, ho, ho!                               <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_204">[Pg 204]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">By wells and rills,<a id="FNanchor_417"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_417">[417]</a> in meadowes greene,<br></span>
<span class="i4">We nightly dance our hey-day guise;<a id="FNanchor_418"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_418">[418]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">And to our fairye king, and queene,<br></span>
<span class="i4">We chant our moon-light minstrelsies.<br></span>
<span class="i8">When larks 'gin sing,                                      <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">Away we fling;<br></span>
<span class="i4">And babes new borne steal as we go,<br></span>
<span class="i8">And else in bed,<br></span>
<span class="i8">We leave instead,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And wend us laughing, ho, ho, ho!                              <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">From hag-bred Merlin's time have I<br></span>
<span class="i4">Thus nightly revell'd to and fro:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for my pranks men call me by<br></span>
<span class="i4">The name of Robin Good-fellow.<br></span>
<span class="i8">Fiends, ghosts, and sprites,                               <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i8">Who haunt the nightes,<br></span>
<span class="i4">The hags and goblins do me know;<br></span>
<span class="i8">And beldames old<br></span>
<span class="i8">My feates have told;<br></span>
<span class="i4">So <i>Vale, Vale</i>; ho, ho, ho!                              <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_416"></a><a href="#FNanchor_416" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[416]</span></a> [Ver. 61. this begins the second part in the Roxburghe copy.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_417"></a><a href="#FNanchor_417" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[417]</span></a> [gills=rivulets, <i>Roxb. copy</i>.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_418"></a><a href="#FNanchor_418" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[418]</span></a> [a misprint for heydegies=rustic dances. The word occurs in
Lily's <i>Endymion</i>, 1591, and in Wm. Bulleyn's <i>Dialogue</i>, 1564,
where the minstrel daunces "Trenchmore" and "Heie de gie."—<i>Chappell.</i>]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XXV.<br>

THE FAIRY QUEEN.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i204.png" id="img_images_i204.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capm"><span class="smcap">We</span> have here a short display of the popular belief concerning
<i>Fairies</i>. It will afford entertainment to a contemplative
mind to trace these whimsical opinions up
to their origin. Whoever considers, how early, how
extensively, and how uniformly, they have prevailed in these
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_205">[Pg 205]</a></span>nations, will not readily assent to the hypothesis of those, who
fetch them from the east so late as the time of the Croisades.
Whereas it is well known that our Saxon ancestors, long before
they left their German forests, believed the existence of a kind of
diminutive demons, or middle species between men and spirits,
whom they called <i>Duergar</i> or <i>Dwarfs</i>, and to whom they attributed
many wonderful performances, far exceeding human art.
Vid. Hervarer Saga Olaj Verelj. 1675. Hickes' Thesaur., &amp;c.</p>
<p>This Song is given (with some corrections by another copy)
from a book intitled, <i>The Mysteries of Love and Eloquence, &amp;c.</i>
Lond. 1658, 8vo.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Dr. Rimbault points out that this song occurs in a rare tract
published more than twenty years before the book mentioned
above. It is entitled, <i>A description of the King and Queen of the</i>
<i>Fayries, their habit, fare, abode, pomp and state, being very delightful</i>
<i>to the sense and full of mirth</i>. London, 1635. The song was to
be sung to the tune of the <i>Spanish Gypsie</i>, which began—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"O follow, follow me<br></span>
<span class="i0">For we be gypsies three."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>Martin Parker wrote a sort of parody called <i>The three merry</i>
<i>Cobblers</i>, commencing—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Come follow, follow me<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the alehouse we'll march all three;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Leave awl, last, thread and leather,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And let's go all together."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>Mr. Chappell prints the first, eighth, fourteenth and last stanzas
(<i>Popular Music</i>, vol. i. p. 272.)]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i205.png" id="img_images_i205.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Come, follow, follow me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">You, fairy elves that be:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which circle on the greene,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Come follow Mab your queene.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hand in hand let's dance around,                                     <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">For this place is fairye ground.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_206">[Pg 206]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">When mortals are at rest,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And snoring in their nest;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unheard, and un-espy'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Through key-holes we do glide;                                    <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Over tables, stools, and shelves.<br></span>
<span class="i0">We trip it with our fairy elves.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">And, if the house be foul<a id="FNanchor_419"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_419">[419]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">With platter, dish or bowl,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Up stairs we nimbly creep,                                        <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And find the sluts asleep:<br></span>
<span class="i0">There we pinch their armes and thighes;<br></span>
<span class="i0">None escapes, nor none espies.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">But if the house be swept,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And from uncleanness kept,                                        <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">We praise the household maid,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And duely she is paid:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For we use before we goe<br></span>
<span class="i0">To drop a tester<a id="FNanchor_420"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_420">[420]</a> in her shoe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Upon a mushroomes head                                            <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Our table-cloth we spread;<br></span>
<span class="i2">A grain of rye, or wheat,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Is manchet,<a id="FNanchor_421"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_421">[421]</a> which we eat;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pearly drops of dew we drink<br></span>
<span class="i0">In acorn cups fill'd to the brink.                                  <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">The brains of nightingales,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With unctuous fat of snailes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Between two cockles stew'd,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_207">[Pg 207]</a></span>
<span class="i2">Is meat that's easily chew'd;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tailes of wormes, and marrow of mice                                <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Do make a dish, that's wonderous nice.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">The grashopper, gnat, and fly,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Serve for our minstrelsie;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Grace said, we dance a while,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And so the time beguile;                                          <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And if the moon doth hide her head,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The gloe-worm lights us home to bed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">On tops of dewie grasse<br></span>
<span class="i2">So nimbly do we passe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The young and tender stalk                                        <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Ne'er bends when we do walk:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet in the morning may be seen<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where we the night before have been.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_419"></a><a href="#FNanchor_419" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[419]</span></a> [Puck's speech in <i>Midsummer Night's Dream</i> (act v. sc. 2)—
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"I am sent with broom before<br></span>
<span class="i0">To sweep the dust behind the door,"<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>
illustrates the delight of the fairies in cleanliness, which is dwelt
upon in this and the following song.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_420"></a><a href="#FNanchor_420" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[420]</span></a> [tester or teston=sixpence.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_421"></a><a href="#FNanchor_421" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[421]</span></a> [best kind of white bread.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XXVI.<br>

THE FAIRIES FAREWELL.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i207.png" id="img_images_i207.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> humorous old song fell from the hand of the witty
Dr. <i>Corbet</i> (afterwards bishop of Norwich, &amp;c.) and is
printed from his <i>Poëtica Stromata</i>, 1648, 12mo. (compared
with the third edition of his poems, 1672.) It
is there called, <i>A proper new Ballad, intitled, The Fairies Farewell,</i>
<i>or God-a-mercy Will, to be sung or whistled to the tune of The Meddow</i>
<i>brow, by the learned; by the unlearned, to the tune of Fortune</i>.</p>
<p>The departure of Fairies is here attributed to the abolition of
monkery: Chaucer has, with equal humour, assigned a cause the
very reverse, in his <i>Wife of Bath's Tale</i>.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"In olde dayes of the king Artour,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of which that Bretons speken gret honour,<br></span>
<span class="i0">All was this lond fulfilled of faerie;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The elf-quene, with hire joly compagnie<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_208">[Pg 208]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Danced ful oft in many a grene mede.<br></span>
<span class="i0">This was the old opinion as I rede;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I speke of many hundred yeres ago;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now can no man see non elves mo,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For now the grete charitee and prayeres<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of limitoures and other holy freres,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That serchen every land and every streme,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As thikke as motes in the sonne beme,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Blissing halles, chambres, kichenes, and boures,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Citees and burghes, castles high and toures,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thropes and bernes, shepenes and dairies,<br></span>
<span class="i0">This maketh that ther ben no faeries:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For ther as wont to walken was an elf,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ther walketh now the limitour himself,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In undermeles and in morweninges,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And sayth his Matines and his holy thinges,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he goth in his limitatioun.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Women may now go safely up and doun,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In every bush, and under every tree,<br></span>
