<span class="i0">Ther is non other incubus but he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he ne will don hem no dishonour."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">Tyrwhitt's <i>Chaucer</i>, i. p. 255.</p>
<p>Dr. Richard Corbet, having been bishop of Oxford about three
years, and afterwards as long bishop of Norwich, died in 1635,
Ætat. 52.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i208.png" id="img_images_i208.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Farewell rewards and Fairies!<br></span>
<span class="i2">Good housewives now may say;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For now foule sluts in dairies,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Doe fare as well as they:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And though they sweepe their hearths no less                         <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Than mayds were wont to doe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet who of late for cleaneliness<br></span>
<span class="i2">Finds sixe-pence in her shoe?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Lament, lament old Abbies,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The fairies lost command;                                         <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They did but change priests babies,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But some have chang'd your land:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_209">[Pg 209]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And all your children stoln from thence<br></span>
<span class="i2">Are now growne Puritanes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who live as changelings ever since,                                 <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For love of your demaines.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At morning and at evening both<br></span>
<span class="i2">You merry were and glad,<br></span>
<span class="i0">So little care of sleepe and sloth,<br></span>
<span class="i2">These prettie ladies had.                                         <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">When Tom came home from labour,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or Ciss to milking rose,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then merrily went their tabour,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And nimbly went their toes.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Witness those rings and roundelayes                                 <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of theirs, which yet remaine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Were footed in queene Maries dayes<br></span>
<span class="i2">On many a grassy playne.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But since of late Elizabeth<br></span>
<span class="i2">And later James came in;                                          <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">They never danc'd on any heath,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As when the time hath bin.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">By which wee note the fairies                                       <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Were of the old profession:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their songs were <i>Ave Maries</i>,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Their dances were procession.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But now, alas! they all are dead,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or gone beyond the seas,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or farther for religion fled,<br></span>
<span class="i1">Or else they take their ease.                                      <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A tell-tale in their company<br></span>
<span class="i2">They never could endure;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And whoso kept not secretly<br></span>
<span class="i2">Their mirth, was punish'd sure:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_210">[Pg 210]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It was a just and christian deed                                    <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To pinch such blacke and blue:<br></span>
<span class="i0">O how the common-welth doth need<br></span>
<span class="i2">Such justices, as you!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now they have left our quarters;<br></span>
<span class="i2">A Register they have,                                             <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who can preserve their charters;<br></span>
<span class="i2">A man both wise and grave.<br></span>
<span class="i0">An hundred of their merry pranks<br></span>
<span class="i2">By one that I could name<br></span>
<span class="i0">Are kept in store; con twenty thanks                                <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To William for the same.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To William Churne of Staffordshire<br></span>
<span class="i2">Give laud and praises due,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who every meale can mend your cheare<br></span>
<span class="i2">With tales both old and true:                                     <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To William all give audience,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And pray yee for his noddle:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For all the fairies evidence<br></span>
<span class="i2">Were lost, if it were addle.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>⁂ After these <i>Songs</i> on the <i>Fairies</i>, the reader may be curious
to see the manner in which they were formerly invoked and bound
to human service. In Ashmole's <i>Collection of MSS.</i> at Oxford
(Num. 8259. 1406. 2), are the papers of some alchymist, which
contain a variety of Incantations and Forms of Conjuring both
<i>Fairies</i>, <i>Witches</i>, and <i>Demons</i>, principally, as it should seem, to
assist him in his Great Work of transmuting Metals. Most of
them are too impious to be reprinted: but the two following may
be very innocently laughed at.</p>
<p>Whoever looks into Ben Jonson's <i>Alchymist</i>, will find that these
impostors, among their other secrets, affected to have a power over
<i>Fairies</i>: and that they were commonly expected to be seen in a
christal glass appears from that extraordinary book, <i>The Relation</i>
<i>of Dr. John Dee's actions with Spirits</i>, 1659, folio.</p>
<p><i>"An excellent way</i> to gett a <i>Fayrie</i>. (For myself I call <i>Margarett</i>
<i>Barrance</i>; but this will obteine any one that is not allready
bownd.)</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_211">[Pg 211]</a></span></p>
<p>"First, gett a broad square christall or Venice glasse, in length
and breadth 3 inches. Then lay that glasse or christall in the
bloud of a white henne, 3 Wednesdayes, or 3 Fridayes. Then
take it out, and wash it with holy aq. and fumigate it. Then take
3 hazle sticks, or wands of an yeare groth: pill them fayre and
white; and make 'them' soe longe, as you write the <i>Spiritts</i>
name, or <i>Fayries</i> name, which you call, 3 times on every sticke
being made flatt on one side. Then bury them under some
hill, whereas you suppose <i>Fayries</i> haunt, the Wednesday before
you call her: and the Friday followinge take them uppe, and call
her at 8 or 3 or 10 of the clocke, which be good planetts and
houres for that turne: but when you call, be in cleane life, and
turne thy face towards the east. And when you have her, bind
her to that stone or glasse."</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"An Unguent to annoynt under the Eyelids, and upon the
Eyelids eveninge and morninge: but especially when you call;
or find your sight not perfect.</p></div>
<p>"R. A pint of sallet-oyle, and put it into a viall glasse: but
first wash it with rose-water, and marygold-water; the flowers 'to'
be gathered towards the east. Wash it till the oyle come white;
then put it into the glasse, <i>ut supra</i>: and then put thereto the
budds of holyhocke, the flowers of marygold, the flowers or toppes
of wild thime, the budds of young hazle: and the thime must be
gathered neare the side of a hill where <i>Fayries</i> use to be: and
'take' the grasse of a fayrie throne, there. All these put into the
oyle, into the glasse: and set it to dissolve 3 dayes in the sunne,
and then keep it for thy use; <i>ut supra</i>."</p>
<p>After this receipt for the unguent follows a form of incantation,
wherein the alchymist conjures a fairy, named <i>Elaby Gathon</i>, to
appear to him in that chrystal glass, meekly and mildly; to resolve
him truly in all manner of questions; and to be obedient to all his
commands, under pain of damnation, &amp;c.</p>
<p>One of the vulgar opinions about fairies is, that they cannot be
seen by human eyes, without a particular charm exerted in favour
of the person who is to see them: and that they strike with blindness
such as having the gift of seeing them, take notice of them
<i>mal-à-propos</i>.</p>
<p>As to the hazle sticks mentioned above, they were to be probably
of that species called the <i>witch hazle</i>; which received its
name from this manner of applying it in incantations.</p></div>
<p class="center">THE END OF BOOK THE SECOND.
</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_212">[Pg 212]</a><br><a id="Page_213">[Pg 213]</a></span></p>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 600px;">
<img alt="" height="96" src="images/i213.png" width="600" id="img_images_i213.png">
</div>
<p class="ph1">RELIQUES OF ANCIENT POETRY, ETC.</p>
<p class="ph1">SERIES THE THIRD.</p>
<hr class="chap">
<h2> <a id="BOOK_III">BOOK III.</a></h2>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_214">[Pg 214]</a><br><a id="Page_215">[Pg 215]</a></span></p>
<div class="figcenter" style="height: 100px;">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i213a.png" id="img_images_i213a.png">
</div>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 600px;">
<img alt="" height="105" src="images/i215.png" width="600" id="img_images_i215.png">
</div>
<h3>I.<br>

THE BIRTH OF ST. GEORGE.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i215t.png" id="img_images_i215t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> incidents in this, and the other ballad of <i>St. George</i>
<i>and the Dragon</i>, are chiefly taken from the old story-book
of the Seven Champions of Christendome; which,
tho' now the play-thing of children, was once in high
repute. Bp. Hall in his <i>Satires</i>, published in 1597, ranks</p>
<p class="center">"St. George's sorell, and his cross of blood,"
</p>
<p>among the most popular stories of his time: and an ingenious
critic thinks that Spencer himself did not disdain to borrow hints
from it;<a id="FNanchor_422"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_422">[422]</a> tho' I much doubt whether this popular romance were
written so early as the <i>Faery Queen</i>.</p>
<p>The author of this book of the <i>Seven Champions</i> was one Richard
Johnson, who lived in the reigns of Elizabeth and James, as we
collect from his other publications: viz.—<i>The nine worthies of</i>
<i>London</i>: 1592, 4to.—<i>The pleasant walks of Moor fields</i>: 1607,
4to.—<i>A crown garland of Goulden Roses, gathered, &amp;c.</i> 1612, 8vo.—<i>The</i>
<i>life and death of Rob. Cecill, E. of Salisbury</i>: 1612, 4to.—<i>The</i>
<i>Hist. of Tom of Lincoln</i>, 4to. is also by R. J. who likewise
reprinted <i>Don Flores of Greece</i>, 4to.</p>
<p>The <i>Seven Champions</i>, tho' written in a wild inflated style, contains
some strong Gothic painting; which seems, for the most
part, copied from the metrical romances of former ages. At least
the story of <i>St. George and the fair Sabra</i> is taken almost verbatim
from the old poetical legend of <i>Syr Bevis of Hampton</i>.</p>
<p>This very antique poem was in great fame in Chaucer's time
(see above, pag. 107.), and so continued till the introduction of
printing, when it ran thro' several editions; two of which are in
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_216">[Pg 216]</a></span>black letter, 4to. "imprinted by Wyllyam Copland," without date;
containing great variations.</p>
<p>As a specimen of the poetic powers of this very old rhimist, and
as a proof how closely the author of the <i>Seven Champions</i> has followed
him, take a description of the dragon slain by sir Bevis.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"—Whan the dragon, that foule is,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had a syght of syr Bevis,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He cast up a loude cry,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As it had thondred in the sky;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He turned his bely towarde the son;<br></span>
<span class="i0">It was greater than any tonne:<br></span>
<span class="i0">His scales was bryghter then the glas,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And harder they were than any bras:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Betwene his shulder and his tayle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was forty fote withoute fayle.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He waltred out of his denne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Bevis pricked his stede then,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to hym a spere he thraste<br></span>
<span class="i0">That all to shyvers he it braste:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The dragon then gan Bevis assayle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And smote syr Bevis with his tayle;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then downe went horse and man,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And two rybbes of Bevis brused than."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>After a long fight, at length, as the dragon was preparing to fly,
sir Bevis</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Hit him under the wynge,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he was in his flyenge,<br></span>
<span class="i0">There he was tender without scale,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Bevis thought to be his bale.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He smote after, as I you saye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With his good sword Morglaye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Up to the hiltes Morglay yode<br></span>
<span class="i0">Through harte, lyver, bone, and bloude:<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the ground fell the dragon,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Great joye syr Bevis begon.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Under the scales al on hight<br></span>
<span class="i0">He smote off his head forth right,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And put it on a spere: &amp;c."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">Sign. K. iv.</p>
<p>Sir Bevis's dragon is evidently the parent of that in the <i>Seven</i>
<i>Champions</i>, see chap, iii., viz. "The dragon no sooner had a sight
of him (St. George) but he gave such a terrible peal, as though it
had thundered in the elements.... Betwixt his shoulders and his<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_217">[Pg 217]</a></span>
tail were fifty feet in distance, his scales glistering as bright as
silver, but far more hard than brass; his belly of the colour of
gold, but bigger than a tun. Thus weltered he from his den, &amp;c....
The champion ... gave the dragon such a thrust with his
spear, that it shivered in a thousand pieces: whereat the furious
dragon so fiercely smote him with his venomous tail, that down
fell man and horse: in which fall two of St. George's ribs were so
bruised, &amp;c.—At length ... St. George smote the dragon under
the wing where it was tender without scale, whereby his good
sword Ascalon with an easie passage went to the very hilt through
both the dragon's heart, liver, bone, and blood.—Then St. George—cut
off the dragon's head and pitcht it upon the truncheon of a
spear, &amp;c."</p>
<p>The <i>History of the Seven Champions</i>, being written just before
the decline of books of chivalry, was never, I believe, translated
into any foreign language: But <i>Le Roman de Beuves of Hantonne</i>
was published at Paris in 1502, 4to. Let. Gothique.</p>
<p>The learned Selden tell us, that about the time of the Norman
invasion was Bevis famous with the title of Earl of Southampton,
whose residence was at Duncton in Wiltshire; but he observes,
that the monkish enlargements of his story have made his very
existence doubted. See <i>Notes on Poly-Olbion, Song</i> iii.</p>
<p>This hath also been the case of <i>St. George</i> himself; whose
martial history is allowed to be apocryphal. But, to prove that
there really existed an orthodox saint of this name (altho' little or
nothing, it seems, is known of his genuine story) is the subject of
<i>An Historical and Critical Inquiry into the Existence and Character</i>
<i>of St. George, &amp;c.</i> By the Rev. J. Milner, F.S.A. 1792, 8vo.</p>
<p>The equestrian figure worn by the Knights of the Garter, has
been understood to be an emblem of the Christian warrior, in his
spiritual armour, vanquishing the old serpent.</p>
<p>But on this subject the inquisitive reader may consult <i>A Dissertation</i>
<i>on the Original of the Equestrian Figure of the George and of</i>
<i>the Garter, ensigns of the most noble order of that name</i>. Illustrated
with copper-plates. By John Petingal, A.M., Fellow of the Society
of Antiquaries, London, 1753, 4to. This learned and curious work
the author of the <i>Historical and Critical Inquiry</i> would have done
well to have seen.</p>
<p>It cannot be denied, but that the following ballad is for the
most part modern: for which reason it would have been thrown
to the end of the volume, had not its subject procured it a place
here.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[In respect to the last paragraph, Ritson writes, "It may be
safely denied, however, that the least part of it is ancient."]</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_218">[Pg 218]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i218.png" id="img_images_i218.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Listen, lords, in bower and hall,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I sing the wonderous birth<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of brave St. George, whose valorous arm<br></span>
<span class="i2">Rid monsters from the earth:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Distressed ladies to relieve                                         <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He travell'd many a day;<br></span>
<span class="i0">In honour of the christian faith,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which shall endure for aye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In Coventry sometime did dwell<br></span>
<span class="i2">A knight of worthy fame,                                          <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">High steward of this noble realme;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Lord Albert was his name.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He had to wife a princely dame,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whose beauty did excell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">This virtuous lady, being with child,                               <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In sudden sadness fell:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For thirty nights no sooner sleep<br></span>
<span class="i2">Had clos'd her wakeful eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But, lo! a foul and fearful dream<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her fancy would surprize:                                         <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She dreamt a dragon fierce and fell<br></span>
<span class="i2">Conceiv'd within her womb;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose mortal fangs her body rent<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ere he to life could come.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All woe-begone, and sad was she;                                    <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">She nourisht constant woe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet strove to hide it from her lord,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Lest he should sorrow know.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In vain she strove, her tender lord,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who watch'd her slightest look,                                   <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Discover'd soon her secret pain,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And soon that pain partook.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_219">[Pg 219]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when to him the fearful cause<br></span>
<span class="i2">She weeping did impart,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With kindest speech he strove to heal                               <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The anguish of her heart.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Be comforted, my lady dear,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Those pearly drops refrain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Betide me weal, betide me woe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I'll try to ease thy pain.                                        <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And for this foul and fearful dream,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That causeth all thy woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Trust me I'll travel far away<br></span>
<span class="i2">But I'll the meaning knowe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then giving many a fond embrace,                                    <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And shedding many a teare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To the weïrd lady of the woods<br></span>
<span class="i2">He purpos'd to repaire.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To the weïrd lady of the woods,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Full long and many a day,                                         <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thro' lonely shades, and thickets rough<br></span>
<span class="i2">He winds his weary way.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At length he reach'd a dreary dell<br></span>
<span class="i2">With dismal yews o'erhung;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where cypress spred its mournful boughs,                            <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And pois'nous nightshade sprung.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">No chearful gleams here pierc'd the gloom,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He hears no chearful sound;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But shrill night-ravens' yelling scream,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And serpents hissing round.                                       <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The shriek of fiends, and damned ghosts<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ran howling thro' his ear:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A chilling horror froze his heart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Tho' all unus'd to fear.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_220">[Pg 220]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Three times he strives to win his way,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And pierce those sickly dews:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Three times to bear his trembling corse<br></span>
<span class="i2">His knocking knees refuse.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At length upon his beating breast<br></span>
<span class="i2">He signs the holy crosse;                                         <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And, rouzing up his wonted might,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He treads th' unhallow'd mosse.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Beneath a pendant craggy cliff,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All vaulted like a grave,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And opening in the solid rock,                                      <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He found the inchanted cave.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">An iron gate clos'd up the mouth,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All hideous and forlorne;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, fasten'd by a silver chain,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Near hung a brazed horne.                                         <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then offering up a secret prayer,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Three times he blowes amaine:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Three times a deepe and hollow sound<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did answer him againe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Sir knight, thy lady beares a son,                                 <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who, like a dragon bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall prove most dreadful to his foes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And terrible in fight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"His name advanc'd in future times<br></span>
<span class="i2">On banners shall be worn:                                         <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But lo! thy lady's life must passe<br></span>
<span class="i2">Before he can be born."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All sore opprest with fear and doubt<br></span>
<span class="i2">Long time lord Albert stood;<br></span>
<span class="i0">At length he winds his doubtful way                                 <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Back thro' the dreary wood.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_221">[Pg 221]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Eager to clasp his lovely dame<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then fast he travels back:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But when he reach'd his castle gate,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His gate was hung with black.                                    <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In every court and hall he found<br></span>
<span class="i2">A sullen silence reigne;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save where, amid the lonely towers,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He heard her maidens 'plaine;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And bitterly lament and weep,                                      <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With many a grievous grone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then sore his bleeding heart misgave,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His lady's life was gone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With faultering step he enters in,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet half affraid to goe;                                         <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With trembling voice asks why they grieve,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet fears the cause to knowe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Three times the sun hath rose and set;"<br></span>
<span class="i2">They said, then stopt to weep:<br></span>
<span class="i0">"Since heaven hath laid thy lady deare                             <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In death's eternal sleep.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"For, ah! in travel sore she fell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So sore that she must dye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unless some shrewd and cunning leech<br></span>
<span class="i2">Could ease her presentlye.                                       <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But when a cunning leech was fet,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Too soon declared he,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She, or her babe must lose its life;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Both saved could not be.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Now take my life, thy lady said,                                  <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My little infant save:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And O commend me to my lord,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When I am laid in grave.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_222">[Pg 222]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"O tell him how that precious babe<br></span>
<span class="i2">Cost him a tender wife:                                          <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And teach my son to lisp her name,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who died to save his life.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Then calling still upon thy name,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And praying still for thee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Without repining or complaint,                                     <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her gentle soul did flee."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What tongue can paint lord Albret's woe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The bitter tears he shed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The bitter pangs that wrung his heart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To find his lady dead?                                           <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He beat his breast: he tore his hair;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And shedding many a tear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">At length he askt to see his son;<br></span>
<span class="i2">The son that cost so dear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">New sorrowe seiz'd the damsells all:                               <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">At length they faultering say;<br></span>
<span class="i0">"Alas! my lord, how shall we tell?<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy son is stoln away.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Fair as the sweetest flower of spring,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Such was his infant mien:                                        <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And on his little body stampt<br></span>
<span class="i2">Three wonderous marks were seen:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"A blood-red cross was on his arm;<br></span>
<span class="i2">A dragon on his breast:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A little garter all of gold                                        <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Was round his leg exprest.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Three carefull nurses we provide<br></span>
<span class="i2">Our little lord to keep:<br></span>
<span class="i0">One gave him sucke, one gave him food,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And one did lull to sleep.                                       <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_223">[Pg 223]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But lo! all in the dead of night,<br></span>
<span class="i2">We heard a fearful sound:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Loud thunder clapt; the castle shook;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And lightning flasht around.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Dead with affright at first we lay;                               <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">But rousing up anon,<br></span>
<span class="i0">We ran to see our little lord:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Our little lord was gone!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But how or where we could not tell;<br></span>
<span class="i2">For lying on the ground,                                         <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In deep and magic slumbers laid,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The nurses there we found."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O grief on grief! lord Albret said:<br></span>
<span class="i2">No more his tongue cou'd say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When falling in a deadly swoone,                                   <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Long time he lifeless lay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At length restor'd to life and sense<br></span>
<span class="i2">He nourisht endless woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No future joy his heart could taste,<br></span>
<span class="i2">No future comfort know.                                          <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So withers on the mountain top<br></span>
<span class="i2">A fair and stately oake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose vigorous arms are torne away,<br></span>
<span class="i2">By some rude thunder-stroke.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At length his castle irksome grew,                                 <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He loathes his wonted home;<br></span>
<span class="i0">His native country he forsakes<br></span>
<span class="i2">In foreign lands to roame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There up and downe he wandered far,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Clad in a palmer's gown;                                         <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Till his brown locks grew white as wool,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His beard as thistle down.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_224">[Pg 224]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At length, all wearied, down in death<br></span>
<span class="i2">He laid his reverend head.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Meantime amid the lonely wilds                                     <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His little son was bred.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There the weïrd lady of the woods<br></span>
<span class="i2">Had borne him far away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And train'd him up in feates of armes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And every martial play.                                          <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">⁂</p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_422"></a><a href="#FNanchor_422" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[422]</span></a> Mr. Warton. Vid. Observations on the <i>Fairy Queen</i>, 2 vol.
1762, 12mo. <i>passim.</i></p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>II.<br>

ST. GEORGE AND THE DRAGON.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i224t.png" id="img_images_i224t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> following ballad is given (with some corrections)
from two ancient black-letter copies in the <i>Pepys Collection</i>:
one of which is in 12mo., the other in folio.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The story of <i>St. George and the Dragon</i> is found in many
forms in the northern languages.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i224o.png" id="img_images_i224o.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Of Hector's deeds did Homer sing;<br></span>
<span class="i4">And of the sack of stately Troy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">What griefs fair Helena did bring,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Which was sir Paris' only joy:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And by my pen I will recite                                          <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George's deeds, and English knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Against the Sarazens so rude<br></span>
<span class="i4">Fought he full long and many a day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where many gyants he subdu'd,<br></span>
<span class="i4">In honour of the christian way:                                 <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And after many adventures past<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Egypt land he came at last.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_225">[Pg 225]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now, as the story plain doth tell,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Within that countrey there did rest<br></span>
<span class="i0">A dreadful dragon fierce and fell,                                  <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Whereby they were full sore opprest;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who by his poisonous breath each day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did many of the city slay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The grief whereof did grow so great<br></span>
<span class="i4">Throughout the limits of the land,                              <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That they their wise-men did intreat<br></span>
<span class="i4">To shew their cunning out of hand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">What way they might this fiend destroy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That did the countrey thus annoy.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The wise-men all before the king                                    <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">This answer fram'd incontinent;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The dragon none to death might bring<br></span>
<span class="i4">By any means they could invent:<br></span>
<span class="i0">His skin more hard than brass was found,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That sword nor spear could pierce nor wound.                        <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When this the people understood,<br></span>
<span class="i4">They cryed out most piteouslye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The dragon's breath infects their blood,<br></span>
<span class="i4">That every day in heaps they dye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Among them such a plague it bred,                                   <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The living scarce could bury the dead.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">No means there were, as they could hear,<br></span>
<span class="i4">For to appease the dragon's rage,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But to present some virgin clear,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Whose blood his fury might asswage;                             <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Each day he would a maiden eat,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For to allay his hunger great.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This thing by art the wise-men found,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Which truly must observed be;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wherefore throughout the city round                                 <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">A virgin pure of good degree<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_226">[Pg 226]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Was by the king's commission still<br></span>
<span class="i0">Taken up to serve the dragon's will.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus did the dragon every day<br></span>
<span class="i4">Untimely crop some virgin flowr,                                <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Till all the maids were worn away,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And none were left him to devour:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Saving the king's fair daughter bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her father's only heart's delight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then came the officers to the king                                  <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">That heavy message to declare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which did his heart with sorrow sting;<br></span>
<span class="i4">She is, quoth he, my kingdom's heir:<br></span>
<span class="i0">O let us all be poisoned here,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere she should die, that is my dear.                                <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then rose the people presently,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And to the king in rage they went;<br></span>
<span class="i0">They said his daughter dear should dye,<br></span>
<span class="i4">The dragon's fury to prevent:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Our daughters all are dead, quoth they,                             <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And have been made the dragon's prey:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And by their blood we rescued were,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And thou hast sav'd thy life thereby;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And now in sooth it is but faire,<br></span>
<span class="i4">For us thy daughter so should die.                              <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O save my daughter, said the king;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And let <span class="smcap">ME</span> feel the dragon's sting.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then fell fair Sabra on her knee,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And to her father dear did say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">O father, strive not thus for me,                                   <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">But let me be the dragon's prey;<br></span>
<span class="i0">It may be, for my sake alone<br></span>
<span class="i0">This plague upon the land was thrown.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_227">[Pg 227]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Tis better I should dye, she said,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Than all your subjects perish quite;                            <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Perhaps the dragon here was laid,<br></span>
<span class="i4">For my offence to work his spite:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And after he hath suckt my gore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Your land shall feel the grief no more.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What hast thou done, my daughter dear,                              <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">For to deserve this heavy scourge?<br></span>
<span class="i0">It is my fault, as may appear,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Which makes the gods our state to purge;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then ought I die, to stint the strife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to preserve thy happy life.                                     <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Like mad-men, all the people cried,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Thy death to us can do no good;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Our safety only doth abide<br></span>
<span class="i4">In making her the dragon's food.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lo! here I am, I come, quoth she,                                   <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Therefore do what you will with me.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nay stay, dear daughter, quoth the queen,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And as thou art a virgin bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That hast for vertue famous been,<br></span>
<span class="i4">So let me cloath thee all in white;                            <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And crown thy head with flowers sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">An ornament for virgins meet.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when she was attired so,<br></span>
<span class="i4">According to her mother's mind,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unto the stake then did she go;                                    <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">To which her tender limbs they bind:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And being bound to stake a thrall<br></span>
<span class="i0">She bade farewell unto them all.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Farewell, my father dear, quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And my sweet mother meek and mild;                             <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Take you no thought nor weep for me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For you may have another child:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_228">[Pg 228]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Since for my country's good I dye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Death I receive most willinglye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The king and queen and all their train                             <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">With weeping eyes went then their way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And let their daughter there remain,<br></span>
<span class="i4">To be the hungry dragon's prey:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But as she did there weeping lye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Behold St. George came riding by.                                  <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And seeing there a lady bright<br></span>
<span class="i4">So rudely tyed unto a stake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As well became a valiant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i4">He straight to her his way did take:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tell me, sweet maiden, then quoth he,                              <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">What caitif thus abuseth thee?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And, lo! by Christ his cross I vow,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Which here is figured on my breast,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I will revenge it on his brow,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And break my lance upon his chest:                             <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And speaking thus whereas he stood,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The dragon issued from the wood.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The lady that did first espy<br></span>
<span class="i4">The dreadful dragon coming so,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unto St. George aloud did cry,                                     <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And willed him away to go;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here comes that cursed fiend, quoth she;<br></span>
<span class="i0">That soon will make an end of me.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">St. George then looking round about,<br></span>
<span class="i4">The fiery dragon soon espy'd,                                  <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And like a knight of courage stout,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Against him did most fiercely ride;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with such blows he did him greet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He fell beneath his horse's feet.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_229">[Pg 229]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For with his launce that was so strong,                            <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">As he came gaping in his face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In at his mouth he thrust along;<br></span>
<span class="i4">For he could pierce no other place:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus within the lady's view<br></span>
<span class="i0">This mighty dragon straight he slew.                               <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The savour of his poisoned breath<br></span>
<span class="i4">Could do this holy knight no harm.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thus he the lady sav'd from death,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And home he led her by the arm;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which when king Ptolemy did see,                                   <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">There was great mirth and melody.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When as that valiant champion there<br></span>
<span class="i4">Had slain the dragon in the field,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To court he brought the lady fair,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Which to their hearts much joy did yield.                      <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He in the court of Egypt staid<br></span>
<span class="i0">Till he most falsely was betray'd.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">That lady dearly lov'd the knight,<br></span>
<span class="i4">He counted her his only joy;                                   <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But when their love was brought to light<br></span>
<span class="i4">It turn'd unto their great annoy:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Th' Morocco king was in the court,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who to the orchard did resort,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Dayly to take the pleasant air,                                    <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">For pleasure sake he us'd to walk,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Under a wall he oft did hear<br></span>
<span class="i4">St. George with lady Sabra talk:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Their love he shew'd unto the king,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which to St. George great woe did bring.                           <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Those kings together did devise<br></span>
<span class="i4">To make the christian knight away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With letters him in curteous wise<br></span>
<span class="i4">They straightway sent to Persia:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_230">[Pg 230]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But wrote to the sophy him to kill,                                <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And treacherously his blood to spill.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus they for good did him reward<br></span>
<span class="i4">With evil, and most subtilly<br></span>
<span class="i0">By much vile meanes they had regard<br></span>
<span class="i4">To work his death most cruelly;                                <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who, as through Persia land he rode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With zeal destroy'd each idol god.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For which offence he straight was thrown<br></span>
<span class="i4">Into a dungeon dark and deep;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where, when he thought his wrongs upon,                            <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">He bitterly did wail and weep:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet like a knight of courage stout,<br></span>
<span class="i0">At length his way he digged out.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Three grooms of the king of Persia<br></span>
<span class="i4">By night this valiant champion slew,                           <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Though he had fasted many a day;<br></span>
<span class="i4">And then away from thence he flew<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the best steed the sophy had;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which when he knew he was full mad.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Towards Christendom he made his flight,                            <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">But met a gyant by the way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With whom in combat he did fight<br></span>
<span class="i4">Most valiantly a summer's day:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who yet, for all his bats of steel,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was forc'd the sting of death to feel.                             <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Back o'er the seas with many bands<br></span>
<span class="i4">Of warlike souldiers soon he past,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Vowing upon those heathen lands<br></span>
<span class="i4">To work revenge; which at the last,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ere thrice three years were gone and spent,                        <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He wrought unto his heart's content.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_231">[Pg 231]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Save onely Egypt land he spar'd<br></span>
<span class="i4">For Sabra bright her only sake,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, ere for her he had regard,<br></span>
<span class="i4">He meant a tryal kind to make:                                 <span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Mean while the king o'ercome in field<br></span>
<span class="i0">Unto saint George did quickly yield.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then straight Morocco's king he slew,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And took fair Sabra to his wife,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But meant to try if she were true                                  <span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Ere with her he would lead his life:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, tho' he had her in his train,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She did a virgin pure remain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Toward England then that lovely dame<br></span>
<span class="i4">The brave St. George conducted strait,                         <span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">An eunuch also with them came,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Who did upon the lady wait;<br></span>
<span class="i0">These three from Egypt went alone.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now mark St. George's valour shown.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When as they in a forest were,                                     <span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">The lady did desire to rest;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Mean while St. George to kill a deer,<br></span>
<span class="i4">For their repast did think it best:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Leaving her with the eunuch there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whilst he did go to kill the deer.                                 <span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But lo! all in his absence came<br></span>
<span class="i4">Two hungry lyons fierce and fell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tore the eunuch on the same<br></span>
<span class="i4">In pieces small, the truth to tell;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Down by the lady then they laid,                                   <span class="linenum">240</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whereby they shew'd, she was a maid.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But when he came from hunting back,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And did behold this heavy chance,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then for his lovely virgin's sake<br></span>
<span class="i4">His courage strait he did advance,                             <span class="linenum">245</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_232">[Pg 232]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And came into the lions sight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who ran at him with all their might.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Their rage did him no whit dismay,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Who, like a stout and valiant knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Did both the hungry lyons slay                                     <span class="linenum">250</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Within the lady Sabra's sight:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who all this while sad and demure,<br></span>
<span class="i0">There stood most like a virgin pure.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now when St. George did surely know<br></span>
<span class="i4">This lady was a virgin true,                                   <span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His heart was glad, that erst was woe,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And all his love did soon renew:<br></span>
<span class="i0">He set her on a palfrey steed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And towards England came with speed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Where being in short space arriv'd                                 <span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Unto his native dwelling-place;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Therein with his dear love he liv'd,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And fortune did his nuptials grace:<br></span>
<span class="i0">They many years of joy did see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And led their lives at Coventry.                                   <span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>III.<br>

LOVE WILL FIND OUT THE WAY.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i232.png" id="img_images_i232.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> excellent song is ancient: but we could only give
it from a modern copy.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Earlier editions of this spirited song are printed in
Evans's <i>Old Ballads</i>, iii. 282 (1810), and Rimbault's <i>Little Book</i>
<i>of Songs and Ballads</i>, p. 137. It is quoted in Brome's <i>Sparagus</i>
<i>Garden</i>, acted in 1635, and Shirley's <i>Constant Maid</i> was republished
in 1661, under the title of <i>Love will find out the Way</i>, by T. B.</p>
<p>Dr. Rimbault has the following note in his <i>Musical Illustrations</i>,
"The old black-letter copy of this ballad is called '<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_233">[Pg 233]</a></span><i>Truth's Integrity:</i>
<i>or, a curious Northerne Ditty</i>, called <i>Love will finde out the Way</i>. To
a pleasant new Tune Printed at London for F. Coules, dwelling in
the Old Bailey.' There is a second part consisting of six stanzas,
which Percy has not reprinted. The tune is here given (translated
from the <i>Tablature</i>) from <i>Musicks Recreation on the Lyra Viol</i>, published
by Playford in 1652. It is also preserved in Forbes's <i>Cantus</i>,
1662; in <i>Musick's Delight on the Cithren</i>, 1666; and in D'Urfey's
<i>Pills to Purge Melancholy</i>, 1719. The <i>Pepysian Collection</i> contains
several ballads to this tune."</p>
<p>Mr. Chappell writes, "The air is still current, for in the summer
of 1855, Mr. Jennings, Organist of All Saints' Church, Maidstone,
noted it down from the wandering hop-pickers singing a song to
it on their entrance into that town." <i>Popular Music</i>, vol. i.
p. 304.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i233.png" id="img_images_i233.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Over the mountains,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And over the waves;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Under the fountains,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And under the graves;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Under the floods that are deepest,                                   <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Which Neptune obey;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Over rocks that are steepest,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Love will find out the way.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Where there is no place<br></span>
<span class="i4">For the glow-worm to lye;                                       <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where there is no space<br></span>
<span class="i4">For receipt of a fly;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where the midge dares not venture,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Lest herself fast she lay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">If love come, he will enter,                                        <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And soon find out his way.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">You may esteem him<br></span>
<span class="i4">A child for his might;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or you may deem him<br></span>
<span class="i4">A coward from his flight;                                       <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_234">[Pg 234]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But if she, whom love doth honour,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Be conceal'd from the day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Set a thousand guards upon her,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Love will find out the way.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Some think to lose him,                                             <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">By having him confin'd;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And some do suppose him,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Poor thing, to be blind;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But if ne'er so close ye wall him,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Do the best that you may,                                       <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Blind love, if so ye call him,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Will find out his way.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">You may train the eagle<br></span>
<span class="i2">To stoop to your fist;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or you may inveigle                                                 <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The phenix of the east;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lioness, ye may move her<br></span>
<span class="i2">To give o'er her prey;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But you'll ne'er stop a lover:<br></span>
<span class="i2">He will find out his way.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">⁂</p>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>IV.<br>

LORD THOMAS AND FAIR ANNET,</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">A Scottish Ballad</span>,
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i234.png" id="img_images_i234.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">Seems</span> to be composed (not without improvements) out
of two ancient English ones, printed in the former part
of this volume. See book i. ballad xv. and book ii.
ballad iv.—If this had been the original, the authors of
those two ballads would hardly have adopted two such different
stories: besides, this contains enlargements not to be found in
either of the others. It is given with some corrections, from a
MS. copy transmitted from Scotland.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_235">[Pg 235]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Jamieson prints a version of this ballad which was taken down
from the recitation of Mrs. W. Arrot of Aberbrothick, and is entitled
<i>Sweet Willie and Fair Annie</i>. He contends that it is "pure
and entire," and expresses his opinion that the text of Percy's
copy had been "adjusted" previous to its leaving Scotland.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i235.png" id="img_images_i235.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Lord Thomas and fair Annet<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sate a' day on a hill;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whan night was cum, and sun was sett,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They had not talkt their fill.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Lord Thomas said a word in jest,                                     <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Fair Annet took it ill:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A'! I will nevir wed a wife<br></span>
<span class="i2">Against my ain friends will.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Gif ye wull nevir wed a wife,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A wife wull neir wed yee.                                         <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Sae he is hame to tell his mither,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And knelt upon his knee:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O rede, O rede, mither, he says,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A gude rede gie to mee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">O sall I tak the nut-browne bride,                                  <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And let faire Annet bee?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The nut-browne bride haes gowd and gear,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Fair Annet she has gat nane;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the little beauty fair Annet has,<br></span>
<span class="i2">O it wull soon be gane!                                           <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he has till his brother gane:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Now, brother, rede ye mee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">A' sall I marrie the nut-browne bride,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And let fair Annet bee?<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_236">[Pg 236]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The nut-browne bride has oxen, brother,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The nut-browne bride has kye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I wad hae ye marrie the nut-browne bride,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And cast fair Annet bye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her oxen may dye i' the house, Billìe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And her kye into the byre;                                        <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And I sall hae nothing to my sell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Bot a fat fadge<a id="FNanchor_423"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_423">[423]</a> by the fyre.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he has till his sister gane:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Now, sister, rede ye mee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">O sall I marrie the nut-browne bride,                               <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And set fair Annet free?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ise rede ye tak fair Annet, Thomas,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And let the browne bride alane;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lest ye sould sigh and say, Alace!<br></span>
<span class="i2">What is this we brought hame?                                     <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">No, I will tak my mithers counsel,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And marrie me owt o' hand;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I will tak the nut-browne bride;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Fair Annet may leive the land.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Up then rose fair Annets father                                     <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Twa hours or it wer day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And he is gane into the bower,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Wherein fair Annet lay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Rise up, rise up, fair Annet, he says,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Put on your silken sheene;                                        <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Let us gae to St. Maries kirke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And see that rich weddeen.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My maides, gae to my dressing roome,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And dress to me my hair;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whair-eir yee laid a plait before,<br></span>
<span class="i2">See yee lay ten times mair.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_237">[Pg 237]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My maids, gae to my dressing room,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And dress to me my smock;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The one half is o' the holland fine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The other o' needle-work.                                         <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The horse fair Annet rade upon,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He amblit like the wind,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wi' siller he was shod before,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Wi' burning gowd behind.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Four and twanty siller bells                                        <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Wer a' tyed till his mane,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yae tift<a id="FNanchor_424"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_424">[424]</a> o' the norland wind,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They tinkled ane by ane.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Four and twanty gay gude knichts<br></span>
<span class="i2">Rade by the fair Annets side,                                     <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And four and twanty fair ladies,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As gin she had bin a bride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And whan she cam to Maries kirk,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She sat on Maries stean:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The cleading that fair Annet had on                                 <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">It skinkled in their een.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And whan she cam into the kirk,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She shimmer'd like the sun;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The belt that was about her waist,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was a' wi' pearles bedone.                                        <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She sat her by the nut-browne bride,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And her een they wer sae clear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lord Thomas he clean forgat the bride,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whan fair Annet she drew near.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He had a rose into his hand,                                        <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And he gave it kisses three,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And reaching by the nut-browne bride,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Laid it on fair Annets knee<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_238">[Pg 238]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Up than spak the nut-browne bride,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She spak wi' meikle spite;                                        <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And whair gat ye that rose-water,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That does mak yee sae white?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O I did get the rose-water,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whair ye wull neir get nane,<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I did get that very rose-water                                  <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Into my mithers wame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The bride she drew a long bodkin,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Frae out her gay head-gear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And strake fair Annet unto the heart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That word she nevir spak mair.                                   <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Lord Thomas he saw fair Annet wex pale,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And marvelit what mote bee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But whan he saw her dear hearts blude,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A' wood-wroth<a id="FNanchor_425"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_425">[425]</a> wexed hee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He drew his dagger, that was sae sharp,                            <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That was sae sharp and meet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And drave into the nut-browne bride,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That fell deid at his feit.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now stay for me, dear Annet, he sed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Now stay, my dear, he cry'd;                                     <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Then strake the dagger untill his heart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fell deid by her side.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Lord Thomas was buried without kirk-wa',<br></span>
<span class="i2">Fair Annet within the quiere;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And o' the tane thair grew a birk,                                 <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The other a bonny briere.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And ay they grew, and ay they threw,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As they wad faine be neare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And by this ye may ken right weil,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They ware twa luvers deare.                                      <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_239">[Pg 239]</a></span></p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_423"></a><a href="#FNanchor_423" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[423]</span></a> [bundle of sticks.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_424"></a><a href="#FNanchor_424" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[424]</span></a> [gust of wind.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_425"></a><a href="#FNanchor_425" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[425]</span></a> [furiously enraged.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>V.<br>

UNFADING BEAUTY.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i239t.png" id="img_images_i239t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> little beautiful sonnet is reprinted from a small
volume of "<i>Poems</i> by <i>Thomas Carew</i>, Esq. one of the
gentlemen of the privie-chamber, and sewer in ordinary
to his majesty (Charles I.) Lond. 1640." This elegant,
and almost-forgotten writer, whose poems have been deservedly
revived, died in the prime of his age, in 1639.</p>
<p>In the original follows a third stanza; which, not being of
general application, nor of equal merit, I have ventured to omit.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Dr. Rimbault informs us that the original music was composed
by Henry Lawes, and is included in his <i>Ayres and Dialogues for</i>
<i>one, two and three Voyces</i>, 1653.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i239h.png" id="img_images_i239h.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hee, that loves a rosie cheeke,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or a corall lip admires,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or from star-like eyes doth seeke<br></span>
<span class="i2">Fuell to maintaine his fires,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As old time makes these decay,                                       <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So his flames must waste away.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But a smooth and stedfast mind,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Gentle thoughts, and calme desires,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hearts with equal love combin'd<br></span>
<span class="i2">Kindle never-dying fires:                                         <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where these are not I despise<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lovely cheekes, or lips, or eyes.<br></span>
<span class="i0">       *       *       *       *       *<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_240">[Pg 240]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>VI.<br>

GEORGE BARNWELL.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i240.png" id="img_images_i240.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> subject of this ballad is sufficiently popular from
the modern play which is founded upon it. This was
written by <i>George Lillo</i>, a jeweller of London, and first
acted about 1730.—As for the ballad it was printed at
least as early as the middle of the last century.</p>
<p>It is here given from three old printed copies, which exhibit a
strange intermixture of Roman and black letter. It is also collated
with another copy in the <i>Ashmole Collection</i> at Oxford,
which is thus intitled, "An excellent ballad of <i>George Barnwell</i>, an
apprentice of London, who ... thrice robbed his master and murdered
his uncle in Ludlow." The tune is <i>The Merchant</i>.</p>
<p>This tragical narrative seems to relate a real fact; but when it
happened I have not been able to discover.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Ritson writes as follows concerning certain improvements made
by Percy in the following ballad (<i>Ancient Songs</i>, 1829, vol. ii. p. 165,
note):—"Throughout this 'second part' (except in a single instance)
the metre of the first line of each stanza is in the old
editions lengthened by a couple of syllables, which are, occasionally
at least, a manifest interpolation. The person also is
for the most part changed from the first to the third, with evident
impropriety. Dr. Percy has very ingeniously restored the measure
by ejecting the superfluous syllables, and given consistency to the
whole by the restoration of the proper person; and as it is now
highly improbable that any further ancient copy will be found, and
those which exist are manifestly corrupt, it seemed justifiable to
adopt the judicious emendations of this ingenious editor."</p>
<p>Dr. Rimbault observes, "This curious tune (<i>The Merchant</i>)
which has been quite overlooked by antiquaries, is found, together
with the original ballad, <i>The Merchant and the Fiddler's Wife</i>, in
D'Urfey's <i>Pills to Purge Melancholy</i>, vol. v. p. 77, edit. 1719."</p>
<p>The former great popularity of the story of the wicked young
prentice is shown by James Smith's parody in the <i>Rejected Addresses</i>
and Thackeray's caricature romance—<i>George de Barnwell</i>.]</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_241">[Pg 241]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<h4><span class="smcap">The First Part.</span>
</h4>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i241.png" id="img_images_i241.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All youths of fair Englànd<br></span>
<span class="i2">That dwell both far and near,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Regard my story that I tell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And to my song give ear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A London lad I was,                                                  <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">A merchant's prentice bound;<br></span>
<span class="i0">My name George Barnwell; that did spend<br></span>
<span class="i2">My master many a pound.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Take heed of harlots then,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And their enticing trains;                                        <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
