<span class="i0">For by that means I have been brought<br></span>
<span class="i2">To hang alive in chains.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As I, upon a day,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was walking through the street<br></span>
<span class="i0">About my master's business,                                         <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">A wanton I did meet.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A gallant dainty dame,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And sumptuous in attire;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With smiling look she greeted me,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And did my name require.                                          <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Which when I had declar'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She gave me then a kiss,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And said, if I would come to her,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I should have more than this.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Fair mistress, then quoth I,                                        <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">If I the place may know,<br></span>
<span class="i0">This evening I will be with you,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For I abroad must go<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_242">[Pg 242]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To gather monies in,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That are my master's due:                                         <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And ere that I do home return,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I'll come and visit you.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Good Barnwell, then quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Do thou to Shoreditch come,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And ask for Mrs. Millwood's house,                                  <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Next door unto the Gun.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And trust me on my truth,<br></span>
<span class="i2">If thou keep touch with me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My dearest friend, as my own heart<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou shall right welcome be.                                      <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus parted we in peace,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And home I passed right;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then went abroad, and gathered in,<br></span>
<span class="i2">By six o'clock at night,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">An hundred pound and one:                                           <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With bag under my arm<br></span>
<span class="i0">I went to Mrs. Millwood's house,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And thought on little harm;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And knocking at the door,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Straightway herself came down;                                    <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Rustling in most brave attire,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With hood and silken gown.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Who, through her beauty bright,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So gloriously did shine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That she amaz'd my dazzling eyes,                                   <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">She seemed so divine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She took me by the hand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And with a modest grace,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Welcome, sweet Barnwell, then quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unto this homely place.                                           <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_243">[Pg 243]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And since I have thee found<br></span>
<span class="i2">As good as thy word to be:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A homely supper, ere we part,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou shalt take here with me.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O pardon me, quoth I,                                               <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Fair mistress, I you pray;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For why, out of my master's house,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So long I dare not stay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Alas, good Sir, she said,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Are you so strictly ty'd,                                         <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">You may not with your dearest friend<br></span>
<span class="i2">One hour or two abide?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Faith, then the case is hard:<br></span>
<span class="i2">If it be so, quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I would I were a prentice bound,                                    <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To live along with thee:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Therefore, my dearest George,<br></span>
<span class="i2">List well what I shall say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And do not blame a woman much,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her fancy to bewray.                                              <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Let not affection's force<br></span>
<span class="i2">Be counted lewd desire;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor think it not immodesty,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I should thy love require.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With that she turn'd aside,                                         <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And with a blushing red,<br></span>
<span class="i0">A mournful motion she bewray'd<br></span>
<span class="i2">By hanging down her head.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A handkerchief she had,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All wrought with silk and gold:                                   <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Which she to stay her trickling tears<br></span>
<span class="i2">Before her eyes did hold.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_244">[Pg 244]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This thing unto my sight<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was wondrous rare and strange;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in my soul and inward thought                                   <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">It wrought a sudden change:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">That I so hardy grew,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To take her by the hand:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Saying, Sweet mistress, why do you<br></span>
<span class="i2">So dull and pensive stand?                                       <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Call me no mistress now,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But Sarah, thy true friend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thy servant, Millwood, honouring thee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Until her life hath end.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If thou wouldst here alledge,                                      <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou art in years a boy;<br></span>
<span class="i0">So was Adonis, yet was he<br></span>
<span class="i2">Fair Venus' only joy.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus I, who ne'er before<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of woman found such grace,                                       <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But seeing now so fair a dame<br></span>
<span class="i2">Give me a kind embrace,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I supt with her that night,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With joys that did abound;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And for the same paid presently,                                   <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In money twice three pound.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">An hundred kisses then,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For my farewel she gave;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Crying, Sweet Barnwell, when shall I<br></span>
<span class="i2">Again thy company have?                                          <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O stay not hence too long,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sweet George, have me in mind.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her words bewicht my childishness,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She uttered them so kind:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_245">[Pg 245]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So that I made a vow,                                              <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Next Sunday without fail,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With my sweet Sarah once again<br></span>
<span class="i2">To tell some pleasant tale.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When she heard me say so,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The tears fell from her eye;                                     <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O George, quoth she, if thou dost fail,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy Sarah sure will dye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Though long, yet loe! at last,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The appointed day was come,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That I must with my Sarah meet;                                    <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Having a mighty sum<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Of money in my hand,<a id="FNanchor_426"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_426">[426]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Unto her house went I,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whereas my love upon her bed<br></span>
<span class="i2">In saddest sort did lye.                                         <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What ails my heart's delight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My Sarah dear? quoth I;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let not my love lament and grieve,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor sighing pine, and die.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But tell me, dearest friend,                                       <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">What may thy woes amend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thou shalt lack no means of help,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Though forty pound I spend.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With that she turn'd her head,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And sickly thus did say,                                         <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Oh me, sweet George, my grief is great,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ten pound I have to pay<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_246">[Pg 246]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Unto a cruel wretch;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And God he knows, quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I have it not. Tush, rise, I said,                                 <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And take it here of me.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ten pounds, nor ten times ten,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Shall make my love decay.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then from my bag into her lap,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I cast ten pound straightway.                                    <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All blithe and pleasant then,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To banqueting we go;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She proffered me to lye with her,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And said it should be so.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And after that same time,                                          <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I gave her store of coyn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yea, sometimes fifty pound at once;<br></span>
<span class="i2">All which I did purloyn.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And thus I did pass on;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Until my master then                                             <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Did call to have his reckoning in<br></span>
<span class="i2">Cast up among his men.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The which when as I heard,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I knew not what to say:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For well I knew that I was out                                     <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Two hundred pound that day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then from my master straight<br></span>
<span class="i2">I ran in secret sort;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And unto Sarah Millwood there<br></span>
<span class="i2">My case I did report.                                            <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But how she us'd this youth,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In this his care and woe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all a strumpet's wiley ways,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The <span class="smcap">SECOND PART</span> may showe."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_247">[Pg 247]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<h4><span class="smcap">The Second Part.</span>
</h4>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i247.png" id="img_images_i247.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Young Barnwell comes to thee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sweet Sarah, my delight;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I am undone unless thou stand<br></span>
<span class="i2">My faithful friend this night.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Our master to accompts,                                              <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Hath just occasion found;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And I am caught behind the hand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Above two hundred pound:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And now his wrath to 'scape,<br></span>
<span class="i2">My love, I fly to thee,                                           <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Hoping some time I may remaine<br></span>
<span class="i2">In safety here with thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With that she knit her brows,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And looking all aquoy,<a id="FNanchor_427"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_427">[427]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth she, What should I have to do                                 <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With any prentice boy?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And seeing you have purloyn'd<br></span>
<span class="i2">Your master's goods away,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The case is bad, and therefore here<br></span>
<span class="i2">You shall no longer stay.                                         <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Why, dear, thou knowst, I said,<br></span>
<span class="i2">How all which I could get,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I gave it, and did spend it all<br></span>
<span class="i2">Upon thee every whit.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth she, Thou art a knave,                                        <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To charge me in this sort,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Being a woman of credit fair,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And known of good report:<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_248">[Pg 248]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Therefore I tell thee flat,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Be packing with good speed;                                       <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I do defie thee from my heart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And scorn thy filthy deed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Is this the friendship, that<br></span>
<span class="i2">You did to me protest?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is this the great affection, which                                  <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">You so to me exprest?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now fie on subtle shrews!<br></span>
<span class="i2">The best is, I may speed<br></span>
<span class="i0">To get a lodging any where,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For money in my need.                                             <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">False woman, now farewell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Whilst twenty pound doth last,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My anchor in some other haven<br></span>
<span class="i2">With freedom I will cast.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When she perceiv'd by this,                                         <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I had store of money there:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Stay, George, quoth she, thou art too quick:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Why, man, I did but jeer:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Dost think for all my speech,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That I would let thee go?                                         <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Faith no, said she, my love to thee<br></span>
<span class="i2">I wiss is more than so.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">You scorne a prentice boy,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I heard you just now swear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wherefore I will not trouble you.——                               <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">——Nay, George, hark in thine ear;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thou shalt not go to-night,<br></span>
<span class="i2">What chance so e're befall:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But man we'll have a bed for thee,<br></span>
<span class="i2">O else the devil take all.                                        <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_249">[Pg 249]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So I by wiles bewitcht,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And snar'd with fancy still,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Had then no power to 'get' away,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or to withstand her will.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For wine on wine I call'd,                                          <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And cheer upon good cheer;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And nothing in the world I thought<br></span>
<span class="i2">For Sarah's love too dear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Whilst in her company,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I had such merriment;                                             <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">All, all too little I did think,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That I upon her spent.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A fig for care and thought!<br></span>
<span class="i2">When all my gold is gone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In faith, my girl, we will have more,                               <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Whoever I light upon.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My father's rich, why then<br></span>
<span class="i2">Should I want store of gold?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay with a father sure, quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A son may well make bold.                                         <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I've a sister richly wed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I'll rob her ere I'll want.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nay, then quoth Sarah, they may well<br></span>
<span class="i2">Consider of your scant.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Nay, I an uncle have;                                               <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">At Ludlow he doth dwell:<br></span>
<span class="i0">He is a grazier, which in wealth<br></span>
<span class="i2">Doth all the rest excell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ere I will live in lack,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And have no coyn for thee:                                        <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I'll rob his house, and murder him,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Why should you not? quoth she:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_250">[Pg 250]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Was I a man, ere I<br></span>
<span class="i2">Would live in poor estate;<br></span>
<span class="i0">On father, friends, and all my kin,                                 <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I would my talons grate.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For without money, George,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A man is but a beast:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But bringing money, thou shalt be<br></span>
<span class="i2">Always my welcome guest.                                         <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For shouldst thou be pursued<br></span>
<span class="i2">With twenty hues and cryes,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with a warrant searched for<br></span>
<span class="i2">With Argus' hundred eyes,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet here thou shalt be safe;                                       <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Such privy ways there be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That if they sought an hundred years,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They could not find out thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And so carousing both<br></span>
<span class="i2">Their pleasures to content:                                      <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">George Barnwell had in little space<br></span>
<span class="i2">His money wholly spent.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Which done, to Ludlow straight<br></span>
<span class="i2">He did provide to go,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To rob his wealthy uncle there;                                    <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His minion would it so.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And once he thought to take<br></span>
<span class="i2">His father by the way,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But that he fear'd his master had<br></span>
<span class="i2">Took order for his stay<a id="FNanchor_428"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_428">[428]</a>.                                    <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Unto his uncle then<br></span>
<span class="i2">He rode with might and main,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who with a welcome and good cheer,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did Barnwell entertain.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_251">[Pg 251]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">One fortnight's space he stayed,                                   <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Until it chanced so,<br></span>
<span class="i0">His uncle with his cattle did<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unto a market go.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">His kinsman rode with him,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where he did see right plain,                                    <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Great store of money he had took:<br></span>
<span class="i2">When coming home again,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sudden within a wood,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He struck his uncle down,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And beat his brains out of his head;                               <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">So sore he crackt his crown.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then seizing fourscore pound,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To London straight he hyed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And unto Sarah Millwood all<br></span>
<span class="i2">The cruell fact descryed.                                        <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Tush,'tis no matter, George,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So we the money have<br></span>
<span class="i0">To have good cheer in jolly sort,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And deck us fine and brave.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus lived in filthy sort,                                         <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Until their store was gone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">When means to get them any more,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I wis, poor George, had none.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Therefore in railing sort,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She thrust him out of door:                                      <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Which is the just reward of those,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who spend upon a whore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O! do me not disgrace<br></span>
<span class="i2">In this my need, quoth he<br></span>
<span class="i0">She call'd him thief and murderer,                                 <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With all the spight might be:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_252">[Pg 252]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To the constable she sent,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To have him apprehended;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And shewed how far, in each degree,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He had the laws offended.                                        <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When Barnwell saw her drift,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To sea he got straightway;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where fear and sting of conscience<br></span>
<span class="i2">Continually on him lay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Unto the lord mayor then,                                          <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He did a letter write;<br></span>
<span class="i0">In which his own and Sarah's fault<br></span>
<span class="i2">He did at large recite.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Whereby she seized was,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And then to Ludlow sent:                                         <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where she was judg'd, condemn'd, and hang'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For murder incontinent.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There dyed this gallant quean,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Such was her greatest gains:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For murder in Polonia,                                             <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Was Barnwell hang'd in chains.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Lo! here's the end of youth,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That after harlots haunt;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who in the spoil of other men,<br></span>
<span class="i2">About the streets do flaunt.                                     <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_253">[Pg 253]</a></span></p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_426"></a><a href="#FNanchor_426" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[426]</span></a> The having a sum of money with him on Sunday, &amp;c. shews
this narrative to have been penned before the civil wars: the strict
observance of the sabbath was owing to the change of manners
at that period.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_427"></a><a href="#FNanchor_427" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[427]</span></a> [coy, shy.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_428"></a><a href="#FNanchor_428" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[428]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> for stopping, and apprehending him at his father's.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>VII.<br>

THE STEDFAST SHEPHERD.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i253t.png" id="img_images_i253t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">These</span> beautiful stanzas were written by <i>George Wither</i>,
of whom some account was given in the former part of
this volume; see the song intitled, <i>The Shepherd's</i>
<i>Resolution</i>, book ii. song xxi. In the first edition of this
work only a small fragment of this sonnet was inserted. It was
afterwards rendered more compleat and intire by the addition of
five stanzas more, extracted from Wither's pastoral poem, intitled,
<i>The Mistress of Philarete</i>, of which this song makes a part. It is
now given still more correct and perfect by comparing it with
another copy, printed by the author in his improved edition of
<i>The Shepherd's Hunting</i>, 1620, 8vo.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The Folio MS. (ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. iii. p. 360) contains
only the fifth and sixth stanzas slightly varied, which were
printed in the first edition of the <i>Reliques</i>, with the title of <i>The</i>
<i>Aspiring Shepherd</i>.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i253h.png" id="img_images_i253h.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hence away, thou Syren, leave me,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Pish! unclaspe these wanton armes;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sugred words can ne'er deceive me,<br></span>
<span class="i4">(Though thou prove a thousand charmes).<br></span>
<span class="i6">Fie, fie, forbeare;                                            <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">No common snare<br></span>
<span class="i4">Can ever my affection chaine:<br></span>
<span class="i6">Thy painted baits,<br></span>
<span class="i6">And poore deceits,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Are all bestowed on me in vaine.                                <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I'me no slave to such, as you be;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Neither shall that snowy brest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rowling eye, and lip of ruby<br></span>
<span class="i4">Ever robb me of my rest:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_254">[Pg 254]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i6">Goe, go display                                               <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">Thy beautie's ray<br></span>
<span class="i4">To some more soone-enamour'd swaine;<br></span>
<span class="i6">Those common wiles<br></span>
<span class="i6">Of sighs and smiles<br></span>
<span class="i4">Are all bestowed on me in vaine.                                <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I have elsewhere vowed a dutie;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Turne away thy tempting eye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shew not me a painted beautie;<br></span>
<span class="i4">These impostures I defie:<br></span>
<span class="i6">My spirit lothes                                              <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">Where gawdy clothes<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fained othes may love obtaine:<br></span>
<span class="i6">I love her so,<br></span>
<span class="i6">Whose looke sweares No;<br></span>
<span class="i2">That all your labours will be vaine.                              <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Can he prize the tainted posies,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Which on every brest are worne;<br></span>
<span class="i0">That may plucke the virgin roses<br></span>
<span class="i4">From their never-touched thorne?<br></span>
<span class="i6">I can goe rest                                                <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">On her sweet brest,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That is the pride of Cynthia's traine:<br></span>
<span class="i6">Then stay thy tongue;<br></span>
<span class="i6">Thy mermaid song<br></span>
<span class="i2">Is all bestowed on me in vaine.                                   <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hee's a foole, that basely dallies,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Where each peasant mates with him:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall I haunt the thronged vallies,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Whilst ther's noble hills to climbe?<br></span>
<span class="i6">No, no, though clownes                                        <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">Are scar'd with frownes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I know the best can but disdaine;<br></span>
<span class="i6">And those Ile prove:<br></span>
<span class="i6">So will thy love<br></span>
<span class="i2">Be all bestowed on me in vaine.                                   <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_255">[Pg 255]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I doe scorne to vow a dutie,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Where each lustfull lad may wooe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Give me her, whose sun-like beautie<br></span>
<span class="i4">Buzzards dare not soar unto:<br></span>
<span class="i6">Shee, shee it is                                              <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">Affoords that blisse<br></span>
<span class="i4">For which I would refuse no paine:<br></span>
<span class="i6">But such as you,<br></span>
<span class="i6">Fond fooles, adieu;<br></span>
<span class="i4">You seeke to captive me in vaine.                               <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Leave me then, you Syrens, leave me;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Seeke no more to worke my harmes:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Craftie wiles cannot deceive me,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Who am proofe against your charmes:<br></span>
<span class="i6">You labour may                                                <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">To lead astray<br></span>
<span class="i4">The heart, that constant shall remaine:<br></span>
<span class="i6">And I the while<br></span>
<span class="i6">Will sit and smile<br></span>
<span class="i4">To see you spend your time in vaine.                            <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>VIII.<br>

THE SPANISH VIRGIN, <span class="smcap">OR</span> EFFECTS OF JEALOUSY.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i255.png" id="img_images_i255.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> subject of this ballad is taken from a folio collection
of tragical stories, intitled, <i>The theatre of God's judgments</i>,
by Dr. Beard and Dr. Taylor, 1642. Pt. ii. p. 89.—The
text is given (with corrections) from two copies;
one of them in black-letter in the Pepys collection. In this every
stanza is accompanied with the following distich by way of burden:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Oh jealousie! thou art nurst in hell:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Depart from hence, and therein dwell."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_256">[Pg 256]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i256.png" id="img_images_i256.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All tender hearts, that ake to hear<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of those that suffer wrong;<br></span>
<span class="i0">All you, that never shed a tear,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Give heed unto my song.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Fair Isabella's tragedy                                              <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My tale doth far exceed:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Alas! that so much cruelty<br></span>
<span class="i2">In female hearts should breed!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In Spain a lady liv'd of late,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who was of high degree;                                           <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose wayward temper did create<br></span>
<span class="i2">Much woe and misery.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Strange jealousies so fill'd her head<br></span>
<span class="i2">With many a vain surmize,<br></span>
<span class="i0">She thought her lord had wrong'd her bed,                           <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And did her love despise.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A gentlewoman passing fair<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did on this lady wait;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With bravest dames she might compare;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her beauty was compleat.                                          <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her lady cast a jealous eye<br></span>
<span class="i2">Upon this gentle maid;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And taxt her with disloyaltye;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And did her oft upbraid.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In silence still this maiden meek                                   <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her bitter taunts would bear,<br></span>
<span class="i0">While oft adown her lovely cheek<br></span>
<span class="i2">Would steal the falling tear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In vain in humble sort she strove<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her fury to disarm;                                               <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">As well the meekness of the dove<br></span>
<span class="i2">The bloody hawke might charm.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_257">[Pg 257]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her lord of humour light and gay,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And innocent the while,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As oft as she came in his way,                                      <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Would on the damsell smile.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And oft before his lady's face,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As thinking her her friend,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He would the maiden's modest grace<br></span>
<span class="i2">And comeliness commend.                                           <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All which incens'd his lady so<br></span>
<span class="i2">She burnt with wrath extreame;<br></span>
<span class="i0">At length the fire that long did glow,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Burst forth into a flame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For on a day it so befell,                                          <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">When he was gone from home,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lady all with rage did swell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And to the damsell come.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And charging her with great offence,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And many a grievous fault;                                        <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She bade her servants drag her thence,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Into a dismal vault,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">That lay beneath the common-shore:<br></span>
<span class="i2">A dungeon dark and deep:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where they were wont, in days of yore,                              <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Offenders great to keep.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There never light of chearful day<br></span>
<span class="i2">Dispers'd the hideous gloom;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But dank and noisome vapours play<br></span>
<span class="i2">Around the wretched room:                                         <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And adders, snakes, and toads therein,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As afterwards was known,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Long in this loathsome vault had bin,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And were to monsters grown.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_258">[Pg 258]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Into this foul and fearful place,                                   <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The fair one innocent<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was cast, before her lady's face;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her malice to content.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This maid no sooner enter'd is,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But strait, alas! she hears                                       <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The toads to croak, and snakes to hiss:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then grievously she fears.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Soon from their holes the vipers creep,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fiercely her assail:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which makes the damsel sorely weep,                                 <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And her sad fate bewail.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With her fair hands she strives in vain<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her body to defend:<br></span>
<span class="i0">With shrieks and cries she doth complain,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But all is to no end.                                             <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A servant listning near the door,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Struck with her doleful noise,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Strait ran his lady to implore;<br></span>
<span class="i2">But she'll not hear his voice.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With bleeding heart he goes agen                                    <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To mark the maiden's groans;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And plainly hears, within the den,<br></span>
<span class="i2">How she herself bemoans.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Again he to his lady hies<br></span>
<span class="i2">With all the haste he may:                                        <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">She into furious passion flies,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And orders him away.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Still back again does he return<br></span>
<span class="i2">To hear her tender cries;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The virgin now had ceas'd to mourn;                                 <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Which fill'd him with surprize.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_259">[Pg 259]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In grief, and horror, and affright,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He listens at the walls;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But finding all was silent quite,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He to his lady calls.                                            <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Too sure, O lady, now quoth he,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Your cruelty hath sped;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Make hast, for shame, and come and see;<br></span>
<span class="i2">I fear the virgin's dead.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She starts to hear her sudden fate,                                <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And does with torches run:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But all her haste was now too late,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For death his worst had done.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The door being open'd strait they found<br></span>
<span class="i2">The virgin stretch'd along:                                      <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Two dreadful snakes had wrapt her round,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which her to death had stung.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">One round her legs, her thighs, her waist<br></span>
<span class="i2">Had twin'd his fatal wreath:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The other close her neck embrac'd,                                 <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And stopt her gentle breath.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The snakes, being from her body thrust,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Their bellies were so fill'd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That with excess of blood they burst,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thus with their prey were kill'd.                                <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The wicked lady at this sight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With horror strait ran mad;<br></span>
<span class="i0">So raving dy'd, as was most right,<br></span>
<span class="i2">'Cause she no pity had.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Let me advise you, ladies all,                                     <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of jealousy beware:<br></span>
<span class="i0">It causeth many a one to fall,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And is the devil's snare.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">⁂</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_260">[Pg 260]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>IX.<br>

JEALOUSY TYRANT OF THE MIND.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i260t.png" id="img_images_i260t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> Song is by <i>Dryden</i>, being inserted in his Tragi-Comedy
of <i>Love Triumphant</i>, &amp;c.—On account of
the subject it is inserted here.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i260w.png" id="img_images_i260w.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What state of life can be so blest,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As love that warms the gentle brest;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two souls in one; the same desire<br></span>
<span class="i0">To grant the bliss, and to require?<br></span>
<span class="i2">If in this heaven a hell we find,                                  <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i6">Tis all from thee,<br></span>
<span class="i6">O Jealousie!<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou tyrant, tyrant of the mind.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All other ills, though sharp they prove,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Serve to refine and perfect love:                                   <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">In absence, or unkind disdaine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sweet hope relieves the lovers paine:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But, oh, no cure but death we find<br></span>
<span class="i6">To sett us free<br></span>
<span class="i6">From jealousie,                                               <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou tyrant, tyrant of the mind.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">False in thy glass all objects are,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Some sett too near, and some too far:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou art the fire of endless night,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The fire that burns, and gives no light.                            <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">All torments of the damn'd we find<br></span>
<span class="i6">In only thee,<br></span>
<span class="i6">O Jealousie;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou tyrant, tyrant of the mind.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_261">[Pg 261]</a></span></p>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>X.<br>

CONSTANT PENELOPE.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i261t.png" id="img_images_i261t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> ladies are indebted for the following notable documents
to the Pepys collection, where the original is
preserved in black-letter, and is intitled, <i>A lookingglass</i>
<i>for ladies, or a mirrour for married women</i>. Tune
<i>Queen Dido, or Troy town</i>.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i261w.png" id="img_images_i261w.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When Greeks and Trojans fell at strife,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And lords in armour bright were seen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">When many a gallant lost his life<br></span>
<span class="i2">About fair Hellen, beauty's queen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ulysses, general so free,                                            <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Did leave his dear Penelope.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When she this wofull news did hear,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That he would to the warrs of Troy;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For grief she shed full many a tear,<br></span>
<span class="i2">At parting from her only joy;                                     <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Her ladies all about her came,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To comfort up this Grecian dame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ulysses, with a heavy heart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unto her then did mildly say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The time is come that we must part;                                 <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My honour calls me hence away;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet in my absence, dearest, be<br></span>
<span class="i0">My constant wife, Penelope.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Let me no longer live, she sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then to my lord I true remain;                                    <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">My honour shall not be betray'd<br></span>
<span class="i2">Until I see my love again;<br></span>
<span class="i0">For I will ever constant prove,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As is the loyal turtle-dove.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_262">[Pg 262]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus did they part with heavy chear,                                <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And to the ships his way he took;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her tender eyes dropt many a tear;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Still casting many a longing look:<br></span>
<span class="i0">She saw him on the surges glide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And unto Neptune thus she cry'd:                                    <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thou god, whose power is in the deep,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And rulest in the ocean main,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My loving lord in safety keep<br></span>
<span class="i2">Till he return to me again:<br></span>
<span class="i0">That I his person may behold,                                       <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To me more precious far than gold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then straight the ships with nimble sails<br></span>
<span class="i2">Were all convey'd out of her sight:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her cruel fate she then bewails,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Since she had lost her hearts delight.                            <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Now shall my practice be, quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i0">True vertue and humility.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My patience I will put in ure,<a id="FNanchor_429"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_429">[429]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">My charity I will extend;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Since for my woe there is no cure,                                  <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The helpless now I will befriend:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The widow and the fatherless<br></span>
<span class="i0">I will relieve, when in distress.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus she continued year by year<br></span>
<span class="i2">In doing good to every one;                                       <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Her fame was noised every where,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To young and old the same was known,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That she no company would mind,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who were to vanity inclin'd.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_263">[Pg 263]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Mean while Ulysses fought for fame,                                 <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">'Mongst Trojans hazarding his life:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Young gallants, hearing of her name,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Came flocking for to tempt his wife:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For she was lovely, young, and fair,<br></span>
<span class="i0">No lady might with her compare.                                     <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With costly gifts and jewels fine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They did endeavour her to win;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With banquets and the choicest wine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For to allure her unto sin:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Most persons were of high degree,                                   <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who courted fair Penelope.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With modesty and comely grace,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Their wanton suits she did denye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">No tempting charms could e'er deface<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her dearest husband's memorye;                                    <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But constant she would still remain,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hopeing to see him once again.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her book her dayly comfort was,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And that she often did peruse;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She seldom looked in her glass;                                     <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Powder and paint she ne'er would use.<br></span>
<span class="i0">I wish all ladies were as free<br></span>
<span class="i0">From pride, as was Penelope.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She in her needle took delight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And likewise in her spinning-wheel;                               <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Her maids about her every night<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did use the distaff, and the reel:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The spiders, that on rafters twine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Scarce spin a thread more soft and fine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sometimes she would bewail the loss                                 <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And absence of her dearest love:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sometimes she thought the seas to cross,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her fortune on the waves to prove.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_264">[Pg 264]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I fear my lord is slain, quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He stays so from Penelope.                                          <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At length the ten years siege of Troy<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did end: in flames the city burn'd;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to the Grecians was great joy,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To see the towers to ashes turn'd:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then came Ulysses home to see                                       <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">His constant, dear, Penelope.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O blame her not if she was glad,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When she her lord again had seen.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thrice-welcome home, my dear, she said,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A long time absent thou hast been:                               <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The wars shall never more deprive<br></span>
<span class="i0">Me of my lord whilst I'm alive.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Fair ladies all example take;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And hence a worthy lesson learn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">All youthful follies to forsake,                                   <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And vice from virtue to discern:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And let all women strive to be,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As constant as Penelope.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_429"></a><a href="#FNanchor_429" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[429]</span></a> [use.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XI.<br>

TO LUCASTA, ON GOING TO THE WARS.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i264.png" id="img_images_i264.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">By</span> Col. Richard Lovelace: from the volume of his
poems, intitled <i>Lucasta</i>, (Lond. 1649. 12mo.). The
elegance of this writer's manner would be more admired,
if it had somewhat more of simplicity.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Percy's admirers would be glad to expunge the above unjust
judgment. Some of Lovelace's poems may be affected, but that
charge cannot be brought against these exquisite verses, the last
two of which have become a world-famed quotation.]</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_265">[Pg 265]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i265.png" id="img_images_i265.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Tell me not, sweet, I am unkinde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That from the nunnerie<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of thy chaste breast and quiet minde,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To warre and armes I flie.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">True, a new mistresse now I chase,                                   <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The first foe in the field;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with a stronger faith imbrace<br></span>
<span class="i2">A sword, a horse, a shield.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Yet this inconstancy is such,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As you too shall adore;                                           <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I could not love thee, deare, so much,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Lov'd I not honour more.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XII.<br>

VALENTINE AND URSINE.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i265t.png" id="img_images_i265t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> old story-book of <i>Valentine and Orson</i> (which suggested
the plan of this tale, but it is not strictly followed
in it) was originally a translation from the
French, being one of their earliest attempts at romance.
See <i>Le Bibliothèque de Romans, &amp;c.</i></p>
<p>The circumstance of the bridge of bells is taken from the old
metrical legend of Sir Bevis, and has also been copied in the
<i>Seven Champions</i>. The original lines are,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Over the dyke a bridge there lay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That man and beest might passe away:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Under the brydge were sixty belles;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Right as the Romans telles;<br></span>
<span class="i0">That there might no man passe in,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But all they rang with a gyn."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">Sign. E. iv.</p>
<p>In the Editor's folio MS. was an old poem on this subject, in a
wretched corrupt state, unworthy the press: from which were
taken such particulars as could be adopted.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_266">[Pg 266]</a></span></p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The poem entitled <i>The Emperour and the Childe</i> in the Folio
MS. (ed. Hales and Furnivall, vol. ii. p. 390) only suggested the
subject of the present ballad. It commences—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Within the Grecyan land some time did dwell<br></span>
<span class="i0">an Emperour, whose name did ffar excell;<br></span>
<span class="i0">he tooke to wiffe the lady B[e]llefaunt,<br></span>
<span class="i0">the only sister to the kinge of ffrance,<br></span>
<span class="i0">with whome he liued in pleasure and delight<br></span>
<span class="i0">vntill that ffortune came to worke them spighte.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>There are no particular signs of "corruption," and the piece is
probably superior to Percy's own effusion.</p>
<p>Percy's trumpery commencement is an echo of the beginning
of the printed copies of <i>Sir Andrew Barton</i>.</p>
<p>The name Ursine, like that of Orson, is derived from Fr. <i>Ourson</i>,
the diminutive of <i>Ours</i>, a bear (Latin, <i>ursus</i>.)]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<h4><span class="smcap">Part the First.</span>
</h4>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i266.png" id="img_images_i266.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then Flora 'gins to decke the fields<br></span>
<span class="i2">With colours fresh and fine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then holy clerkes their mattins sing<br></span>
<span class="i2">To good Saint Valentine!<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The king of France that morning fair                                 <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He would a hunting ride:<br></span>
<span class="i0">To Artois forest prancing forth<br></span>
<span class="i2">In all his princelye pride.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To grace his sports a courtly train<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of gallant peers attend;                                          <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And with their loud and cheerful cryes<br></span>
<span class="i2">The hills and valleys rend.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Through the deep forest swift they pass,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Through woods and thickets wild;<br></span>
<span class="i0">When down within a lonely dell                                      <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">They found a new-born child;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_267">[Pg 267]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">All in a scarlet kercher lay'd<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of silk so fine and thin:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A golden mantle wrapt him round<br></span>
<span class="i2">Pinn'd with a silver pin.                                         <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The sudden sight surpriz'd them all;<br></span>
<span class="i2">The courtiers gather'd round;<br></span>
<span class="i0">They look, they call, the mother seek;<br></span>
<span class="i2">No mother could be found.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">At length the king himself drew near,                               <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And as he gazing stands,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The pretty babe look'd up and smil'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And stretch'd his little hands.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now, by the rood, king Pepin says,<br></span>
<span class="i2">This child is passing fair:                                       <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I wot he is of gentle blood;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Perhaps some prince's heir.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Goe bear him home unto my court<br></span>
<span class="i2">With all the care ye may:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Let him be christen'd Valentine,                                    <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In honour of this day:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And look me out some cunning nurse;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Well nurtur'd let him bee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor ought be wanting that becomes<br></span>
<span class="i2">A bairn of high degree.                                           <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">They look'd him out a cunning nurse;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And nurtur'd well was hee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor ought was wanting that became<br></span>
<span class="i2">A bairn of high degree.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus grewe the little Valentine                                     <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Belov'd of king and peers;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And shew'd in all he spake or did<br></span>
<span class="i2">A wit beyond his years.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_268">[Pg 268]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But chief in gallant feates of arms<br></span>
<span class="i2">He did himself advance,                                           <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That ere he grewe to man's estate<br></span>
<span class="i2">He had no peere in France.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And now the early downe began<br></span>
<span class="i2">To shade his youthful chin;<br></span>
<span class="i0">When Valentine was dubb'd a knight,                                 <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That he might glory win.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A boon, a boon, my gracious liege,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I beg a boon of thee!<br></span>
<span class="i0">The first adventure, that befalls,<br></span>
<span class="i2">May be reserv'd for mee.                                          <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The first adventure shall be thine;<br></span>
<span class="i2">The king did smiling say.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor many days, when lo! there came<br></span>
<span class="i2">Three palmers clad in graye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Help, gracious lord, they weeping say'd;                            <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And knelt, as it was meet:<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Artoys forest we be come,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With weak and wearye feet.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Within those deep and drearye woods<br></span>
<span class="i2">There wends a savage boy;                                         <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Whose fierce and mortal rage doth yield<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy subjects dire annoy.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Mong ruthless beares he sure was bred;<br></span>
<span class="i2">He lurks within their den:<br></span>
<span class="i0">With beares he lives; with beares he feeds;                         <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And drinks the blood of men.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To more than savage strength he joins<br></span>
<span class="i2">A more than human skill:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For arms, ne cunning may suffice<br></span>
<span class="i2">His cruel rage to still:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_269">[Pg 269]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Up then rose sir Valentine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And claim'd that arduous deed.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Go forth and conquer, say'd the king,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And great shall be thy meed.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Well mounted on a milk-white steed,                                 <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His armour white as snow;<br></span>
<span class="i0">As well beseem'd a virgin knight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who ne'er had fought a foe;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To Artoys forest he repairs<br></span>
<span class="i2">With all the haste he may;                                        <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And soon he spies the savage youth<br></span>
<span class="i2">A rending of his prey.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">His unkempt hair all matted hung<br></span>
<span class="i2">His shaggy shoulders round:<br></span>
<span class="i0">His eager eye all fiery glow'd:                                     <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His face with fury frown'd.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Like eagles' talons grew his nails:<br></span>
<span class="i2">His limbs were thick and strong;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dreadful was the knotted oak<br></span>
<span class="i2">He bare with him along.                                          <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Soon as sir Valentine approach'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He starts with sudden spring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yelling forth a hideous howl,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He made the forests ring.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As when a tyger fierce and fell                                    <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Hath spyed a passing roe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And leaps at once upon his throat;<br></span>
<span class="i2">So sprung the savage foe;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So lightly leap'd with furious force<br></span>
<span class="i2">The gentle knight to seize:                                      <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But met his tall uplifted spear,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which sunk him on his knees.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_270">[Pg 270]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A second stroke so stiff and stern<br></span>
<span class="i2">Had laid the savage low;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But springing up, he rais'd his club,                              <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And aim'd a dreadful blow.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The watchful warrior bent his head,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And shun'd the coming stroke;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Upon his taper spear it fell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all to shivers broke.                                        <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then lighting nimbly from his steed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He drew his burnisht brand:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The savage quick as lightning flew<br></span>
<span class="i2">To wrest it from his hand.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Three times he grasp'd the silver hilt;                            <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Three times he felt the blade;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Three times it fell with furious force;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Three ghastly wounds it made.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now with redoubled rage he roared;<br></span>
<span class="i2">His eye-ball flash'd with fire;                                  <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Each hairy limb with fury shook;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all his heart was ire.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then closing fast with furious gripe<br></span>
<span class="i2">He clasp'd the champion round,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with a strong and sudden twist                                 <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He laid him on the ground.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But soon the knight, with active spring,<br></span>
<span class="i2">O'erturn'd his hairy foe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And now between their sturdy fists<br></span>
<span class="i2">Past many a bruising blow.                                       <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">They roll'd and grappled on the ground,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And there they struggled long:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Skilful and active was the knight;<br></span>
<span class="i2">The savage he was strong.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_271">[Pg 271]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But brutal force and savage strength                               <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To art and skill must yield:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Valentine at length prevail'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And won the well-fought field.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then binding strait his conquer'd foe<br></span>
<span class="i2">Fast with an iron chain,                                         <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He tyes him to his horse's tail,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And leads him o'er the plain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To court his hairy captive soon<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sir Valentine doth bring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And kneeling downe upon his knee,                                  <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Presents him to the king.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With loss of blood and loss of strength,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The savage tamer grew;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And to sir Valentine became<br></span>
<span class="i2">A servant try'd and true.                                        <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And 'cause with beares he erst was bred,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ursine they call his name;<br></span>
<span class="i0">A name which unto future times<br></span>
<span class="i2">The Muses shall proclame.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="tb">
<h4><span class="smcap">Part the Second.</span>
</h4>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i271.png" id="img_images_i271.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In high renown with prince and peere<br></span>
<span class="i2">Now liv'd sir Valentine:<br></span>
<span class="i0">His high renown with prince and peere<br></span>
<span class="i2">Made envious hearts repine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It chanc'd the king upon a day                                       <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Prepar'd a sumptuous feast:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there came lords, and dainty dames,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And many a noble guest.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_272">[Pg 272]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Amid their cups, that freely flow'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Their revelry, and mirth;                                         <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">A youthful knight tax'd Valentine<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of base and doubtful birth.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The foul reproach, so grossly urg'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His generous heart did wound:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And strait he vow'd he ne'er would rest                             <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Till he his parents found.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then bidding king and peers adieu,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Early one summer's day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With faithful Ursine by his side,<br></span>
<span class="i2">From court he took his way.                                       <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O'er hill and valley, moss and moor,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For many a day they pass;<br></span>
