<span class="i0">At length upon a moated lake,<a id="FNanchor_430"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_430">[430]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">They found a bridge of brass.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Beyond it rose a castle fair                                        <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Y-built of marble stone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The battlements were gilt with gold,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And glittred in the sun.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Beneath the bridge, with strange device,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A hundred bells were hung;                                        <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">That man, nor beast, might pass thereon,<br></span>
<span class="i2">But strait their larum rung.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This quickly found the youthful pair,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who boldly crossing o'er,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The jangling sound bedeaft their ears,                              <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And rung from shore to shore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quick at the sound the castle gates<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unlock'd and opened wide,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And strait a gyant huge and grim<br></span>
<span class="i2">Stalk'd forth with stately pride.                                 <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_273">[Pg 273]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now yield you, caytiffs, to my will;<br></span>
<span class="i2">He cried with hideous roar;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Or else the wolves shall eat your flesh,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And ravens drink your gore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Vain boaster, said the youthful knight,                             <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I scorn thy threats and thee:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I trust to force thy brazen gates,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And set thy captives free.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then putting spurs unto his steed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He aim'd a dreadful thrust:                                       <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The spear against the gyant glanc'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And caus'd the blood to burst.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Mad and outrageous with the pain,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He whirl'd his mace of steel:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The very wind of such a blow                                        <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Had made the champion reel.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It haply mist; and now the knight<br></span>
<span class="i2">His glittering sword display'd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And riding round with whirlwind speed<br></span>
<span class="i2">Oft made him feel the blade.                                      <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As when a large and monstrous oak<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unceasing axes hew:<br></span>
<span class="i0">So fast around the gyant's limbs<br></span>
<span class="i2">The blows quick-darting flew.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">As when the boughs with hideous fall                                <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Some hapless woodman crush:<br></span>
<span class="i0">With such a force the enormous foe<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did on the champion rush.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A fearful blow, alas! there came,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Both horse and knight it took.                                    <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And laid them senseless in the dust;<br></span>
<span class="i2">So fatal was the stroke.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_274">[Pg 274]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then smiling forth a hideous grin,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The gyant strides in haste,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, stooping, aims a second stroke:                                <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">"Now caytiff breathe thy last!"<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But ere it fell, two thundering blows<br></span>
<span class="i2">Upon his scull descend:<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Ursine's knotty club they came,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who ran to save his friend.                                       <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Down sunk the gyant gaping wide,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And rolling his grim eyes:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The hairy youth repeats his blows:<br></span>
<span class="i2">He gasps, he groans, he dies.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quickly sir Valentine reviv'd                                       <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With Ursine's timely care:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And now to search the castle walls<br></span>
<span class="i2">The venturous youths repair.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The blood and bones of murder'd knights<br></span>
<span class="i2">They found where'er they came:                                    <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">At length within a lonely cell<br></span>
<span class="i2">They saw a mournful dame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her gentle eyes were dim'd with tears;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her cheeks were pale with woe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And long sir Valentine besought                                     <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her doleful tale to know.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Alas! young knight," she weeping said,<br></span>
<span class="i2">"Condole my wretched fate:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A childless mother here you see;<br></span>
<span class="i2">A wife without a mate.                                           <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"These twenty winters here forlorn<br></span>
<span class="i2">I've drawn my hated breath;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sole witness of a monster's crimes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And wishing aye for death.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_275">[Pg 275]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Know, I am sister of a king;                                      <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And in my early years<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was married to a mighty prince,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The fairest of his peers.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"With him I sweetly liv'd in love<br></span>
<span class="i0">A twelvemonth and a day:                                           <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">When, lo! a foul and treacherous priest<br></span>
<span class="i0">Y-wrought our loves' decay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"His seeming goodness wan him pow'r;<br></span>
<span class="i2">He had his master's ear:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And long to me and all the world                                   <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He did a saint appear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"One day, when we were all alone,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He proffer'd odious love:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The wretch with horrour I repuls'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And from my presence drove.                                      <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"He feign'd remorse, and piteous beg'd<br></span>
<span class="i2">His crime I'd not reveal:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which, for his seeming penitence,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I promis'd to conceal.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"With treason, villainy, and wrong                                 <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My goodness he repay'd:<br></span>
<span class="i0">With jealous doubts he fill'd my lord,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And me to woe betray'd.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"He hid a slave within my bed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then rais'd a bitter cry.                                        <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">My lord, possest with rage, condemn'd<br></span>
<span class="i2">Me, all unheard, to dye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But 'cause I then was great with child,<br></span>
<span class="i2">At length my life he spar'd;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But bade me instant quit the realme,                               <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">One trusty knight my guard.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_276">[Pg 276]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Forth on my journey I depart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Opprest with grief and woe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And tow'rds my brother's distant court,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With breaking heart, I goe.                                      <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Long time thro' sundry foreign lands<br></span>
<span class="i2">We slowly pace along:<br></span>
<span class="i0">At length within a forest wild<br></span>
<span class="i2">I fell in labour strong:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"And while the knight for succour sought,                          <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And left me there forlorn,<br></span>
<span class="i0">My childbed pains so fast increast<br></span>
<span class="i2">Two lovely boys were born.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"The eldest fair, and smooth, as snow<br></span>
<span class="i2">That tips the mountain hoar:                                     <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The younger's little body rough<br></span>
<span class="i2">With hairs was cover'd o'er.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But here afresh begin my woes:<br></span>
<span class="i2">While tender care I took<br></span>
<span class="i0">To shield my eldest from the cold,                                 <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And wrap him in my cloak;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"A prowling bear burst from the wood,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And seiz'd my younger son:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Affection lent my weakness wings,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And after them I run.                                            <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But all forewearied, weak and spent,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I quickly swoon'd away;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there beneath the greenwood shade<br></span>
<span class="i2">Long time I lifeless lay.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"At length the knight brought me relief,                           <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And rais'd me from the ground:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But neither of my pretty babes<br></span>
<span class="i2">Could ever more be found.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_277">[Pg 277]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"And, while in search we wander'd far,<br></span>
<span class="i2">We met that gyant grim;                                          <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Who ruthless slew my trusty knight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And bare me off with him.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But charm'd by heav'n, or else my griefs,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He offer'd me no wrong;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Save that within these lonely walls                                <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">I've been immur'd so long."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now, surely, said the youthful knight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">You are lady Bellisance,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Wife to the Grecian emperor:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Your brother's king of France.                                   <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For in your royal brother's court<br></span>
<span class="i2">Myself my breeding had;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where oft the story of your woes<br></span>
<span class="i2">Hath made my bosom sad.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">If so, know your accuser's dead,                                   <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And dying own'd his crime;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And long your lord hath sought you out<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thro' every foreign clime.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when no tidings he could learn<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of his much-wronged wife,                                        <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">He vow'd thenceforth within his court<br></span>
<span class="i2">To lead a hermit's life.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now heaven is kind! the lady said;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And dropt a joyful tear:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Shall I once more behold my lord?                                  <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That lord I love so dear?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But, madam, said sir Valentine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And knelt upon his knee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Know you the cloak that wrapt your babe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">If you the same should see?                                      <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_278">[Pg 278]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And pulling forth the cloth of gold,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In which himself was found;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lady gave a sudden shriek,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fainted on the ground.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But by his pious care reviv'd,                                     <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His tale she heard anon;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And soon by other tokens found,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He was indeed her son.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But who's this hairy youth? she said;<br></span>
<span class="i2">He much resembles thee:                                          <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The bear devour'd my younger son,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or sure that son were he.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Madam, this youth with bears was bred,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And rear'd within their den.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But recollect ye any mark                                          <span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To know you son agen?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Upon his little side, quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was stampt a bloody rose.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Here, lady, see the crimson mark<br></span>
<span class="i2">Upon his body grows!                                             <span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then clasping both her new-found sons<br></span>
<span class="i2">She bath'd their cheeks with tears;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And soon towards hèr brother's court<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her joyful course she steers.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What pen can paint king Pepin's joy,                               <span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His sister thus restor'd!<br></span>
<span class="i0">And soon a messenger was sent<br></span>
<span class="i2">To cheer her drooping lord:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Who came in haste with all his peers,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To fetch her home to Greece;                                     <span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where many happy years they reign'd<br></span>
<span class="i2">In perfect love and peace.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_279">[Pg 279]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To them sir Ursine did succeed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And long the scepter bare.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir Valentine he stay'd in France,                                 <span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And was his uncle's heir.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">⁂</p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_430"></a><a href="#FNanchor_430" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[430]</span></a> Ver. 23. <i>i.e.</i> a lake that served for a moat to a castle.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XIII.<br>

THE DRAGON OF WANTLEY.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i279.png" id="img_images_i279.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> humourous song (as a former Editor<a id="FNanchor_431"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_431">[431]</a> has well observed)
is to old metrical romances and ballads of
chivalry, what <i>Don Quixote</i> is to prose narratives of
that kind:—a lively satire on their extravagant fictions.
But altho' the satire is thus general, the subject of this ballad is
local and peculiar: so that many of the finest strokes of humour
are lost for want of our knowing the minute circumstances to
which they allude. Many of them can hardly now be recovered,
altho' we have been fortunate enough to learn the general subject
to which the satire referred, and shall detail the information, with
which we have been favoured, at the end of this introduction.</p>
<p>In handling his subject, the Author has brought in most of
the common incidents which occur in romance. The description
of the dragon<a id="FNanchor_432"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_432">[432]</a>—his outrages—the people flying to the knight
for succour—his care in chusing his armour—his being drest for
fight by a young damsel—and most of the circumstances of the
battle and victory (allowing for the burlesque turn given to them)
are what occur in every book of chivalry, whether in prose or
verse.</p>
<p>If any one piece, more than other, is more particularly levelled
at, it seems to be the old rhiming legend of sir Bevis. There a
<i>Dragon</i> is attacked from a <i>Well</i> in a manner not very remote from
this of the ballad:—</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">There was a well, so have I wynne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Bevis stumbled ryght therein.<br></span>
<span class="i0">       *       *       *       *       *<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than was he glad without fayle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And rested a whyle for his avayle;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And dranke of that water his fyll;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_280">[Pg 280]</a></span>
<span class="i0">And then he lepte out, with good wyll,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with Morglay his brande<br></span>
<span class="i0">He assayled the dragon, I understande:<br></span>
<span class="i0">On the dragon he smote so faste,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where that he hit the scales braste:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The dragon then faynted sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And cast a galon and more<br></span>
<span class="i0">Out of his mouthe of venim strong,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And on syr Bevis he it flong:<br></span>
<span class="i0">It was venymous y-wis.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>This seems to be meant by the Dragon of Wantley's stink,
ver. 110. As the politick knight's creeping out, and attacking the
dragon, &amp;c. seems evidently to allude to the following:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Bevis blessed himselfe and forth yode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And lepte out with haste full good;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Bevis unto the dragon gone is;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the dragon also to Bevis.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Longe, and harde was that fyght<br></span>
<span class="i0">Betwene the dragon, and that knyght:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But ever whan syr Bevis was hurt sore,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He went to the well, and washed him thore;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He was as hole as any man,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ever freshe as whan he began.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The dragon sawe it might not avayle<br></span>
<span class="i0">Besyde the well to hold batayle;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He thought he would, wyth some wyle,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Out of that place Bevis begyle;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He woulde have flowen then awaye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Bevis lepte after with good Morglaye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hyt him under the wynge,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he was in his flyenge, &amp;c.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">Sign. M. jv. L. j. &amp;c.</p>
<p>After all, perhaps the writer of this ballad was acquainted with
the above incidents only thro' the medium of Spenser, who has
assumed most of them in his <i>Faery Queen</i>. At least some particulars
in the description of the Dragon, &amp;c. seem evidently borrowed
from the latter. See book i. canto 11, where the Dragon's
"two wynges like sayls—huge long tayl—with stings—his cruel
rending clawes—and yron teeth—his breath of smothering smoke
and sulphur"—and the duration of the fight for upwards of two
days, bear a great resemblance to passages in the following ballad;
though it must be confessed that these particulars are common to
all old writers of romance.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_281">[Pg 281]</a></span></p>
<p>Altho' this ballad must have been written early in the last
century, we have met with none but such as were comparatively
modern copies. It is here printed from one in Roman letter,
in the Pepys collection, collated with such others as could be
procured.</p>
<p>A description of the supposed scene of this ballad, which was
communicated to the Editor in 1767, is here given in the words
of the relater:—</p>
<p>"In Yorkshire, 6 miles from Rotherham, is a village, called
<i>Wortley</i>, the seat of the late <i>Wortley Montague</i>, Esq. About a
mile from this village is a lodge, named <i>Warncliff Lodge</i>, but
vulgarly called <i>Wantley</i>: here lies the scene of the song. I was
there about forty years ago: and it being a woody rocky place,
my friend made me clamber over rocks and stones, not telling me
to what end, till I came to a sort of a cave; then asked my
opinion of the place, and pointing to one end, says, Here lay the
dragon killed by <i>Moor</i> of <i>Moor-hall</i>: here lay his head; here
lay his tail; and the stones we came over on the hill, are those he
could not crack; and yon white house you see half a mile off, is
<i>Moor-hall</i>. I had dined at the lodge, and knew the man's name
was <i>Matthew</i>, who was a keeper to Mr. Wortley, and, as he endeavoured
to persuade me, was the same Matthew mentioned in
the song: In the house is the picture of the Dragon and Moor of
Moor-hall, and near it a well, which, says he, is the well described
in the ballad."</p>
<p>Since the former editions of this humorous old song were printed,
the following <i>Key to the Satire</i> hath been communicated by <i>Godfrey</i>
<i>Bosville</i>, Esq. of Thorp, near Malton, in Yorkshire; who, in
the most obliging manner, gave full permission to adjoin it to the
poem.</p>
<p><i>Warncliffe</i> Lodge, and <i>Warncliffe</i> Wood (vulgarly pronounced
<i>Wantley</i>), are in the parish of Penniston, in Yorkshire. The
rectory of Penniston was part of the dissolved monastery of
St. Stephen's, Westminster; and was granted to the Duke of
Norfolk's family: who therewith endowed an hospital, which he
built at Sheffield, for women. The trustees let the impropriation
of the great Tythes of Penniston to the Wortley family, who got a
great deal by it, and wanted to get still more; for Mr. Nicholas
Wortley attempted to take the tythes in kind, but Mr. Francis
Bosville opposed him, and there was a decree in favour of the
Modus in 37th Eliz. The vicarage of Penniston did not go along
with the rectory, but with the copyhold rents, and was part of a
large purchase made by Ralph Bosville, Esq. from Q. Elizabeth,
in the 2d year of her reign: and that part he sold in 12th Eliz. to
his elder brother Godfrey, the father of Francis; who left it, with
the rest of his estate, to his wife, for her life, and then to Ralph,<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_282">[Pg 282]</a></span>
3d son of his uncle Ralph. The widow married Lyonel Rowlestone,
lived eighteen years, and survived Ralph.</p>
<p>This premised, the ballad apparently relates to the law-suit
carried on concerning this claim of tythes made by the Wortley
family. "Houses and churches, were to him geese and turkeys:"
which are tytheable things, the dragon chose to live on. Sir
Francis Wortley, the son of Nicholas, attempted again to take
the tythes in kind: but the parishioners subscribed an agreement
to defend their Modus. And at the head of the agreement was
Lyonel Rowlestone, who is supposed to be one of "the Stones,
dear Jack, which the Dragon could not crack." The agreement
is still preserved in a large sheet of parchment, dated 1st of James I.,
and is full of names and seals, which might be meant by the coat
of armour, "with spikes all about, both within and without."
<i>More</i> of <i>More-hall</i> was either the attorney, or counsellor, who
conducted the suit. He is not distinctly remembered, but More-hall
is still extant at the very bottom of Wantley [Warncliff]
Wood, and lies so low, that it might be said to be in a well: as
the dragon's den [Warncliff Lodge] was at the top of the wood,
"with Matthew's house hard by it." The keepers belonging to
the Wortley family were named, for many generations, Matthew
Northall: the last of them left this lodge, within memory, to be
keeper to the Duke of Norfolk. The present owner of More-hall
still attends Mr. Bosville's Manor-Court at Oxspring, and pays a
rose a year. "More of More-hall, with nothing at all, slew the
Dragon of Wantley." He gave him, instead of tythes, so small a
Modus, that it was in effect nothing at all, and was slaying him
with a vengeance. "The poor children three," &amp;c. cannot surely
mean the three sisters of Francis Bosville, who would have been
coheiresses, had he made no will? The late Mr. Bosville had a
contest with the descendants of two of them, the late Sir Geo.
Saville's father, and Mr. Copley, about the presentation to Penniston,
they supposing Francis had not the power to give this part
of the estate from the heirs at law; but it was decided against
them. The dragon (Sir Francis Wortley) succeeded better with
his cousin Wordesworth, the freehold lord of the manor (for it is
the copyhold manor that belongs to Mr. Bosville) having persuaded
him not to join the refractory parishioners, under a promise
that he would let him his tythes cheap: and now the estates
of Wortley and Wordesworth are the only lands that pay tythes in
the parish.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<p>N.B. "Two days and a night," mentioned in ver. 125, as the
duration of the combat, was probably that of the trial at law.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[In Gough's edition of Camden's <i>Britannia</i> we learn that "Sir
Thomas Wortley, who was knight of the body to Edward IV.,<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_283">[Pg 283]</a></span>
Richard III., Henry VII. and VIII., built a lodge in his chace
of Warncliffe, and had a house and park there, disparked in the
Civil War."</p>
<p>Mr. Gilfillan has the following note in his edition of the <i>Reliques</i>,
"A legend current in the Wortley family states the dragon to have
been a formidable drinker, drunk dead by the chieftain of the opposite
moors. Ellis thinks it was a wolf or some other fierce animal
hunted down by More of More-hall." A writer in the <i>Notes and</i>
<i>Queries</i> (3rd S. ix. 29), who signs himself "Fitzhopkins," expresses
his disbelief in the above explanation communicated to Percy by
Godfrey Bosville.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i283.png" id="img_images_i283.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Old stories tell how Hercules<br></span>
<span class="i4">A dragon slew at Lerna,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With seven heads, and fourteen eyes,<br></span>
<span class="i4">To see and well discern-a:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But he had a club, this dragon to drub,                              <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Or he had ne'er done it, I warrant ye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But More of More-Hall, with nothing at all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He slew the dragon of Wantley.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">This dragon had two furious wings,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Each one upon each shoulder;                                    <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With a sting in his tayl as long as a flayl,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Which made him bolder and bolder.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He had long claws, and in his jaws<br></span>
<span class="i2">Four and forty teeth of iron;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With a hide as tough, as any buff,                                  <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Which did him round environ.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Have you not heard how the Trojan horse<br></span>
<span class="i4">Held seventy men in his belly?<br></span>
<span class="i2">This dragon was not quite so big,<br></span>
<span class="i4">But very near, I'll tell ye.                                    <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Devoured he poor children three,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That could not with him grapple;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And at one sup he eat them up,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As one would eat an apple.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_284">[Pg 284]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">All sorts of cattle this dragon did eat.                          <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Some say he ate up trees,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And that the forests sure he would<br></span>
<span class="i4">Devour up by degrees:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For houses and churches were to him geese and turkies;<a id="FNanchor_433"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_433">[433]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">He ate all, and left none behind,                                 <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But some stones, dear Jack, that he could not crack,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which on the hills you will find.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">In Yorkshire, near fair Rotherham,<a id="FNanchor_434"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_434">[434]</a><br></span>
<span class="i4">The place I know it well;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Some two or three miles, or thereabouts,                          <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">I vow I cannot tell.<br></span>
<span class="i0">But there is a hedge, just on the hill edge,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And Matthew's house hard by it;<br></span>
<span class="i0">O there and then was this dragon's den,<br></span>
<span class="i2">You could not chuse but spy it.                                   <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Some say, this dragon was a witch;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Some say, he was a devil,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For from his nose a smoke arose,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And with it burning snivel;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which he cast off, when he did cough,                               <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">In a well that he did stand by;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Which made it look, just like a brook<br></span>
<span class="i2">Running with burning brandy.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Hard by a furious knight there dwelt,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Of whom all towns did ring;                                     <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">For he could wrestle, play at quarter-staff, kick, cuff, and huff,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Call son of a whore, do any kind of thing:<br></span>
<span class="i0">By the tail and the main, with his hands twain<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_285">[Pg 285]</a></span>
<span class="i2">He swung a horse till he was dead;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And that which is stranger, he for very anger                       <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Eat him all up but his head.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">These children, as I am told, being eat;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Men, women, girls and boys,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sighing and sobbing, came to his lodging,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And made a hideous noise:                                       <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">O save us all, More of More-Hall,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou peerless knight of these woods;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Do but slay this dragon, who won't leave us a rag on,<br></span>
<span class="i2">We'll give thee all our goods.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Tut, tut, quoth he, no goods I want;                              <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">But I want, I want, in sooth,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A fair maid of sixteen, that's brisk, and keen,<br></span>
<span class="i4">With smiles about the mouth;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hair black as sloe, skin white as snow,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With blushes her cheeks adorning;                                 <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">To anoynt me o'er night, ere I go to fight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And to dress me in the morning.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">This being done, he did engage<br></span>
<span class="i4">To hew the dragon down;<br></span>
<span class="i2">But first he went, new armour to                                  <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Bespeak at Sheffield town;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With spikes all about, not within but without,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of steel so sharp and strong;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Both behind and before, arms, legs, and all o'er<br></span>
<span class="i2">Some five or six inches long.                                     <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Had you but seen him in this dress,<br></span>
<span class="i4">How fierce he look'd and how big,<br></span>
<span class="i2">You would have thought him for to be<br></span>
<span class="i4">Some Egyptian porcupig:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_286">[Pg 286]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He frighted all, cats, dogs, and all,                               <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Each cow, each horse, and each hog:<br></span>
<span class="i0">For fear they did flee, for they took him to be<br></span>
<span class="i2">Some strange outlandish hedge-hog.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">To see this fight, all people then<br></span>
<span class="i4">Got up on trees and houses,                                     <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">On churches some, and chimneys too;<br></span>
<span class="i4">But these put on their trowses,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not to spoil their hose. As soon as he rose,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To make him strong and mighty,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He drank by the tale, six pots of ale,                              <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And a quart of aqua-vitæ.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">It is not strength that always wins,<br></span>
<span class="i4">For wit doth strength excell;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which made our cunning champion<br></span>
<span class="i4">Creep down into a well;                                        <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Where he did think, this dragon would drink,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And so he did in truth;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And as he stoop'd low, he rose up and cry'd, boh!<br></span>
<span class="i2">And hit him in the mouth.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">O, quoth the dragon, pox take thee, come out,                    <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Thou disturb'st me in my drink:<br></span>
<span class="i2">And then he turn'd, and s... at him;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Good lack how he did stink!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Beshrew thy soul, thy body's foul,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy dung smells not like balsam;                                 <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou son of a whore, thou stink'st so sore,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sure thy diet is unwholesome.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Our politick knight, on the other side,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Crept out upon the brink,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And gave the dragon such a douse,                                <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">He knew not what to think:<br></span>
<span class="i0">By cock, quoth he, say you so: do you see?<br></span>
<span class="i2">And then at him he let fly<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_287">[Pg 287]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With hand and with foot, and so they went to't;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And the word it was, Hey boys, hey!                              <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Your words, quoth the dragon, I don't understand:<br></span>
<span class="i4">Then to it they fell at all,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Like two wild boars so fierce, if I may,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Compare great things with small.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Two days and a night, with this dragon did fight                   <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Our champion on the ground;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Tho' their strength it was great, their skill it was neat,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They never had one wound.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">At length the hard earth began to quake,<br></span>
<span class="i4">The dragon gave him a knock,                                   <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Which made him to reel, and straitway he thought,<br></span>
<span class="i4">To lift him as high as a rock,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thence let him fall. But More of More-Hall,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Like a valiant son of Mars,<br></span>
<span class="i0">As he came like a lout, so he turn'd him about,                    <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And hit him a kick on the a...<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Oh, quoth the dragon, with a deep sigh,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And turn'd six times together,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sobbing and tearing, cursing and swearing<br></span>
<span class="i4">Out of his throat of leather;                                  <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">More of More-Hall! O thou rascàl!<br></span>
<span class="i2">Would I had seen thee never;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With the thing at thy foot, thou hast prick'd my a...gut,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And I'm quite undone for ever.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Murder, murder, the dragon cry'd,                                <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Alack, alack, for grief;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Had you but mist that place, you could<br></span>
<span class="i4">Have done me no mischief.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_288">[Pg 288]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then his head he shaked, trembled and quaked,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And down he laid and cry'd;                                      <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">First on one knee, then on back tumbled he,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So groan'd, kickt, s..., and dy'd.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_431"></a><a href="#FNanchor_431" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[431]</span></a> Collection of Historical Ballads in 3 vol. 1727.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_432"></a><a href="#FNanchor_432" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[432]</span></a> See above, pp. <a href="#Page_108" class="pginternal">108</a>, 216.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_433"></a><a href="#FNanchor_433" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[433]</span></a> Ver. 29. were to him gorse and birches. <i>Other Copies.</i></p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_434"></a><a href="#FNanchor_434" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[434]</span></a> [Wharncliffe is about six miles from Rotherham.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XIV.<br>

ST. GEORGE FOR ENGLAND.</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">The First Part.</span>
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i288a.png" id="img_images_i288a.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">As</span> the former song is in ridicule of the extravagant incidents
in old ballads and metrical romances; so this is
a burlesque of their style; particularly of the rambling
transitions and wild accumulations of unconnected
parts, so frequent in many of them.</p>
<p>This ballad is given from an old black-letter copy in the Pepys
collection, "imprinted at London, 1612." It is more ancient
than many of the preceding; but we place it here for the sake
of connecting it with the <i>Second Part</i>.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<p>[<i>Saint George that, O! did break the dragon's heart</i> is one of the
ballads offered for sale by Nightingale, the ballad-singer in Ben
Jonson's comedy of <i>Bartholomew Fair</i> (act ii. sc. 1), and according
to Fielding's Tom Jones, <i>St. George, he was for England</i>, was one
of Squire Western's favourite tunes.</p>
<p>This ballad is printed in several collections, and Mr. Chappell
notices a modernization subscribed S. S. and "printed for W.
Gilbertson in Giltspur Street," about 1659, which commences—</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"What need we brag or boast at all<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Arthur and his knights."]<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i288w.png" id="img_images_i288w.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Why doe you boast of Arthur and his knightes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Knowing 'well' how many men have endured fightes?<br></span>
<span class="i2">For besides king Arthur, and Lancelot du lake,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or sir Tristram de Lionel, that fought for ladies sake;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_289">[Pg 289]</a></span>
<span class="i2">Read in old histories, and there you shall see<br></span>
<span class="i2">How St. George, St. George the dragon made to flee.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Mark our father Abraham, when first he resckued Lot<br></span>
<span class="i2">Onely with his household, what conquest there he got:<br></span>
<span class="i2">David was elected a prophet and a king,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He slew the great Goliah, with a stone within a sling:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet these were not knightes of the table round;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor St. George, St. George, who the dragon did confound.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Jephthah and Gideon did lead their men to fight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">They conquered the Amorites, and put them all to flight:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Hercules his labours 'were' on the plaines of Basse;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And Sampson slew a thousand with the jawbone of an asse,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And eke he threw a temple downe, and did a mighty spoyle:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But St. George, St. George he did the dragon foyle.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">The warres of ancient monarchs it were too long to tell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And likewise of the Romans, how farre they did excell;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_290">[Pg 290]</a></span>
<span class="i2">Hannyball and Scipio in many a fielde did fighte:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Orlando Furioso he was a worthy knighte:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Remus and Romulus, were they that Rome did builde:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But St. George, St. George the dragon made to yielde.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">The noble Alphonso, that was the Spanish king,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The order of the red scarffes and bandrolles in did bring:<a id="FNanchor_435"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_435">[435]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">He had a troope of mighty knightes, when first he did begin,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which sought adventures farre and neare, that conquest they might win:<br></span>
<span class="i2">The ranks of the Pagans he often put to flight:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But St. George, St. George did with the dragon fight.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Many 'knights' have fought with proud Tamberlaine.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Cutlax the Dane, great warres he did maintaine:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Rowland of Beame, and good 'sir' Olivere<br></span>
<span class="i2">In the forest of Acon slew both woolfe and beare:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Besides that noble Hollander, 'sir' Goward with the bill:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But St. George, St. George the dragon's blood did spill.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_291">[Pg 291]</a></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Valentine and Orson were of king Pepin's blood:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Alfride and Henry they were brave knightes and good:<br></span>
<span class="i2">The four sons of Aymon, that follow'd Charlemaine:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sir Hughon of Burdeaux, and Godfrey of Bullaine:<br></span>
<span class="i2">These were all French knightes that lived in that age:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But St. George, St. George the dragon did assuage.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Bevis conquered Ascapart, and after slew the boare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And then he crost beyond the seas to combat with the moore:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Sir Isenbras, and Eglamore they were knightes most bold;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And good Sir John Mandeville of travel much hath told:<br></span>
<span class="i2">There were many English knights that Pagans did convert:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But St. George, St. George pluckt out the dragon's heart.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">The noble earl of Warwick, that was call'd sir Guy,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The infidels and pagans stoutlie did defie;<br></span>
<span class="i2">He slew the giant Brandimore, and after was the death<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of that most ghastly dun cowe, the divell of Dunsmore heath;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Besides his noble deeds all done beyond the seas:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But St George, St. George the dragon did appease.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_292">[Pg 292]</a></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Richard Cœur-de-lion erst king of this land,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He the lion gored with his naked hand:<a id="FNanchor_436"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_436">[436]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">The false duke of Austria nothing did he feare;<br></span>
<span class="i2">But his son he killed with a boxe on the eare;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Besides his famous actes done in the holy lande:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But St. George, St. George the dragon did withstande.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Henry the fifth he conquered all France,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And quartered their arms, his honour to advance:<br></span>
<span class="i2">He their cities razed, and threw their castles downe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And his head he honoured with a double crowne:<br></span>
<span class="i2">He thumped the French-men, and after home he came:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But St. George, St. George he did the dragon tame.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">St. David of Wales the Welsh-men much advance:<br></span>
<span class="i2">St. Jaques of Spaine, that never yet broke lance:<br></span>
<span class="i2">St. Patricke of Ireland, which was St. Georges boy,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Seven yeares he kept his horse, and then stole him away:<br></span>
<span class="i2">For which knavish act, as slaves they doe remaine:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But St. George, St. George the dragon he hath slaine.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_293">[Pg 293]</a></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_435"></a><a href="#FNanchor_435" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[435]</span></a> This probably alludes to "An Ancient Order of Knighthood,
called the Order of the Band, instituted by Don Alphonsus, king
of Spain, ... to wear a red riband of three fingers breadth," &amp;c.
See Ames <i>Typog.</i> p. 327.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_436"></a><a href="#FNanchor_436" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[436]</span></a> Alluding to the fabulous exploits attributed to this king in
the old romances. See the dissertation affixed to this volume.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XV.<br>

ST. GEORGE FOR ENGLAND.</h3>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">The Second Part.</span>
</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i293.png" id="img_images_i293.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capm"><span class="smcap">Was</span> written by <span class="smcap">John Grubb</span>, M.A. of Christ Church,
Oxford. The occasion of its being composed is said
to have been as follows. A set of gentlemen of the
university had formed themselves into a club, all the
members of which were to be of the name of <i>George</i>: Their anniversary
feast was to be held on <i>St. George's</i> day. Our author
solicited strongly to be admitted; but his name being unfortunately
<i>John</i>, this disqualification was dispensed with only upon this condition,
that he would compose a song in honour of their Patron
Saint, and would every year produce one or more new stanzas,
to be sung on their annual festival. This gave birth to the following
humorous performance, the several stanzas of which were
the produce of many successive anniversaries.<a id="FNanchor_437"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_437">[437]</a></p>
<p>This diverting poem was long handed about in manuscript, at
length a friend of <i>Grubb's</i> undertook to get it printed, who, not
keeping pace with the impatience of his friends, was addressed in
the following whimsical macaronic lines, which, in such a collection
as this, may not improperly accompany the poem itself.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<p><i>Expostulatiuncula</i>, sive <i>Querimoniuncula</i> ad <i>Antonium</i> [<i>Atherton</i>]
ob Poema <i>Johannis Grubb</i>, Viri του πανυ ingeniosissimi in lucem
nondum editi.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0"><i>Toni!</i> Tune sines divina poemata Grubbi<br></span>
<span class="i0">Intomb'd in secret thus still to remain any longer,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Τουνομα σου shall last, Ω Γρυββε διαμπερες αει,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Grubbe tuum nomen vivet dum nobilis ale-a<br></span>
<span class="i0">Efficit heroas, dignamque heroe puellam.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_294">[Pg 294]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Est genus heroum, quos nobilis efficit alea-a<br></span>
<span class="i0">Qui pro niperkin clamant, quaternque liquoris<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quem vocitant Homines Brandy, Superi Cherry-brandy,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sæpe illi longcut, vel small-cut flare Tobacco<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sunt soliti pipos. Ast si generosior herba<br></span>
<span class="i0">(Per varios casus, per tot discrimina rerum)<br></span>
<span class="i0">Mundungus desit, tum non funcare recusant<br></span>
<span class="i0">Brown-paper tostâ, vel quod fit arundine bed-mat.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Hic labor, hoc opus est heroum ascendere sedes!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Ast ego quo rapiar! quo me feret entheus ardor<br></span>
<span class="i0">Grubbe, tui memorem? Divinum expande poema.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quæ mora? quæ ratio est, quin Grubbi protinus anser<br></span>
<span class="i0">Virgilii, Flaccique simul canat inter olores?<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>At length the importunity of his friends prevailed, and Mr.
Grubb's song was published at Oxford, under the following title:</p>
<p class="center"><i>The British Heroes.</i><br>
A New Poem in honour of St. George,<br>
By Mr. <i>John Grubb</i>,<br>
School-master of Christ-Church,<br>
<i>Oxon.</i> 1688.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Favete linguis: carmina non prius<br></span>
<span class="i0">Audita, musarum sucerdos<br></span>
<span class="i0">Canto.—<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright"><span class="smcap">Hor.</span></p>
<p class="center">Sold by Henry Clements. Oxon.
</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i294.png" id="img_images_i294.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">The story of king Arthur old<br></span>
<span class="i4">Is very memorable,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The number of his valiant knights,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And roundness of his table:<br></span>
<span class="i2">The knights around his table in                                    <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">A circle sate d'ye see:<br></span>
<span class="i2">And altogether made up one<br></span>
<span class="i4">Large hoop of chivalry.<br></span>
<span class="i2">He had a sword, both broad and sharp,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_295">[Pg 295]</a></span>
<span class="i4">Y-clepd Caliburn,                                               <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Would cut a flint more easily,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Than pen-knife cuts a corn;<br></span>
<span class="i2">As case-knife does a capon carve,<br></span>
<span class="i4">So would it carve a rock,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And split a man at single slash,                                  <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">From noddle down to nock.<br></span>
<span class="i2">As Roman Augur's steel of yore<br></span>
<span class="i4">Dissected Tarquin's riddle,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So this would cut both conjurer<br></span>
<span class="i4">And whetstone thro' the middle.                                 <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He was the cream of Brecknock,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And flower of all the Welsh:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But George he did the dragon fell,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And gave him a plaguy squelsh.<a id="FNanchor_438"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_438">[438]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;           <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Pendragon, like his father Jove,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Was fed with milk of goat;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And like him made a noble shield<br></span>
<span class="i4">Of she-goat's shaggy coat:                                      <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">On top of burnisht helmet he<br></span>
<span class="i4">Did wear a crest of leeks;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And onions' heads, whose dreadful nod<br></span>
<span class="i4">Drew tears down hostile cheeks.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Itch, and Welsh blood did make him hot,                           <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And very prone to ire;<br></span>
<span class="i2">H' was ting'd with brimstone, like a match,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And would as soon take fire.<br></span>
<span class="i2">As brimstone he took inwardly<br></span>
<span class="i4">When scurf gave him occasion,                                   <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His postern puff of wind was a<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sulphureous exhalation.<br></span>
<span class="i2">The Briton never tergivers'd,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_296">[Pg 296]</a></span>
<span class="i4">But was for adverse drubbing,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And never turn'd his back to aught,                               <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">But to a post for scrubbing.<br></span>
<span class="i2">His sword would serve for battle, or<br></span>
<span class="i4">For dinner, if you please;<br></span>
<span class="i2">When it had slain a Cheshire man,<br></span>
<span class="i4">'Twould toast a Cheshire cheese.                                <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He wounded, and, in their own blood<br></span>
<span class="i4">Did anabaptize Pagans:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But George he made the dragon an<br></span>
<span class="i4">Example to all dragons.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;           <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Brave Warwick Guy, at dinner time,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Challeng'd a gyant savage;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And streight came out the unweildy lout<br></span>
<span class="i4">Brim-full of wrath and cabbage:                                 <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He had a phiz of latitude,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And was full thick i' th' middle;<br></span>
<span class="i2">The chekes of puffed trumpeter,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And paunch of squire Beadle.<a id="FNanchor_439"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_439">[439]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">But the knight fell'd him, like an oak,                           <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And did upon his back tread;<br></span>
<span class="i2">The valiant knight his weazon cut,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And Atropos his packthread.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Besides he fought with a dun cow,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As say the poets witty,                                         <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">A dreadful dun, and horned too,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Like dun of Oxford city:<br></span>
<span class="i2">The fervent dog-days made her mad,<br></span>
<span class="i4">By causing heat of weather,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Syrius and Procyon baited her,                                    <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_297">[Pg 297]</a></span>
<span class="i4">As bull-dogs did her father:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Grafiers, nor butchers this fell beast,<br></span>
<span class="i4">E'er of her frolick hindered;<br></span>
<span class="i2">John Dosset<a id="FNanchor_440"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_440">[440]</a> she'd knock down as flat,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As John knocks down her kindred:                                <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her heels would lay ye all along,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And kick into a swoon;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Frewin's<a id="FNanchor_441"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_441">[441]</a> cow-heels keep up your corpse,<br></span>
<span class="i4">But hers would beat you down.<br></span>
<span class="i2">She vanquisht many a sturdy wight,                                <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And proud was of the honour;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was pufft by mauling butchers so,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As if themselves had blown her.<br></span>
<span class="i2">At once she kickt, and pusht at Guy,<br></span>
<span class="i4">But all that would not fright him;                              <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who wav'd his winyard o'er sir-loyn,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As if he'd gone to knight him.<br></span>
<span class="i2">He let her blood, frenzy to cure,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And eke he did her gall rip;<br></span>
<span class="i2">His trenchant blade, like cook's long spit,                       <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Ran thro' the monster's bald-rib:<br></span>
<span class="i2">He rear'd up the vast crooked rib,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Instead of arch triumphal:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But George hit th' dragon such a pelt,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As made him on his bum fall.                                   <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Tamerlain, with Tartarian bow,<br></span>
<span class="i4">The Turkish squadrons slew;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fetch'd the pagan crescent down,                             <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">With half-moon made of yew:<br></span>
<span class="i2">His trusty bow proud Turks did gall,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_298">[Pg 298]</a></span>
<span class="i4">With showers of arrows thick,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And bow-strings, without strangling, sent<br></span>
<span class="i4">Grand Viziers to old Nick:                                     <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Much turbants, and much Pagan pates<br></span>
<span class="i4">He made to humble in dust;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And heads of Saracens he fixt<br></span>
<span class="i4">On spear, as on a sign-post:<br></span>
<span class="i2">He coop'd in cage Bajazet the prop                               <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Of Mahomet's religion,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As if't been the whispering bird,<br></span>
<span class="i4">That prompted him; the pigeon.<br></span>
<span class="i2">In Turkey leather scabbard, he<br></span>
<span class="i4">Did sheathe his blade so trenchant:                            <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">But George he swinged the dragon's tail,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And cut off every inch on't.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">The amazon Thalestris was                                        <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Both beautiful, and bold;<br></span>
<span class="i2">She sear'd her breasts with iron hot,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And bang'd her foes with cold.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her hand was like the tool, wherewith<br></span>
<span class="i4">Jove keeps proud mortals under:                                <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">It shone just like his lightning,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And batter'd like his thunder.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her eye darts lightning, that would blast<br></span>
<span class="i4">The proudest he that swagger'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And melt the rapier of his soul,                                 <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">In its corporeal scabbard.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her beauty, and her drum to foes<br></span>
<span class="i4">Did cause amazement double;<br></span>
<span class="i2">As timorous larks amazed are<br></span>
<span class="i4">With light, and with a low-bell:                               <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_299">[Pg 299]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">With beauty, and that lapland-charm,<a id="FNanchor_442"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_442">[442]</a><br></span>
<span class="i4">Poor men she did bewitch all;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Still a blind whining lover had,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As Pallas had her scrich-owl.<br></span>
<span class="i2">She kept the chastness of a nun                                  <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">In armour, as in cloyster:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But George undid the dragon just<br></span>
<span class="i4">As you'd undo an oister.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.                        <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Stout Hercules, was offspring of<br></span>
<span class="i4">Great Jove, and fair Alcmene:<br></span>
<span class="i2">One part of him celestial was,<br></span>
<span class="i4">One part of him terrene.<br></span>
<span class="i2">To scale the hero's cradle walls                                 <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Two fiery snakes combin'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And, curling into swaddling cloaths,<br></span>
<span class="i4">About the infant twin'd:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But he put out these dragons' fires,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And did their hissing stop;                                    <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">As red-hot iron with hissing noise<br></span>
<span class="i4">Is quencht in blacksmith's shop.<br></span>
<span class="i2">He cleans'd a stable, and rubb'd down<br></span>
<span class="i4">The horses of new-comers;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And out of horse-dung he rais'd fame,                            <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">As Tom Wrench<a id="FNanchor_443"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_443">[443]</a> does cucumbers.<br></span>
<span class="i2">He made a river help him through;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Alpheus was under-groom;<br></span>
<span class="i2">The stream, disgust at office mean,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Ran murmuring thro' the room:                                  <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">This liquid ostler to prevent<br></span>
<span class="i4">Being tired with that long work,<br></span>
<span class="i2">His father Neptune's trident took,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_300">[Pg 300]</a></span>
<span class="i4">Instead of three-tooth'd dung-fork.<br></span>
<span class="i2">This Hercules, as soldier, and                                   <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">As spinster, could take pains;<br></span>
<span class="i2">His club would sometimes spin ye flax,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And sometimes knock out brains:<br></span>
<span class="i2">H' was forc'd to spin his miss a shift<br></span>
<span class="i4">By Juno's wrath and hér-spite;                                 <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Fair Omphale whipt him to his wheel,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As cook whips barking turn-spit.<br></span>
<span class="i2">From man, or churn he well knew how<br></span>
<span class="i4">To get him lasting fame:<br></span>
<span class="i2">He'd pound a giant, till the blood,                              <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And milk till butter came.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Often he fought with huge battoon,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And oftentimes he boxed;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Tapt a fresh monster once a month,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As Hervey<a id="FNanchor_444"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_444">[444]</a> doth fresh hogshead.                            <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He gave Anteus such a hug,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As wrestlers give in Cornwall:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But George he did the dragon kill,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As dead as any door-nail.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;          <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">The Gemini, sprung from an egg,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Were put into a cradle:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Their brains with knocks and bottled ale,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Were often-times full addle:                                   <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And, scarcely hatch'd, these sons of him,<br></span>
<span class="i4">That hurls the bolt trisulcate,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With helmet-shell on tender head,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Did tustle with red-ey'd pole-cat.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Castor a horseman, Pollux tho'                                   <span class="linenum">205</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_301">[Pg 301]</a></span>
<span class="i4">A boxer was, I wist:<br></span>
<span class="i2">The one was fam'd for iron heel;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Th' other for leaden fist.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Pollux to shew he was god,<br></span>
<span class="i4">When he was in a passion                                       <span class="linenum">210</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With fist made noses fall down flat<br></span>
<span class="i4">By way of adoration:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">This fist, as sure as French disease,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Demolish'd noses' ridges:<br></span>
<span class="i2">He like a certain lord<a id="FNanchor_445"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_445">[445]</a> was famd'                            <span class="linenum">215</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">For breaking down of bridges.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Castor the flame of fiery steed,<br></span>
<span class="i4">With well-spur'd boots took down;<br></span>
<span class="i2">As men, with leathern buckets, quench<br></span>
<span class="i4">A fire in country town.                                        <span class="linenum">220</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His famous horse, that liv'd on oats,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Is sung on oaten quill;<br></span>
<span class="i2">By bards' immortal provender<br></span>
<span class="i4">The nag surviveth still.<br></span>
<span class="i2">This shelly brood on none but knaves                             <span class="linenum">225</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Employ'd their brisk artillery:<br></span>
<span class="i2">And flew as naturally at rogues,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As eggs at thief in pillory.<a id="FNanchor_446"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_446">[446]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Much sweat they spent in furious fight,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Much blood they did effund:                                    <span class="linenum">230</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Their whites they vented thro' the pores;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Their yolks thro' gaping wound:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then both were cleans'd from blood and dust<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_302">[Pg 302]</a></span>
<span class="i4">To make a heavenly sign;<br></span>
<span class="i2">The lads were, like their armour, scowr'd,                       <span class="linenum">235</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And then hung up to shine;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Such were the heavenly double-Dicks,<br></span>
<span class="i4">The sons of Jove and Tyndar:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But George he cut the dragon up,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As he had bin duck or windar.<a id="FNanchor_447"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_447">[447]</a> <span class="linenum">240</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Gorgon a twisted adder wore<br></span>
<span class="i4">For knot upon her shoulder:<br></span>
<span class="i2">She kemb'd her hissing periwig,                                  <span class="linenum">245</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And curling snakes did powder.<br></span>
<span class="i2">These snakes they made stiff changelings<br></span>
<span class="i4">Of all the folks they hist on;<br></span>
<span class="i2">They turned barbars into hones,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And masons into free-stone:                                    <span class="linenum">250</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Sworded magnetic Amazon<br></span>
<span class="i4">Her shield to load-stone changes;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then amorous sword by magic belt<br></span>
<span class="i4">Clung fast unto her haunches.<br></span>
<span class="i2">This shield long village did protect,                            <span class="linenum">255</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And kept the army from-town,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And chang'd the bullies into rocks,<br></span>
<span class="i4">That came t' invade Long-Compton.<a id="FNanchor_448"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_448">[448]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">She post-diluvian stores unmans,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And Pyrrha's work unravels;                                    <span class="linenum">260</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And stares Deucalion's hardy boys<br></span>
<span class="i4">Into their primitive pebbles.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Red noses she to rubies turns,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_303">[Pg 303]</a></span>
<span class="i4">And noddles into bricks:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But George made dragon laxative;                                 <span class="linenum">265</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And gave him a bloody flix.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
