<span class="i2">By boar-spear Meleager got,<br></span>
<span class="i4">An everlasting name,                                           <span class="linenum">270</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And out of haunch of basted swine,<br></span>
<span class="i4">He hew'd eternal fame.<br></span>
<span class="i2">This beast each hero's trouzers ript,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And rudely shew'd his bare-breech,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Prickt but the wem, and out there came                           <span class="linenum">275</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Heroic guts and garbadge.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Legs were secur'd by iron boots<br></span>
<span class="i4">No more, than peas by peascods:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Brass helmets, with inclosed sculls,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Wou'd crackle in's mouth like chestnuts.                       <span class="linenum">280</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His tawny hairs erected were<br></span>
<span class="i4">By rage, that was resistless;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And wrath, instead of cobler's wax,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Did stiffen his rising bristles.<br></span>
<span class="i2">His tusk lay'd dogs so dead asleep,                              <span class="linenum">285</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Nor horn, nor whip cou'd wake 'um:<br></span>
<span class="i2">It made them vent both their last blood,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And their last album-grecum.<br></span>
<span class="i2">But the knight gor'd him with his spear,<br></span>
<span class="i4">To make of him a tame one,                                     <span class="linenum">290</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And arrows thick, instead of cloves,<br></span>
<span class="i4">He stuck in monster's gammon.<br></span>
<span class="i2">For monumental pillar, that<br></span>
<span class="i4">His victory might be known,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He rais'd up, in cylindric form,                                 <span class="linenum">295</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">A collar of the brawn.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_304">[Pg 304]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">He sent his shade to shades below,<br></span>
<span class="i4">In Stygian mud to wallow:<br></span>
<span class="i2">And eke the stout St. George eftsoon,<br></span>
<span class="i4">He made the dragon follow.                                     <span class="linenum">300</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Achilles of old Chiron learnt<br></span>
<span class="i4">The great horse for to ride;<br></span>
<span class="i2">H' was taught by th' Centaur's rational part,                    <span class="linenum">305</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">The hinnible to bestride.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Bright silver feet, and shining face<br></span>
<span class="i4">Had that stout hero's mother;<br></span>
<span class="i2">As rapier's silver'd at one end,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And wounds you at the other.                                   <span class="linenum">310</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Her feet were bright, his feet were swift,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As hawk pursuing sparrow:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her's had the metal, his the speed<br></span>
<span class="i4">Of Braburn's<a id="FNanchor_449"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_449">[449]</a> silver arrow.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thetis to double pedagogue                                       <span class="linenum">315</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Commits her dearest boy;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who bred him from a slender twig<br></span>
<span class="i4">To be the scourge of Troy:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But ere he lash't the Trojans, h' was<br></span>
<span class="i4">In Stygian waters steept;                                      <span class="linenum">320</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">As birch is soaked first in piss,<br></span>
<span class="i4">When boys are to be whipt.<br></span>
<span class="i2">With skin exceeding hard, he rose<br></span>
<span class="i4">From lake, so black and muddy,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As lobsters from the ocean rise,                                 <span class="linenum">325</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">With shell about their body:<br></span>
<span class="i2">And, as from lobster's broken claw,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Pick out the fish you might:<br></span>
<span class="i2">So might you from one unshell'd heel<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_305">[Pg 305]</a></span>
<span class="i4">Dig pieces of the knight.                                      <span class="linenum">330</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His myrmidons robb'd Priam's barns<br></span>
<span class="i4">And hen-roosts, says the song;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Carried away both corn and eggs,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Like ants from whence they sprung.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Himself tore Hector's pantaloons,                                <span class="linenum">335</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And sent him down bare-breech'd<br></span>
<span class="i2">To pedant Radamanthus, in<br></span>
<span class="i4">A posture to be switch'd.<br></span>
<span class="i2">But George he made the dragon look,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As if he had been bewitch'd.                                   <span class="linenum">340</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Full fatal to the Romans was<br></span>
<span class="i4">The Carthaginian Hanni-<br></span>
<span class="i2">bal; him I mean, who gave them such                              <span class="linenum">345</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">A devilish thump at Cannæ:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Moors thick, as goats on Penmenmure,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Stood on the Alpes's front:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Their one-eyed guide,<a id="FNanchor_450"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_450">[450]</a> like blinking mole,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Bor'd thro' the hindring mount:                                <span class="linenum">350</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who, baffled by the massy rock,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Took vinegar for relief;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Like plowmen, when they hew their way<br></span>
<span class="i4">Thro' stubborn rump of beef.<br></span>
<span class="i2">As dancing louts from humid toes                                 <span class="linenum">355</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">Cast atoms of ill favour<br></span>
<span class="i2">To blinking Hyatt,<a id="FNanchor_451"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_451">[451]</a> when on vile crowd<br></span>
<span class="i4">He merriment does endeavour,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And saws from suffering timber out<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_306">[Pg 306]</a></span>
<span class="i4">Some wretched tune to quiver:                                  <span class="linenum">360</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">So Romans slunk and squeak'd at sight<br></span>
<span class="i4">Of Affrican carnivor.<br></span>
<span class="i2">The tawny surface of his phiz<br></span>
<span class="i4">Did serve instead of vizzard:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But George he made the dragon have                               <span class="linenum">365</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">A grumbling in his gizzard.<br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">The valour of Domitian,<br></span>
<span class="i4">It must not be forgotten;                                      <span class="linenum">370</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who from the jaws of worm-blowing flies,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Protected veal and mutton.<br></span>
<span class="i2">A squadron of flies errant,<br></span>
<span class="i4">Against the foe appears;<br></span>
<span class="i2">With regiments of buzzing knights,                               <span class="linenum">375</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">And swarms of volunteers:<br></span>
<span class="i2">The warlike wasp encourag'd 'em,<br></span>
<span class="i4">With animating hum;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And the loud brazen hornet next,<br></span>
<span class="i4">He was their kettle-drum:                                      <span class="linenum">380</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The Spanish don Cantharido<br></span>
<span class="i4">Did him most sorely pester,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And rais'd on skin of vent'rous knight<br></span>
<span class="i4">Full many a plaguy blister.<br></span>
<span class="i2">A bee whipt thro' his button hole,                               <span class="linenum">385</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">As thro' key hole a witch,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And stabb'd him with her little tuck<br></span>
<span class="i4">Drawn out of scabbard breech:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But the undaunted knight lifts up<br></span>
<span class="i4">An arm both big and brawny,                                    <span class="linenum">390</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And slasht her so, that here lay head,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And there lay bag and honey:<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_307">[Pg 307]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i2">Then 'mongst the rout he flew as swift,<br></span>
<span class="i4">As weapon made by Cyclops,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And bravely quell'd seditious buz,                               <span class="linenum">395</span><br></span>
<span class="i4">By dint of massy fly-flops.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Surviving flies do curses breathe,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And maggots too at Cæsar:<br></span>
<span class="i2">But George he shav'd the dragon's beard,<br></span>
<span class="i4">And Askelon<a id="FNanchor_452"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_452">[452]</a> was his razor.                                <span class="linenum">400</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">St. George he was for England; St. Dennis was for France;<br></span>
<span class="i4">Sing, <i>Honi soit qui mal y pense</i>.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 100px;">
<img alt="" height="36" src="images/i307.png" width="100" id="img_images_i307.png">
</div>
<p><i>John Grubb</i>, the facetious writer of the foregoing song, makes a
distinguished figure among the Oxford wits so humorously enumerated
in the following distich:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Alma novem genuit célebres Rhedycina poetas<br></span>
<span class="i0">Bub, Stubb, Grubb, Crabb, Trap, Young, Carey, Tickel, Evans.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>These were Bub Dodington (the late lord Melcombe), Dr. Stubbes,
our poet <i>Grubb</i>, Mr. Crabb, Dr. Trapp the poetry-professor, Dr.
Edw. Young, the author of Night-Thoughts, Walter Carey, Thomas
Tickel, Esq., and Dr. Evans the epigrammatist.</p>
<p>As for our poet <i>Grubb</i>, all that we can learn further of him is
contained in a few extracts from the University Register, and from
his epitaph. It appears from the former that he was matriculated
in 1667, being the son of John Grubb, "<i>de Acton Burnel in</i>
<i>comitatu Salop. pauperis</i>." He took his degree of Bachelor of Arts,
June 28, 1671: and became Master of Arts, June 28, 1675. He
was appointed Head Master of the Grammar School at Christ
Church: and afterwards chosen into the same employment at
Gloucester, where he died in 1697, as appears from his monument
in the church of St. Mary de Crypt in Gloucester, which is inscribed
with the following epitaph:—</p>
<p class="center">H. S. E.<br>
<i>Johannes Grubb, A. M.</i><br>
Natus apud Acton Burnel in agro Salopiensi<br>
Anno Dom. 1645.<br>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_308">[Pg 308]</a></span>Cujus variam in linguis notitiam,<br>
et felicem erudiendis pueris industriam,<br>
gratâ adhuc memoriâ testatur Oxonium:<br>
Ibi enim Ædi Christi initiatus,<br>
artes excoluit;<br>
Pueros ad easdem mox excolendas<br>
accuratè formavit:<br>
Huc demum<br>
unanimi omnium consensu accitus,<br>
eandem suscepit provinciam,<br>
quam feliciter adeo absolvit,<br>
ut nihil optandum sit<br>
nisi ut diutius nobis interfuisset:<br>
Fuit enim<br>
propter festivam ingenij suavitatem,<br>
simplicem morum candorem, et<br>
præcipuam erga cognatos benevolentiam,<br>
omnibus desideratissimus.<br>
Obiit 2do die Aprilis, Anno Dni. 1697.<br>
Ætatis suæ 51.
</p>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_437"></a><a href="#FNanchor_437" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[437]</span></a> To this circumstance it is owing that the editor has never met
with two copies, in which the stanzas are arranged alike, he has
therefore thrown them into what appeared the most natural order.
The verses are properly long Alexandrines, but the narrowness of
the page made it necessary to subdivide them: they are here
printed with many improvements.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_438"></a><a href="#FNanchor_438" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[438]</span></a> [blow.]</p></div>

Oxford.</p></div>

and tripe.</p></div>

<span class="i0">Not carted bawd, or Dan de Foe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In wooden ruff ere bluster'd so.<br></span>
</div></div>

<i>Oxfordshire</i>.</p></div>

<hr class="chap">
<h3>XVI.<br>

MARGARET'S GHOST.</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i308.png" id="img_images_i308.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> ballad, which appeared in some of the public newspapers
in or before the year 1724, came from the pen
of David Mallet, Esq. who in the edition of his poems,
3 vols. 1759, informs us that the plan was suggested
by the four verses quoted above in page <a href="#Page_124" class="pginternal">124</a>, which he supposed
to be the beginning of some ballad now lost.</p>
<p>"These lines, says he, naked of ornament and simple, as they
are, struck my fancy; and bringing fresh into my mind an unhappy
adventure much talked of formerly, gave birth to the following
poem, which was written many years ago."</p>
<p>The two introductory lines (and one or two others elsewhere)
had originally more of the ballad simplicity, viz.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"When all was wrapt in dark midnight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all were fast asleep," &amp;c.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>In a late publication, intitled, <i>The Friends</i>, &amp;c. Lond. 1773,
2 vols. 12mo. (in the first volume, p. 71) is inserted a copy of<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_309">[Pg 309]</a></span>
the foregoing ballad, with very great variations, which the editor
of that work contends was the original; and that Mallet adopted
it for his own and altered it, as here given.—But the superior
beauty and simplicity of the present copy, gives it so much more
the air of an original, that it will rather be believed that some
transcriber altered it from Mallet's, and adapted the lines to his
own taste; than which nothing is more common in popular songs
and ballads.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This ballad, more generally known as <i>William and Margaret</i>,
is supposed to have been printed for the first time in Aaron Hill's
<i>Plain Dealer</i> (No. 36, July 24, 1724), when the author was a very
young man. Hill introduced it to the reader as the work of an
old poet, and wrote, "I am sorry I am not able to acquaint my
readers with his name to whom we owe this melancholy piece of
finished poetry under the humble title of a ballad." In the following
month the editor announced that "he had discovered the
author to be still alive." The verses were probably written in
1723, in the August of which year Mallet left Scotland, for Allan
Ramsay, in his <i>Stanzas to Mr. David Mallock on his departure from</i>
<i>Scotland</i>, alludes to them:—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But he that could, in tender strains,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Raise Margaret's plaining shade,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And paints distress that chills the veins,<br></span>
<span class="i2">While William's crimes are red."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>The ballad at once became popular, and was printed in several
collections, undergoing many alterations for the worse by the
way. Sundry attempts were made to rob Mallet of the credit of
his song. Besides the one mentioned above by Percy, Captain
Thompson, the editor of Andrew Marvell's Works, claimed it for
Marvell, but this claim was even more ridiculous than those he
set up against Addison and Watts. Although Mallet doubtless
knew the ballads <i>Fair Margaret and Sweet William</i> (book ii.
No. 4) and <i>Sweet William's Ghost</i> (No. 6), he is said to have
founded his own upon a true story which came under his observation.
A daughter of Professor James Gregory of St. Andrews,
and afterwards of Edinburgh, was seduced by a son of Sir William
Sharp of Strathyrum, who had promised to marry her, but heartlessly
deserted her.</p>
<p>The ballad has been extravagantly praised: Ritson observes,
"It may be questioned whether any English writer has produced
so fine a ballad as <i>William and Margaret</i>." Percy describes it as
one of the most beautiful ballads in our own or any other language;
and Allan Ramsay writes, "I know not where to seek a finer
mixture of pathos and terror in the whole range of Gothic romance."
Scott, on the other hand, was of opinion that "The<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_310">[Pg 310]</a></span>
ballad, though the best of Mallet's writing, is certainly inferior to
the original, which I presume to be the very fine and terrific old
Scottish tale, beginning</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'There came a ghost to Margaret's door.'"<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>The extreme popularity of the poem is seen by the various parodies,
one of which, <i>Watty and Madge</i>, is printed in Ramsay's <i>Tea</i>
<i>Table Miscellany</i> (vol. iii.). It commences—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"'Twas at the shining mid-day hour,"<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>and each succeeding verse is parodied in the same manner. Vincent
Browne imitated the original in Latin verse, and a German
version was published as <i>Wilhelm und Gretchen</i>.</p>
<p>Mallet was a native of Crieff in Perthshire, and is believed to
have been born in the year 1702. He was sometime tutor to the
Montrose family, through whose influence he was introduced into
public life. He changed his name from Malloch to Mallet when
he settled in London, and in 1742 he was appointed Under Secretary
to the Prince of Wales. He died on the 21st of April, 1765.
Mallet is a writer little cared for now, but he can hardly be said
to be neglected, for in 1857 Mr. Frederick Dinsdale published an
illustrated edition of his Ballads and Songs, chiefly made up of
copious notes on <i>William and Margaret</i> and <i>Edwin and Emma</i>.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i310.png" id="img_images_i310.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'Twas at the silent solemn hour,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When night and morning meet;<br></span>
<span class="i0">In glided Margaret's grimly ghost,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And stood at William's feet.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her face was like an April morn,                                     <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Clad in a wintry cloud:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And clay-cold was her lily hand,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That held her sable shrowd.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So shall the fairest face appear,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When youth and years are flown:                                   <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Such is the robe that kings must wear,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When death has reft their crown.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_311">[Pg 311]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her bloom was like the springing flower,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That sips the silver dew;<br></span>
<span class="i0">The rose was budded in her cheek,                                   <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Just opening to the view.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But love had, like the canker worm,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Consum'd her early prime:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The rose grew pale, and left her cheek;<br></span>
<span class="i2">She dy'd before her time.                                         <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Awake!" she cry'd, "thy true love calls,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Come from her midnight grave;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now let thy pity hear the maid,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy love refus'd to save.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"This is the dark and dreary hour,                                  <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">When injur'd ghosts complain;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Now yawning graves give up their dead,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To haunt the faithless swain.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Bethink thee, William, of thy fault,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thy pledge, and broken oath:                                      <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And give me back my maiden vow,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And give me back my troth.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Why did you promise love to me,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And not that promise keep?<br></span>
<span class="i0">Why did you swear mine eyes were bright,                            <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet leave those eyes to weep?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"How could you say my face was fair,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And yet that face forsake?<br></span>
<span class="i0">How could you win my virgin heart,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Yet leave that heart to break?                                    <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Why did you say my lip was sweet,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And made the scarlet pale?<br></span>
<span class="i0">And why did I, young witless maid,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Believe the flattering tale?<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_312">[Pg 312]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"That face, alas! no more is fair;                                  <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">These lips no longer red:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Dark are my eyes, now clos'd in death,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And every charm is fled.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"The hungry worm my sister is;<br></span>
<span class="i2">This winding-sheet I wear:                                        <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And cold and weary lasts our night,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Till that last morn appear.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"But hark! the cock has warn'd me hence!<br></span>
<span class="i2">A long and last adieu!<br></span>
<span class="i0">Come see, false man, how low she lies,                              <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who dy'd for love of you."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The lark sung loud; the morning smil'd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With beams of rosy red:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Pale William shook in ev'ry limb,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And raving left his bed.                                          <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He hyed him to the fatal place,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Where Margaret's body lay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And stretch'd him on the grass-green turf,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That wrapt her breathless clay:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And thrice he call'd on Margaret's name,                            <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And thrice he wept full sore:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then laid his cheek to her cold grave,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And word spake never more.<br></span>
</div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XVII.<br>

LUCY AND COLIN</h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i312.png" id="img_images_i312.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capm"><span class="smcap">Was</span> written by Thomas Tickell, Esq. the celebrated friend
of Mr. Addison, and editor of his works. He was son
of a clergyman in the north of England, had his education
at Queen's college, Oxon, was under secretary to
Mr. Addison and Mr. Craggs, when successively secretaries of<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_313">[Pg 313]</a></span>
state; and was lastly (in June, 1724) appointed secretary to the
Lords Justices in Ireland, which place he held till his death in
1740.<a id="FNanchor_453"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_453">[453]</a> He acquired Mr. Addison's patronage by a poem in praise
of the opera of <i>Rosamond</i>, written while he was at the University.</p>
<p>It is a tradition in Ireland, that the song was written at Castletown,
in the county of Kildare, at the request of the then Mrs.
Conolly—probably on some event recent in that neighbourhood.</p>
<p>[Gray called <i>Lucy and Colin</i> "the prettiest" ballad in the world,
although he was not partial to Tickell's other poems.</p>
<p>The fine old melody given by Dr. Rimbault for this ballad is
taken from "<i>The Merry Musician; or a Cure for the Spleen</i>; being
a collection of the most diverting Songs and pleasant Ballads
set to Musick," 1716.]</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i313.png" id="img_images_i313.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Of Leinster, fam'd for maidens fair,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Bright Lucy was the grace;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor e'er did Liffy's limpid stream<br></span>
<span class="i2">Reflect so fair a face.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Till luckless love, and pining care                                  <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Impair'd her rosy hue,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Her coral lip, and damask cheek,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And eyes of glossy blue.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Oh! have you seen a lily pale,<br></span>
<span class="i2">When beating rains descend?                                       <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">So droop'd the slow-consuming maid;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Her life now near its end.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">By Lucy warn'd, of flattering swains<br></span>
<span class="i2">Take heed, ye easy fair:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of vengeance due to broken vows,                                    <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Ye perjured swains, beware.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Three times, all in the dead of night,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A bell was heard to ring;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And at her window, shrieking thrice,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The raven flap'd his wing.                                        <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_314">[Pg 314]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Too well the love-lorn maiden knew<br></span>
<span class="i2">That solemn boding sound;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus, in dying words, bespoke<br></span>
<span class="i2">The virgins weeping round.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"I hear a voice, you cannot hear,                                   <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Which says I must not stay:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I see a hand, you cannot see,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Which beckons me away.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"By a false heart, and broken vows,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In early youth I die.                                             <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Am I to blame, because his bride<br></span>
<span class="i2">Is thrice as rich as I?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Ah Colin! give not her thy vows;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Vows due to me alone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor thou, fond maid, receive his kiss,                              <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Nor think him all thy own.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"To-morrow in the church to wed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Impatient, both prepare;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But know, fond maid, and know, false man,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That Lucy will be there,                                          <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Then, bear my corse; ye comrades, bear,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The bridegroom blithe to meet;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He in his wedding-trim so gay,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I in my winding-sheet."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She spoke, she dy'd;—her corse was borne,                          <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">The bridegroom blithe to meet;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He in his wedding-trim so gay,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She in her winding-sheet.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then what were perjur'd Colin's thoughts?<br></span>
<span class="i2">How were those nuptials kept?                                     <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">The bride-men flock'd round Lucy dead,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all the village wept.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_315">[Pg 315]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Confusion, shame, remorse, despair<br></span>
<span class="i2">At once his bosom swell:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The damps of death bedew'd his brow,                                <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He shook, he groan'd, he fell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">From the vain bride (ah bride no more!)<br></span>
<span class="i2">The varying crimson fled,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When, stretch'd before her rival's corse,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She saw her husband dead.                                         <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then to his Lucy's new-made grave,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Convey'd by trembling swains,<br></span>
<span class="i0">One mould with her, beneath one sod,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For ever now remains.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Oft at their grave the constant hind                                <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And plighted maid are seen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">With garlands gay, and true-love knots<br></span>
<span class="i2">They deck the sacred green.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But, swain forsworn, whoe'er thou art,<br></span>
<span class="i2">This hallow'd spot forbear;                                       <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Remember Colin's dreadful fate,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And fear to meet him there.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_453"></a><a href="#FNanchor_453" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[453]</span></a> Born 1686.</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XVIII.<br>

THE BOY AND THE MANTLE,</h3>
<p class="center">AS REVISED AND ALTERED BY A MODERN HAND.</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i315.png" id="img_images_i315.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capm"><span class="smcap">Mr</span>. Warton, in his ingenious <i>Observations on Spenser</i>,
has given his opinion, that the fiction of the <i>Boy and</i>
<i>the Mantle</i> is taken from an old French piece intitled
<i>Le court mantel</i>, quoted by M. de St. Palaye in his
curious <i>Mémoires sur l'ancienne Chevalerie</i>, Paris, 1759, 2 tom.
12mo., who tells us the story resembles that of Ariosto's inchanted
cup. 'Tis possible our English poet may have taken the hint of
this subject from that old French romance, but he does not appear
to have copied it in the manner of execution; to which (if one<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_316">[Pg 316]</a></span>
may judge from the specimen given in the <i>Mémoires</i>) that of the
ballad does not bear the least resemblance. After all, 'tis most
likely that all the old stories concerning K. Arthur are originally
of British growth, and that what the French and other southern
nations have of this kind, were at first exported from this island.
See <i>Mémoires de l'Acad. des Inscrip.</i> tom. xx. p. 352.</p>
<p>(Since this volume was printed off, the <i>Fabliaux ou Contes</i>, 1781,
5 tom. 12mo., of <i>M. le Grand</i>, have come to hand: and in tom. i.
p. 54, he hath printed a modern version of the old tale <i>Le Court</i>
<i>Mantel</i>, under a new title <i>Le Manteau maltaillé</i>; which contains the
story of this ballad much enlarged, so far as regards the <i>Mantle</i>;
but without any mention of the <i>Knife</i>, or the <i>Horn</i>.)</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[See book i. No. 1, for the original of this ballad.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i316.png" id="img_images_i316.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In Carleile dwelt king Arthur,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A prince of passing might;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And there maintain'd his table round,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Beset with many a knight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And there he kept his Christmas                                      <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With mirth and princely cheare,<br></span>
<span class="i0">When, lo! a straunge and cunning boy<br></span>
<span class="i2">Before him did appeare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A kirtle and a mantle<br></span>
<span class="i2">This boy had him upon,                                            <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">With brooches, rings, and owches<a id="FNanchor_454"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_454">[454]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Full daintily bedone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He had a sarke<a id="FNanchor_455"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_455">[455]</a> of silk<br></span>
<span class="i2">About his middle meet;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus, with seemly curtesy,                                      <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He did king Arthur greet.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_317">[Pg 317]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"God speed thee, brave king Arthur,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thus feasting in thy bowre.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And Guenever thy goodly queen,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That fair and peerlesse flowre.                                   <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Ye gallant lords, and lordings,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I wish you all take heed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lest, what ye deem a blooming rose<br></span>
<span class="i2">Should prove a cankred weed."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then straitway from his bosome                                      <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">A little wand he drew;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And with it eke a mantle<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of wondrous shepe, and hew.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Now have thou here, king Arthur,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Have this here of mee,                                            <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And give unto thy comely queen,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All-shapen as you see.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"No wife it shall become,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That once hath been to blame."<br></span>
<span class="i0">Then every knight in Arthur's court                                 <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Slye glaunced at his dame.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And first came lady Guenever,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The mantle she must trye.<br></span>
<span class="i0">This dame, she was new-fangled,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And of a roving eye.                                              <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When she had tane the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And all was with it cladde,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From top to toe it shiver'd down,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As tho' with sheers beshradde.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">One while it was too long,                                          <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Another while too short,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wrinkled on her shoulders<br></span>
<span class="i2">In most unseemly sort.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_318">[Pg 318]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Now green, now red it seemed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Then all of sable hue.                                            <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"Beshrew me, quoth king Arthur,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I think thou beest not true."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Down she threw the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Ne longer would not stay;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But storming like a fury,                                           <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">To her chamber flung away.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She curst the whoreson weaver,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That had the mantle wrought:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And doubly curst the froward impe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who thither had it brought.                                       <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"I had rather live in desarts<br></span>
<span class="i2">Beneath the green-wood tree:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Than here, base king, among thy groomes,<br></span>
<span class="i2">The sport of them and thee."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Kay call'd forth his lady,                                      <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And bade her to come near:<br></span>
<span class="i0">"Yet dame, if thou be guilty,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I pray thee now forbear."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">This lady, pertly gigling,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With forward step came on,                                        <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And boldly to the little boy<br></span>
<span class="i2">With fearless face is gone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When she had tane the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With purpose for to wear:<br></span>
<span class="i0">It shrunk up to her shoulder,                                       <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And left her b**side bare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then every merry knight,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That was in Arthur's court,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Gib'd, and laught, and flouted,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To see that pleasant sport.                                       <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_319">[Pg 319]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Down she threw the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i2">No longer bold or gay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But with a face all pale and wan,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To her chamber slunk away.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then forth came an old knight,                                      <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">A pattering o'er his creed;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And proffer'd to the little boy<br></span>
<span class="i2">Five nobles to his meed;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"And all the time of Christmass<br></span>
<span class="i2">Plumb-porridge shall be thine,                                    <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou wilt let my lady fair<br></span>
<span class="i2">Within the mantle shine."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">A saint his lady seemed,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With step demure, and slow,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And gravely to the mantle                                           <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With mincing pace doth goe,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When she the same had taken,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That was so fine and thin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">It shrivell'd all about her,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And show'd her dainty skin.                                      <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Ah! little did <span class="smcap">HER</span> mincing,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or <span class="smcap">HIS</span> long prayers bestead;<br></span>
<span class="i0">She had no more hung on her,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Than a tassel and a thread.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Down she threwe the mantle,                                        <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">With terror and dismay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And, with a face of scarlet,<br></span>
<span class="i2">To her chamber hyed away.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Cradock call'd his lady,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And bade her to come neare;                                      <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">"Come win this mantle, lady,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And do me credit here.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_320">[Pg 320]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Come win this mantle, lady,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For now it shall be thine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">If thou hast never done amiss,                                     <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Sith first I made thee mine."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The lady gently blushing,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With modest grace came on,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And now to trye this wondrous charm<br></span>
<span class="i2">Courageously is gone.                                            <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When she had tane the mantle,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And put it on her backe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">About the hem it seemed<br></span>
<span class="i2">To wrinkle and to cracke.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Lye still, shee cried, O mantle!                                  <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And shame me not for nought,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I'll freely own whate'er amiss,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Or blameful I have wrought.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Once I kist Sir Cradocke<br></span>
<span class="i2">Beneathe the green wood tree:                                    <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Once I kist Sir Cradocke's mouth<br></span>
<span class="i2">Before he married me."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When thus she had her shriven,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And her worst fault had told,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The mantle soon became her                                         <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Right comely as it shold.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Most rich and fair of colour,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Like gold it glittering shone:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And much the knights in Arthur's court<br></span>
<span class="i2">Admir'd her every one.                                           <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then towards king Arthur's table<br></span>
<span class="i2">The boy he turn'd his eye:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Where stood a boar's-head garnished<br></span>
<span class="i2">With bayes and rosemarye.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_321">[Pg 321]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When thrice he o'er the boar's head                                <span class="linenum">145</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His little wand had drawne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth he, "There's never a cuckold's knife,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Can carve this head of brawne."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then some their whittles rubbed<br></span>
<span class="i2">On whetstone, and on hone:                                       <span class="linenum">150</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Some threwe them under the table,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And swore that they had none.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Cradock had a little knife<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of steel and iron made;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And in an instant thro' the skull                                  <span class="linenum">155</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">He thrust the shining blade.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He thrust the shining blade<br></span>
<span class="i2">Full easily and fast:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And every knight in Arthur's court<br></span>
<span class="i2">A morsel had to taste.                                           <span class="linenum">160</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The boy brought forth a horne,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All golden was the rim:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Said he, "No cuckolde ever can<br></span>
<span class="i2">Set mouth unto the brim.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"No cuckold can this little horne                                  <span class="linenum">165</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Lift fairly to his head;<br></span>
<span class="i0">But or on this, or that side,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He shall the liquor shed."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Some shed it on their shoulder,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Some shed it on their thigh;                                     <span class="linenum">170</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And hee that could not hit his mouth,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was sure to hit his eye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus he, that was a cuckold,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Was known of every man:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Cradock lifted easily,                                         <span class="linenum">175</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And wan the golden can.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_322">[Pg 322]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thus boar's head, horn and mantle<br></span>
<span class="i2">Were this fair couple's meed:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And all such constant lovers,<br></span>
<span class="i2">God send them well to speed.                                     <span class="linenum">180</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then down in rage came Guenever,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And thus could spightful say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">"Sir Cradock's wife most wrongfully<br></span>
<span class="i2">Hath borne the prize away.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"See yonder shameless woman,                                       <span class="linenum">185</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">That makes herselfe so clean:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet from her pillow taken<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thrice five gallants have been.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Priests, clarkes, and wedded men<br></span>
<span class="i2">Have her lewd pillow prest:                                      <span class="linenum">190</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Yet she the wondrous prize forsooth<br></span>
<span class="i2">Must beare from all the rest."<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then bespake the little boy,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who had the same in hold:<br></span>
<span class="i0">"Chastize thy wife, king Arthur,                                   <span class="linenum">195</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of speech she is too bold:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Of speech she is too bold,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of carriage all too free;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sir king, she hath within thy hall<br></span>
<span class="i2">A cuckold made of thee.                                          <span class="linenum">200</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"All frolick light and wanton<br></span>
<span class="i2">She hath her carriage borne:<br></span>
<span class="i0">And given thee for a kingly crown<br></span>
<span class="i2">To wear a cuckold's horne."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">⁂</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>⁂ The Rev. Evan Evans, editor of the specimens of <i>Welsh</i>
<i>Poetry</i>, 4to. affirmed that the <i>Boy and the Mantle</i> is taken from
what is related in some of the old Welsh MSS. of Tegan Earfron,
one of King Arthur's mistresses. She is said to have possessed a
mantle that would not fit any immodest or incontinent woman;<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_323">[Pg 323]</a></span>
this, (which, the old writers say, was reckoned among the curiosities
of Britain) is frequently alluded to by the old Welsh Bards.</p>
<p><i>Carleile</i>, so often mentioned in the ballads of K. Arthur, the
editor once thought might probably be a corruption of <i>Caer-leon</i>,
an ancient British city on the river Uske, in Monmouthshire, which
was one of the places of K. Arthur's chief residence; but he is
now convinced, that it is no other than <i>Carlisle</i>, in Cumberland;
the old English minstrels, being most of them northern men,
naturally represented the hero of romance as residing in the north:
And many of the places mentioned in the old ballads are still to
be found there: As <i>Tearne-Wadling</i>, &amp;c.</p>
<p>Near Penrith is still seen a large circle, surrounded by a mound
of earth, which retains the name of Arthur's Round Table.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<p>[For a full statement of the claims of the "North" to be considered
as the home of King Arthur, see J. S. Stuart Glennie's
Essay on <i>Arthurian Localities</i>, in the edition of the Prose Romance
of <i>Merlin</i>, published by the Early English Text Society.]</p></div>
<div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_454"></a><a href="#FNanchor_454" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[454]</span></a> [bosses or buttons of gold.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_455"></a><a href="#FNanchor_455" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[455]</span></a> [shirt.]</p></div></div>
<hr class="chap">
<h3>XIX.<br>

THE ANCIENT FRAGMENT OF THE
MARRIAGE OF SIR GAWAINE.<a id="FNanchor_456"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_456">[456]</a></h3>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i323.png" id="img_images_i323.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> second poem in this volume, intitled <i>The Marriage</i>
<i>of Sir Gawaine</i>, having been offered to the reader with
large conjectural supplements and corrections, the old
fragment itself is here literally and exactly printed from
the editor's folio MS. with all its defects, inaccuracies, and errata;
that such austere antiquaries, as complain that the ancient copies
have not been always rigidly adhered to, may see how unfit for
publication many of the pieces would have been, if all the blunders,
corruptions, and nonsense of illiterate reciters and transcribers
had been superstitiously retained, without some attempt to correct
and emend them.</p>
<p>This ballad had most unfortunately suffered by having half of
every leaf in this part of the MS. torn away; and, as about nine
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_324">[Pg 324]</a></span>stanzas generally occur in the half page now remaining, it is concluded,
that the other half contained nearly the same number of
stanzas.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[The following poem is printed in Hales' and Furnivall's edition
of the MS., vol. i. p. 105.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i324.png" id="img_images_i324.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Kinge Arthur liues in merry Carleile,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; seemely is to see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; there he hath w<sup>th</sup> him Queene Genev<sup>r</sup>,<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> bride soe bright of blee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And there he hath w<sup>th</sup> him Queene Genever,<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> bride soe bright in bower,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; all his barons about him stoode<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> were both stiffe &amp; stowre.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The K. kept a royall Christmasse<br></span>
<span class="i0">of mirth &amp; great honor,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; when....<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center">[<i>About Nine Stanzas wanting.</i>]
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And bring me word what thing it is<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> a woman most desire.<br></span>
<span class="i0">this shalbe thy ransome, Arthur, he sayes<br></span>
<span class="i0">for Ile haue noe other hier.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">K. Arthur then held vp his hand<br></span>
<span class="i0">according thene as was the law;<br></span>
<span class="i0">he tooke his leaue of the baron there,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; homward can he draw.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he came to Merry Carlile,<br></span>
<span class="i0">to his chamber he is gone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; ther came to him his Cozen S<sup>r</sup> Gawaine<br></span>
<span class="i0">as he did make his mone.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And there came to him his Cozen S<sup>r</sup> Gawaine<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> was a curteous knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">why sigh you soe sore vnckle Arthur, he said<br></span>
<span class="i0">or who hath done thee vnright.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O peace, o peace, thou gentle Gawaine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> faire may thee beffall,<br></span>
<span class="i0">for if thou knew my sighing soe deepe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">thou wold not meruaile att all;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">ffor when I came to tearne wadling,<br></span>
<span class="i0">a bold barron there I fand,<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_325">[Pg 325]</a></span>
<span class="i0">w<sup>th</sup> a great club vpon his backe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">standing stiffe &amp; strong;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he asked me wether I wold fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">or from him I shold be gone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">o[r] else I must him a ransome pay<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; soe dep't him from.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To fight w<sup>th</sup> him I saw noe cause,<br></span>
<span class="i0">me thought it was not meet,<br></span>
<span class="i0">ffor he was stiffe &amp; strong w<sup>th</sup> all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">his strokes were nothing sweete.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Therfor this is my ransome, Gawaine<br></span>
<span class="i0">I ought to him to pay<br></span>
<span class="i0">I must come againe, as I am sworne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">vpon the Newyeers day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And I must bring him word what thing it is<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center">[<i>About Nine Stanzas wanting.</i>]
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then king Arthur drest him for to ryde<br></span>
<span class="i0">in one soe rich array<br></span>
<span class="i0">toward the foresaid Tearne wadling,<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> he might keepe his day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And as he rode over a more,<br></span>
<span class="i0">hee see a lady where shee sate<br></span>
<span class="i0">betwixt an oke &amp; a greene hollen<a id="FNanchor_457"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_457">[457]</a>:<br></span>
<span class="i0">she was cladd in red scarlett.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then there as shold have stood her mouth,<br></span>
<span class="i0">then there was sett her eye<br></span>
<span class="i0">the other was in her forhead fast<br></span>
<span class="i0">the way that she might see.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Her nose was crooked &amp; turnd outward,<br></span>
<span class="i0">her mouth stood foule a wry;<br></span>
<span class="i0">a worse formed lady then shee was,<br></span>
<span class="i0">neuer man saw w<sup>th</sup> his eye.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To halch<a id="FNanchor_458"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_458">[458]</a> vpon him, k. Arthur<br></span>
<span class="i0">this lady was full faine<br></span>
<span class="i0">but k. Arthur had forgott his lesson<br></span>
<span class="i0">what he shold say againe<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_326">[Pg 326]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What knight art thou, the lady sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i0">that wilt not speake to me?<br></span>
<span class="i0">of me be thou nothing dismayd<br></span>
<span class="i0">tho I be vgly to see;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">for I haue halched you curteouslye,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; you will not me againe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">yett I may happen S<sup>r</sup> knight, shee said<br></span>
<span class="i0">to ease thee of thy paine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Giue thou ease me, lady, he said<br></span>
<span class="i0">or helpe me any thing,<br></span>
<span class="i0">thou shalt haue gentle Gawaine, my cozen<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; marry him w<sup>th</sup> a ring.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Why, if I helpe thee not, thou noble k. Arthur<br></span>
<span class="i0">of thy owne hearts desiringe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">of gentle Gawaine....<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center">[<i>About Nine Stanzas wanting.</i>]
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he came to the tearne wadling<br></span>
<span class="i0">the baron there cold he fimde<a id="FNanchor_459"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_459">[459]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">w<sup>th</sup> a great weapon on his backe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">standing stiffe &amp; stronge<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And then he tooke k. Arthur's letters in his hands<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; away he cold them fling,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; then he puld out a good browne sword,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; cryd himselfe a k.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And he sayd, I haue thee &amp; thy land, Arthur<br></span>
<span class="i0">to doe as it pleaseth me,<br></span>
<span class="i0">for this is not thy ransome sure,<br></span>
<span class="i0">therfore yeeld thee to mee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And then bespoke him noble Arthur,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; bad him hold his hands,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; give me leave to speake my mind<br></span>
<span class="i0">in defence of all my land.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He said as I came over a More,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I see a lady where shee sate<br></span>
<span class="i0">betweene an oke &amp; a green hollen;<br></span>
<span class="i0">shee was clad in red scarlett;<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_327">[Pg 327]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And she says a woman will haue her will,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; this is all her cheefe desire:<br></span>
<span class="i0">doe me right as thou art a baron of sckill,<br></span>
<span class="i0">this is thy ransome &amp; and all thy hyer.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">He sayes an early vengeance light on her,<br></span>
<span class="i0">she walkes on yonder more;<br></span>
<span class="i0">it was my sister that told thee this<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; she is a misshappen hore.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">But heer Ile make mine avow<a id="FNanchor_460"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_460">[460]</a> to god<br></span>
<span class="i0">to do her an euill turne,<br></span>
<span class="i0">for an euer I may thate fowle theefe get,<br></span>
<span class="i0">in a fyer I will her burne.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center">[<i>About Nine Stanzas wanting.</i>]</p>
<hr class="tb">
<h4><span class="smcap">The 2d Part.</span>
</h4>
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i327.png" id="img_images_i327.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Lancelott &amp; S<sup>r</sup> Steven bold<br></span>
<span class="i0">they rode w<sup>th</sup> them that day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">and the formost of the company<br></span>
<span class="i0">there rode the steward Kay,<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Soe did S<sup>r</sup> Banier &amp; S<sup>r</sup> Bore<br></span>
<span class="i0">S<sup>r</sup> Garrett w<sup>th</sup> them soe gay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">soe did S<sup>r</sup> Tristeram y<sup>t</sup> gentle k<sup>t</sup>,<br></span>
<span class="i0">to the forrest fresh &amp; gay<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when he came to the greene forrest<br></span>
<span class="i0">vnderneath a greene holly tree<br></span>
<span class="i0">their sate that lady in red scarlet<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> vnseemly was to see.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">S<sup>r</sup> Kay beheld this Ladys face,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; looked vppon her smire<a id="FNanchor_461"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_461">[461]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">whosoeuer kisses this lady, he sayes<br></span>
<span class="i0">of his kisse he standes in feare.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sir Kay beheld the lady againe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; looked vpon her snout,<br></span>
<span class="i0">whosoeuer kisses this lady, he saies,<br></span>
<span class="i0">of his kisse he stands in doubt.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_328">[Pg 328]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Peace coz. Kay, then said S<sup>r</sup> Gawaine<br></span>
<span class="i0">amend thee of thy life;<br></span>
<span class="i0">for there is a knight amongst us all<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> must marry her to his wife.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What, wedd her to wiffe, then said S<sup>r</sup> Kay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">in the diuells name anon,<br></span>
<span class="i0">gett me a wiffe where ere I may,<br></span>
<span class="i0">for I had rather be slaine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then soome tooke vp their hawkes in hast<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; some tooke vp their hounds,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; some sware they wold not marry her<br></span>
<span class="i0">for Citty nor for towne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And then be spake him noble k. Arthur,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; sware there by this day,<br></span>
<span class="i0">for a litle foule sight and misliking<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center">[<i>About Nine Stanzas wanting.</i>]
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then shee said choose thee gentle Gawaine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">truth as I doe say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">wether thou wilt haue me in this liknesse<br></span>
<span class="i0">in the night or else in the day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And then bespake him Gentle Gawaine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">w<sup>th</sup> one soe mild of moode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">sayes, well I know what I wold say,<br></span>
<span class="i0">god grant it may be good.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">To haue thee fowle in the night<br></span>
<span class="i0">when I w<sup>th</sup> thee shold play;<br></span>
<span class="i0">yet I had rather, if I might<br></span>
<span class="i0">haue thee fowle in the day.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">What, when Lords goe w<sup>th</sup> ther seires,<a id="FNanchor_462"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_462">[462]</a> shee said<br></span>
<span class="i0">both to the Ale &amp; wine<br></span>
<span class="i0">alas then I must hyde my selfe,<br></span>
<span class="i0">I must not goe withinne.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And then bespake him gentle gawaine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">said, Lady thats but a skill;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And because thou art my owne lady,<br></span>
<span class="i0">thou shalt haue all thy will.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_329">[Pg 329]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then she said, blesed be thou gentle Gawain<br></span>
<span class="i0">this day y<sup>t</sup> I thee see,<br></span>
<span class="i0">for as thou see me att this time,<br></span>
<span class="i0">from hencforth I wilbe:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My father was an old knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; yett it chanced soe<br></span>
<span class="i0">that he marryed a younge lady<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> brought me to this woe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Shee witched me, being a faire young Lady,<br></span>
<span class="i0">to the greene forrest to dwell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; there I must walke in womans liknesse,<br></span>
<span class="i0">most like a feend of hell.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She witched my brother to a Carlist B....<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="center">[<i>About Nine Stanzas wanting</i>.]
</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">that looked soe foule &amp; that was wont<br></span>
<span class="i0">on the wild more to goe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Come kisse her, Brother Kay, then said S<sup>r</sup> Gawaine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; amend the of thy liffe;<br></span>
<span class="i0">I sweare this is the same lady<br></span>
<span class="i0">y<sup>t</sup> I marryed to my wiffe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">S<sup>r</sup> Kay kissed that lady bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">standing vpon his ffeete;<br></span>
<span class="i0">he swore, as he was trew knight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">the spice was neuer soe sweete.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Well, Coz. Gawaine, sayes S<sup>r</sup> Kay,<br></span>
<span class="i0">thy chance is fallen arright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">for thou hast gotten one of the fairest maids<br></span>
<span class="i0">I euer saw w<sup>th</sup> my sight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It is my fortune, said S<sup>r</sup> Gawaine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">for my Vnckle Arthurs sake<br></span>
<span class="i0">I am glad as grasse wold be of raine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">great Ioy that I may take.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">S<sup>r</sup> Gawaine tooke the lady by the one arme,<br></span>
<span class="i0">S<sup>r</sup> Kay tooke her by the tother,<br></span>
<span class="i0">they led her straight to k. Arthur<br></span>
<span class="i0">as they were brother &amp; brother.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_330">[Pg 330]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">K. Arthur welcomed them there all,<br></span>
<span class="i0">&amp; soe did lady Geneuer his queene,<br></span>
<span class="i0">w<sup>th</sup> all the knights of the round table<br></span>
<span class="i0">most seemly to be seene.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">K. Arthur beheld that lady faire<br></span>
<span class="i0">that was soe faire &amp; bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">he thanked christ in trinity<br></span>
<span class="i0">for S<sup>r</sup> Gawaine that gentle knight;<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Soe did the knights, both more and lesse,<br></span>
<span class="i0">reioyced all that day<br></span>
<span class="i0">for the good chance y<sup>t</sup> hapened was<br></span>
<span class="i0">to S<sup>r</sup> Gawaine &amp; his lady gay.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">Ffins.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_331">[Pg 331]</a></span></p><div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_457"></a><a href="#FNanchor_457" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[457]</span></a> [holly.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_458"></a><a href="#FNanchor_458" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[458]</span></a> [salute.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_459"></a><a href="#FNanchor_459" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[459]</span></a> Sic MS. = finde.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_460"></a><a href="#FNanchor_460" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[460]</span></a> [my vow.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_461"></a><a href="#FNanchor_461" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[461]</span></a> [qy. for swire = neck.]</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_462"></a><a href="#FNanchor_462" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[462]</span></a> Sic in MS. pro <i>feires</i>, i.e. Mates.</p></div></div>
<p class="center">THE END OF THE THIRD BOOK.
</p>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 600px;">
<img alt="" height="96" src="images/i331.png" width="600" id="img_images_i331.png">
</div>
<h2><a id="APPENDIX_I">APPENDIX I.</a><br>

THE WANTON WIFE OF BATH.</h2>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 100px;">
<img alt="" height="35" src="images/i331a.png" width="100" id="img_images_i331a.png">
</div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_332">[Pg 332]</a><br><a id="Page_333">[Pg 333]</a></span></p>
<div class="figcenter" style="width: 600px;">
<img alt="" height="104" src="images/i333.png" width="600" id="img_images_i333.png">
</div>
<p class="ph2">APPENDIX I.</p>
<p class="ph2"><a id="THE_WANTON_WIFE_OF_BATH">THE WANTON WIFE OF BATH.</a></p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i333f.png" id="img_images_i333f.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">From</span> an ancient copy in black-print, in the Pepys
Collection. Mr. Addison has pronounced this an
excellent ballad: see the <i>Spectator</i>, No. 248.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[This ballad was printed in the third volume of the first edition
of the <i>Reliques</i>, Book ii. No. 12, but was afterwards expunged
by Percy. Professor Child gives the following references in
his collection of <i>English and Scottish Ballads</i>, vol. viii. p. 152:—"The
same story circulates among the peasantry of England and
Scotland in the form of a penny tract or chap-book, <i>Notices of</i>
<i>Popular Histories</i>, p. 16, (<i>Percy Soc.</i> vol. xxiii.); <i>Notes and Queries</i>,
New Series, vol. iii. p. 49. This jest is an old one. Mr. Halliwell
refers to a fabliau in Barbazan's Collection, which contains
the groundwork of this piece, <i>Du Vilain qui Conquist Paradis par</i>
<i>Plait</i>, Meon's ed. iv. 114."]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="figleft">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i333i.png" id="img_images_i333i.png">
</div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">In Bath a wanton wife did dwelle,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As Chaucer he doth write;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Who did in pleasure spend her dayes;<br></span>
<span class="i2">And many a fond delight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Upon a time sore sicke she was                                       <span class="linenum">5</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And at the length did dye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And then her soul at heaven gate,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Did knocke most mightilye.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_334">[Pg 334]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">First Adam came unto the gate:<br></span>
<span class="i2">Who knocketh there? quoth hee                                     <span class="linenum">10</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I am the wife of Bath, she sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And faine would come to thee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thou art a sinner, Adam sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And here no place shalt have.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And so art thou, I trowe, quoth shee,                               <span class="linenum">15</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">'and eke a' doting knave.<a id="FNanchor_463"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_463">[463]</a><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I will come in, in spight, she sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Of all such churles as thee;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou wert the causer of our woe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Our paine and misery;                                             <span class="linenum">20</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And first broke God's commandiments,<br></span>
<span class="i2">In pleasure of thy wife.<br></span>
<span class="i0">When Adam heard her tell this tale,<br></span>
<span class="i2">He ranne away for life.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then downe came Jacob at the gate,                                  <span class="linenum">25</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And bids her packe to hell,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou false deceiving knave, quoth she<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou mayst be there as well.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">For thou deceiv'dst thy father deare,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And thine own brother too.                                        <span class="linenum">30</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Away 'slunk' Jacob presently,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And made no more adoo.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">She knockes again with might and maine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And Lot he chides her straite,<br></span>
<span class="i0">How now, quoth she, thou drunken ass,                               <span class="linenum">35</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who bade thee here to prate?<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">With thy two daughters thou didst lye,<br></span>
<span class="i2">On them two bastardes got.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thus most tauntingly she chaft<br></span>
<span class="i2">Against poor silly Lot.                                           <span class="linenum">40</span><br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_335">[Pg 335]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Who calleth there, quoth Judith then,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With such shrill sounding notes?<br></span>
<span class="i0">This fine minkes surely came not here,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Quoth she, for cutting throats.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Good Lord, how Judith blush'd for shame,                            <span class="linenum">45</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">When she heard her say soe!<br></span>
<span class="i0">King David hearing of the same,<br></span>
