<span class="i2">He to the gate would goe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Quoth David, who knockes there so loud,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And maketh all this strife;                                       <span class="linenum">50</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">You were more kinde, good sir, she sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Unto Uriah's wife.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And when thy servant thou didst cause<br></span>
<span class="i2">In battle to be slaine;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou causedst far more strife than I,                               <span class="linenum">55</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who would come here so faine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">The woman's mad, quoth Solomon,<br></span>
<span class="i2">That thus doth taunt a king.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Not half so mad as you, she sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I trowe in manye a thing.                                         <span class="linenum">60</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Thou hadst seven hundred wives at once,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For whom thou didst provide;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And yet God wot, three hundred whores<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou must maintaine beside:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And they made thee forsake thy God,                                 <span class="linenum">65</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And worship stockes and stones;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Besides the charge they put thee to<br></span>
<span class="i2">In breeding of young bones.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Hadst thou not bin beside thy wits,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou wouldst not thus have ventur'd;                              <span class="linenum">70</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">And therefore I do marvel much,<br></span>
<span class="i2">How thou this place hast enter'd.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_336">[Pg 336]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I never heard, quoth Jonas then,<br></span>
<span class="i2">So vile a scold as this.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou whore-son run-away, quoth she,                                 <span class="linenum">75</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou diddest more amiss.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">'They say,' quoth Thomas, women's tongues,<a id="FNanchor_464"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_464">[464]</a><br></span>
<span class="i2">Of aspen-leaves are made.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Thou unbelieving wretch, quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All is not true that's sayd.                                      <span class="linenum">80</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When Mary Magdalen heard her then,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She came unto the gate.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Quoth she, good woman, you must think<br></span>
<span class="i2">Upon your former state.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">No sinner enters in this place                                      <span class="linenum">85</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Quoth Mary Magdalene. Then<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Twere ill for you, fair mistress mine,<br></span>
<span class="i2">She answered her agen:<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">You for your honestye, quoth she,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Had once been ston'd to death;                                    <span class="linenum">90</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">Had not our Saviour Christ come by,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And written on the earth.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">It was not by your occupation,<br></span>
<span class="i2">You are become divine:<br></span>
<span class="i0">I hope my soul in Christ his passion,                               <span class="linenum">95</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Shall be as safe as thine.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Uprose the good apostle Paul,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And to this wife he cryed,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Except thou shake thy sins away,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou here shalt be denyed.                                       <span class="linenum">100</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Remember, Paul, what thou hast done,<br></span>
<span class="i2">All through a lewd desire:<br></span>
<span class="i0">How thou didst persecute God's church,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With wrath as hot as fire.<br></span>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_337">[Pg 337]</a></span></div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Then up starts Peter at the last,                                  <span class="linenum">105</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">And to the gate he hies:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fond fool, quoth he, knock not so fast,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Thou weariest Christ with cries.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Peter, said she, content thyselfe,<br></span>
<span class="i2">For mercye may be won,                                           <span class="linenum">110</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">I never did deny my Christ,<br></span>
<span class="i2">As thou thyselfe hast done.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">When as our Saviour Christ heard this,<br></span>
<span class="i2">With heavenly angels bright,<br></span>
<span class="i0">He comes unto this sinful soul,                                    <span class="linenum">115</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">Who trembled at his sight.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Of him for mercye she did crave.<br></span>
<span class="i2">Quoth he, thou hast refus'd<br></span>
<span class="i0">My proffer'd grace, and mercy both,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And much my name abus'd.                                         <span class="linenum">120</span><br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">Sore have I sinned, Lord, she sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">And spent my time in vaine,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But bring me like a wandring sheepe<br></span>
<span class="i2">Into thy flocke againe.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">O Lord my God, I will amend                                        <span class="linenum">125</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">My former wicked vice:<br></span>
<span class="i0">The thief for one poor silly word,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Past into Paradise.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">My lawes and my commandments,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Saith Christ, were known to thee;                                <span class="linenum">130</span><br></span>
<span class="i0">But of the same in any wise,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Not yet one word did yee.<br></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">I grant the same, O Lord, quoth she;<br></span>
<span class="i2">Most lewdly did I live:<br></span>
<span class="i0">But yet the loving father did                                      <span class="linenum">135</span><br></span>
<span class="i2">His prodigal son forgive.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_338">[Pg 338]</a></span>
</div><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">So I forgive thy soul, he sayd,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Through thy repenting crye;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Come enter then into my joy,<br></span>
<span class="i2">I will not thee denye.                                           <span class="linenum">140</span><br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_339">[Pg 339]</a></span></p><div class="footnotes"><h4>FOOTNOTES:</h4>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_463"></a><a href="#FNanchor_463" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[463]</span></a> Ver. 16. Now gip you, <i>P.</i></p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_464"></a><a href="#FNanchor_464" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[464]</span></a> Ver. 77. I think, <i>P.</i></p></div></div>
<div class="figcenter" style="height: 100px;">
<img alt="" height="100" src="images/i338.png" id="img_images_i338.png">
</div>
<h2><a id="APPENDIX_II">APPENDIX II.</a><br>

ON THE ANCIENT METRICAL ROMANCES, &amp;c.</h2>
<p class="center">I.</p>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i339.png" id="img_images_i339.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">The</span> first attempts at composition among all
barbarous nations are ever found to be
poetry and song. The praises of their
gods, and the achievements of their heroes,
are usually chanted at their festival meetings. These
are the first rudiments of history. It is in this
manner that the savages of North America preserve
the memory of past events<a id="FNanchor_465"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_465">[465]</a>; and the same method
is known to have prevailed among our Saxon ancestors
before they quitted their German forests<a id="FNanchor_466"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_466">[466]</a>.
The ancient Britons had their Bards, and the Gothic
nations their Scalds or popular poets<a id="FNanchor_467"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_467">[467]</a>, whose business
it was to record the victories of their warriors,
and the genealogies of their princes, in a kind of
narrative songs, which were committed to memory,
and delivered down from one reciter to another. So
long as poetry continued a distinct profession, and
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_340">[Pg 340]</a></span>while the Bard, or Scald, was a regular and stated
officer in the prince's court, these men are thought
to have performed the functions of the historian
pretty faithfully; for though their narrations would
be apt to receive a good deal of embellishment, they
are supposed to have had at the bottom so much of
truth as to serve for the basis of more regular annals.
At least succeeding historians have taken up with
the relations of these rude men, and for the want of
more authentic records, have agreed to allow them
the credit of true history<a id="FNanchor_468"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_468">[468]</a>.</p>
<p>After letters began to prevail, and history assumed
a more stable form, by being committed to plain
simple prose; these songs of the Scalds or Bards
began to be more amusing than useful. And in proportion
as it became their business chiefly to entertain
and delight, they gave more and more into
embellishment, and set off their recitals with such
marvellous fictions, as were calculated to captivate
gross and ignorant minds. Thus began stories of
adventures with giants and dragons, and witches
and enchanters, and all the monstrous extravagances
of wild imagination, unguided by judgment, and
uncorrected by art<a id="FNanchor_469"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_469">[469]</a>.</p>
<p>This seems to be the true origin of that species of
romance, which so long celebrated feats of chivalry,
and which at first in metre, and afterwards in prose,
was the entertainment of our ancestors, in common
with their contemporaries on the continent, till the
satire of Cervantes, or rather the increase of knowledge
and classical literature, drove them off the
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_341">[Pg 341]</a></span>stage to make room for a more refined species of
fiction, under the name of French Romances, copied
from the Greek<a id="FNanchor_470"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_470">[470]</a>.</p>
<p>That our old romances of chivalry may be derived
in a lineal descent from the ancient historical songs
of the Gothic Bards and Scalds, will be shown below,
and indeed appears the more evident, as many of
those songs are still preserved in the north, which
exhibit all the seeds of chivalry before it became a
solemn institution<a id="FNanchor_471"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_471">[471]</a>. "Chivalry, as a distinct military
order, conferred in the way of investiture, and
accompanied with the solemnity of an oath, and
other ceremonies," was of later date, and sprung out
of the feudal constitution, as an elegant writer has
clearly shown<a id="FNanchor_472"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_472">[472]</a>. But the ideas of chivalry prevailed
long before in all the Gothic nations, and may
be discovered as in embriyo in the customs, manners,
and opinions of every branch of that people<a id="FNanchor_473"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_473">[473]</a>.
That fondness of going in quest of adventures, that
spirit of challenging to single combat, and that respectful
complaisance shewn to the fair sex, (so
different from the manners of the Greeks and Romans),
all are of Gothic origin, and may be traced
up to the earliest times among all the northern
nations<a id="FNanchor_474"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_474">[474]</a>. These existed long before the feudal
ages, though they were called forth and strengthened
in a peculiar manner under that constitution, and at
length arrived to their full maturity in the times
of the Crusades, so replete with romantic adventures<a id="FNanchor_475"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_475">[475]</a>.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_342">[Pg 342]</a></span></p>
<p>Even the common arbitrary fictions of romance
were (as is hinted above) most of them familiar to the
ancient Scalds of the North, long before the time of
the Crusades. They believed the existence of giants
and dwarfs<a id="FNanchor_476"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_476">[476]</a>; they entertained opinions not unlike
the more modern notion of fairies<a id="FNanchor_477"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_477">[477]</a>, they were
strongly possessed with the belief of spells and inchantment<a id="FNanchor_478"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_478">[478]</a>,
and were fond of inventing combats
with dragons and monsters<a id="FNanchor_479"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_479">[479]</a>.</p>
<p>The opinion therefore seems very untenable, which
some learned and ingenious men have entertained,
that the turn for chivalry, and the taste for that species
of romantic fiction were caught by the Spaniards
from the Arabians or Moors after their invasion of
Spain, and from the Spaniards transmitted to the
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_343">[Pg 343]</a></span>bards of Armorica<a id="FNanchor_480"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_480">[480]</a>, and thus diffused through
Britain, France, Italy, Germany, and the North.
For it seems utterly incredible, that one rude people
should adopt a peculiar taste and manner of writing
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_344">[Pg 344]</a></span>or thinking from another, without borrowing at the
same time any of their particular stories and fables,
without appearing to know anything of their heroes,
history, laws, and religion. When the Romans began
to adopt and imitate the Grecian literature, they
immediately naturalized all the Grecian fables, histories,
and religious stories; which became as familiar
to the poets of Rome, as of Greece itself. Whereas
all the old writers of chivalry, and of that species of
romance, whether in prose or verse, whether of the
Northern nations, or of Britain, France, and Italy,
not excepting Spain itself<a id="FNanchor_481"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_481">[481]</a>, appear utterly unacquainted
with whatever relates to the Mahometan
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_345">[Pg 345]</a></span>nations. Thus with regard to their religion, they
constantly represent them as worshipping idols, as
paying adoration to a golden image of Mahomet, or
else they confound them with the ancient pagans,
&amp;c. And indeed in all other respects they are so
grossly ignorant of the customs, manners, and
opinions of every branch of that people, especially of
their heroes, champions, and local stories, as almost
amounts to a demonstration that they did not imitate
them in their songs or romances: for as to dragons,
serpents, necromancies, &amp;c., why should these be
thought only derived from the Moors in Spain so
late as after the eighth century? since notions of
this kind appear too familiar to the northern Scalds
and enter too deeply into all the northern mythology,
to have been transmitted to the unlettered Scandinavians,
from so distant a country, at so late a
period. If they may not be allowed to have brought
these opinions with them in their original migrations
from the north of Asia, they will be far more likely
to have borrowed them from the Latin poets after the
Roman conquests in Gaul, Britain, Germany, &amp;c.
For, I believe one may challenge the maintainers
of this opinion, to produce any Arabian poem or
history, that could possibly have been then known in
Spain, which resembles the old Gothic romances of
chivalry half so much as the Metamorphoses of
Ovid.</p>
<p>But we well know that the Scythian nations situate
in the countries about Pontus, Colchis, and the
Euxine sea, were in all times infamous for their
magic arts: and as Odin and his followers are said
to have come precisely from those parts of Asia; we
can readily account for the prevalence of fictions of
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_346">[Pg 346]</a></span>this sort among the Gothic nations of the North,
without fetching them from the Moors in Spain;
who for many centuries after their irruption, lived in
a state of such constant hostility with the unsubdued
Spanish Christians, whom they chiefly pent up in the
mountains, as gave them no chance of learning their
music, poetry, or stories; and this, together with the
religious hatred of the latter for their cruel invaders,
will account for the utter ignorance of the old
Spanish romancers in whatever relates to the Mahometan
nations, although so nearly their own
neighbours.</p>
<p>On the other hand, from the local customs and
situations, from the known manners and opinions of
the Gothic nations in the north, we can easily account
for all the ideas of chivalry and its peculiar
fictions<a id="FNanchor_482"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_482">[482]</a>. For, not to mention their distinguished
respect for the fair sex, so different from the manners
of the Mahometan nations<a id="FNanchor_483"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_483">[483]</a>, their national and domestic
history so naturally assumes all the wonders
of this species of fabling, that almost all their historical
narratives appear regular romances. One might
refer in proof of this to the old northern Sagas in
general: but to give a particular instance it will be
sufficient to produce the history of King Regner
Lodbrog, a celebrated warrior and pirate, who reigned
in Denmark about the year 800<a id="FNanchor_484"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_484">[484]</a>. This hero
signalized his youth by an exploit of gallantry. A
Swedish prince had a beautiful daughter whom he
intrusted (probably during some expedition) to the
care of one of his officers, assigning a strong castle
for their defence. The officer fell in love with his
ward, and detained her in his castle, spite of all the
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_347">[Pg 347]</a></span>efforts of her father. Upon this he published a proclamation
through all the neighbouring countries,
that whoever would conquer the ravisher and rescue
the lady should have her in marriage. Of all that
undertook the adventure, Regner alone was so happy
as to achieve it: he delivered the fair captive, and
obtained her for his prize. It happened that the
name of this discourteous officer was Orme, which in
the Islandic language signifies serpent: Wherefore
the Scalds, to give the more poetical turn to the adventure,
represent the lady as detained from her
father by a dreadful dragon, and that Regner slew
the monster to set her at liberty. This fabulous
account of the exploit is given in a poem still extant,
which is even ascribed to Regner himself, who was a
celebrated poet; and which records all the valiant
achievements of his life<a id="FNanchor_485"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_485">[485]</a>.</p>
<p>With marvelous embellishments of this kind the
Scalds early began to decorate their narratives: and
they were the more lavish of these, in proportion as
they departed from their original institution, but it
was a long time before they thought of delivering a
set of personages and adventures wholly feigned.
Of the great multitude of romantic tales still preserved
in the libraries of the North, most of them
are supposed to have had some foundation in truth,
and the more ancient they are, the more they are
believed to be connected with true history<a id="FNanchor_486"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_486">[486]</a>.</p>
<p>It was not probably till after the historian and the
bard had been long disunited, that the latter ventured
at pure fiction. At length when their business
was no longer to instruct or inform, but merely to
amuse, it was no longer needful for them to adhere
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_348">[Pg 348]</a></span>to truth. Then succeeded fabulous songs and romances
in verse, which for a long time prevailed in
France and England before they had books of chivalry
in prose. Yet in both these countries the
minstrels still retained so much of their original institution,
as frequently to make true events the subject
of their songs<a id="FNanchor_487"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_487">[487]</a>; and indeed, as during the
barbarous ages, the regular histories were almost all
written in Latin by the monks, the memory of events
was preserved and propagated among the ignorant
laity by scarce any other means than the popular
songs of the minstrels.</p>
<p>II. The inhabitants of Sweden, Denmark, and
Norway, being the latest converts to Christianity,
retained their original manners and opinions longer
than the other nations of Gothic race: and therefore
they have preserved more of the genuine compositions
of their ancient poets, than their southern
neighbours. Hence the progress, among them, from
poetical history to poetical fiction is very discernible:
they have some old pieces, that are in effect complete
Romances of Chivalry<a id="FNanchor_488"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_488">[488]</a>. They have also
(as hath been observed) a multitude of Sagas<a id="FNanchor_489"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_489">[489]</a> or
histories on romantic subjects, containing a mixture
of prose and verse, of various dates, some of them
written since the times of the Crusades, others long
before: but their narratives in verse only are esteemed
the more ancient.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_349">[Pg 349]</a></span></p>
<p>Now as the irruption of the Normans<a id="FNanchor_490"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_490">[490]</a> into
France under Rollo did not take place till towards
the beginning of the tenth century, at which time
the Scaldic art was arrived to the highest perfection
in Rollo's native country, we can easily trace the
descent of the French and English romances of
chivalry from the Northern Sagas. That conqueror
doubtless carried many Scalds with him from the
north, who transmitted their skill to their children
and successors. These adopting the religion, opinions,
and language of the new country, substituted
the heroes of Christendom instead of those of their
pagan ancestors, and began to celebrate the feats of
Charlemagne, Roland, and Oliver; whose true history
they set off and embellished with the Scaldic
figments of dwarfs, giants, dragons, and enchantments.
The first mention we have in song of those
heroes of chivalry is in the mouth of a Norman
warrior at the conquest of England<a id="FNanchor_491"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_491">[491]</a>: and this
circumstance alone would sufficiently account for
the propagation of this kind of romantic poems
among the French and English.</p>
<p>But this is not all; it is very certain, that both
the Anglo-Saxons and the Franks had brought with
them, at their first emigrations into Britain and Gaul,
the same fondness for the ancient songs of their ancestors,
which prevailed among the other Gothic
tribes<a id="FNanchor_492"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_492">[492]</a>, and that all their first annals were
transmitted in these popular oral poems. This fondness
they even retained long after their conversion to
Christianity, as we learn from the examples of
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_350">[Pg 350]</a></span>Charlemagne and Alfred<a id="FNanchor_493"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_493">[493]</a>. Now poetry, being
thus the transmitter of facts, would as easily learn
to blend them with fictions in France and England,
as she is known to have done in the north, and that
much sooner, for the reasons before assigned<a id="FNanchor_494"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_494">[494]</a>.
This, together with the example and influence of
the Normans, will easily account to us, why the
first romances of chivalry that appeared both in
England and France<a id="FNanchor_495"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_495">[495]</a> were composed in metre,
as a rude kind of epic songs. In both kingdoms
tales in verse were usually sung by minstrels to
the harp on festival occasions: and doubtless both
nations derived their relish for this sort of entertainment
from their Teutonic ancestors, without either
of them borrowing it from the other. Among both
people narrative songs on true or fictitious subjects
had evidently obtained from the earliest times. But
the professed romances of chivalry seem to have
been first composed in France, where also they had
their name.</p>
<p>The Latin tongue, as is observed by an ingenious
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_351">[Pg 351]</a></span>writer<a id="FNanchor_496"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_496">[496]</a>, ceased to be spoken in France about the
ninth century, and was succeeded by what was called
the Romance tongue, a mixture of the language of
the Franks and bad Latin. As the songs of chivalry
became the most popular compositions in that language,
they were emphatically called Romans or Romants;
though this name was at first given to any
piece of poetry. The romances of chivalry can be
traced as early as the eleventh century<a id="FNanchor_497"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_497">[497]</a>. I know
not if the <i>Roman de Brut</i> written in 1155, was such:
but if it was, it was by no means the first poem of
the kind; others more ancient are still extant<a id="FNanchor_498"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_498">[498]</a>.
And we have already seen, that, in the preceding
century, when the Normans marched down to the
battle of Hastings, they animated themselves, by
singing (in some popular romance or ballad) the
exploits of Roland and the other heroes of chivalry<a id="FNanchor_499"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_499">[499]</a>.</p>
<p>So early as this I cannot trace the songs of chivalry
in English. The most ancient I have seen, is that
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_352">[Pg 352]</a></span>of Hornechild described below, which seems not
older than the twelfth century. However, as this
rather resembles the Saxon poetry than the French,
it is not certain that the first English romances were
translated from that language<a id="FNanchor_500"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_500">[500]</a>. We have seen above,
that a propensity to this kind of fiction prevailed
among all the Gothic nations<a id="FNanchor_501"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_501">[501]</a>; and, though after
the Norman Conquest, this country abounded with
French romances, or with translations from the
French, there is good reason to believe, that the
English had original pieces of their own.</p>
<p>The stories of King Arthur and his Round Table,
may be reasonably supposed of the growth of this
island; both the French and the Armoricans probably
had them from Britain<a id="FNanchor_502"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_502">[502]</a>. The stories of Guy
and Bevis, with some others, were probably the
invention of English minstrels<a id="FNanchor_503"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_503">[503]</a>. On the other
hand, the English procured translations of such
romances as were most current in France; and in
the list given at the conclusion of these remarks,
many are doubtless of French original.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_353">[Pg 353]</a></span></p>
<p>The first prose books of chivalry that appeared in
our language, were those printed by Caxton<a id="FNanchor_504"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_504">[504]</a>; at
least, these are the first I have been able to discover,
and these are all translations from the French.
Whereas romances of this kind had been long current
in metre, and were so generally admired in the
time of Chaucer, that his rhyme of Sir Thopas was
evidently written to ridicule and burlesque them<a id="FNanchor_505"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_505">[505]</a>.</p>
<p>He expressly mentions several of them by name
in a stanza, which I have had occasion to quote more
than once in this volume:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Men speken of Romaunces of pris<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Horn-Child, and of Ipotis<br></span>
<span class="i8">Of Bevis, and Sire Guy<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Sire Libeux, and Pleindamour,<br></span>
<span class="i0">But Sire Thopas, he bereth the flour<br></span>
<span class="i8">Of real chevalrie"<a id="FNanchor_506"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_506">[506]</a>.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>Most, if not all of these are still extant in MS. in
some or other of our libraries, as I shall shew in the
conclusion of this slight essay, where I shall give a
list of such metrical histories and romances as have
fallen under my observation.</p>
<p>As many of these contain a considerable portion
of poetic merit, and throw great light on the manners
and opinions of former times, it were to be wished
that some of the best of them were rescued from
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_354">[Pg 354]</a></span>oblivion. A judicious collection of them accurately
published with proper illustrations, would be an important
accession to our stock of ancient English
literature. Many of them exhibit no mean attempts
at epic poetry, and though full of the exploded fictions
of chivalry, frequently display great descriptive and
inventive powers in the bards, who composed them.
They are at least generally equal to any other poetry
of the same age. They cannot indeed be put in
competition with the nervous productions of so universal
and commanding a genius as Chaucer, but
they have a simplicity that makes them be read with
less interruption, and be more easily understood:
and they are far more spirited and entertaining than
the tedious allegories of Gower, or the dull and
prolix legends of Lydgate. Yet, while so much
stress was laid upon the writings of these last, by
such as treat of English poetry, the old metrical
romances, though far more popular in their time,
were hardly known to exist. But it has happened
unluckily, that the antiquaries, who have revived the
works of our ancient writers, have been for the most
part men void of taste and genius, and therefore have
always fastidiously rejected the old poetical romances,
because founded on fictitious or popular subjects,
while they have been careful to grub up every petty
fragment of the most dull and insipid rhymist, whose
merit it was to deform morality, or obscure true history.
Should the publick encourage the revival of some
of those ancient epic songs of chivalry, they would
frequently see the rich ore of an Ariosto or a Tasso,
though buried it may be among the rubbish and
dross of barbarous times.</p>
<p>Such a publication would answer many important
uses: It would throw new light on the rise and progress
of English poetry, the history of which can be
but imperfectly understood, if these are neglected:<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_355">[Pg 355]</a></span>
It would also serve to illustrate innumerable passages
in our ancient classic poets, which without their help
must be for ever obscure. For, not to mention
Chaucer and Spencer, who abound with perpetual
allusions to them, I shall give an instance or two
from Shakespeare, by way of specimen of their use.</p>
<p>In his play of <i>King John</i> our great dramatic poet
alludes to an exploit of Richard I. which the reader
will in vain look for in any true history. Faulconbridge
says to his mother, act i. sc. 1.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Needs must you lay your heart at his dispose ...<br></span>
<span class="i0">Against whose furie and unmatched force,<br></span>
<span class="i0">The awlesse lion could not wage the fight,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Nor keepe his princely heart from Richard's hand:<br></span>
<span class="i0">He that perforce robs Lions of their hearts<br></span>
<span class="i0">May easily winne a woman's:"<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>The fact here referred to, is to be traced to its
source only in the old romance of <i>Richard Ceur["Cœur"?] de</i>
<i>Lyon</i><a id="FNanchor_507"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_507">[507]</a>, in which his encounter with a lion makes a
very shining figure. I shall give a large extract from
this poem, as a specimen of the manner of these old
rhapsodists, and to shew that they did not in their
fictions neglect the proper means to produce the
ends, as was afterwards so childishly done in the
prose books of chivalry.</p>
<p>The poet tells us, that Richard, in his return from
the Holy Land, having been discovered in the habit
of "a palmer in Almayne," and apprehended as a
spy, was by the king thrown into prison. Wardrewe,
the king's son, hearing of Richard's great strength,
desires the jailor to let him have a sight of his prisoners.
Richard being the foremost, Wardrewe asks
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_356">[Pg 356]</a></span>him, "if he dare stand a buffet from his hand?" and
that on the morrow he shall return him another.
Richard consents, and receives a blow that staggers
him. On the morrow, having previously waxed his
hands, he waits his antagonist's arrival. Wardrewe
accordingly, proceeds the story, "held forth as a
trewe man," and Richard gave him such a blow on
the cheek, as broke his jawbone, and killed him on
the spot. The king, to revenge the death of his son,
orders, by the advice of one Eldrede, that a lion,
kept purposely from food, shall be turned loose upon
Richard. But the king's daughter having fallen in
love with him, tells him of her father's resolution,
and at his request procures him forty ells of white
silk "kerchers;" and here the description of the
combat begins:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"The kever-chefes<a id="FNanchor_508"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_508">[508]</a> he toke on honde,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And aboute his arme he wonde;<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thought in that ylke while,<br></span>
<span class="i0">To slee the lyon with some gyle.<br></span>
<span class="i0">And syngle in a kyrtyll he stode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And abode the lyon fyers and wode,<br></span>
<span class="i0">With that came the jaylere,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And other men that wyth him were,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lyon them amonge;<br></span>
<span class="i0">His pawes were stiffe and stronge.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The chambre dore they undone,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And the lyon to them is gone.<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rycharde sayd, Helpe lorde Jesu!<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lyon made to hym venu,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And wolde hym have all to rente:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Kynge Rycharde besyde hym glente<a id="FNanchor_509"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_509">[509]</a><br></span>
<span class="i0">The lyon on the breste hym spurned,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That aboute he tourned.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lyon was hongry and megre,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And bette his tayle to be egre;<br></span>
<span class="i0">He loked aboute as he were madde;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Abrode he all his pawes spradde.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He cryed lowde, and yaned<a id="FNanchor_510"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_510">[510]</a> wyde.<br></span><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_357">[Pg 357]</a></span>
<span class="i0">Kynge Rycharde bethought hym that tyde<br></span>
<span class="i0">What hym was beste, and to hym sterte,<br></span>
<span class="i0">In at the throte his honde he gerte,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And hente out the herte with his honde,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Lounge and all that he there fonde.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The lyon fell deed to the grounde:<br></span>
<span class="i0">Rycharde felte no wem<a id="FNanchor_511"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_511">[511]</a>, ne wounde.<br></span>
<span class="i0">He fell on his knees on that place,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And thanked Jesu of his grace."<br></span>
<span class="i0">       *       *       *       *       *<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>What follows is not so well, and therefore I shall
extract no more of this poem.—For the above feat
the author tells us, the king was deservedly called</p>
<p class="center">"Stronge Rycharde Cure de Lyowne."
</p>
<p>That distich which Shakespeare puts in the mouth
of his madman in <i>K. Lear</i>, act iii. sc. 4.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Mice and Rats and such small deere<br></span>
<span class="i0">Have been Tom's food for seven long yeare,"<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>has excited the attention of the critics. Instead of
<i>deere</i>, one of them would substitute <i>geer</i>; and another
<i>cheer</i><a id="FNanchor_512"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_512">[512]</a>. But the ancient reading is established by
the old romance of Sir Bevis, which Shakespeare
had doubtless often heard sung to the harp. This
distich is part of a description there given of the
hardships suffered by Bevis, when confined for seven
years in a dungeon:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Rattes and myse and such small dere<br></span>
<span class="i0">Was his meate that seven yere."—Sign. F. iii.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>III. In different parts of this work, the reader
will find various extracts from these old poetical
legends; to which I refer him for farther examples
of their style and metre. To complete this subject,
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_358">[Pg 358]</a></span>it will be proper at least to give one specimen of
their skill in distributing and conducting their fable,
by which it will be seen that nature and common
sense had supplied to these old simple bards the
want of critical art, and taught them some of the
most essential rules of epic poetry.—I shall select
the romance of <i>Libius Disconius</i><a id="FNanchor_513"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_513">[513]</a>, as being one of
those mentioned by Chaucer, and either shorter or
more intelligible than the others he has quoted.</p>
<p>If an epic poem may be defined,<a id="FNanchor_514"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_514">[514]</a> "A fable related
by a poet, to excite admiration, and inspire
virtue, by representing the action of some one hero,
favoured by heaven, who executes a great design, in
spite of all the obstacles that oppose him:" I know
not why we should withold the name of Epic Poem
from the piece which I am about to analyse.</p>
<p>My copy is divided into IX. Parts or Cantos, the
several arguments of which are as follows.</p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Part I.</span></p>
<p>Opens with a short exordium to bespeak attention:
the hero is described; a natural son of Sir Gawain a
celebrated knight of king Arthur's court, who being
brought up in a forest by his mother, is kept ignorant
of his name and descent. He early exhibits marks
of his courage, by killing a knight in single combat,
who encountered him as he was hunting. This inspires
him with a desire of seeking adventures: therefore
cloathing himself in his enemy's armour, he goes
to K. Arthur's court, to request the order of knighthood.
His request granted, he obtains a promise
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_359">[Pg 359]</a></span>of having the first adventure assigned him that shall
offer.—A damsel named Ellen, attended by a dwarf,
comes to implore K. Arthur's assistance, to rescue a
young princess, "the Lady of Sinadone" their mistress,
who is detained from her rights, and confined
in prison. The adventure is claimed by the young
knight Sir Lybius: the king assents; the messengers
are dissatisfied, and object to his youth; but are
forced to acquiesce. And here the first book closes
with a description of the ceremony of equipping him
forth.</p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Part II.</span></p>
<p>Sir Lybius sets out on the adventure: he is derided
by the dwarf and the damsel on account of his youth:
they come to the bridge of Perill, which none can
pass without encountering a knight called William
de la Braunch. Sir Lybius is challenged: they just
with their spears: De la Braunch is dismounted:
the battle is renewed on foot: Sir William's sword
breaks: he yields. Sir Lybius makes him swear to
go and present himself to K. Arthur, as the first-fruits
of his valour. The conquered knight sets out
for K. Arthur's court: is met by three knights, his kinsmen;
who, informed of his disgrace, vow revenge, and
pursue the conqueror. The next day they overtake
him: the eldest of the three attacks Sir Lybius; but
is overthrown to the ground. The two other brothers
assault him: Sir Lybius is wounded; yet cuts off
the second brother's arm: the third yields; Sir
Lybius sends them all to K. Arthur. In the third
evening he is awaked by the dwarf, who has discovered
a fire in the wood.</p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Part III.</span></p>
<p>Sir Lybius arms himself, and leaps on horseback:
he finds two giants roasting a wild boar, who have<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_360">[Pg 360]</a></span>
a fair lady their captive. Sir Lybius, by favour of
the night, runs one of them through with his spear:
is assaulted by the other: a fierce battle ensues: he
cuts off the giant's arm, and at length his head. The
rescued lady (an Earl's daughter) tells him her
story; and leads him to her father's castle; who
entertains him with a great feast; and presents him
at parting with a suit of armour and a steed. He
sends the giant's head to K. Arthur.</p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Part IV.</span></p>
<p>Sir Lybius, maid Ellen, and the dwarf, renew their
journey: they see a castle stuck round with human
heads; and are informed it belongs to a knight called
Sir Gefferon, who, in honour of his lemman or mistress,
challenges all comers: He that can produce a
fairer lady, is to be rewarded with a milk-white
faulcon, but if overcome, to lose his head. Sir
Lybius spends the night in the adjoining town: In
the morning goes to challenge the faulcon. The
knights exchange their gloves: they agree to just
in the market place: the lady and maid Ellen
are placed aloft in chairs: their dresses: the superior
beauty of Sir Gefferon's mistress described:
the ceremonies previous to the combat. They engage:
the combat described at large: Sir Gefferon
is incurably hurt; and carried home on his shield.
Sir Lybius sends the faulcon to K. Arthur; and
receives back a large present in florins. He stays
40 days to be cured of his wounds, which he spends
in feasting with the neighbouring lords.</p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Part V.</span></p>
<p>Sir Lybius proceeds for Sinadone: in the forest
he meets a knight hunting, called Sir Otes de Lisle:
maid Ellen charmed with a very beautiful dog, begs<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_361">[Pg 361]</a></span>
Sir Lybius to bestow him upon her: Sir Otes meets
them, and claims his dog: is refused: being unarmed
he rides to his castle, and summons his followers:
they go in quest of Sir Lybius: a battle
ensues: he is still victorious, and forces Sir Otes to
follow the other conquered knights to K. Arthur.</p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Part VI.</span></p>
<p>Sir Lybius comes to a fair city and castle by a
riverside, beset round with pavilions or tents: he is
informed, in the castle is a beautiful lady besieged
by a giant named Maugys, who keeps the bridge,
and will let none pass without doing him homage:
this Lybius refuses: a battle ensues: the giant described:
the several incidents of the battle; which
lasts a whole summer's day; the giant is wounded:
put to flight; slain. The citizens come out in procession
to meet their deliverer: the lady invites him
into her castle: falls in love with him; and seduces
him to her embraces. He forgets the princess of
Sinadone, and stays with this bewitching lady a
twelvemonth. This fair sorceress, like another
Alcina, intoxicates him with all kinds of sensual
pleasure; and detains him from the pursuit of
honour.</p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Part VII.</span></p>
<p>Maid Ellen by chance gets an opportunity of
speaking to him; and upbraids him with his vice
and folly: he is filled with remorse, and escapes
the same evening. At length he arrives at the
city and castle of Sinadone: Is given to understand
that he must challenge the constable of the
castle to single combat, before he can be received
as a guest. They just: the constable is worsted:
Sir Lybius is feasted in the castle: he declares his<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_362">[Pg 362]</a></span>
intention of delivering their lady; and inquires the
particulars of her history. "Two necromancers have
built a fine palace by sorcery, and there keep her inchanted,
till she will surrender her duchy to them,
and yield to such base conditions as they would
impose."</p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Part VIII.</span></p>
<p>Early on the morrow Sir Lybius sets out for the
inchanted palace. He alights in the court: enters
the hall: the wonders of which are described in
strong Gothic painting. He sits down at the high
table: on a sudden all the lights are quenched: it
thunders, and lightens; the palace shakes; the walls
fall in pieces about his ears. He is dismayed and
confounded: but presently hears horses neigh, and
is challenged to single combat by the sorcerers.
He gets to his steed: a battle ensues, with various
turns of fortune: he loses his weapon; but gets a
sword from one of the necromancers, and wounds
the other with it: the edge of the sword being
secretly poisoned, the wound proves mortal.</p>
<p class="center"><span class="smcap">Part IX.</span></p>
<p>He goes up to the surviving sorcerer, who is carried
away from him by inchantment: at length he
finds him, and cuts off his head; he returns to the
palace to deliver the lady; but cannot find her: as
he is lamenting, a window opens, through which
enters a horrible serpent with wings and a woman's
face: it coils round his neck and kisses him; then
is suddenly converted into a very beautiful lady.
She tells him she is the Lady of Sinadone, and was
so inchanted, till she might kiss Sir Gawain, or some
one of his blood: that he has dissolved the charm,
and that herself and her dominions may be his re<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_363">[Pg 363]</a></span>ward.
The knight (whose descent is by this means
discovered) joyfully accepts the offer; makes her his
bride, and then sets out with her for King Arthur's
court.</p>
<p>Such is the fable of this ancient piece: which the
reader may observe, is as regular in its conduct, as
any of the finest poems of classical antiquity. If the
execution, particularly as to the diction and sentiments,
were but equal to the plan, it would be a
capital performance; but this is such as might be
expected in rude and ignorant times, and in barbarous
unpolished language.</p>
<p>IV. I shall conclude this prolix account, with a
list of such old metrical romances as are still extant;
beginning with those mentioned by Chaucer.</p>
<p>1. The romance of <i>Horne Childe</i> is preserved in
the British Museum, where it is intitled þe ᵹeste
kyng Horne. See Catalog. Harl. MSS. 2253, p. 70.
The language is almost Saxon, yet from the mention
in it of Sarazens, it appears to have been written
after some of the Crusades. It begins thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"All heo ben blyþe<br></span>
<span class="i0">þat to my sonȝ ylyþe:<br></span>
<span class="i0">A sonȝ ychulle ou sinȝ<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of Allof þe ȝode kynȝe,"<a id="FNanchor_515"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_515">[515]</a> &amp;c.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>Another copy of this poem, but greatly altered,
and somewhat modernized, is preserved in the Advocates
Library at Edinburgh, in a MS. quarto volume
of old English poetry [W. 4. 1.] Num. XXXIV. in
seven leaves or folios<a id="FNanchor_516"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_516">[516]</a>, intitled, <i>Horn-child and</i>
<i>Maiden Rinivel</i>, and beginning thus:</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_364">[Pg 364]</a></span></p><div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Mi leve frende dere,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Herken and ye may here."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>2. The poem of <i>Ipotis</i> (or <i>Ypotis</i>) is preserved in
the Cotton Library, Calig. A. 2, fo. 77, but is rather
a religious legend, than a romance. Its beginning is,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"He þat wyll of wysdome here<br></span>
<span class="i0">Herkeneth nowe ye may here<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a tale of holy wryte<br></span>
<span class="i0">Seynt Jon the Evangelyste wytnesseth hyt."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>3. The romance of Sir <i>Guy</i> was written before
that of Bevis, being quoted in it<a id="FNanchor_517"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_517">[517]</a>. An account of
this old poem is given above, p. <a href="#Page_107" class="pginternal">107</a>. To which it
may be added, that the two complete copies in MS.
are preserved at Cambridge, the one in the public
library<a id="FNanchor_518"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_518">[518]</a>, the other in that of Caius College, Class
A. 8.—In Ames's Typog. p. 153, may be seen the
first lines of the printed copy.—The first MS.
begins,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Sythe the tyme that God was borne."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>4. <i>Guy and Colbronde</i>, an old romance in three
parts, is preserved in the Editor's folio MS. (p. <a href="#Page_349" class="pginternal">349</a>.)
[printed edition, vol. ii. p. 527.] It is in stanzas of
six lines, the first of which may be seen in vol. ii. p.
175, beginning thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"When meate and drinke is great plentye."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>In the Edinburgh MS. (mentioned above) are two
ancient poems on the subject of <i>Guy of Warwick</i>:
viz. Num. XVIII. containing 26 leaves, and XX.
59 leaves. Both these have unfortunately the
be<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_365">[Pg 365]</a></span>ginnings wanting, otherwise they would perhaps be
found to be different copies of one or both the preceding
articles.</p>
<p>5. From the same MS. I can add another article
to this list, viz. the romance of <i>Rembrun</i> son of Sir
Guy; being Num. XXI. in 9 leaves: this is properly
a continuation of the History of <i>Guy</i>: and in Art. 3,
the Hist. of Rembrun follows that of Guy as a necessary
part of it. This Edinburgh romance of Rembrun
begins thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Jesu that erst of mighte most<br></span>
<span class="i0">Fader and sone and Holy Ghost."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>Before I quit the subject of Sir Guy, I must observe,
that if we may believe Dugdale in his <i>Baronage</i>
(vol. i. p. 243, col. 2), the fame of our English
Champion had in the time of Henry IV. travelled as
far as the East, and was no less popular among the
Sarazens, than here in the West among the nations
of Christendom. In that reign a Lord Beauchamp
travelling to Jerusalem was kindly received by a
noble person, the Soldan's Lieutenant, who hearing
he was descended from the famous Guy of Warwick,
"whose story they had in books of their own language,"
invited him to his palace; and royally feasting
him, presented him three precious stones of great
value, besides divers cloaths of silk and gold given to
his servants.</p>
<p>6. The romance of <i>Syr Bevis</i> is described in page
216 of this vol. Two manuscript copies of this poem
are extant at Cambridge, viz., in the public library<a id="FNanchor_519"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_519">[519]</a>,
and in that of Caius Coll. Class A. 9. (5.)—The
first of these begins,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Lordyngs lystenyth grete and smale."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_366">[Pg 366]</a></span></p>
<p>There is also a copy of this romance of <i>Sir Bevis</i>
<i>of Hamptoun</i>, in the Edinburgh MS. Numb. XXII.
consisting of twenty-five leaves, and beginning thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Lordinges herkneth to mi tale,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Is merier than the nightengale."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>The printed copies begin different from both, viz.,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Lysten, Lordinges, and hold you styl."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>7. <i>Libeaux</i> (<i>Libeaus</i>, or <i>Lybius</i>) <i>Disconius</i> is preserved
in the Editor's folio MS. (page <a href="#Page_317" class="pginternal">317</a>) [pr. ed,
vol. ii. p. 415], where the first stanza is,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Jesus Christ christen kinge,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And his mother that sweete thinge,<br></span>
<span class="i2">Helpe them at their neede,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That will listen to my tale,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Of a Knight I will you tell,<br></span>
<span class="i2">A doughtye man of deede."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>An older copy is preserved in the Cotton Library
(Calig. A. 2. fol. 40) but containing such innumerable
variations, that it is apparently a different translation
of some old French original, which will account for
the title of <i>Le Beaux Disconus</i>, or the Fair Unknown.
The first line is,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Jesu Christ our Savyour."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>As for <i>Pleindamour</i>, or <i>Blandamoure</i>, no romance
with this title has been discovered; but as the word
<i>Blaundemere</i> occurs in the romance of <i>Libius Disconius</i>,
in the Editor's folio MS. p. <a href="#Page_319" class="pginternal">319</a> [pr. ed. vol. ii.
p. 420], he thought the name of <i>Blandamoure</i> (which
was in all the editions of Chaucer he had then seen)
might have some reference to this. But <i>Pleindamour</i>,
the name restored by Mr. Tyrwhitt, is more
remote.</p>
<p>8. <i>Le Morte Arthure</i> is among the Harl. MSS
2252, § 49. This is judged to be a translation from
the French; Mr. Wanley thinks it no older than the<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_367">[Pg 367]</a></span>
time of Henry VII., but it seems to be quoted in
Syr Bevis, (Sign. K. ij. b.) It begins,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Lordinges, that are lesse and deare."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>In the library of Bennet Coll. Cambridge, No.
351, is a MS. intitled in the catalogue <i>Acta Arthuris</i>
<i>Metrico Anglicano</i>, but I know not its contents.</p>
<p>9. In the Editor's folio MS. are many songs and
romances about King Arthur and his knights, some
of which are very imperfect, as <i>King Arthur and the</i>
<i>King of Cornwall</i> (page <a href="#Page_24" class="pginternal">24</a>) [pr. ed. vol. i. p. 61], in
stanzas of four lines, beginning,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"'Come here,' my cozen Gawaine so gay."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><i>The Turke and Gawain</i> (p. <a href="#Page_38" class="pginternal">38</a>) [pr. ed. vol. i. p. 90],
in stanzas of six lines beginning thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Listen lords great and small,"<a id="FNanchor_520"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_520">[520]</a><br></span>
</div></div>
<p>but these are so imperfect that I do not make distinct
articles of them. See also in this volume, Book I.
No. I., II., IV., V.</p>
<p>In the same MS. p. <a href="#Page_203" class="pginternal">203</a> [pr. ed. vol. ii. p. 58], is the
<i>Greene Knight</i>, in two parts, relating a curious adventure
of Sir Gawain, in stanzas of six lines, beginning
thus:—</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"List: wen Arthur he was k:"<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>10. <i>The Carle of Carlisle</i> is another romantic tale
about Sir Gawain, in the same MS. p. 448 [pr. ed.
vol. iii. p. 277], in distichs:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Listen: to me a litle stond."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>In all these old poems the same set of knights
are always represented with the same manners and
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_368">[Pg 368]</a></span>characters; which seem to have been as well known,
and as distinctly marked among our ancestors, as
Homer's Heroes were among the Greeks: for, as
<i>Ulysses</i> is always represented crafty, <i>Achilles</i> irascible,
and <i>Ajax</i> rough; so <i>Sir Gawain</i> is ever courteous
and gentle, <i>Sir Kay</i> rugged and disobliging,
&amp;c. "<i>Sir Gawain with his olde curtesie</i>" is mentioned
by Chaucer as noted to a proverb, in his
<i>Squire's Tale</i>. <i>Canterb. Tales</i>, vol. ii. p. 104.</p>
<p>11. <i>Syr Launfal</i>, an excellent old romance concerning
another of King Arthur's knights, is preserved
in the Cotton Library, Calig. A 2, f. 33. This is a
translation from the French<a id="FNanchor_521"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_521">[521]</a>, made by one <i>Thomas</i>
<i>Chestre</i>, who is supposed to have lived in the reign
of Henry VI. (See Tanner's Biblioth.) It is in
stanzas of six lines, and begins,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Be douyty Artours dawes."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>The above was afterwards altered by some minstrel
into the romance of <i>Sir Lambewell</i>, in three
parts, under which title it was more generally known<a id="FNanchor_522"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_522">[522]</a>.
This is the Editor's folio MS. p. <a href="#Page_60" class="pginternal">60</a> [pr. ed. vol.
i. p. 144], beginning thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Doughty in king Arthures dayes."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>12. <i>Eger and Grime</i>, in six parts (in the Editor's
folio MS. p. <a href="#Page_124" class="pginternal">124</a>) [pr. ed. vol. i. p. 354], is a well invented
tale of chivalry, scarce inferior to any of Ariosto's.
This which was inadvertently omitted in the
former editions of this list, is in distichs, and begins
thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"It fell sometimes in the Land of Beame."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_369">[Pg 369]</a></span></p>
<p>13. The romance of <i>Merline</i>, in nine parts (preserved
in the same folio MS. p. <a href="#Page_145" class="pginternal">145</a> [pr. ed. vol. i.
p. 422]), gives a curious account of the birth, parentage,
and juvenile adventures of this famous British
Prophet. In this poem the <i>Saxons</i> are called <i>Sarazens</i>;
and the thrusting the rebel angels out of
heaven is attributed to "<i>oure Lady</i>." It is in distichs
and begins thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"He that made with his hand."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>There is an old romance <i>Of Arthour and of Merlin</i>,
in the Edinburgh MS. of old English poems: I
know not whether it has anything in common with
this last mentioned. It is in the volume numbered
xxiii. and extends through fifty-five leaves. The
two first lines are:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Jesu Crist, heven king<br></span>
<span class="i0">Al ous graunt gode ending."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>14. <i>Sir Isenbras</i> (or as it is in the MS. copies, <i>Sir</i>
<i>Isumbras</i>), is quoted in Chaucer's <i>R. of Thopas</i>, v. 6.
Among Mr. Garrick's old plays is a printed copy;
of which an account has been already given in
vol. i. book iii. No. vii. It is preserved in MS.
in the Library of Caius Coll. Camb., Class A. 9 (2),
and also in the Cotton Library, Calig. A. 12 (f. 128).
This is extremely different from the printed copy.
E.g.</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"God þat made both erþe and hevene."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>15. <i>Emarè</i>, a very curious and ancient romance, is
preserved in the same vol. of the Cotton Library,
f. 69. It is in stanzas of six lines, and begins thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Jesu þat ys kyng in trone."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>16. <i>Chevelere assigne</i>, or The Knight of the Swan,
preserved in the Cotton Library, has been already
described in vol. ii. Appendix, <i>Essay on P. Plowman's</i>
<i>Metre</i>, &amp;c., as hath also</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_370">[Pg 370]</a></span></p>
<p>17. <i>The Sege of Fēr̄lam</i> (or Jerusalem), which
seems to have been written after the other, and may
not improperly be classed among the romances; as
may also the following, which is preserved in the
same volume, viz.,</p>
<p>18. <i>Owaine Myles</i> (fol. 90), giving an account of
the wonders of St. Patrick's Purgatory. This is a
translation into verse of the story related in Mat.
Paris's <i>Hist.</i> (sub. Ann. 1153.) It is in distichs beginning
thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"God þat ys so full of myght."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>In the same manuscript are three or four other
narrative poems, which might be reckoned among
the romances, but being rather religious legends, I
shall barely mention them; as <i>Tundale</i>, f. 17; <i>Trentale</i>
<i>Sci Gregorii</i>, f. 84; <i>Jerome</i>, f. 133; <i>Eustache</i>,
f. 136.</p>
<p>19. <i>Octavian imperator</i>, an ancient romance of
chivalry, is in the same vol. of the Cotton Library,
f. 20. Notwithstanding the name, this old poem has
nothing in common with the history of the Roman
Emperors. It is in a very peculiar kind of stanza,
whereof 1, 2, 3, &amp; 5 rhyme together, as do the 4
and 6. It begins thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Ihesu Þat was with spere ystonge."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>In the public library at Cambridge<a id="FNanchor_523"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_523">[523]</a>, is a poem
with the same title, and begins very differently:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Lyttyll and mykyll, olde and yonge."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>20. <i>Eglamour of Artas</i> (or <i>Artoys</i>) is preserved
in the same vol. with the foregoing, both in the
Cotton Library and Public Library at Cambridge.
It is also in the Editor's folio MS. p. <a href="#Page_295" class="pginternal">295</a> [pr. ed.
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_371">[Pg 371]</a></span>vol. ii. p. 341], where it is divided into six parts. A
printed copy in the Bodleian Library, C. 39. Art.
Seld., and also among Mr. Garrick's old plays, K.
vol. x. It is in distichs, and begins thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Ihesu Crist of heven kyng."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>21. <i>Syr Triamore</i> (in stanzas of six lines) is preserved
in MS. in the Editor's volume, p. <a href="#Page_210" class="pginternal">210</a> [pr. ed.
vol. ii. p. 80], and in the Public Library at Cambridge
(690, § 29. Vid. Cat. MSS. p. 394.) Two
printed copies are extant in the Bodleian Library,
and among Mr. Garrick's plays in the same volumes
with the last article. Both the editor's MS. and the
printed copy begin,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Nowe Jesu Chryste our heven kynge."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>The Cambridge copy thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Heven blys that all shall wynne."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>22. <i>Sir Degree</i> (<i>Degare</i>, or <i>Degore</i>, which last
seems the true title) in five parts, in distichs, is preserved
in the Editor's folio MS. p. <a href="#Page_371" class="pginternal">371</a> [pr. ed.
vol. iii. p. 20], and in the Public Library at Cambridge
(ubi supra). A printed copy is in the Bod. Library
C. 39. Art. Seld. and among Mr. Garrick's plays, K.
vol. ix. The Editor's MS. and the printed copies
begin,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Lordinges, and you wyl holde you styl."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>The Cambridge MS. has it,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Lystenyth, lordyngis, gente and fre."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>23. <i>Ipomydon</i> (or <i>Chylde Ipomydon</i>), is preserved
among the Harl. MSS. 2252 (44). It is in distichs,
and begins,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Mekely, lordyngis, gentylle and fre."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>In the library of Lincoln Cathedral, K k. 3, 10, is<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_372">[Pg 372]</a></span>
an old imperfect printed copy, wanting the whole
first sheet A.</p>
<p>24. <i>The Squyr of Lowe degre</i>, is one of those burlesqued
by Chaucer in his Rhyme of Thopas<a id="FNanchor_524"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_524">[524]</a>. Mr.
Garrick has a printed copy of this, among his old
plays, K. vol. ix. It begins,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"It was a squyer of lowe degre,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That loved the kings daughter of Hungre."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>25. <i>Historye of K. Richard Cure [Cœur] de</i>
<i>Lyon.</i> (Impr. W. de Worde, 1528, 4to.) is preserved
in the Bodleian Library, C. 39, Art. Selden. A fragment
of it is also remaining in the Edinburgh MS.
of old English poems; No. xxxvi. in two leaves. A
large extract from this romance has been given
already above, p. <a href="#Page_356" class="pginternal">356</a>. Richard was the peculiar
patron of Chivalry, and favourite of the old minstrels
and troubadours. See Warton's <i>Observ.</i> vol. i. p. 29,
vol. ii. p. 40.</p>
<p>26. Of the following I have only seen No. 27, but
I believe they may all be referred to the class of
romances.</p>
<p>The <i>Knight of Courtesy and the Lady of Faguel</i>
(Bod. Lib. C. 39. Art. Sheld. a printed copy).
This Mr. Warton thinks is the story of Coucy's
Heart, related in Fauchet, and in Howel's Letters.
(v. i. s. 6, L. 20, see Wart. <i>Obs.</i> v. ii. p. 40). The
Editor has seen a very beautiful old ballad on this
subject in French.</p>
<p>27. The four following are all preserved in the
MS. so often referred to in the Public Library at
Cambridge, (690. Appendix to Bp. More's MSS. in
Cat. MSS. tom. ii. p. 394), viz., <i>The Lay of Erle of</i>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_373">[Pg 373]</a></span><i>Tholouse</i> (No. 27), of which the Editor hath also a
copy from "Cod. MSS. Mus. Ashmol. Oxon." The
first line of both is,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Jesu Chryste in Trynyte."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>28. <i>Roberd Kynge of Cysyll</i> (or Sicily) shewing
the fall of pride. Of this there is also a copy among
the Harl. MSS. 1703 (3). The Cambridge MS.
begins,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Princis that be prowde in prese."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>29. <i>Le bone Florence of Rome</i>, beginning thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"As ferre as men ride or gone."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>30. <i>Dioclesian the Emperour</i>, beginning,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Sum tyme ther was a noble man."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>31. The two knightly brothers <i>Amys and Amelion</i>
(among the Harl MSS. 2386, §. 42) is an old romance
of chivalry, as is also, I believe, the fragment
of the <i>Lady Belesant, the Duke of Lombardy's fair</i>
<i>daughter</i>, mentioned in the same article. See the
catalog. vol. ii.</p>
<p>32. In the Edinburgh MS. so often referred to
(preserved in the Advocates Library, W. 4. i.) might
probably be found some other articles to add to this
list, as well as other copies of some of the pieces
mentioned in it, for the whole volume contains not
fewer than thirty-seven poems or romances, some of
them very long. But as many of them have lost the
beginnings, which have been cut out for the sake of
the illuminations, and as I have not had an opportunity
of examining the MS. myself, I shall be content
to mention only the articles that follow<a id="FNanchor_525"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_525">[525]</a>: viz.</p>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_374">[Pg 374]</a></span></p>
<p>An old romance about <i>Rouland</i> (not I believe the
famous Paladine, but a champion named <i>Rouland</i>
<i>Louth</i>; query) being in the volume, No. xxvii. in
five leaves, and wants the beginning.</p>
<p>33. Another romance that seems to be a kind of
continuation of this last, intitled, <i>Otuel a Knight</i>,
(No. xxviii. in eleven leaves and a half). The two
first lines are,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Herkneth both yinge and old,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That willen heren of battailes bold."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>34. <i>The King of Tars</i> (No. iv. in five leaves and
a half; it is also in the Bodleyan Library, MS. Vernon,
f. 304) beginning thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Herkneth to me bothe eld and ying<br></span>
<span class="i0">For Maries love that swete thing."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>35. A tale or romance (No. i. two leaves), that
wants both beginning and end. The first lines now
remaining are,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Th Erl him graunted his will y-wis. that the knicht him haden y told.<br></span>
<span class="i0">The Baronnis that were of mikle pris. befor him thay weren y-cald."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>36. Another mutilated tale or romance (No. iii.
four leaves). The first lines at present are,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"To Mr. Steward wil y gon.  and tellen him the sothe of the<br></span>
<span class="i0">Reseyved bestow sone anon.  gif you will serve and with hir be."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>37. A mutilated tale or romance (No. xi. in thirteen
leaves). The two first lines that occur are,</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"That riche Dooke his fest gan hold<br></span>
<span class="i0">With Erls and with Baronns bold."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>I cannot conclude my account of this curious manuscript,
without acknowledging that I was indebted
to the friendship of the Rev. Dr. Blair, the ingenious<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_375">[Pg 375]</a></span>
professor of Belles Lettres, in the University of
Edinburgh, for whatever I learned of its contents,
and for the important additions it enabled me to
make to the foregoing list.</p>
<p>To the preceding articles two ancient metrical romances
in the Scottish dialect may now be added,
which are published in Pinkerton's <i>Scottish Poems</i>,
reprinted "from scarce editions," Lond. 1792, in 3
vols. 8vo. viz.</p>
<p>38. <i>Gawan and Gologras</i>, a metrical romance;
from an edition printed at Edinburgh, 1508, 8vo.
beginning:—</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"In the tyme of Arthur, as trew men me tald."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>It is in stanzas of thirteen lines.</p>
<p>39. <i>Sir Gawan and Sir Galaron of Galloway</i>, a
metrical romance, in the same stanzas as No. 38,
from an ancient MS. beginning thus:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"In the tyme of Arthur an aunter<a id="FNanchor_526"></a><a class="fnanchor pginternal" href="#Footnote_526">[526]</a> betydde<br></span>
<span class="i0">By the Turnwathelan, as the boke tells;<br></span>
<span class="i0">Whan he to Carlele was comen, and conqueror kyd," &amp;c.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>Both these (which exhibit the union of the old
alliterative metre, with rhyme, &amp;c., and in the termination
of each stanza the short triplets of the
Turnament of Tottenham), are judged to be as old
as the time of our K. Henry VI., being apparently
the production of an old poet, thus mentioned
by Dunbar, in his <i>Lament for the Deth of the</i>
<i>Makkaris</i>:</p>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Clerk of Tranent eik he hes take,<br></span>
<span class="i0">That made the aventers of Sir Gawane."<br></span>
</div></div>
<p>It will scarce be necessary to remind the reader,
that <i>Turnewathelan</i> is evidently <i>Tearne-Wadling</i>,
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_376">[Pg 376]</a></span>celebrated in the old ballad of the <i>Marriage of Sir</i>
<i>Gawaine</i>. See pp. <a href="#Page_14" class="pginternal">14</a> and <a href="#Page_325" class="pginternal">325</a> of this volume.</p>
<p>Many new references, and perhaps some additional
articles might be added to the foregoing list from
Mr. Warton's <i>History of English Poetry</i>, 3 vols. 4to.
and from the notes to Mr. Tyrwhitt's improved
edition of <i>Chaucer's Canterbury Tales</i>, &amp;c. in 5 vols.
8vo. which have been published since this Essay, &amp;c.
was first composed; but it will be sufficient once for
all to refer the curious reader to those popular
works.</p>
<p>The reader will also see many interesting particulars
on the subject of these volumes, as well as on
most points of general literature, in Sir John Hawkins's
curious <i>History of Music</i>, &amp;c., in 5 volumes,
4to., as also in Dr. Burney's <i>Hist.</i> &amp;c. in 4 vols. 4to.</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[Much has been written upon the subject of this Essay since
Percy's time, but no exhaustive work has yet appeared. The
reader may consult W. C. Hazlitt's new edition of Warton's
<i>History</i>, 1871; Ellis's <i>Specimens of Early English Metrical Romances</i>,
new edition, by J. O. Halliwell, 1848; Dunlop's <i>History</i>
<i>of Fiction</i>; J. M. Ludlow's <i>Popular Epics of the Middle Ages,</i>
<i>Norse, German, and Carlovingian Cycles</i>, 1865; G. W. Cox and
E. H. Jones's <i>Popular Romances of the Middle Ages</i>, 1871; and
also the prefaces of the various old English romances printed by
the Percy, Camden, and Early English Text Societies; and by the
Abbotsford, Bannatyne, and Roxburghe Clubs.]</p></div>
<p><span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_377">[Pg 377]</a></span></p>

<i>of the Rise and Progress of Poetry</i>.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
