c. ii.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_467"></a><a href="#FNanchor_467" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[467]</span></a> <i>Barth. Antiq. Dan.</i> lib. i. cap. x. <i>Wormii Literatura Runica</i>,
ad finem.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_468"></a><a href="#FNanchor_468" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[468]</span></a> See <i>Northern Antiquities, or a Description of the Manners,</i>
<i>Customs, &amp;c., of the ancient Danes and other Northern Nations,</i>
<i>translated from the Fr. of M. Mallet</i>, 1770, 2 vols. 8vo. (vol. i.
p. 49, &amp;c.)</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_469"></a><a href="#FNanchor_469" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[469]</span></a> <i>Vid. infra</i>, pp. 341, 342, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_470"></a><a href="#FNanchor_470" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[470]</span></a> Viz. <i>Astræa</i>, <i>Cassandra</i>, <i>Clelia</i>, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_471"></a><a href="#FNanchor_471" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[471]</span></a> Mallet, vid. <i>Northern Antiquities</i>, vol. i. p. 318, &amp;c.; vol. ii.
p. 234, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_472"></a><a href="#FNanchor_472" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[472]</span></a> <i>Letters concerning Chivalry</i>, 8vo. 1763.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_473"></a><a href="#FNanchor_473" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[473]</span></a> Mallet.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_474"></a><a href="#FNanchor_474" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[474]</span></a> Mallet.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_475"></a><a href="#FNanchor_475" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[475]</span></a> The seeds of chivalry sprung up so naturally out of the
original manners and opinions of the northern nations, that it is
not credible they arose so late as after the establishment of the
Feudal System, much less the Crusades. Nor, again, that the
romances of chivalry were transmitted to other nations, through
the Spaniards, from the Moors and Arabians. Had this been the
case the first French romances of chivalry would have been on
Moorish, or at least Spanish subjects: whereas the most ancient
stories of this kind, whether in prose or verse, whether in Italian,
French, English, &amp;c., are chiefly on the subjects of Charlemagne
and the Paladins, or of our British Arthur and his Knights of the
Round Table, &amp;c., being evidently borrowed from the fabulous
chronicles of the supposed Archbishop Turpin and of Jeffery of
Monmouth. Not but some of the oldest and most popular French
romances are also on Norman subjects, as <i>Richard Sans-peur</i>,
<i>Robert le Diable</i>, &amp;c., whereas I do not recollect so much as one
in which the scene is laid in Spain, much less among the Moors,
or descriptive of Mahometan manners. Even in <i>Amadis de Gaul</i>,
said to have been the first romance printed in Spain, the scene is
laid in Gaul and Britain; and the manners are French: which
plainly shews from what school this species of fabling was learnt
and transmitted to the southern nations of Europe.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_476"></a><a href="#FNanchor_476" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[476]</span></a> Mallet. <i>North. Antiquities</i>, vol. i. p. 36; vol. ii. <i>passim</i>.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_477"></a><a href="#FNanchor_477" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[477]</span></a> <i>Olaus Verelius, Herv. Saga</i>, pp. 44, 45. Hickes's <i>Thesaur.</i>
vol. ii. p. 311. <i>Northern Antiquities</i>, vol. ii. <i>passim</i>.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_478"></a><a href="#FNanchor_478" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[478]</span></a> <i>Ibid.</i> vol. i. pp. 69, 374, &amp;c.; vol. ii. p. 216, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_479"></a><a href="#FNanchor_479" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[479]</span></a> Rollof's <i>Saga</i>, c. 35, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_480"></a><a href="#FNanchor_480" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[480]</span></a> It is peculiarly unfortunate that such as maintain this opinion
are obliged to take their first step from the Moorish provinces in
Spain, without one intermediate resting place, to Armorica or
Bretagne, the province in France from them most remote, not
more in situation than in the manners, habits, and language of its
Welsh inhabitants, which are allowed to have been derived from
this island, as must have been their traditions, songs, and fables;
being doubtless all of Celtic original. See p. <a href="#Page_3" class="pginternal">3</a> of the <i>Dissertation</i>
<i>on the Origin of Romantic Fiction in Europe</i>, prefixed to Mr. Tho.
Warton's <i>History of English Poetry</i>, vol. i. 1774, 4to. If any pen
could have supported this darling hypothesis of Dr. Warburton
that of this ingenious critic would have effected it. But under the
general term Oriental, he seems to consider the ancient inhabitants
of the north and the south of Asia, as having all the same manners,
traditions, and fables; and because the secluded people of
Arabia took the lead under the religion and empire of Mahomet,
therefore everything must be derived from them to the Northern
Asiatics in the remotest ages, &amp;c. With as much reason under
the word Occidental, we might represent the early traditions and
fables of the north and south of Europe to have been the same;
and that the Gothic mythology of Scandinavia, the Druidic or
Celtic of Gaul and Britain, differed not from the classic of Greece
and Rome.
</p>
<p>
There is not room here for a full examination of the minuter
arguments, or rather slight coincidences, by which our agreeable
dissertator endeavours to maintain and defend this favourite
opinion of Dr. W., who has been himself so completely confuted
by Mr. Tyrwhitt. (See his notes on <i>Love's Labour Lost</i>, &amp;c.)
But some of his positions it will be sufficient to mention: such as
the referring the Gog and Magog, which our old Christian bards
might have had from Scripture, to the <i>Jaguiouge</i> and <i>Magiouge</i> of
the Arabians and Persians, &amp;c. (p. <a href="#Page_13" class="pginternal">13</a>). That "we may venture
to affirm that this (Geoffrey of Monmouth's) Chronicle, supposed
to contain the ideas of the Welsh bards, entirely consists of Arabian
inventions" (p. <a href="#Page_13" class="pginternal">13</a>). And that, "as Geoffrey's history is the
grand repository of the acts of Arthur, so a fabulous history
ascribed to Turpin is the groundwork of all the chimerical legends
which have been related concerning the conquests of Charlemagne
and his twelve peers. Its subject is the expulsion of the Saracens
from Spain, and it is filled with fictions evidently congenial to
those which characterize Geoffrey's History" (p. <a href="#Page_17" class="pginternal">17</a>). That is, as
he afterwards expresses it, "lavishly decorated by the Arabian
fablers" (p. <a href="#Page_58" class="pginternal">58</a>). We should hardly have expected that the Arabian
fablers would have been lavish in decorating a history of their
enemy: but what is singular, as an instance and proof of this
Arabian origin of the fictions of Turpin, a passage is quoted from
his fourth chapter, which I shall beg leave to offer, as affording
decisive evidence, that they could not possibly be derived from a
Mahometan source. Sc. "The Christians under Charlemagne are
said to have found in Spain a golden idol, or image of Mahomet,
as high as a bird can fly—it was framed by Mahomet himself of
the purest metal, who, by his knowledge in necromancy, had
sealed up within it a legion of diabolical spirits. It held in its
hand a prodigious club; and the Saracens had a prophetic tradition,
that this club should fall from the hand of the image in that
year when a certain king should be born in France, &amp;c." (<i>vid.</i>
p. <a href="#Page_18" class="pginternal">18</a>, note.)</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_481"></a><a href="#FNanchor_481" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[481]</span></a> The little narrative songs on Morisco subjects, which the
Spaniards have at present in great abundance, and which they call
peculiarly <i>romances</i>, (see vol. i. book iii. no. xvi. &amp;c.), have nothing
in common with their proper romances (or histories) of chivalry,
which they call <i>Historias de Cavallerias</i>; these are evidently imitations
of the French, and shew a great ignorance of Moorish
manners: and with regard to the Morisco, or song <i>romances</i>, they
do not seem of very great antiquity; few of them appear, from
their subjects, much earlier than the reduction of Granada, in the
fifteenth century: from which period, I believe, may be plainly
traced among the Spanish writers, a more perfect knowledge of
Moorish customs, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_482"></a><a href="#FNanchor_482" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[482]</span></a> See <i>Northern Antiquities</i>, passim.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_483"></a><a href="#FNanchor_483" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[483]</span></a> <i>Ibid.</i></p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_484"></a><a href="#FNanchor_484" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[484]</span></a> <i>Saxon Gram.</i> p. 152, 153. Mallet, <i>North. Antiq.</i> vol. i.
p. 321.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">

latter kind. It was probably from this custom of the minstrels
that some of our first historians wrote their chronicles in verse, as
Rob. of Gloucester, Harding, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_488"></a><a href="#FNanchor_488" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[488]</span></a> See a specimen in 2d vol. of <i>Northern Antiquities</i>, &amp;c.,

<div class="footnote">

<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_490"></a><a href="#FNanchor_490" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[490]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> Northern men, being chiefly emigrants from Norway,
Denmark, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_491"></a><a href="#FNanchor_491" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[491]</span></a> See the account of Taillefer in vol. i. Essay, and Note.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_492"></a><a href="#FNanchor_492" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[492]</span></a> "Ipsa Carmina memoriæ mandabant, &amp; prælia inituri decantabant;
qua memoriâ tam fortium gestorum a majoribus patratorum
ad imitationem animus adderetur."—<i>Jornandes de Gothis.</i></p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_493"></a><a href="#FNanchor_493" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[493]</span></a> <i>Eginhartus de Carolo magno.</i> "Item barbara, &amp; antiquissima
carmina, quibus veterum regum actus &amp; bella canebantur,
scripsit."—c. 29.
</p>
<p>
<i>Asserius de Ælfredo magno.</i> "Rex inter bella, &amp;c.... Saxonicos libros recitare, &amp; <i>maxime carmina Saxonica</i> memoriter
discere, aliis imperare, &amp; solus assidue pro viribus, studiosissime
non desinebat."—Ed. 1722, 8vo. p. 43.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_494"></a><a href="#FNanchor_494" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[494]</span></a> See above, pp. <a href="#Page_340" class="pginternal">340</a>, 347.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_495"></a><a href="#FNanchor_495" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[495]</span></a> The romances on the subject of Perceval, San Graal,
Lancelot du Lac, Tristan, &amp;c., were among the first that appeared
in the French language in prose, yet these were originally composed
in metre: the editor has in his possession a very old French
MS. in verse, containing <i>L'ancien Roman de Perceval</i>, and metrical
copies of the others may be found in the libraries of the curious.
See a note of Wanley's in <i>Harl. Catalog. Num.</i> 2252, p. 49, &amp;c.
Nicholson's <i>Eng. Hist. Library</i>, 3rd ed. p. 91, &amp;c. See also a
curious collection of old French romances, with Mr. Wanley's
account of this sort of pieces, in <i>Harl. MSS. Catal.</i> 978, 106.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_496"></a><a href="#FNanchor_496" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[496]</span></a> The author of the <i>Essay on the Genius of Pope</i>, p. 282.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_497"></a><a href="#FNanchor_497" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[497]</span></a> <i>Ibid.</i> p. 283. <i>Hist. Lit.</i> tom. 6, 7.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_498"></a><a href="#FNanchor_498" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[498]</span></a> <i>Voir Preface aux</i> "Fabliaux &amp; Contes des Poetes François
des xii. xiii. xiv. &amp; xv. siècles, &amp;c., Paris, 1756, 3 tom. 12mo." (a
very curious work).</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_499"></a><a href="#FNanchor_499" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[499]</span></a> <i>Vid. supra</i>, note (d), vol. i. Essay, &amp;c. <i>Et vide</i> Rapin,
Carte, &amp;c. This song of <i>Roland</i> (whatever it was) continued for
some centuries to be usually sung by the French in their marches,
if we may believe a modern French writer. "Un jour qu'on
chantoit la <i>Chanson de Roland</i>, comme c'etoit l'usage dans les
marches. Il y a long temps, dit il (John K. of France, who died
in 1364), qu'on ne voit plus de Rolands parmi les François. On
y verroit encore des Rolands, lui répondit un vieux capitaine,
s'ils avoient un Charlemagne à leur tête." <i>Vid.</i> tom. iii. p. 202,
<i>des Essaies Hist. sur Paris, de M. de Saintefoix</i>: who gives as his
authority, Boethius in <i>Hist. Scotorum</i>. This author, however,
speaks of the complaint and repartee, as made in an Assembly of
the States (<i>vocato senatu</i>), and not upon any march, &amp;c. <i>Vid.</i>
Boeth. lib. xv. vol. 327. Ed. Paris, 1574.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_500"></a><a href="#FNanchor_500" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[500]</span></a> See on this subject, vol. i. note, s. 2, p. 404; and in note
G g, p. 424, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_501"></a><a href="#FNanchor_501" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[501]</span></a> The first romances of chivalry among the Germans were in
metre: they have some very ancient narrative songs (which they
call <i>Lieder</i>) not only on the fabulous heroes of their own country,
but also on those of France and Britain, as Tristram, Arthur,
Gawain, and the knights <i>von der Tafel-ronde</i> (<i>vid.</i> Goldasti Not. in
<i>Eginhart. Vit. Car. Mag.</i> 4to. 1711, p. 207.)</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_502"></a><a href="#FNanchor_502" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[502]</span></a> The Welsh have still some very old romances about K.
Arthur; but as these are in prose, they are not probably their first
pieces that were composed on that subject.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_503"></a><a href="#FNanchor_503" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[503]</span></a> It is most credible that these stories were originally of
English invention, even if the only pieces now extant should be
found to be translations from the French. What now pass for the
French originals were probably only amplifications, or enlargements
of the old English story. That the French romances borrowed
some things from the English, appears from the word
<i>termagant</i>.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_504"></a><a href="#FNanchor_504" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[504]</span></a> <i>Recuyel of the Hystoryes of Troy</i>, 1471; <i>Godfroye of Boloyne</i>,
1481; <i>Le Morte de Arthur</i>, 1485; <i>The Life of Charlemagne</i>, 1485,
&amp;c. As the old minstrelsy wore out, prose books of chivalry
became more admired, especially after the Spanish romances began
to be translated into English towards the end of Q. Elizabeth's
reign: then the most popular metrical romances began to be
reduced into prose, as <i>Sir Guy</i>, <i>Bevis</i>, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_505"></a><a href="#FNanchor_505" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[505]</span></a> See extract from a letter, written by the editor of these
volumes, in Mr. Warton's <i>Observations</i>, vol. ii. p. 139.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_506"></a><a href="#FNanchor_506" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[506]</span></a> <i>Canterbury Tales</i> (Tyrwhitt's edit.), vol. ii. p. 238. In all
the former editions which I have seen the name at the end of the
fourth line is <i>Blandamoure</i>.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_507"></a><a href="#FNanchor_507" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[507]</span></a> Dr. Grey has shewn that the same story is alluded to in
Rastell's <i>Chronicle</i>: as it was doubtless originally had from the
romance, this is proof that the old metrical romances throw light
on our first writers in prose: many of our ancient historians have
recorded the fictions of romance.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_508"></a><a href="#FNanchor_508" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[508]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> handkerchiefs. Here we have the etymology of the
word, viz. "<i>Couvre le Chef</i>."</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_509"></a><a href="#FNanchor_509" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[509]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> slipt aside.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_510"></a><a href="#FNanchor_510" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[510]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> yawned.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_511"></a><a href="#FNanchor_511" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[511]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> hurt.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_512"></a><a href="#FNanchor_512" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[512]</span></a> Dr. Warburton.—Dr. Grey.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_513"></a><a href="#FNanchor_513" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[513]</span></a> So it is intitled in the editor's MS. But the true title is <i>Le</i>
<i>Beaux Disconus</i>, or the Fair Unknown. See a note on the <i>Canterbury</i>
<i>Tales</i>, vol. iv. p. 333.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_514"></a><a href="#FNanchor_514" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[514]</span></a> Vid. <i>Discours sur la Poesie Epique</i>, prefixed to <i>Télémaque</i>.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_515"></a><a href="#FNanchor_515" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[515]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> May all they be blithe that to my song listen: A song
I shall you sing, Of Allof the good king, &amp;c.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_516"></a><a href="#FNanchor_516" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[516]</span></a> In each full page of this volume are forty-four lines, when the
poem is in long metre: and eighty-eight when the metre is short,
and the page in two columns.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_517"></a><a href="#FNanchor_517" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[517]</span></a> Sign. K. 2. b.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_518"></a><a href="#FNanchor_518" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[518]</span></a> For this and most of the following, which are mentioned as
preserved in the Public Library, I refer the reader to the <i>Oxon</i>
<i>Catalogue of MSS.</i>, 1697, vol. ii p. 394; in Appendix to Bp.
More's MSS. No. 690, 33, since given to the University of Cambridge.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_519"></a><a href="#FNanchor_519" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[519]</span></a> No. 690, § 31. Vid. <i>Catalog. MSS.</i> p. 394.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_520"></a><a href="#FNanchor_520" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[520]</span></a> In the former editions, after the above, followed mention of
a fragment in the same MS., intitled, <i>Sir Lionel</i>, in distichs (p. <a href="#Page_32" class="pginternal">32</a>)
[pr. ed. vol. i. p. 75]; but this being only a short ballad, and not
relating to K. Arthur, is here omitted.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_521"></a><a href="#FNanchor_521" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[521]</span></a> The French original is preserved among the Harl. MSS.
No. 978, § 112, <i>Lanval</i>.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_522"></a><a href="#FNanchor_522" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[522]</span></a> See Laneham's <i>Letter concern. Q. Eliz. entertainment at</i>
<i>Killingworth</i>, 1575, 12mo. p. 34.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_523"></a><a href="#FNanchor_523" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[523]</span></a> No. 690. (30.) <i>Vid. Oxon Catalog. MSS.</i> p. 394.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_524"></a><a href="#FNanchor_524" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[524]</span></a> This is alluded to by Shakespeare in his <i>Hen. V.</i> (Act v.),
where Fluellyn tells Pistol, he will make him a squire of low
degree, when he means, to knock him down.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_525"></a><a href="#FNanchor_525" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[525]</span></a> Some of these I give, though mutilated and divested of their
titles, because they may enable a curious inquirer to complete or
improve other copies.</p></div>
<div class="footnote">
<p><a id="Footnote_526"></a><a href="#FNanchor_526" class="pginternal"><span class="label">[526]</span></a> <i>i.e.</i> adventure.</p></div></div>

</div>
<h2><a id="GLOSSARY">GLOSSARY</a><br>

TO THE THREE VOLUMES.</h2>
<div>
<img alt="" class="drop-capi" height="100" src="images/i377t.png" id="img_images_i377t.png">
</div>
<p class="drop-capa"><span class="smcap">This</span> is an amalgamation of the three original
glossaries, with large additions and
alterations, and the introduction of references.
It has not, however, been thought
necessary to refer to every passage in which a particular
word may occur.</p>
<p>Percy's explanatory notes are marked with the
letter P.</p>
<p>Many words which appear in a slightly varied
form from the present spelling are not included in
this glossary.</p>
<p>
A', <i>all</i>.<br>
<br>
A, <i>at</i>.<br>
<br>
A, i. 27, <i>of</i>.<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">Watter a Twyde, i. 25, <i>water of Tweed</i>.<br></span>
<br>
Abacke, <i>back</i>.<br>
<br>
Abenche, i. 409, <i>on a bench</i>.<br>
<br>
Able, i. 87, <i>fit</i>, <i>suitable</i>.<br>
<br>
Abone, i. 24;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">aboon, i. 323;</span><br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">aboone, i. 101;</span><br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">aboun, i. 32, <i>above</i>.</span><br>
<br>
Aboven ous, ii. 8, <i>above us</i>.<br>
<br>
Abowght, i. 40, <i>about</i>.<br>
<br>
Abraide, i. 168, <i>abroad</i>.<br>
<br>
Abuve, ii. 83, <i>in the uplands</i>.<br>
<br>
Abye, iii. <a href="#Page_31" class="pginternal">31</a>, <i>suffer</i>, <i>pay for</i>, <i>expiate</i>.<br>
<br>
Acton, i. 72, <i>a quilted leather jacket, worn under the coat of mail</i>. Fr. hacqueton.<br>
<br>
Advoutry, ii. 136, <i>adultery</i>.<br>
<br>
Aff, ii. 70, <i>off</i>.<br>
<br>
Affore, i. 269;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">afore, ii. 115, <i>before</i>.<br></span>
<br>
Aft, i. 321, <i>oft</i>.<br>
<br>
Agayne, i. 121, <i>against</i>.<br>
<br>
Ageyn, i. 119, <i>against</i>.<br>
<br>
Agone, ii. 41, <i>gone</i>.<br>
<br>
Ahte, ii. 11, <i>ought</i>.<br>
<br>
Aik, iii. <a href="#Page_147" class="pginternal">147</a>, <i>oak</i>.<br>
<br>
Ail, ii. 84, <i>trouble</i>.<br>
<br>
Ain, i. 102, <i>own</i>.<br>
<br>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_378">[Pg 378]</a></span>Aith, ii. 70, <i>oath</i>.<br>
<br>
Al, ii. 9, <i>albeit</i>, <i>although</i>.<br>
<br>
Al gife, <i>although</i>.<br>
<br>
Alace, iii. <a href="#Page_236" class="pginternal">236</a>, <i>alas</i>.<br>
<br>
Alane, ii. 83, <i>alone</i>.<br>
<br>
Alemaigne, ii. 7, <i>Germany</i>.<br>
<br>
Allgyf, i. 125, <i>although</i>.<br>
<br>
Almaine, iii. <a href="#Page_110" class="pginternal">110</a>, <i>Germany</i>.<br>
<br>
Alyes, ii. 33, <i>always</i>.<br>
<br>
Amang, ii. 20, <i>among</i>.<br>
<br>
Amangis, ii. 81, <i>amongst</i>.<br>
<br>
Amblit, iii. <a href="#Page_237" class="pginternal">237</a>, <i>ambled</i>.<br>
<br>
Among, ii. 35, <i>at intervals</i>, <i>sometimes</i>.<br>
<br>
An, <i>and</i>.<br>
<br>
An, i, 60, <i>if</i>.<br>
<br>
Ancyent, i. 271, <i>flag</i>, <i>banner</i>, <i>standard</i>.<br>
<br>
And, <i>if</i>, but and, i. 27;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;"><i>but if</i>; and youe, <i>if you</i>.<br></span>
<br>
And but, ii. 15, <i>and unless</i>.<br>
<br>
Ane, i. 30, ii. 118, <i>one</i>, <i>an</i>, <i>a</i>.<br>
<br>
Anes, ii. 112, <i>once</i>, ii. 109. (?)<br>
<br>
Angel, ii. 176, <i>a gold coin varying in value from 6s. 8d. to 10s.</i><br>

<br>
Avaunce, ii. 49, <i>advance</i>.<br>
<br>
Avow, iii. <a href="#Page_327" class="pginternal">327</a>;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">avowe, i. 23, 34, 47, 172;<br></span>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">ii. 23, 58, <i>vow</i>.<br></span>
<br>
Aw, iii. <a href="#Page_145" class="pginternal">145</a>, <i>all</i>.<br>
<br>
Awa', ii. 69, <i>away</i>.<br>
<br>
Awin, ii. 133, <i>own</i>.<br>
<br>
Awne, i. 121, 274, <i>own</i>.<br>
<br>
Axed, i. 129, <i>asked</i>.<br>
<br>
Ay, ii. 70, <i>ever</i>;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">also <i>ah!</i> <i>alas!</i><br></span>
<br>
Ayein, ii. 12, <i>against</i>.<br>
<br>
Ayont the ingle, ii. 68, <i>beyond the fire</i>.<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;"><i>The fire was in the middle</i>
<i>of the room</i>.<br></span>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"In the west of Scotland, at
this present time, in many cottages,
they pile their peats and
turfs upon stones in the middle
of the room. There is a hole
above the fire in the ridge of the
house to let the smoke out at.
In some places are cottage-houses,
from the front of which
a very wide chimney projects
like a bow-window: the fire is
in a grate, like a malt-kiln grate,
round which the people sit:
sometimes they draw this grate
into the middle of the room."
(Mr. Lambe.) P.</p></div>
<p>
<br>Ba', i. 59, <i>ball.</i><br>
<br>
Bacheleere, i. 64, 78, <i>knight</i>;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">bachelary, ii. 28;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">bachelery, ii. 23, <i>company of bachelors</i>.</span><br></span>

Badena, iii. <a href="#Page_93" class="pginternal">93</a>, <i>delayed not</i>.<br>

<div class="blockquot">
<p>Mr. Lambe also interprets  "Bickering," by rattling, <i>e.g.</i>,</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">And on that slee Ulysses head<br></span>
<span class="i0">Sad curses down does <span class="smcap">BICKER</span>.<br></span>
</div></div>
<p class="stageright">Translat. of Ovid. P.</p>
<p>
Bide at hame, iii. <a href="#Page_97" class="pginternal">97</a>, <i>remain at home</i>.<br>

<span style="margin-left: 1em;">This word is incorrectly explained in the text as <i>crutch</i>. It is really a form of the French <i>crèche</i>, a crib or manger. It occurs as <i>cracche</i> in the "Promptorium Parv." (1440).<br></span>

<br>
Eldridge, i. 64, 78, <i>wild</i>, <i>hideous</i>, <i>ghostly</i>, <i>lonesome</i>, <i>uninhabited</i>.<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"In the ballad of <i>Sir Cauline</i>
we have 'Eldridge Hills,' p. <a href="#Page_65" class="pginternal">65</a>,
'Eldridge Knight,' p. <a href="#Page_65" class="pginternal">65</a>, 'Eldridge
Sword,' p. <a href="#Page_67" class="pginternal">67</a>. So Gawin
Douglas calls the Cyclops the
'Elriche Brethir,' <i>i.e.</i> brethren
(b. ii. p. 91, l. 16), and in his
Prologue to b. vii. (p. 202, l. 3)
he thus describes the Night-Owl:—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"'Laithely of forme, with crukit camscho beik,<br></span>
<span class="i0">'Ugsome to here was his wyld  <i>elrische</i> skreik.'<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"In Bannatyne's MS. Poems
(fol. 135, in the Advocate's Library
at Edinburgh) is a whimsical
rhapsody of a deceased old
woman travelling in the other
world; in which</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"'Scho wanderit, and yeid by, to an <i>Elrich</i> well.'<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"In the Glossary to G. Douglas,
Elriche, &amp;c. is explained
by 'Wild, hideous: Lat. <i>Trux</i>,
<i>immanis</i>;' but it seems to imply
somewhat more, as in Allan
Ramsay's Glossaries." P.</p></div>
<p>

<span style="margin-left: 1em;">fytte, i. 44, <i>part or division of a song</i>.</span><br>
<br>
Fitts, <i>i.e.</i> divisions or parts in music, are alluded to in "Troilus and Cressida," act. iii. sc. 1.<br>

<br>
Flote, i. 201.<br>
<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_387">[Pg 387]</a></span><span style="margin-left: 1em;">To flote is to flete or fleet, to flit, to change position easily, to move away quickly; as fleeting moments, flitting birds</span><br>
<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">Flote and flete are two forms of the same word; and flutter bears the same relation to flote that flitter does to flete.</span><br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">In the Roxburghe copy of the ballad of <i>Willow, Willow</i> this word is printed as "fleet." (Roxb. Ballads, ed. Chappell, part i. p. 172.)</span><br>

God before, <i>God be thy guide</i>, a form of blessing.<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">So in Shakespeare's "King  Hen. V." (A. iii. sc. 8) the King says:—</span><br>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">"My army's but a weak and sickly guard;</span><br>
<span style="margin-left: 2.5em;">Yet, God before, tell him we will come on." P.</span><br>

<br>
Growte, ii. 256.<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">In Northamptonshire is a kind of small beer extracted from the malt after the strength has been drawn off. In Devon it is a kind of sweet ale medicated with eggs, said to be a Danish liquor. (Growte is a kind of fare much used by Danish sailors, being boiled groats, <i>i.e.</i> hulled oats, or else shelled barley, served up very thick, and butter added to it.—<i>Mr. Lambe.</i>) P.</span><br>

<br>
Hech, ii. 27, <i>hatch</i>, <i>half door of a cottage</i> (sometimes spelt heck).<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">"Dogs leap the hatch," <i>King Lear</i>, act. iii. sc. 6.</span><br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">"'He'll have to ride the <i>hatch</i>' is a familiar phrase about Looe, and signifies 'He'll be brought to trial.' It is generally used jocosely in the case of any loud professor of religion who has been 'overtaken in a fault;' and the idea is that his trial will be the ordeal of attempting to ride or sit on the top or narrow edge of a hatch or half-door, when if he maintain his seat he will be pronounced innocent, if he fall he is guilty. If he fall inwards (<i>i.e.</i> within the room or building), he will be pardoned, but if he fall outwards, he will be excommunicated." W. Pengelly (<i>Devonshire Association Report</i>, vol. vii. p. 488).</span><br>
<br>
Hecht to lay thee law, <i>promised (engaged) to lay the law</i>.<br>

Holtis hair, ii. 81, 86, <i>hoary or grey woods or heaths</i>. <br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">"Holtes seems evidently to signify hills in the following passage from Turberville's "Songs and Sonnets," 12mo. 1567, fol. 56:—</span><br>
<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">"Yee that frequent the hilles,</span><br>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And highest Holtes of all;</span><br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">Assist me with your skilfull quilles,</span><br>
<span style="margin-left: 2em;">And listen when I call."</span><br>
<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">"As also in this other verse of an ancient poet:—</span><br>
<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">"Underneath the Holtes so hoar." P.</span><br>

</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"<i>Germanis</i> Camp, <i>Exercitum,</i>
<i>aut Locum ubi Exercitus</i>
<i>castrametatur, significat: inde</i>
<i>ipsis Vir Castrensis et Militaris</i>
kemffer, <i>et</i> kempher, <i>et</i> kemper,
<i>et</i> kimber, <i>et</i> kamper, <i>pro varietate</i>
<i>dialectorum, vocatur: Vocabulum</i>
<i>hoc nostro sermone</i>
<i>nondum penitus exolevit; Nor</i>
<i>folcienses enim plebeio et proletario</i>
<i>sermone dicunt</i>. 'He is a
kemper old man, <i>i.e. Senex Vegetus</i>
<i>est:' Hinc</i> Cimbris <i>suum</i>
<i>nomen</i>: 'kimber <i>enim Homo</i>
<i>bellicosus, pugil, robustus miles,</i>
<i>&amp;c. significat</i>.' Sheringham de
Anglor. gentis. orig. pag. 57. <i>Rectius</i>
<i>autem Lazius</i> [apud eundem,
p. <a href="#Page_49" class="pginternal">49</a>]. 'Cimbros <i>a bello quod</i>
kamff, <i>et Saxonice</i> kamp <i>nuncupatos</i>
<i>crediderim: unde bellatores</i>
<i>viri</i> Die Kempffer, Die
Kemper.'" P.</p></div>

<div class="blockquot">
<p>"Bale, in his 'Actes of Eng.
Votaries' (part ii. fol. 53), uses
the word Kyrtle to signify a
monk's frock. He says, Roger,
Earl of Shrewsbury, when he
was dying, sent 'to Clunyake,
in France, for the kyrtle of holy
Hugh the abbot there,' &amp;c." P.</p></div>

Lothly, ii. 142, <i>loathsome</i>.<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"The adverbial terminations
<i>-some</i> and <i>-ly</i> were applied indifferently
by our old writers:
thus, as we have <i>lothly</i> for
<i>loathsome</i> above, so we have
<i>ugsome</i> in a sense not very
remote from <i>ugly</i> in Lord Surrey's
version of Æn. 2nd, viz.—</p>
<p>"'In every place the ugsome sightes I saw' (p. <a href="#Page_29" class="pginternal">29</a>)." P.</p></div>

<br>
Makys, i. 33, <i>mates</i>.<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"As the words make and mate
were, in some cases, used promiscuously
by ancient writers,
so the words cake and cate
seem to have been applied with
the same indifferency; this will
illustrate that common English
proverb, 'to turn cat (<i>i.e.</i> cate)
in pan.' A pancake is in Northamptonshire
still called a pancate." P.</p></div>

Maze, <i>a labyrinth</i>, <i>anything entangled or intricate</i>.<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"On the top of Catherine-hill,
Winchester (the usual play-place
of the school), was a very perplexed
and winding path, running
in a very small space over a great
deal of ground, called a Miz-Maze.
The senior boys obliged
the juniors to tread it, to prevent
the figure from being lost, as I
am informed by an ingenious
correspondent." P.</p></div>

</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"Outrake is a common term
among shepherds. When their
sheep have a free passage from
enclosed pastures into open and
airy grounds they call it a good
outrake." (Mr. Lambe.) P.</p></div>

Pious chanson, i. 183, <i>a godly song or ballad</i>.<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"Mr. Rowe's Edition of Shakespeare
has 'The first Row of
the Rubrick;' which has been
supposed by Dr. Warburton to
refer to the red-lettered titles of
old ballads. In the large collection
made by Mr. Pepys, I do
not remember to have seen one
single ballad with its title printed
in red letters." P.</p></div>

<div class="blockquot">
<p>Sowle is still used in the north
for anything eaten with bread.
P.</p></div>

<br>

<br>
Speere, ii. 144;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">speered, ii. 144, <i>sparred</i>, <i>fastened</i>, <i>shut</i>.</span><br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>So in an old "Treatyse
agaynst Pestilence, etc. 4to
Emprynted by Wynkyn de
Worde:" we are exhorted to
"Spere [i.e. shut or bar] the
wyndowes ayenst the south."
fol. 5. P.</p></div>

<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_403">[Pg 403]</a></span>Speik, iii. <a href="#Page_96" class="pginternal">96</a>, <i>speak</i>.<br>

Speir, ii. 69;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">iii. <a href="#Page_95" class="pginternal">95</a>, <i>ask</i>, <i>inquire</i>.<br></span>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>So Chaucer, in his Rhyme of
Sir Thopas—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">——"He foughte north and south,<br></span>
<span class="i0">And oft he spired with his mouth."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p><i>i.e.</i> "inquired." Not spied, as
in the new edit. of Cant. Tales,
vol. ii. p. 234. P.</p></div>
<p>
Speir, iii. <a href="#Page_98" class="pginternal">98</a>, <i>spear</i>.<br>
<br>
Spek, ii. 12, <i>spoke</i>;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">speken, iii. <a href="#Page_207" class="pginternal">207</a>, <i>speak</i>.</span><br>
<br>
Spence, ii. 52;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">spens, ii. 21, <i>expense</i>.</span><br>
<br>
Spendyd, <i>grasped</i>.<br>
<br>
Spill, i. 196, iii. <a href="#Page_51" class="pginternal">51</a>;<br>
<span style="margin-left: 1em;">spille, i. 75, <i>spoil</i>, <i>kill</i>.</span><br>
<br>
Spillan, iii. <a href="#Page_134" class="pginternal">134</a>, <i>spilling</i>.<br>
<br>
Spindles and whorles, ii. 71, <i>the instruments used for spinning in Scotland instead of spinning-wheels</i>.<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"The Rock, Spindles, and
Whorles are very much used
in Scotland and the northern
parts of Northumberland at
this time. The thread for
shoemakers, and even some
linen webs, and all the twine
of which the Tweed salmon-nets
are made, are spun upon
spindles. They are said to make
a more even and smooth thread
than spinning-wheels." (<i>Mr.</i>
<i>Lambe.</i>) P.</p></div>
<p>

<div class="blockquot">

North to signify dust agitated
and put in motion, as by the
sweeping of a room, &amp;c. P.</p></div>

<div class="blockquot">
<p>To swarm, in the midland
counties, is to draw oneself up a
tree or any other thing, clinging
to it with the legs and arms. P.</p></div>

Swepyls, ii. 25,<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"a swepyl is that
staff of the flail with which the
corn is beaten out. Vulg. a
supple (called in the midland
counties a swindgell, where the
other part is termed the hand-staff)." P.</p></div>

Tent, ii. 83, <i>heed</i>.<br>
<br>
Termagaunt, i. 85, 96, <i>the god of the Saracens</i>.<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>The old French Romancers,
who had corrupted <i>Termagant</i>
into <i>Tervagant</i>, couple it with
the name of Mahomet as constantly
as ours; thus in the old
<i>Roman de Blanchardin</i>,</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Cy guerpison tuit Apolin,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Et Mahomet et <i>Tervagant</i>."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>Hence La Fontaine, with great
humour, in his Tale, intitled <i>La</i>
<i>Fiancée du Roy de Garbe</i>, says,</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Et reniant Mahom, Jupin, et <i>Tervagant</i>,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Avec maint autre Dieu non moins extravagant."<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>—<i>Mem. de l'Acad. des Inscript.</i>
<i>tom.</i> 20, 4to. p. 352.</p>
<p>As <i>Termagant</i> is evidently of
Anglo-Saxon derivation and can<span class="pagenum"><a id="Page_405">[Pg 405]</a></span>
only be explained from the elements
of that language, its being
corrupted by the old French Romancers
proves that they borrowed
some things from ours. P.</p></div>
<p>
Terrene, iii. <a href="#Page_299" class="pginternal">299</a>, <i>earthly</i>.<br>
<br>
Terry, ii. 19, <i>Thierry</i>, or a <i>diminutive of Terence</i>.<br>

Too-fall, ii. 365, <i>twilight</i>.<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>"Too-fall of the night" seems
to be an image drawn from a
suspended canopy, so let fall as
to cover what is below. (<i>Mr.</i>
<i>Lambe.</i>) P.</p></div>

<br>
Wane, i. 29, <i>the same as</i> ane, <i>one</i>, <i>so</i> wone <i>is one</i>.<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>In fol. 355 of Bannatyne's
MS. is a short fragment, in
which "wane" is used for
"ane" or "one," viz.:—</p></div>
<div class="poem"><div class="stanza">
<span class="i0">"Amongst the monsters that we find,<br></span>
<span class="i0">There's <i>wane</i> belovved of woman-kind,<br></span>
<span class="i0">Renowned for antiquity,<br></span>
<span class="i0">From Adame drivs his pedigree." P.<br></span>
</div></div>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>The word wane in the text,
however, is probably a misreading
for mane.</p></div>

</p>
<hr class="tb">
<div class="blockquot">
<p>[In several of the poems Percy
used the letter z to represent the
Anglo-Saxon character ȝ, but as
this is incorrect, and, moreover,
gives rise to a very frequent mispronunciation,
the z has been
replaced by y in this edition,
and several words have therefore
been left out that occurred
in the original glossary.]</p></div>
<hr class="tb">
<p>
Zacring bell, ii. 288, <i>sacring bell</i>,<br>
</p>
<div class="blockquot">
<p>a little bell rung to give notice
of the elevation of the host. P.</p></div>

<h2> <a id="INDEX">INDEX<br>
TO THE THREE VOLUMES.</a></h2>
<p class="center">The Titles of the various Poems included in the <i>Reliques</i> are distinguished
from the other entries by being printed in italics.</p>

<i>—— The Stedfast Shepherd</i>, III. <a href="#Page_253" class="pginternal">253</a>-<a href="#Page_255" class="pginternal">255</a>.<br>
<br>
Wokey-hole in Somersetshire, I. 325.<br>
<br>
Wortley (Sir Thomas), III. <a href="#Page_282" class="pginternal">282</a>.<br>
<br>
Wotton (Sir H.), <i>Character of a Happy Life</i>, I. 317-318.<br>
<br>
<i>—— You Meaner Beauties</i>, II. 312-314.<br>
<br>
<br>
<i>Yarrow, The Braes of</i>, II. 362-367.<br>
<br>
<i>You Meaner Beauties</i>, II. 312-314.<br>
<br>
<i>Young Waters</i>, II. 228-231.<br>
<br>
<i>Youth and Age</i>, I. 237-238.<br>

Ypotis, Poem of, III. <a href="#Page_364" class="pginternal">364</a>.<br>
</p>
<div class="transnote">
<p>Transcriber's Notes:</p>
<p>Simple spelling, grammar, and typographical errors
were corrected.</p>
<p>Punctuation normalized.</p>
<p>Anachronistic and non-standard spellings retained as printed.</p>
<p>Proper drop caps were not possible with poetry as the poem would not
wrap properly around the image. The drop cap images were included in
the left margin adjacent to where they should have been.</p>
<p>This e-text includes characters that will only display in UTF-8 (Unicode) file encoding,
such as:</p>
<ul style="list-style-type: none;">
<li><ins title="Anglo Saxon Uncial">Ðe.. næꝼꞃe nohꞇ leaꞅunᵹa. ne ιꝺeleꞅ leoðeꞅ pẏꞃcean ne mιhꞇe;</ins></li>
<li>Œ, œ ("oe" ligature)</li>
</ul>
<p>If any of these characters do not display properly, you may have an incompatible
browser or unavailable fonts. First, make sure that the browser's "character set" or
"file encoding" is set to Unicode (UTF-8). You may also need to change your browser's
default font. The free <a href="http://junicode.sourceforge.net" id="id-3239984572487189251"> Junicode</a> font works well.</p>
<p class="center">The following Anglo-Saxon Uncial characters
have no Unicode equivalent.  Ordinary Latin 1 characters were substituted instead.</p>
<table class="tdc" style="border-spacing: 0px;padding: 4px;border-width: 1px;" data-summary="Uncial script substitutions">
